List of schools currently affiliated with Hua Van: For complete information about the alumni of Hua Van University, please refer to Alumni Light (archived on the Internet Archive).

It was the first major German defeat of World War II. The German Army withdrew its attack on the North Caucasus Army Group A to Rostov-on-Don, during which time the Soviet Union launched a large-scale Red Army counterattack on the southern front in Operation Saturn, the German Army lost a great deal of equipment and personnel in the process, and the opportunity to occupy the Soviet oil fields to compensate for the German shortage of oil was lost forever. The Battle of Stalingrad was the most serious strategic failure of the Germans, not only ended the offensive situation maintained by the German Army Group South since 22 June 1941, but also directly caused a fundamental change in the balance of power between the Soviet Union and Germany as a whole. From a global perspective, the Battle of Stalingrad, together with the simultaneous Battle of Guadalcanal and the Second Battle of Alaman, constituted the biggest turning point of World War II at the end of 1942.

Due to the fact that the monarchy is not subject to national laws, the term "kingdom despotism" is also referred to as infinite monarchy, as opposed to the representative constitutional monarchy of finite monarchy that later developed. Historically, monarchy has been subjected in most cases to feudal systems and feudal laws, political power of the nobility, religious power of the clergy, and economic power of the bourgeoisie, as was the case before the European Renaissance; and after the Renaissance, the decline of Catholicism and the development of capitalist economies gave European kings the opportunity to consolidate power and strengthen despotism.

At the end of that year, the Eighty Forces had engaged in the Winter Offensive in the Eighth Ward, but were not the main offensive units. In 1940, the Eighty Forces' 26th Division was under the direct control of the Eighth Ward, the National Revolutionary Army's 165th Division in the Tenth Ward (Major General Wang Zhiqi) and the National Revolutionary Army's new 27th Division (Major General Wang Zhiqi) joined the army. In the autumn of the same year, 97th Division was withdrawn from the Eighth Ward, the Eighty Forces' 165th Division and the New 27th Division were under the direct control of the Eighty Forces in 1920. In May 1941, the Eighty Forces engaged in the Battle of Jinnan, were rebuilt by the Japanese Army, the new 27th Division Major General Wang Zhiqi was killed, after the end of the battle, the Eighty Forces were transferred to the National Revolutionary Army's 37th Army Group, the new 27th Division Major General was taken over by the National Revolutionary Army's 78th Division Deputy Major General Yan Yinggao.

Coordinates: 28°37′N 121°49′E / 28.61°N 121.82°E / 28.61; 121.82 中国人民解放军 反共救国军解放军称393人陣亡、1,027人受伤 The Battle of Ijiangshan Island (Chinese: 一江山島) was fought on January 18, 1955 between the Chinese People's Liberation Army and the National Army of the Republic of China during the first Taiwan Strait Crisis in Ijiangshan Island, Zhejiang Province (present-day Zhejiang City, Zhejiang Prefecture).

At the time of its founding, the Union had 12 member states, which later increased to 37. Due to financial problems, the Union suspended all its activities on 26 January 2012, dissolved the Secret Service (starting on 31 July 2012), and terminated the employment relationship of all its staff. According to the official website of the Union, all countries that meet the following criteria qualify for membership: The Union now has 34 official members and three permanent observers on four continents. The official languages of the different Romance-speaking countries are classified as follows (with overlap): The Union has five official languages, namely French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish and Romanian, the first four of which are also the working languages of the Union. All the main documents have versions in four working languages, and some have versions in Catalan and Romanian.

Pierre Jean Marie Laval (French pronunciation: ; 28 June 1883 – 15 October 1945) was a French politician who served as Prime Minister of France from 27 January 1931 to 20 February 1932 and again from 7 June 1935 to 24 January 1936. Early on, Laval was a socialist, and in 1909 became a lawyer, famous for defending strikers, trade unionists and leftists against government prosecutions. In 1914, he entered the House of Commons as a member of the Socialist Party, and during World War I, he upheld his pacifist beliefs. After his defeat in the 1919 elections, Laval withdrew from the Socialist Party and became mayor of Aubeville.

Huang Hua (January 25, 1913 – November 24, 2010) was a Chinese politician and diplomat who graduated from Yanjing University. He joined the Communist Party of China in 1936. He was a member of the 10th, 11th and 12th Central Committees of the Communist Party of China, Standing Committee of the 13th Advisory Committee of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. He served as Minister of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China, Deputy Premier of the State Council, State Councilor, Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. Huang Hua was president of the Students' Association of Yanjing University. General Secretary of the Students' Union of the Twenty-nine Movement. He secretly joined the Communist Party of China at Yanjing University in January 1936.

Presidium or praesidium (Latin: praesidēre, meaning "supervising" or "presiding") refers to an administrative or standing committee, or an aggregate of several chairpersons of the legislative or other bodies of a part of a country. In communist countries, praesidium usually refers to a standing committee in a legislative body, such as the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union. The Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union was established in 1936, replacing the Presidium of the Central Executive Committee, the governing body of the Soviet Congress and its recesses. The term praesidium can be found today in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (the Presidium of the Supreme People's Congress) and the People's Republic of China (the Presidium of the National People's Congress during its opening and the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress during its recesses); in addition, the heads of state of Bosnia and Herzegovina also refer to the Presidium of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Portuguese and Dutch romans are not one-to-one with pseudonyms, and are used only in a limited range of medium-sized missionaries and scholars. The original Japanese romans corresponding to pseudonyms are those used in the first edition of James Curtis Hepburn's "Japanese-English Forest Integrated" (1867), and are therefore referred to as Plain (Black) Romans. Hepburn Romans were designed on the basis of English pronunciation. In 1885, Tachibana Tanaka designed Japanese Romans based on phonetic theory. They adhere to a single letter corresponding to a syllable. They are designed more like phonemes than letters. Pronunciation of letters is also more difficult for English users. Japanese Cabinet Instruction No. 3 of 1937 issued the two-based imperative Romans. After World War II, confusion arose in the United States as a result of the resurgence of Plain Romans.

On September 11, Wang Hongwen, with the backing of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China, set up another "Central Office Office Duty Room" in the Central and South China Seas, and in the name of the Central Office of the Communist Party of China, notified all over the country that important issues should be submitted to them in a timely manner by designated officers on duty; attempted to cut off the communication between the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and Hua Guangfeng with the provinces, cities, and autonomous regions, by which they issued orders to command the whole country: 299; on the same day, Li Xianning immediately reported to Hua Guangfeng the contents of the conversation and the attitude of Ye Jianying. On September 16, Hua Guangfeng summoned Li Xianning, Wu De, Chen Xilian, Ji Dengqiu, Chen Yonggui, and others to a meeting in the State Council Chamber.

Lithium burning is common in brown dwarfs, but does not occur in low-mass stars. Stars, which are defined as having a core that is sufficient for hydrogen fusion at high temperatures (2.5 × 106 K), rapidly deplete their lithium. When lithium-7 and protons collide, two helium-4 atomic nuclei are formed, and the temperature at which this reaction occurs is below the temperature required for hydrogen fusion. In low-mass stars, convection ensures that the entire lithium is easily depleted, so that in brown dwarf candidates, the presence of lithium spectra is an important indicator of the existence of a brown dwarf, otherwise it is a secondary star. A study of the lithium abundance of 53 Taurus T stars has found that lithium depletion is strongly correlated with size, suggesting that lithium burning fusion is carried out via the P-P chain. During the high convection and instability of the final stages of the current main sequence, Linzhong condensation may be one of the main sources of energy for Taurus T stars.

Delhi is the capital of India. New Delhi is jointly administered by the federal government of India and the local government of Delhi. Delhi hosted the first and ninth Asian Games in 1951 and 1982, the 1983 Non-Aligned Movement Summit, the 2010 Men's Hockey World Cup, the 2010 Commonwealth Games, and was one of the host cities of the 2011 Cricket World Cup. "Delhi" comes from a variety of sources. In Mongolian, "Delhi" means "world" and may have been named after the ruling class of the Mughal Empire. However, most people believe that a man named "Dhillu" ruled the area.

After World War II, the Japanese repatriated to mainland Japan, and the military facilities and attached buildings that remained in the Eastern District attracted residents of various provinces of China to move in, forming many family villages. In 1941, the city plan announced that Park Road (now Linsen Road) and Outer Ring Road (now China East Road) would be established in today's Eastern District. In the 1970s, the aforementioned roads were finally built, along with the construction of the Zhongshan Expressway, and traffic improvements in the Eastern District grew rapidly. Until the eve of the 2010 municipal merger, the Eastern District was the most populous district in Tainan Province, with nearly 200,000 people. In the 1970s, the Eastern District was repeatedly redeveloped to meet the population growth, during which time many military sites were also released for the use of the city plan. The most important of these was the Fourth Redevelopment District, the Second A Redevelopment District, and the Toro Dormitory Redevelopment District. The Fourth Redevelopment District is located in Takuan Cuo, which has Tainan Cultural Center, a supervisory station, a land administration office, a district public office, a municipal hospital, and other facilities.

In addition to sitcoms, there are a number of other comedy-themed episodes that, although similar in content, form, and duration (around 45 minutes) to the plot series, are usually included in the category when competing for television awards. Traditionally, sitcom characters are typically independent entities, meaning that the characters are largely relatively static, and the story is resolved at the end of each episode. Typically, animation-themed sitcoms such as The Simpsons and The Glee Club have a continuously evolving storyline, such as the popular 1990s American sitcom The Six, with several storylines running in parallel over the course of a decade, and a suspenseful ending each season that incorporates a lot of soap opera elements. Other sitcoms involve social judgment, such as All in the Family.

The Chinese word "province" has been used as early as the Wei Jin Dynasty to refer to the provinces of Shanxi and Chuxiang, but they are all named after Chinese cardinals, and these provinces are not directly under the jurisdiction of the central government. After the Yuan Dynasty, because of the unprecedented expansion of the territory, provinces were established in the provinces of Chuxiang, shortened to provinces or provinces in the private sector, and provinces have since become officially the names of the first-class administrative districts, and are also commonly used as the names of first-class districts. The English word "province" was confirmed in about 1330, is derived from the 13th century Old French word "province". The latter is derived from the Latin "provincia", which means "the area of power of the government officials", especially referring to a foreign territory. One misconception is that the word comes from the Latin "pro-" (with the meaning of "representative") and "vincere" (with the meaning of "victory" or "control").

X-rays and ultraviolet radiation emitted by flares affect the Earth's ionosphere, disrupting long-distance radio communications. Radio waves at millimeter wavelengths interfere directly with radar and the operation of instruments and equipment using these wavelengths. The first observations of solar flares were made independently by Richard Carlinton and Richard Hodgson in 1859, when they observed a small area of brightness in the black cluster. By examining the light curves of stars observed by telescopes or satellites, it is possible to infer whether other stars produce stellar flares. The frequency of solar flares varies greatly with the average 11-year period of activity, ranging from a few days during the solar period to less than a week during the quiet period (see solar cycle). Large flares appear at a much lower frequency than small ones. According to NASA observations, on July 23, 2012, a solar superstorm with a large and potentially destructive force (flares, coronal mass ejections, and solar electromagnetic pulses) passed over the Earth and accelerated charged particles, mainly electrons interacting with plasma material.

Provisional Regulations on Appointment and Removal of Staff of State Organs of the Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China: Central Committee of the People's Republic of China: National Government Committee of the People's Republic of China The Central People's Committee of the People's Republic of China was the supreme organ of the Central People's Government, established in October 1949 after the founding of the People's Republic of China, but abolished in September 1954 by the promulgation of the Constitution of the People's Republic of China to implement the system of the People's Congress.The Central People's Committee consists of the Chairman of the Central People's Government, six Vice-Chairmen of the Central People's Government and 56 members of the Central People's Government, elected by the Plenary Session of the People's Political Consultative Conference of the People's Republic of China.The Chairman of the Central People's Government is responsible for presiding over the meetings of the Committee of the Central People's Government and leading its work, and the Vice-Chairman of the Central People's Government is responsible for assisting the Chairman in the performance of his duties.

Although in the traditional English pronunciation, the "ch" in "Charon" is pronounced as k, Christie changed the pronunciation of the "ch" in this moon to sh(IPA), because the "ch" in his wife's name, Charlene, is pronounced sh. So the pronunciation of sh also became popular in astronomy, everyone uses this pronunciation, and in Chinese there is a corresponding translation of "Shalong". However, other languages besides English still use the original mythological pronunciation, k sounds. Robin Kanji's simulation results published in 2005 suggest that Charon was formed in a large collision about 4.5 billion years ago, very much like the situation of the Earth and the Moon. In this model, a giant Kuiper belt object collided with Pluto at a high speed, destroyed itself, and blew up most of Pluto's mantle, and Charon was formed from these fragments.

The Military Academy of the People's Republic of China (Chinese: 中華民國陸軍官校; pinyin: Zhōngqīn Guóngqīn) is a military academy of the People's Republic of China, founded on June 16, 1924, by the order of the Prime Minister of the People's Republic of China, Sun Yat-sen (Chinese: 孫文; traditionally known as Sun Yat-sen), and the first president of the Nationalist Party of China, Chiang Kai-shek. It was founded in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, China on June 16, 1924, and is now known as "Huangpu Military Academy" or "Huangpu Military Academy". The school was founded with the support of the Soviet Union, and many of the founders and generals of the People's Republic of China came from the school. The Military Academy is also the birthplace of the fifth national anthem of the People's Republic of China, because the first day of the school's opening ceremony by Sun Yat-sen is the lyrics of today's national anthem of the Republic of China. The Military Academy is currently affiliated with the Ministry of Defense of the Republic of China, and its purpose and founding purpose is to cultivate the Republic of China's military officers.

Liquor, also called shochu, brewing liquor, dry liquor, sparkling liquor, sorghum liquor, is a traditional distilled liquor, a kind of brewing liquor, mainly produced in mainland China and Taiwan, is a distilled liquor commonly consumed by Chinese people, and is also a gift in traditional festivals. It is actually a mixture of many different kinds of distilled liquor, the ingredients may be different grains, varieties, but all its core brewing technology is pure grain solid or semi-solid fermentation technology, this is the biggest feature that distinguishes liquor from other distilled liquors. Because the majority of liquor main ingredient is sorghum, it is also called sorghum liquor, only a small number of liquor does not use sorghum and rice or maize as the main ingredient. To make liquor, the first step is to make koji, i.e. to use a mixture of cooked grain and bacterial species, to make koji, then to mix with solid grains at the same time to sugarize and ferment to make liquor, then to distill.

Information technology, also known as information and communications technology (ICT), is a general term for a variety of technologies used primarily for the management and processing of information, primarily for the application of computer science and communications technology to the design, development, installation, and deployment of information systems and application software. Information technology development can be divided into several different stages according to the differences in information storage and processing: pre-mechanical (3000–1450 BC), mechanical (1450–1840), electromechanical (1840–1940), and electronic (1940–present).

The fifty-second army of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) is regarded as one of the main forces of the 10th Army of the Kingdom. The fifty-second army of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) was formed in Shaanxi Xianyang in 1937 and disbanded in Taipei, Taiwan in 1989. The forerunner of the 2nd Division was the Huangpu Military Officers' School Teaching Regiment. In the spring of 1925, the Teaching Regiment of the 1st Brigade was formed after the first Eastern Expedition to Freshwater, Cotton Lake and Xingning with the Teaching Regiment of the 2nd Brigade. On July 3, 1925, the Guangzhou National Government established a Military Committee, decided to abolish the name of the local army, and all were renamed the National Revolutionary Army. In August 1925, the First Brigade of the Party Army and the Teaching Regiment of the 3rd Brigade were expanded into the First Division of the Army of the National Revolutionary Army (Director Ho). In May 1926, the 1st Division in Guangdong Chao'an and the 14th Division of the Cantonese Army (Director Feng Xiaoping) exchanged two regiments: in September 1927, the 3rd, 14th and 21st Divisions were merged into the 9th Army.

The First Guangdong-Guangdong War, also known as the Two Guangdong War, was a war fought between the Guangdong army commanded by Chen Jiongming and the Guangdong warlord Lu Rongting between August and November 1920. The main battle area was Guangdong Province. At the end of 1915, Yuan Shikai was appointed Emperor, and Lu Rongting fought against Yuan on behalf of the Guangxi Telecommunications Company. The Guangdong army participated in the War of National Defense. Yuan Shikai died of illness on June 6, 1916, and Li Yuan Hong succeeded to the throne. At the end of the War of National Defense, Li Yuan Hong appointed Lu Rongting as Guangdong Governor in the name of the central government, but the former Guangdong Governor, Long Jiguang, refused to resign. Lu Rongting sent Mo Rongxin, Ma Ji, and Tan Homing to attack Guangdong with the Guangdong army, defeating Long Jiguang, and Guangdong became the sphere of influence of the former Guangdong army. On June 12, 1917, Zhang Chong forced Li Yuanhong to dissolve the Diet. On June 20, the Two Guangdong declared independence.

Oxygen is a non-metallic, highly reactive oxidant that can form oxides with most elements. At standard temperature and pressure, two oxygen atoms naturally bond to form colorless, tasteless oxygen, called diatomic oxygen (O2). Oxygen is one of the major components of the Earth's atmosphere, accounting for 20.8% of its volume, second only to nitrogen.

After Peru gained its independence in 1821, José de San Martín called for elections to the Constituent Assembly in order to establish a constitution for a country that had been formed for the first time. The Constituent Assembly, presided over by Francisco Javier de Luna Pizarro, drafted the Constitution of 1823, the origin of the unicameral system of the Peruvian Congress, unlike the two-chamber system of other Latin American countries. The last Constituent Assembly (Democratic Constituent Assembly - CCD) was convened in 1993, which established the Constitution of 1993 (the current Constitution). The current Constitution established a unicameral, 120-seat Congress, which was later expanded to 130 members. In computing, a virtual desktop extends the virtual space of a computer desktop environment beyond the physical screen area by using software. One of its main methods is a switchable virtual desktop, which allows users to create virtual copies of their desktop view ports, and switch between them, with open windows present in a single virtual desktop. The switchable desktop was originally implemented as "Rooms" by Austin Henderson and Stuart Card at Xerox PARC in 1986. The switchable desktop was introduced to a wider audience by Tom LaStrange in 1989 in swm. The windows of the running applications are no longer simply placed on an x, y position, but on an x, y position on a given virtual desktop "context".

Mammals are small concave-faced bats up to 30 to 40 mm in length, and blue whales up to 30 m long (the largest in Earth's history). They range in lifespan from 2 to 211 years (bowhead whales). In addition to the oviparous species, other extant mammals give birth directly during childbirth. The largest group of mammals is a class of animals known as placental animals, whose placenta can be fed to a fetus during pregnancy. Most mammals have cognitive abilities, some have large brains and self-awareness, and use tools. Mammals can communicate and vocalize in many different ways, such as ultrasound, scent marking, warning signals, singing, echolocation, etc. Mammals organize into fission-fusion societies, harems, and hierarchies — but some are more solitary, with their own territories.

Over the next 750 years, independent Muslim states were established, and Muslim-controlled areas were known as Al-Andalus. Meanwhile, the weaker Christian states of the north, supported by Catholic forces, launched a long-running campaign against the peninsula, historically known as the Restoration of the Lands. With the seizure of Granada in 1492, the campaign was declared over. The Restoration of the Lands led to the formation of numerous Christian kingdoms on the Iberian Peninsula, led by the Kingdom of Castile, the Kingdom of Aragon, the Kingdom of Navarre, and the Kingdom of Portugal. In addition to the four foreign countries mentioned above, there were also the Kingdom of León, the Kingdom of Galicia, the Kingdom of Toledo, the Kingdom of Murcia, the Kingdom of Córdoba, the Kingdom of Han, the Kingdom of Seville, the Kingdom of Granada, the Principality of Asturias, the Marquess of Alava, the House of Biscay, and the House of Molina (these kingdoms and the Kingdom of Castile formed the United Kingdom of Castile); the Kingdom of Barcelona, the Kingdom of Valencia, and the Kingdom of Mallorca (these kingdoms and the Kingdom of Aragon formed the United Kingdom of Aragon).

A subdwarf B star (abbreviated as sdB) is a spectral type B subdwarf. This star differs from typical subdwarfs in that it has a higher surface temperature and brightness, and is located in the "extreme horizontal branch" of the Hertzsprung diagram. These stars have a mass of about 0.5 times that of the Sun, and contain only 1% hydrogen, the rest being mostly helium. The radius is 0.15 to 0.25 times that of the Sun, and the surface temperature is 20,000 to 40,000 K. A subdwarf B star is in the late stages of stellar evolution. The core of a red giant loses its predominantly hydrogen outer layer before it begins to fuse helium, and the remaining core is a B-type subdwarf. The reason for the early loss of mass of these red giants is still unknown, but interactions between the binary system and another member star may be a major mechanism.

In late September 1979, the Observatory, using radio telescopes to study the effects of the Atlas rocket liftoff on the ionosphere, unexpectedly detected a strange fluctuation near South Africa, when no storm or earthquake had caused the fluctuation. Scientists at Cornell University then analyzed the possibility of a small nuclear explosion in the South Atlantic. On 23 May 1980, an investigation team organized by U.S. President Jimmy Carter concluded that the Sagittarius satellite did not detect a nuclear explosion, but an erroneous record caused by a meteorite impact satellite. Some military intelligence sources claimed that the Nuclear Tests Secret Study Group believed that the event had a 90% probability of being caused by nuclear tests, and that there was some cooperation between the two countries. In the late 1950s, South Africa set up a nuclear research and development program, and in 1969 acquired more sophisticated nuclear technology, set up a small uranium enrichment laboratory ("Y-factory") in the Pellindaba area outside Pretoria.

Political Topics The Vice-Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (Chinese: 中国人民政治协商会议全国委员会副主席; abbreviated as the Vice-Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference or the Vice-Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference) is the deputy leader of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and is a deputy leader at the national level. Article 32 of the Constitution of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference stipulates that "the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference shall be presided over by the Chairman, Vice-Chairman, a number of Vice-Chairmen and the Secretary-General." Article 34 stipulates that the Vice-Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference shall be elected by the plenary meeting of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. Article 35 of the Constitution of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference stipulates that "the Standing Committee of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference shall preside over the meetings of the Committee. The Standing Committee shall be composed of the Chairman, Vice-Chairman, the Secretary-General and the Standing Committee.

The Soviet Union first concluded a trade agreement with Nazi Germany in August 1939. Between April and August 1939, Britain, France, and the Soviet Union held military and political negotiations in Moscow. During the negotiations, the Soviet Union made a number of proposals to Britain and France: however, the negotiations were fruitless. Britain and France agreed that Germany would operate freely in Eastern and Central and South-Eastern Europe, and rejected the Soviet Union's offer to guarantee the national security of Central and South-Eastern Europe. Between May and August, Hitler repeatedly told the Soviet Union, through Foreign Minister Ribbentrop, that Germany had no intention of invading the Soviet Union and that he hoped to improve their relations.

Zhongzheng Military Reserve School (Chinese: 中正預備学校) is the only high-level secondary military school in Kaohsiung City, Taiwan, located in Fengshan Mountains, Taiwan. It is under the Ministry of Defense of the Republic of China. It is a full secondary school, has a high school and a junior high school. Zhongzheng Preschool is a merger of the Army Reserve School (formerly the Army Officers School Reserve Class), the Navy Officers School Reserve Class, and the Air Force Junior High School, and the school ground is the original Army Officers Reserve School. Established in 1958, the first to eighth grades admit only high school dropouts, one year after graduation, upgrading to the Army Officers School 32-39. In 1964, the seventh and ninth grades are admitted at the same time, the ninth grade (the Army Officers 40th grade) is changed to admit junior high school graduates (three-year high school). In 1965, the eighth and tenth grades are admitted at the same time. In 1974, the school site was moved from the Army Officers East Camp District to the original Second Officers School (now the current site of Zhongzheng Military Reserve School), and renamed the Army Officers Reserve School.

Li Jiatong (Chinese: 李家同; born January 5, 1939) is a Taiwanese information scientist and writer. Born in Shanghai, Taiwan. Formerly President of National Tsinghua University, President of Shijiazhuang University and National Jian International University, Professor of the Department of Information Engineering and Department of Information Management. Retired from the position of Professor of Jian International University on May 31, 2008. In 2009, he was appointed by the President of the Republic of China as a non-permanent professor. Currently, he also teaches at National Tsinghua University. On January 6, 2011, he was awarded the First Prize of Education and Culture by the Ministry of Education of the Republic of China. Li Jiatong's father is an economist, his elder brother is a grandson of Li Hongzhang, and Li Jiatong is a grandson of Li Hongzhang. Li Jiatong's research fields include symbolic logic, algorithm design analysis, parallel computing methods, biological information, and has published more than 100 international papers in these fields.

Fast rotation tends to increase the mixture, increasing the transport of lithium into the deeper depths, causing them to be destroyed there. The rotation speed of this year's T star increases with age, accelerating the rotation by contraction to conserve angular momentum. As the age increases, this leads to an increase in the rate of loss of lithium. Lithium burning also increases with increasing temperature and mass, and most lithium burning lasts slightly longer than 100 million years. The P-P chain of lithium burning is as follows: P + Li-6 -> Be-7 (unstable)Be-7 + e -> Li-7 + νP + Li-7 -> Be-8 (unstable)Be-8 -> 2He-4 + energyThis does not happen in an object with a mass less than 60 times that of Jupiter. In this way, the age of the star can be calculated based on the consumption of lithium.

Even though French orthography prescribes the use of ligatures between parts of a composite administrative or political entity's name (in this case, the name of the country must be written Côte-d'Ivoire), the government of the country did not follow suit and did not use ligatures in the name. As the government should have requested, the People's Republic of China changed its pronunciation to Côte d'Ivoire. Countries that do not use French as their mother tongue now use their French names officially, but most of their names are still interpreted in various languages: for example, Spain calls the country Costa de Marfil; Portugal calls it Costa do Marfim. The German-speaking country calls it Elfenbeinküste, but refers to its people by the French-derived names Ivorer or Ivorerin.

Europe (dark grey) — Montenegro (Montenegrin:Црна Гора/Crna Gora, literally: Black Mountain) is a mountainous country on the eastern shore of the Adriatic Sea in the southwestern part of the European Balkans. To the northeast of Montenegro is Serbia, to the east is Kosovo (unilaterally declared independence on 17 February 2008), to the southeast is Albania, to the northwest is Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia, and to the southwest is the Adriatic Sea (part of the Mediterranean). Montenegro was originally the Kingdom of Montenegro founded in 1910, after World War I it joined the newly formed Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, during World War II the Axis invasion of Yugoslavia, Montenegro became the protectorate of Italy, after the Nazi occupation and Allied liberation. After World War II it became one of the six member republics of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, the four members of Yugoslavia (Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia) After independence in the early 1990s, Montenegro and Serbia became the only two remaining member republics of Yugoslavia.

As of 2008 (2008-Missing required parameter 1=month!), three Centauri asteroids have been found to have cometary activity: Ceres, Echeclus, and 166P/NEAT, so Ceres and Echeclus, both of which are minor planets, are also cometary. Other Centauri asteroids, such as Okyrhoe, are suspected of similar cometary activity. Any one that is perturbated and approaches the Sun at a sufficient distance is expected to become a comet. Centauri does not have a stable orbit and will eventually be moved out of the Solar System by a giant planet.

At the beginning of his pontificate, Pope John XXIII appointed 87 cardinals, including several bishops from developing countries, black bishops, and non-Italian bishops. This was the highest number ever. Promoting unity with other religions was one of the most important agendas of his pontificate. He died on 3 June 1963 at the age of 82. His reign, though only four years and seven months, was mourned by the world's faithful, including Catholics, Protestants, Eastern Orthodox, Jews and non-believers. Finally, he was honoured with the title of "Good Pope John." In 2000, Pope John XXIII was ordained a saint by Pope Paul II for the miraculous healing of Sister Caterina Capitani in 1966. On 5 July 2013, the Vatican confirmed Pope Francis' passing of his canonization in the absence of a second miracle by Pope John XXIII.

The Chinese Cultural Revival Movement is an ideological and cultural movement launched by the Government of the Republic of China with the aim of reviving Chinese culture. In order to preserve traditional Chinese culture, promote the spirit of revolution: 230. Since the Chinese mainland was in the midst of the disaster of the Cultural Revolution, under the slogan of "breaking old and building new," a group of outstanding heritage of Chinese culture was greatly damaged, and the entire Chinese cultural intellectual community was subjected to humiliation and brutality; this was another major disaster after the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party, which had a very negative impact on the normal development of Chinese culture; the Government of the Republic of China has unveiled the banner of the revival of Chinese culture, hoping to establish the image of the heirs and defenders of Chinese culture.

In 2002, Gwangbo Electronics, Asahi Kasei Corporation, Gwangbo Technology and Fortune Inc. merged to become Gwangbo Technology, Gwangbo Technology and renamed Gwangbo Technology Co., Ltd. In June 2003, Gwangbo Technology Headquarters was moved to Taipei City Inner Lake Technology Park. In 2006, Gwangbo Electronics merged BenQ's Optical Disc Equipment Division to become one of the world's top three optical disc equipment suppliers. In 2014, Gwangbo One LITE-ON "Seven Ones" merged with Gwangbo, Guanglin, Lishin, Power Storage, Gwangbo Mobility and Dongguan on the Mainland to form Gwangbo Group. In 2015, National Tsinghua University and Gwangbo Group established a Joint Development Center (DJSI) component. In 2016, Gwangbo Group Medical Establishment established a Singapore Biotechnology Development Center. On August 30, 2019, Gwangbo Group sold Gwangbo Electronics business to Toshiba Memory for $165 million.

António de Oliveira Salazar (Portuguese pronunciation: ; 28 April 1889 – 27 July 1970) was a Portuguese politician who served as Prime Minister of Portugal from 1932 to 1968 and was the supreme ruler of the New National Government (Portuguese: Estado Novo). The New National Government was a communist dictatorship that ruled Portugal until the Carnation Revolution of 1974. Salazar was a trained economist. Following the coup d'état of 28 May 1926 in Portugal, he entered public life with the support of President Antonio Oscar de Zaragoza Carmona, initially as Minister of Finance and later as Prime Minister. Salazar opposed democracy, communism, socialism, anarchism and liberalism, and his rule was essentially conservative and nationalist.

Symbiotic twins are a type of binary star, usually referred to simply as symbiotic stars. They are usually a combination of a white dwarf with a red giant as a companion. Low-surface giants, which lose mass through Roche flap overflows or stellar winds, usually flow through the accretion disk to densely heated stars. Astronomers are particularly interested in symbiotic twins because they can be used to understand the evolution of stars. At the same time, because of the unique interstellar dynamics of the system, they are also important for stellar winds, ionic nebulae, and astrophysics. Many symbiotic twins show variations in brightness, and are therefore classified as variable stars. Zodiac Z is usually considered a prototype of a symbiotic twin, but more commonly it is only considered a prototype of a symbiotic binary classification, with irregular variations of up to 4 magnitudes. Even Zodiac Z-type variable stars are also considered to be an inhomogeneous group.

Nuclear fusion (called fusion in Taiwan), also known as fusion reaction, is a form of nuclear reaction in which two lighter nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus and a very light nucleus (or particle). In the process, matter is not conserved, because some of the matter in the fusioning atomic nucleus is converted into photons (energy). Nuclear fusion is the process of providing energy to active or "main-order" stars. Two lighter nuclei lose mass in the fusion process and release huge amounts of energy.

Parallel multiplexing refers to the fact that the distance between two railway lines is very close (the speed multiplexing is not less than 4 meters, the high-speed multiplexing is not less than 4.4 meters), the direction of travel is roughly parallel, and the stations along the railway line are the same. Generally, this situation is adopted in the case of simple terrain or a newly constructed multiplexing, which has the advantages of saving on land, saving on investment, and sharing technical equipment and stations. The bridges and tunnels that pass through are often multiplexed bridges and multiplexed tunnels. Non-parallel multiplexing refers to the fact that although the two lines are also divided into fixed up and down tracks, the distances may be far apart, the direction of travel may be inconsistent, and the stations along the railway line may be inconsistent. This is because of the complexity of the terrain along the line, and it is difficult to arrange double tracks.

Hao Baicun (born August 8, 1919. General of the Republic of China, politician. Vice President of the 1st Nationalist Party of China, Chairman of the 16th to 20th Central Committee of the Nationalist Party of China, 13th President of the Executive Council. First-class general of the Republic of China Army. He was awarded the Order of the Cloud, the Order of the Blue Sky, the Order of the Cloud and the Flag of Honour. Hao Baicun graduated from the 12th Division of Artillery of the Military Academy, served as a basic officer during the eight-year war, as the commander of the Ninth Division of the 9th Infantry of the Little Kinmen Army during the 83rd Artillery Battle of the Front Line, went to the United States Army Academy of Military Sciences Special Class of the Republic of China to study for the first time, was one of the Commanders-in-Chief of the Republic of China Armed Forces, the longest serving Chief of Staff of the Republic of China, Minister of Defense, the President of the Executive Council, and resigned from the Party and ran for the 9th Vice President of the Republic of China. He is the second Chief of the Executive Council after Chen Cheng.

This "main anti-Japanese troops" performance caused the People's Republic of China to lose sight of the fact that the Korean side's initiative to advance and retreat was confused, several times the other side's heavy casualties, plus Chen Yi had infiltrated the Chen Taiyun, Li Mingyang and Li Yangtze Rivers of the National Army before the war, so that in the battle only the ROK's heirs troops were deeply isolated, while the New Fourth Army combat troops of more than 4,000 people, in order to ease labor and easily win, the New Fourth Army claimed that the National Army of more than 110,000 people were killed or captured, the National Army claimed that the number of casualties was "over 5,000" officers and men.

Upper Volta (French: Haute-Volta) was the old name of the present-day West African state of Burkina Faso from 1958 to 1984. Upper Volta has been a French colony since 1895, part of French West Africa. On 11 December 1958, Upper Volta became an Autonomous Republic. On 5 August 1960, the Republic of Upper Volta became officially independent. In 1984, the then President of Upper Volta, Thomas Sankara, changed the name of the state to the current state of Burkina Faso. Upper Volta Republic (French: Haute-Volta) was an inland West African state established on 11 December 1958. Before becoming an autonomous colony of the French colonial empire, it was part of French West Africa and the French Community. On 5 August 1960, it became fully independent of France.

By the time of Emperor Wu of Han, South Vietnam was subjugated to the Western Han Dynasty. At this time, Nankai County was divided into six counties: Panyu, Boro, Zhongjuku, Longchuan, Shihe and Kaiyang, and Meizhou was subjugated to Longchuan and Kaiyang. The other counties in Meizhou were subjugated to Haiyang County in Yi'an County. Subsequently, the establishment of the counties of Meizhou City was largely separated from Haiyang County. The first county to be separated from Haiyang County was Tai Po County, which was established in 413 AD in the Eastern Jin Dynasty. Then, Chengxiang County was established in Nan Qi, and the county boundaries including the present-day Meijiang District, Mei County District, Pingyuan, the entire territory of Zhouling and parts of Fengshun remained in Yi'an County. It was not until the fifth generation of the Later Jin dynasty in 945 that Keizhou was established. This was the beginning of the division of Chaomei County, but only Chengxiang County (now Mei County District) was established, and Xingning and Tai Po were not under the jurisdiction of Keizhou.

In the 17th century, the German astronomer Johann Bayer called the constellation Triplicitas and Orbis terrarum tripertitus, representing three major regions of Europe, Asia and Africa respectively. In order to distinguish it from the southern constellation Triangulus Septentrionalis, the constellation was also named Triangulus Septentrionalis. Triangulus Septentrionalis has a small area, is located on the north and west sides of the constellation Aries, on the west side of Pisces, on the south side of Aries, and on the east side of Perseus. The center of the constellation lies in the middle of the constellation between Generalissimo I and Lousatia III. Bayer catalogued the five stars in the constellation, allocating the Greek letters "Α" to "Ε" using Bayer's nomenclature. John Franzide added "Η", "Ι" and four Roman letters on the basis of Bayer, but most of them were eliminated in later tables and charts. Only "Ι" was named after the triangle, which has formed a narrow triangle of three brighter stars, the brightest of which is the white giant Generalissimo IX of magnitude 3.00. The second brightest star is the yellow subgiant Lousatia VI of magnitude 3.41, also a spectroscopic binary, located about seven degrees north-northwest of Lousatia III, is the apex of the triangle.

The variable stars R Coronae Australis and TY Coronae Australis illuminate some of the dark nebulae, and the brightness varies with the period. In 1922, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) established 88 modern constellations, the Latin name for Corona Australis being "Corona Australis". Coronae Australis is the northern constellation of Ursa Major, the western constellation of Scorpio, the southern constellation of Telescope, and the southern constellation of Ursa Major. In 1922, the IAU defined Coronae Australis as the three-letter abbreviation for "CrA". Coronae Australis is faint, but the shape of its stellar composition is easily recognizable. Only Alpha Meridiana, the official internationally recognized name for Coronae Australis, is a combination of the Arabic constellation name and the Latin "South".

The main purpose of establishing special economic zones is mostly to enable the country to adapt to globalization and benefit from it in order to improve the standard of living of the local economy and protect the local cultural industries so as to accelerate the erosion and destruction without being affected by globalization. During the Cold War era, Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore in Asia made full use of these economic strategies and achieved the Four Little Dragons of Asia. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, many socialist parties either collapsed or began to adopt policies similar to special economic zones, such as the reform and opening of the People's Republic of China. On the one hand, they hoped to preserve socialist-style politics and traditional culture, on the other hand, they hoped that the economic level would reach the level of developed countries, especially in countries with more traditional restrictions and undeveloped countries.

The first plain is called "Chiu Chiu Po" (belongs to Xinzhuang District), now called "Chiu Mae"; the second plain is called "Niu Chiu Po" (belongs to Sanjiang District), now called "Niu"; and the third plain is called "Sanjiang Po" (belongs to Sanjiang District), now called "Sanjiang Po". During the Xianfeng era of the Qing Dynasty, because the upper reaches of the Freshwater River brought a large amount of sand, sedimented riverbed, the riverbed became higher, it was inconvenient for ships to sail, the development center gradually shifted from Xinzhuang to the lower reaches of the Niu Chiu Po and Sanjiang Po areas. Among them, Sanjiang Po, due to the advantage of the land, replaced the status of the upper reaches of Xinzhuang and Sanjiang Po with the east bank of the Freshwater River, the Sanjiang Bridgehead Port and the Sanjiang Bridge Town crossing became an important crossing point between the two places, led to the development of Sanjiang Po, commercial growth, made Sanjiang rapidly develop into a lively town, and gradually became famous in the northern region.

John Maxwell Coetzee (born February 9, 1940) is a South African contemporary novelist, winner of the 1987 Jerusalem Prize and the 2003 Nobel Prize in Literature. Coetzee primarily writes in English. In 2006, he was naturalized as an Australian citizen and taught at the University of Adelaide College of Letters. Born in Cape Town, South Africa in 1940, Coetzee was a descendant of Dutch immigrants. He grew up in South Africa during the formative and formative years of apartheid. He began writing at the University of Cape Town, South Africa in 1963, earned a Ph.D. in computer analysis from the University of Texas in the United States, and then returned to South Africa. In 1984, Coetzee became a professor of English literature at the University of Cape Town, South Africa.

Second: 1170 kJ·mol−1 Gadolinium is a rare earth element with the chemical symbol Gd. It has an atomic number of 64 and an atomic mass of 7002157250000000000♠157.25 u. It is a member of the Gadolite family. It is ferromagnetic, with a Curie point at about room temperature (19°C, 66°F) and a lump of gadolinium that is placed in ice water and cooled to absorb magnets, but then melts away from the magnets. It is stable in dry air compared to other rare earth elements. It has a moderate reaction with water and dissolves in rare acids. It can be directly synthesized with most elements to form compounds of Gd(III). It can react with nitrogen, sulfur, phosphorus, selenium, carbon, silicon or arsenic to form binary compounds when heated or at high temperatures.

The Republic of Mozambique (Portuguese: República de Moçambique, Portuguese pronunciation:. ), as a country with no constitutional relations with the United Kingdom, joined the British Commonwealth in 1995 as a special case because of its support for the abolition of apartheid in South Africa in the 1980s and 1990s, as well as its trade relations with the British Commonwealth. Mozambique's economy is depressed, it is the world's lowest-developed country declared by the United Nations and a heavily indebted poor country. Mozambique (Moçambique) is named by the Portuguese from the island of Mozambique, which derives from the Arabic name Musa Bin Bique (موسى بن بيك), he was a wealthy Muslim merchant who ruled the island.

Taipei (Chinese: 台北; Vietnamese: 排灣語: Taihuku; Taiwanese: Tâi-pak; Hakka: Thòi-pet; English: Taipei) is a city in northern Taiwan, literally "North of Taiwan"; originally used as a geographical term to refer to northern Taiwan, after Taipei City was built at the end of the 19th century, it was used specifically to refer to the city developed as the center of the city. After the Chinese government moved to Taipei in 1949, Taipei became the capital of the Republic of China. "Taipei" by different definitions covers different areas. Special administrative division refers to Taipei, broadly also refers to the Taipei metropolitan area and the surrounding satellite cities (Taipei Metropolitan Area), including Taipei, New Taipei City, Keelung City, with a population of more than 7 million; some organizations have also expanded the Taipei metropolitan area to include Taipei Living Area composed of Taoyuan City, with a population of more than 920 million, an area of 3,678 square kilometers, is the world's 43rd largest metropolitan area.

He was elected to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cambodia in January 1976. After the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia in 1979, the Khmer Rouge regime was overthrown, and he fled to the jungle. After Pol Pot resigned as Prime Minister in the same year, he was appointed Deputy Prime Minister for Foreign Affairs of the anti-Vietnamese Democratic Kampuchea Joint Government and Chairman of the Khmer Rouge's "National Front for Patriotic Democracy and National Solidarity." He first formed the Democratic Kampuchea Joint Government with Sihanouk and Song in 1982, and persisted in the armed struggle. He was appointed Deputy Prime Minister for Foreign Affairs. In 1985, he nominally replaced Pol Pot as General Secretary of the party and became the Supreme Leader of the Khmer Rouge. In 1991, the Cambodian Civil War parties signed the Paris Peace Agreement. After that, he advocated for the Khmer Rouge to lay down its weapons and participate in the 1993 elections, becoming a legitimate party, but was unsuccessful in the resolute opposition of the Pol Pot faction.

Fujian Province (Minnan: Hok-kiàn-síng, Hok-gióng-sēng, Putian: Hoǒh-geǒ̍ng-sêng) is one of the two provinces of the Republic of China that has been virtualized. Currently, it actually controls Kinmen County (Kinmen Island, Ryuyu and Wuyi, etc.) and Linjiang County (Mazure Island, Juguang and Dongping, etc.), which is often referred to as the "Kinma Region." The Executive Yuan also has the Kinma Joint Service Center to control local affairs. Fujian Province of the Republic of China originally inherited the territory of Fujian Province of the Qing Dynasty. In the late stages of the Second National Civil War, the Republic of China's army was defeated by the Liberation Army. Given the situation, the Fujian government moved the army from Fuzhou City to Kinmen since August 1949. After the outbreak of the Korean War, the Liberation Army had repeatedly attacked the area and the army was unable to counterattack the mainland, thus forming a situation in which Fujian was subjugated by one of the two political entities.

The Cocos (Keeling) Islands are an Australian archipelago in the Indian Ocean, lying between the Australian mainland and Indonesia at 12°0′00′′S 96°30′00′′E. The archipelago covers an area of 14.2 square kilometres and has a population of 628 (as of July 2005). It consists of 27 coral islands. Only Home Island and West Island are inhabited. The administrative centre of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is located on West Island. The country and territory code for the islands is.cc. The islands were originally uninhabited and were discovered in 1609 by William Keeling, a British East India Company sailor. In 1826, a British explorer named Alexander Hare settled there with slaves and concubines of Malay descent.

Parallax (from the ancient Greek μέλλαξις (parallaxis), meaning "difference") refers to the change and difference in the position of an object in the field of view when it is observed from two different positions. From two points of view, the angle between the two lines of sight is called the angle of parallax between the two points, and the distance between the two points is called the parallax baseline. From the same two points of view, the closer the distance between the objects, the greater the parallax, so that the parallax can be used to estimate the distance of the object in reverse. For example, astronomers use the principle of parallax to measure the distance of an object from the Earth, including the Moon, the Sun, and stars outside the Solar System. For example, the Ibadan satellite measured the distance of more than 100,000 nearby stars.

Wilhelm Pieck (January 3, 1876 – September 7, 1960) was a German communist politician who served as the President of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany and the President of the German Democratic Republic. Born in 1876 to a poor working-class family in Koblenz, he was a carpenter and joined the German Union of Carpenters in 1894. He joined the Social Democratic Party of Germany in 1895. Disappointed with the party's leadership's cooperation with the conservative forces during World War I, he became an early member of the Spartak League and joined the founding of the Communist Party of Germany. In 1933, he was forced to flee Germany under Hitler. Twelve years later, he returned home in July 1945. In April 1946, the Social Democratic Party of Germany merged with the Communist Party of Germany to form the Socialist Unity Party of Germany, and was elected one of the two chairmen of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany along with Otto Grothewald.

Both sides, after several rounds of clashes, realized that they could not drive each other off the island, so in 1648 signed a peace treaty on the peak of the island, divided the island of St. Martin, and the French even deployed naval ships in the open sea on the island, to intimidate the Dutch to give them more land. However, after the treaty was signed until 1816, the Franco-Dutch forces on the island continued to clash, they also repaired the boundary 16 times, and because of several Franco-Dutch wars with the British, the entire island was occupied by the British. The present boundary was formed in 1816, the Franco-Dutch occupation zone 54 square kilometers, the Dutch occupation zone 41 square kilometers. The Spaniards first brought black slaves to St. Martin, but the number of slaves rose dramatically, and surpassed the number of slave owners until cotton, tobacco and sugar plantations appeared on the island. Due to the cruel treatment, the slaves had rebelled, and the overwhelming number of slave owners could not be ignored. French St. Martin abolished slavery on July 12, 1848, and the Dutch occupation zone was abolished 15 years later.

In 1624, the Dutch army withdrew from Penghu and moved to Taiwan. The Dutch East India Company established the first colonial government in the history of Taiwan, namely "The Lanzhou Castle" (now Anping Fort) on the sandy island of Zhangjiang on the banks of the Taiwan Jiangxi River, as the center of its rule in Taiwan. Then, to the east of the castle, "Taiwan Street" (in the vicinity of today's Yanping Street) and "Pramancheng Street" (now People's Rights Road) were built, respectively. The former was a long-standing and prosperous commercial street, hence the name "Taiwan First Street." Between the end of March 1661 and the beginning of February 1662, King Cheng Cheng of Yanping County led a force of 25,000 troops from Kinmen to cross the Taiwan Strait, entered the Taiwan Strait from the Kalmen Canal into the Taiwan Strait, first captured Pramancheng City, then besieged The Lanzhou Castle, finally forced the Dutch East India Company to surrender the garrison and withdraw from Yanping and Taiwan.

Gasoline is a liquid volatile, flammable hydrocarbon mixture that is distilled or cracked from petroleum and used as a fuel. It is also known as "electrical oil" in Hong Kong. The origin of the word "gasoline" comes from the trademark name "Cazeline". It may have been changed by John Cassell to his surname Cassell. An advertisement in The Times in 1862 read: "The Patent Cazeline Oil, safe, economical, and brilliant... possesses all the requisites which have so long been desired as a means of powerful artificial light."

In 1966, 60 years after Pickering claimed the discovery of "Thames", the French astronomer Audouin Charles Dollfus reported the discovery of a new moon. Originally thought to have recovered "Thames", but later thought to be a new moon, it was named after the Roman mythical gatekeeper Janus. However, the same as "Thames"; no one else could find the moon except Dollfus. Until 1979 to 1980, when Pioneer 11 explored Saturn; several new moon were discovered, three of which were later confirmed to be the same moon. Later confirmed that the moon and Janus discovered by Dollfus were the same moon, and finally confirmed the existence of Saturn X. The crater on Saturn X, named after a person associated with Castor and Porus in Greek mythology.

The Nobel Prize in Physics (Swedish: Nobelpriset i Physik) is an award given annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to recognize outstanding contributions to physics since 1901; the prize money is awarded by the Nobel Foundation. The prize is one of five Nobel Prizes established in Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, the other four being the Chemistry Prize, the Literary Prize, the Peace Prize and the Physiological Medicine Prize. The Nobel Prize in Physics is generally considered the highest honour that can be awarded in the field of physics. The award ceremony is held annually on 10 December, the anniversary of Nobel's death, in Stockholm, Sweden. The first Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Wilhelm Lunchen, a German-Dutch physicist who discovered X-rays.

Almost all planets and moons with solid surfaces have craters. The density of craters on some objects can be used to determine the age of the corresponding surface regions. Daniel Barringer was the first to identify a geological formation on Earth as a crater: he noted that Barringer's crater in Arizona, USA, was a crater. However, his theory did not gain much support at the time, when most geologists believed that there were no craters left on Earth. In the 1920s, American geologist Walter H. Bucher studied a series of craters in the United States. He concluded that these craters were caused by large explosions, but he believed that these explosions were caused by strong volcanic eruptions. However, in 1936, other geologists concluded that these craters may have been caused by impacts.

He returned to the Senate in 1961 and briefly served as Speaker from 6 November 1963 to 27 November 1963. On 13 February 1965, the National Assembly failed to pass the government's draft national budget for 1965, the third Ismail Inani coalition government resigned, on 20 February an agreement was reached between the Justice Party, the New Turkish Party, the Republican Peasant National Party and the National Party to form a new joint law enforcement agency, the fourth coalition government was formed, and a non-partisan senator named Yildirim became Prime Minister. The Yildirim government's policies were not significantly different from those of the previous governments, but in terms of foreign policy they reflected Turkey's new trend after the coup of 1960, which was to implement a more independent policy within NATO and improve relations with the Soviet Union and the countries of the Eastern European Group. In May 1965, the Soviet Foreign Minister visited Turkey, and in August Yildirim's Prime Minister made an official visit to the Soviet Union, where technical experts discussed the problems that the Soviet Union would help Turkey to build some industrial projects, thus further developing trade and economic cooperation between the two countries and significantly improving relations between the two countries.

The Chinese Democratic Socialist Party (CDSP) is a defunct political party in the People's Republic of China. It was formed by the merger of the Chinese National Socialist Party (CNSP) and the Chinese Democratic Constitutional Party (CDCP) on 14 August 1946 in Shanghai. It participated in the Constitutional National Assembly of the People's Republic of China during the mainland period and moved to Taiwan with the government of the Republic of China in 1949. During the martial law period, the CDSP was one of the three legitimate political parties in the Republic of China. Following the lifting of the party ban in the late 1980s, some members of the party successively split into separate parties, while Taiwanese nationals with a certain influence were transferred to the Democratic Progressive Party. After the general elections of the early 1990s, the party lost seats even more thoroughly and rapidly bubbled.

Information economics, a branch of microeconomics, was first proposed by the American economist George Stigler in 1961, who himself argued that the content of product information has a certain influence on economic activity and consumer purchasing decisions. We take the most basic product price information, and each retailer on the market has a different price for a product, so that consumers, in pursuit of the cheapest price, compare prices one by one to arrive at a lowest price, and this number of actions we call "searching."

When Christopher Columbus discovered the West Indies in 1492, the Spanish name "Andalus" was used to refer to these islands, and hence "Andalus Sea" became the alternative name for the Caribbean in some European languages. For a century thereafter, Spain held absolute hegemony. For a long time, the Caribbean was a completely unknown area for Eurasian civilization, until Columbus sailed into the area in 1492 in an attempt to discover the routes to Asia. At that time, much of the western hemisphere was unknown to Europeans. After Columbus' discovery of the Caribbean, the region was quickly colonized by Western civilizations (first Spain, then Portugal, England, the Netherlands Republic, France, and Denmark). As a result, the Caribbean became a hub for European shipping and maritime trade, eventually leading to piracy.

Sun Yat-sen's Rebellion, or simply Sun Yat-sen's Rebellion, was a mutiny that occurred at the end of the Eastern Jin Dynasty, which broke out in 399 AD and ended in 411 AD. It lasted about 11 years. The background of this mutiny was the Five-Dune Meadows, but it was actually caused by the people's dissatisfaction with the rule of the Eastern Jin Dynasty, so that the leaders could take time to start. The incident can be divided into "Sun Yat-sen's Rebellion" (399 - 402 AD) and "Sun Yat-sen's Rebellion" (403 - 411 AD), according to the leaders, Sun Yat-sen was Sun Yat-sen's sister-in-law. Both incidents threatened Jiankang, the master of the Eastern Jin Dynasty (now in Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province). The school building project was commissioned by the Taipei City Government to the National Housing Department for planning and construction. Due to rising land prices and real estate, the budget could not be coordinated, through several tenders, the first phase of the project (Administrative Building and the third and fourth teaching buildings) was subcontracted in September 1987, and the tendering work was completed. The school was officially established on August 1, 1988, Mr. Lin was the first principal, and in September of the same year, the first new students were admitted to the school. In the first three years of the school, 9 male and female students each, the average number of each class was more than 56, the maximum was 64; in the fourth year, the number of students increased to 20, male and female students each 10. The first students, because the school building project had not been completed, were negotiating to borrow part of the teaching spaces of two schools in the nearby Chugoku and Saihu provinces, so that students could study in the classrooms. One year later, in September 1989, they returned to the newly constructed school building. In December 1989 and April 1990, the second phase of the project (the second teaching building) and the fourth phase of the project (building A: specialized classrooms such as hearing, experimentation, etc.) continued to be subcontracted construction, and in July 1991, all ordinary classrooms, sports grounds and stadiums were completed, and the campus beautification project was also completed at the same time.

The Tamzi District Office is the dispatching agency of the Taichung City Government in the Tamzi District, the executive agency of the Vari District Administration of the Government of the Republic of China, and the senior supervisory agency of the Taichung City Government. The district director is appointed by the mayor, whose term of office is guaranteed without a term. Under the district director and secretary of the director, there are 9 internal units such as 5 divisions and 4 rooms. The Tamzi District Office was originally located on Zhongshan Road, but was moved in September 2018 to the Tamzi Joint Office Building in the Tamzi Administrative Park on Fengxing Road.

Born in Yongding County, Fujian Province, he joined the Communist Party of China in August 1973. He graduated from the Department of Finance and Finance, Xiamen University in June 1981. He holds a postgraduate degree in finance and holds a PhD in economics. He is currently a member of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China, Vice-Chairman of the National Committee of the CPPCC and Director of the State Development and Reform Commission, and Secretary of the Party Group. He was a substitute member of the 17th and 18th Central Committees of the CPPCC, a member of the 19th Central Committee, a member of the 20th Central Committee, and a member of the Politburo. In August 1973, at the age of 18, he went to Yongding County, Fujian Province, to participate in the work of the Xinzhi Qingqing Interdiction Team. From November 1976, he participated in the construction of the Yongding County Lion Xiangtan Hydroelectric Power Station. After the restoration of the entrance examination system, he was admitted to the Department of Economics, Xiamen University in February 1978, where he studied finance and finance.

A university is a higher education institution that provides teaching and research conditions, authorizes the granting of associate degrees and degrees. Modern universities usually include graduate schools or institutes that grant associate degrees and bachelor's degrees, establish different colleges and departments, and grant master's and doctoral degrees. The term "university" refers not only to one of the four Confucian classics, the "University," but also to a body that gathers in a specific place to organize, research and disseminate knowledge in a deep field. According to the literature, the university as a higher education institution can be traced back to the reign of the Five Emperors and the Upper Temple; Dong Zhongshu said: "If the University of the Five Emperors is said to be a reign of reign, then the Upper Temple is also a reign of reign." In the reign of Yu Shun, the establishment of the Upper Temple, "the Upper Temple" means "higher school"; Zheng Xuan: "The Upper Temple is a university, in the western suburbs of the King's City."

A fiscal year, also known as an accounting year, refers to the statistical time at which a company or a country sets its budget or calculates its income each year. However, each country or organization governed by its laws differs, and is usually divided into two categories: calendar year and interannual. A fiscal year refers to the statistical year used by the government for accounting purposes. In most countries, the tax year used by the tax authorities is the same as the fiscal year used by the government, but private companies may choose their own fiscal year for accounting purposes. However, in some countries, the fiscal year used by the government is not uniform. For example, in the United Kingdom, the fiscal year starts on April 1, and corporate taxes use the same tax year, but the tax year used for personal income taxes starts on April 6 and ends on April 5. In the United States, the federal government's fiscal year starts on October 1, but the fiscal years of each state are different, and individuals and companies are free to choose their own fiscal year.

If a country is a democracy, with no royalty or kings, the executive power is vested in the government, which is exercised by the president's representative, subject to the constitutional and parliamentary constraints. This or similar system can promote a country's transition from human rule to the rule of law, and is an important stage in the development of a democracy. The coexistence of three governmental institutions and the form of governmental organization that is mutually balanced is a political system that is currently used in most countries in the world. The idea of decentralization can be traced back to the ancient Greek Aristotle, who first mentioned the concept of "mixed government" or "mixed polity" in his book Politics, in which he referred to many constitutional forms of ancient Greek cities. In the Roman Republic, the Roman Senate, the Roman Consulate and the Roman People's Assembly, Polybius presented an example of what he called a mixed polity. Polybius described and explained the system of checks and balances in detail, and attributed the first such government to Laërtius of Sparta.

On 6 July 2018, Sharif was convicted of concealing large amounts of assets overseas and sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment and 7 years' imprisonment for him and his daughter, respectively. He and his daughter were imprisoned after returning from London on 14 July. Sharif objected and filed an appeal. On 19 September 2018, the High Court of Islamabad held a hearing on Sharif's appeal, granting him bail and suspending his imprisonment.
