The Kuiper belt, also known as the Leonard–Kuiper belt, is a dense disk-like region of celestial bodies near the ecliptic outside the orbit of Neptune (about 30 AU from the Sun). The Kuiper belt is located in a low inclination orbit 40 to 50 AU from the Sun. It was once thought to be empty, the end of the Solar System. In fact, it is full of frozen microplanets ranging in diameter from a few kilometers to thousands of kilometers. The origin and exact structure of the Kuiper belt is unclear, and current theories speculate that it originated from fragments on the solar protoplanetary disk, which attracted collisions with each other, but ultimately formed a microplanetary belt rather than a planet, where solar winds and matter slowed down. The Kuiper belt is sometimes mistaken for the boundary of the Solar System, but the Solar System also includes the Oort Cloud, which extends two light-years outward.

In 1507, the German cartographer Martin Waldsheimer published his mapping work, "Overview of Cartography," in which he named the regions visited by explorers such as Columbus in the Latin name of Amerigo Vespucci. The term "America" has been used since then. Europeans have entered the Americas, on the one hand bringing the diseases of the indigenous peoples of the Americas, on the other hand facing the massacre of the indigenous peoples of the Americas, and have established countries of European colonists. The northernmost land of the Americas is the island of Capricorn, which is also the northernmost land in the world. The easternmost is the mountain of Greenland's Nordost négociationen, and the westernmost is the island of Atu. America is divided by wide plains in the mountains on both sides. The western coast is the Cordillera Mountains, in North America mainly the Rocky Mountains. There are 35 countries in the Americas, 23 of which are in North America (2 in North America, 8 in Central America, 13 in the Caribbean region), 12 in South America.

Freshwater turtles are generally smaller than sea turtles, but there are also larger species, such as the Asiatic tortoise (Pelochelys cantorii), which in a few cases can reach the same size.. Later, more terrifying turtles larger than the ancient giant tortoise were discovered. The smallest tortoise is the spotted turtle, which lives in South America, and is no longer than 8 cm (3.1 in) long and weighs only 140 grams (4.9 ounces). In human history, tortoiseshells have been used as gemstones. Currently, tortoiseshells are protected under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, and many countries have banned the hunting of tortoiseshells and the export of tortoiseshell products.

The Guangzhou Metro is the urban rail transportation system of Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, China. Line 1, the first section of the network, is Huangsha-Silong, which is also the first sub-provincial city, provincial capital and district city in mainland China to have a subway. So far, the Guangzhou Metro Line has 16 lines (1-9, 13, 14, 18, 21, 22 and Guangzhou Metro Line and APM Line), with a total of 260 stations. The Guangzhou Metro has now become one of the most important means of transportation for Guangzhou citizens, with more than 2.8 billion passenger trips in 2021, accounting for 61% of the total public transportation trips in the city. So far, the Guangzhou Metro has 16 operating lines, with a total length of 621.05 km. Of these, 15 lines (1-9, 13, 14, 18, 21, 22 and Guangzhou Metro Line) are conventional medium-duty railways, and the Pearl River New City Passenger Automatic Transportation System (APM Line) uses a rubber wheel system.

VY Canis Major was first observed on March 7, 1801 by the French astronomer Jerome Lalande in his catalogue as a 7th magnitude star. Later, in the 19th century, when studying its luminosity, it was thought that its magnitude began to decline in 1850. It has been known since 1847 that VY Canis Major is a deep red star. VY Canis Major is a high-luminosity M-type star, with an effective surface temperature of about 3000 K, located in the upper right-hand corner of the Hertzsprung diagram, so the process of becoming a supergiant is thought to be quite complicated. It may have originally been an O-type main sequence star. Star distances can be used to measure the parallax produced when the Earth orbits the Sun. However, the parallax of VY Canis Major is too small and the error is too large to use this method. In 1976, Charles J. Lada and Mark J. Reid discovered a molecular cloud at the 15th corner to the east of VY Canis Major.

The official name of Cambodia is "Kingdom of Cambodia" (Khmer:ព្រះរាជាណាចក្រកម្ពុជា, Romanized: Preăh Réachéanachâk Kâmpŭchéa). Among them, "God" means "holy", "Kingdom" means "kingdom", "Cambodia" means "Cambodia". The name "Cambodia" derives from the Sanskrit word "Kambujadeśa", meaning "Land of Swords and Sands". This implies the mythology of the establishment of the Kingdom of Cambodia. According to one myth, Cambodia was founded by the saint from India, Kambu Swayambhuva, after marrying Mera, a noblewoman of the Southern Peninsula, and Kambu Swayambhuva's son was Shreshtha Varman, king of Laos.

In mines and cities, new art forms evolved and evolved: the use of dynamic art from plastic strips to bicycle strips. From the 1850s onwards, folk artists influenced by Dutch culture, Trekboer pastoralists and white artists who followed the changing culture of Europe continued to contribute to this evolving cultural mix. During the apartheid era, South Africa developed a new art form called "rural art", which became very popular in the 1960s and 1970s. "rural art" often focused on depicting the daily lives of poor black South Africans, and common visual elements of this art style included an old house, a woman washing clothes, whistling, and a pair of black mothers and sons.

Otto Wilhelm von Struve (German: Otto Wilhelm von Struve; Russian: Отто Васильевич Струве; 7 May 1819 – 14 April 1905) was a Russian Imperial astronomer, Baltic German. He and his father Vasily Yakovlevich Struve were famous 19th century astronomers, and served as director of the Pulkovo Observatory between 1862 and 1889, as well as a member of the Russian Academy of Sciences. Born in 1819 in the Russian Empire-ruled Dorpat (now Tartu, Estonia), Otto was the third of eight children born to Vasily Yakovlevich Struve and his first wife Emilie Wall (1796–1834).

On April 1, 1898, the Fourth Affiliated School established the Secondary School Department; on August 16, 1898, the First Affiliated School was independently renamed the "Shilan Public School"; the Third Affiliated School was abolished; the former Second Affiliated School was renamed the First Affiliated School; the former Fourth Affiliated School was renamed the Second Affiliated School; the former First Affiliated Girls' School was renamed the Third Affiliated School; on March 30, 1902, the Second Affiliated School was independently renamed Taipei Second Ordinary School; the former Third Affiliated School was renamed the Second Affiliated School; on October 3, 1904, the Third Affiliated School was established as a Japanese Girls' Higher Education School; on May 4, 1907, the First Affiliated School was renamed the National Language School; the Second Affiliated Middle School was independently renamed the Taiwan Governor's Middle School; the Third Affiliated School was renamed the Second Affiliated School; on April 1, 1910, the Second Affiliated School was renamed the Second Affiliated Public School; the Second Affiliated School was renamed the Second Affiliated Girls' School; and on September 8, 1904, Taipei Third Ordinary Higher School (now Nanmen Elementary School) was renamed Taipei Normal Secondary School.

Yangjiang City (Chinese: 阳江市; pinyin: Yeungkong), formerly known as Moyang, Nan'an Province, is a city in the southwest coast of Guangdong Province of the People's Republic of China. It is bordered by Jiangmen City to the east, Yunfu City to the north, Maoming City to the west, and the South China Sea to the south. It is located in the low-lying hilly area along the west coast of Guangdong Province, the cloudy mountains to the northwest, Tianlu Mountain to the northeast, the desert Yang River valley and the Yangchun Basin to the south-east. The desert Yang River runs through the city, and its tributaries include the Tamsui River and the Nalong River. The total area of the city is 7,955 square kilometers, the population is 260.3 million, and the city's people's government is located in Jiangcheng City.

Tesco (Chinese: 乐购; Taiwanese: 特易购; Malaysian: 特易购; Chinese: 乐购) is a major supermarket chain in the United Kingdom, currently the largest retailer in the United Kingdom, and the world's third largest supermarket group, after Wal-Mart (United States) and Carrefour (France). Tesco started out as a food retailer and gradually expanded into clothing, electrical appliances, customer financial services, Internet services, auto insurance and telecommunications. As of the end of 2018, Tesco's turnover exceeded £568.83 billion.

Pictor is a constellation located in the Southern Hemisphere, between Old Star and the Large Magellanic Cloud. The constellation name "Pictor" means "painter" in Latin and is an abbreviation of the former Latin name "Equuleus Pictoris". Pictor is commonly represented by Pictor, named by the monastery of Nicolas Louis Lacaille in the 18th century. The brightest star in Pictor is Alpha Pictoris, a white main sequence star about 97 light years away from Earth. RR Pictoris is also in the constellation. The cataclysmic variable system erupted as a nova in 1925, peaking at 1.2 magnitudes, and then gradually darkened. Beta Pictoris is of concern because of its second bright star, which is 63.4 light years away from Earth, surrounded by an unusual dust disk with high carbon content, and also has an extrasolar planet.

Railway, also known as railway, is a form of public transport in which trains use rail wheels to travel on the railway tracks. In linguistic terms, it is sometimes referred to as the concept of railway transport. The operation of railway also includes railway tracks, railway stations, interchanges and railway locomotives. The oldest known railway capable of carrying people or animals dates back to the 6th century BC in Corinth, Greece. In the middle of the 16th century, horse-drawn railways appeared in Germany. In the early 19th century, with the development of steam locomotives, Britain formed the first railway transport system in the modern sense. In 1825, the locomotive No. 1 built by George Stephenson and his son Robert Stephenson Company was the first steam locomotive capable of carrying passengers on the railways (Stockton and Darlington Railways). George Stephenson also built the world's first intercity railway that only allowed steam locomotives to travel, the Liverpool and Manchester Railways, which opened in 1830.

" Every day, the public and private people go to the waterside to wash. Not only the Han folk custom, even the emperor and queen also go to the water to cleanse the dirt and purify the evil. Later, this custom further evolved into the drinking of the water. Wei Jin later changed to the first three of March, became an important festival, the washing of the body gradually evolved into the drinking of the water banquet guests and the outskirts of the spring, and the practice of the water floating eggs and the water floating namely, and so on, and so on, and so on, and so on into the flowing water. In the first three of March of the ninth year (353 AD) of the East Jin Dynasty, forty-two people, including Wang Xizhi's family and friends Xie An, Sun Yuan, and so on, gathered in the garden of the garden of Jishanyin (now Shaoxing, Zhejiang Province) after the ceremony, held a game of the water flowing water, forty-two people drank wine and sang poetry, the poems were combined into "Lanting Collection," Wang Xizhi for the collection "Lanting Collection Introduction." Since then, the flowing water, poetry essays, drinking wine and scenery, has been passed down for thousands of years.

Since 1850, the number of known variable stars has increased rapidly, especially since 1890, when it was possible to identify variable stars by photographic means. The 2008 Variable Stars Overview lists more than 46,000 variable stars in the Milky Way, 10,000 in other galaxies, and more than 10,000 candidates for possible variable stars. The most common types of variable stars involve changes in measurement, but there are also other types of variables that occur, particularly changes in spectra. By combining light curve data with observed spectral changes, astronomers can usually explain why a particular star changes. Variable stars are usually analyzed by means of luminosity measurements, spectral photography, and spectroscopy. Light curves can be plotted by measuring the variation in brightness over time. For regular variable stars, the changes in their periods and amplitudes can be well determined; however, for many variable stars, these values can vary slowly over time, even from one period to the next.

The Napoleonic Wars are usually described as five conflicts: the Third Anti-Fascist Alliance (1803–1806), the Fourth Anti-Fascist Alliance (1806–07), the Fifth Anti-Fascist Alliance (1809), the Sixth Anti-Fascist Alliance (1813–14), the Seventh Anti-Fascist Alliance (1815), and the Peninsular War (1807–1814) and the Russo-French War (1812). Napoleon succeeded in establishing an unusually powerful army and a financially and politically stable state after he became the first French regent in 1799, after a great deal of reform.

Io (minor planet 243) is a member of the Orion family of minor planets in the main belt, discovered by John Paliza on 29 September 1884. Its name derives from a Greek mythological Nephr. Observed by astronomical telescopes, Io is classified as an S-type asteroid, one of the largest members of the inner belt. On 28 August 1993, the Galileo spacecraft that visited Jupiter approached Io. It is the second asteroid to be approached by a spacecraft, and the first to be discovered to have a moon. Like other main belt asteroids, Io orbits between Mars and Jupiter. Its orbital period is 4.84 years, and its rotation period is 4.63 hours. Ida has an average diameter of 31.4 km (19.5 mi). It has an irregular, elliptical shape, distinctly linked by two large bodies, shaped like ox horn bread.

Chiang Kai-shek, through his relationship with Zhang Jingjiang and Sun Wen, continued to express his intention to marry Chiang Kai-shek, and eventually obtained her consent. Chiang stated to Chiang Kai-shek that he had separated from the original bride and concubine, and promised "you will be my only legitimate wife." Chiang Kai-shek claimed to have married Chiang Kai-shek on December 5, 1921, but Chiang told The New York Times on September 27, 1927 that Chen was only a concubine. In 1921, in Shanghai, Chiang Kai-shek was cared for by Chiang Kai-shek's subordinate Chen Guofu, and Chiang Kai-shek's concubine, Chiang Kai-shek, went to Shanghai with Chiang Kai-shek to become Chiang Kai-shek's stepmother.

Each month, whether big or small, is the first half of the month from 1 to 15 days, and the second half of the month from 16 days. The second letter and the number table that follows are the order in which the stars were discovered in that half-month, without the addition of the letter "I". For example, the eighth star discovered in the second half of March 1950 would be 1950 FH. However, modern technology dictates that there must be more than 25 asteroids discovered in that half-month, so the number below the sign indicates that the letter has been circulated several times. Thus, the 28th star discovered in the second half of March 1950 would be 1950 FC1. However, due to limitations of computer ASCII codes, the numbers below the sign should sometimes be placed directly at the same height, so they could also be marked directly as 1950FC1. 1926 GA1 The first asteroid to use the sign system.

In 1954, the Constitution of the People's Republic of China did not stipulate the functions and powers of the Vice-Chairman. According to the Organization Law of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China of 1954, the Vice-Chairman's main function was to "elect from among the Vice-Chairmen an acting Chairman of the Standing Committee when the Chairman of the Standing Committee is unable to work or is absent for a long period of time because of his health condition, until the Chairman recovers his health or the National People's Congress elects a new Chairman." In addition, the Vice-Chairman could submit proposals to the Standing Committee. In 1975, the First Session of the Fourth National People's Congress adopted the amended Constitution of the People's Republic of China, which did not stipulate the functions and powers of the Vice-Chairman.

In the early days of the Northern Song Dynasty, Zhao Pu said to Emperor Taizong that "China is secure, the barbarians are self-sustaining, and the father-in-law is the one who wants to leave the country, so he must stay in." Yuan Ming's "Emergency Supplies must be Strengthened to Preserve the Emperor's Work" mentioned that "the subjects are consulted, the frontier troops must be provided with food, and they must leave the country and stay in." On November 30, 1930, Chiang Kai-shek gave a speech at an oath-taking ceremony for foreign minister Gu Weijun, claiming that "the foreigners must leave the country and stay in." The so-called "inner" refers to the need for unity and stability in the country, to make the country unified, and thus to fight against the separatists, and the so-called "unification party can defend itself." At that time, there were two main concerns in the national government about internal affairs: the armed separatist movement of the Chinese Communist Party, and the rebellion of local forces.

The mass of the Sun (symbolized M☉) is the mass unit used in astronomy to represent the mass of large objects such as stars, clusters, or galaxies. It is defined as the mass of the Sun, approximately 2×1030 kilograms, which means that one solar mass is 333,000 times the mass of the Earth. The mass of the Sun can also be expressed in terms of the length of a year, the distance between the Earth and the Sun, astronomical units, and the universal gravitational constant (G): currently, both astronomical units and universal gravitational constants have been accurately measured, however, the mass of other planets or binary stars in the Solar System is not often used to represent the mass of the Sun; it is used only for the measurement of massive objects.

Shushkevich supported a policy of denuclearization, a free-market economy and a policy of privatization. He maintained diplomatic independence, took a negative stance on the consolidation of the CIS, and refused to sign a collective security agreement with the CIS, which led to his opposition to the Supreme Soviet. His reform policies were also thwarted by members of parliament headed by Prime Minister Vyacheslav Kuznetsov. Belarus was plunged into inflation, the economic crisis deepened, and the rule of the regime weakened. In January 1994, Alexander Lukashenko, in the name of corruption, impeached 70 Belarusian officials, including Shushkevich. The Belarusian parliament launched a motion of no confidence, and Shushkevich eventually resigned, succeeded by Vyacheslav Nikolayevich Kuznetsov, and later elected Myechyslaw Hryb as his successor.

The Vela satellite system, part of the U.S. Department of Defense and the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission's Project Vela, consists of 12 satellites launched between October 1963 and April 1970, equipped with sensors such as X-ray detectors, gamma-ray detectors, neutron detectors, visible light detectors, electromagnetic pulse detectors, and other sensors capable of detecting near-field and atmospheric nuclear explosions.

Taoyuan Municipal Daxi Senior High School (DXSH) is located in Daxi District, Taoyuan City. It covers an area of more than 9,000 square meters. It was first enrolled in the 98th academic year (2009). Governor Zhu Lilong hoped that Daxi High School would become a competitive and distinctive public high school. It is now a community high school for graduates from Daxi District, Longtan District, and Fuxing District. The new building is an office building, and is used for residential education, including books, arts and crafts performances, etc. 10 classes were enrolled in September 2009.

With the development of agriculture, hunter-gatherers gradually switched to agriculture or animal husbandry, and the hunter-gatherer lifestyle withdrew from the historical scene. Today, only a very small number of societies or groups are classified as hunter-gatherers. Hunting refers to the way of moving and grazing between different ranches. One of the most striking differences between hunter-gatherers and hunter-gatherers is the domestication of animals. It is commonly believed that hunting has undergone three stages of development, one of which is the increase in population and the complexity of social organizations. Karim Sadr proposes the following stages: The herders migrate to certain fixed areas and make temporary settlements as the seasons change (spring, summer, autumn and winter or dry and rainy seasons); in the real sense, hunting depends only on the availability of resources. Hunting is the result of the Neolithic Revolution and the rise of agriculture. In the Neolithic Revolution, humans began to domesticate animals and plants as food and began to form cities.

Luzhou District is located in the northwestern part of the Taipei Basin, on the west bank of the lower reaches of the Tamsui River. The northeastern part of the district is separated from the Tamsui River by the Shashi Island in the Shilin District of Taipei City, and the western part is adjacent to the Five Point District. The southeastern part of the district is adjacent to the Three Point District, and the terrain is low-lying, gradually decreasing from the southeast to the northwest and slightly sloping to the northwest. Luzhou District is a fertile soil, suitable for agriculture. The east and west sides of Luzhou District and the Three Point District are surrounded by the Tamsui River and the Double Floodway, respectively, forming the same island, and are called the Three Point District. There are three major subdivisions in Luzhou District, respectively, the Grey Point District, the Wise Point District and the South Port District. Due to the low-lying terrain and lack of flood control facilities in early years, Luzhou was prone to the tidal influence of the Tamsui River, flooding problems are quite difficult; whenever heavy rainstorm roads often accumulate water and knees, and in severe cases it is even possible to get in by ferry. After the completion of the Double Floodway and related flood control facilities, Luzhou was not able to escape the nightmare of flooding. The New Taipei City Government has planned a comprehensive all-round urban plan for Luzhou District, an agricultural district that was abandoned due to flooding in the past, and after the plan is pushed forward, Luzhou District will have a new coastal townscape.

In the autumn of 1953, the People's Literature and Arts College of South China (Graduate School of Fine Arts), the People's Literature and Arts College of South China (Graduate School of Fine Arts) and the Guangxi Academy of Fine Arts (Graduate School of Fine Arts) were reorganized into the Central and South China Academy of Fine Arts, located in Wuchang, Hubei. In 1958, the Central and South America Academy of Fine Arts relocated to Guangzhou. In August of the same year, it was renamed the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts, and undergraduate students began to be admitted. In 1969, the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts was merged with the Guangzhou Academy of Music and the Guangzhou Academy of Dance to form the Guangdong People's Academy of Fine Arts. In February 1978, the original structure of the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts was restored, and graduate students began to be admitted throughout the country. In 1982, it was granted the right to confer a master's degree, one of the first units in the country to obtain the right to confer a master's degree. In 1986, continuing education students began to be admitted. In 1998, the design departments and specialized departments formed the design branch, and in 2004 it was renamed the "Design College".

At that time, Cao Yulin, who was appointed as the head of transportation, was known as "the traitor" because he was responsible for handing over part of his rights and interests to Japan. He was also known as "the traitor" together with the president of the Monetary Bureau, Lu Zongyu, and the ambassador to Japan, Zhang Zongxiang. One of the famous slogans of the time was "fight for sovereignty abroad, punish the traitor internally." When the May 4th incident occurred, students marched near the house of Zhao and tried to capture Cao Yulin, who was accused of being a traitor, but Zhao escaped and fled the house. They mistook Zhang Zongxiang, who was at the time in the house of Zhao, for Cao Yulin, so they beat Zhao severely and burned the house down. Later, the incident evolved into a large-scale strike, strike and market. On June 10, Cao, Lu and Zhang were dismissed from their posts. Under pressure from the public, the Beiyang government finally officially refused to sign the Treaty of Versailles. The Shandong issue was referred to the Washington Conference. Cao then transferred to the industry, remaining general manager of the Bank of Communications, general manager of the Bank of Commerce of China, general manager of Tianhe Coal Mine Company, general manager of the Bank of Industry of China, and chairman of Zhengfeng Coal Mine Co. Wei Dao Ming (October 28, 1899 - May 18, 1978)In 1919, Wei Dao Ming went to study in France. In 1925, he graduated with a doctorate in law from the University of Paris and was the first Chinese to hold a doctorate in law, with a thesis entitled "Le chèque en Chine" (The Cheque in China). In 1925, he returned to China with Zheng Yuxiu, and the two opened a law firm in the Shanghai Public Concession. In 1927, he was appointed chief secretary of the Ministry of Justice of the Nanjing National Government. In 1928, he was promoted to the position of deputy director and minister of the Ministry of Justice (which was renamed the "Ministry of Judicial Administration" in that year). In 1930, he was appointed mayor of the Nanjing Special City. In 1931, he went to Europe to explain the truth of Japan's aggression against northeastern China to all countries. In 1935, Wei Dao Ming returned to China and became the general manager of the newspapers of Confucius, such as Jiji Xin, Mainland, and Dai Evening.

During her time at school, she and Lu Xun launched a campaign to denounce Yang Yam-yu, the first principal of Beijing Women's Normal University, who had been expelled. She publicly expressed her feelings for her teacher Lu Xun in the newspapers one year before graduation. In 1927, they lived together in Guangzhou. They soon moved to Shanghai. Lu Xun's only child, Zhou Hai-yi, was born in Shanghai in 1929. Xu lived with Lu Xun until his death. After the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, Xu served as Deputy Secretary-General of the Administrative Council of the Central People's Government, Vice-Chairman of the National Women's Union, Vice-Chairman of the Chinese Cultural Union, and so on. In 1954, she was elected as the first deputy to the National People's Congress. In September, she attended the first session of the first National People's Congress to discuss the draft Constitution, and spoke during the session. She was the third secretary-general of the Democratic Party of China's Democratic Promotion Association (Minjin), the fourth and fifth vice-chairmen of the Central Committee; the first to the third Standing Committee of the CPPCC, and the first to the third Standing Committee of the National People's Congress.

With the deepening of colonial activity in the 19th century, most of the world's easily developed land was divided, and European colonists began to occupy Papua Island. In 1884, the British and Germans succeeded in partitioning the eastern half of the island and the surrounding islands, and the dividing line between the two territories was the central mountain range. In 1906, British New Guinea came under the administration of the Australian Federation, and was renamed Australian Papua Territory. After World War I, the Australian army occupied German New Guinea. On December 17, 1920, the International Union decided to entrust Australia with the administration of New Guinea Territory; during World War II, New Guinea was once occupied by the Japanese army, and after the war, the United Nations entrusted Australia with the administration. In 1949, Australia merged the two parts into one administrative unit, called the "New Papua Territory". On December 1, 1973, it implemented internal self-government. On September 16, 1975, it became a member of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

The 20th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China The 24th Standing Committee of the National People's Congress The 14th People's Political Consultative Conference of the State Council of the People's Republic of China The 14th National Committee The 20th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China The 20th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China was elected by the 20th National Congress on October 22, 2022, and its members included Central Committee members and Central Alternate Committee members.

Early in his career, Aden attended Eton College and graduated from Christchurch College, Oxford University. He majored in foreign languages and was more proficient in French, German and Persian in addition to speaking Russian and Arabic. He joined the British Army during World War I and was awarded the Cross of Merit. He served as brigade major of the Infantry Brigade from 26 May 1918 to 198 May 1918. He retired from the British Army on 13 June 1919. In 1923, he was elected to the House of Commons as a Conservative Member of Parliament for Warwick and Leamington, from which he entered politics. In the same year, he married Patricia Burgess and had two sons.

In 1898, he was appointed as a teacher at Nanyang Normal School, and in 1901, he was appointed as the headmaster of Nanyang Normal School Affiliated Primary School (now Nanyang Model Secondary School in Shanghai). In 1903, he wrote an article in the Suzhou Gazette attacking the Qing Dynasty and accusing the then ruling Empress Dowager Jia of being a "prostitute." After the Suzhou Gazette was published, he went to London via Hong Kong. In 1904, he went to Edinburgh University to study English. In the winter of 1905, he joined the League of Nations. In 1906, he participated in the organization of the World Society in Paris. In 1907, he published the New Century Weekly and the World Painting Magazine, and promoted anarchism. This was one of the first socialist ideas to enter China. Later, it had a great influence in China. After the rise of the Chinese Communist Party, it was gradually suppressed and declined. After 1911, he engaged in cultural movements. In 1912, together with Li Shizheng, Wang Xiewei, Cai Yuanpei, etc., he founded the Liu Fajian Society, launched Liu Fajian Labour and Labour Studies. At its peak, he sent 1,600-2000 students to France between 1919 and 1920. Many of them later became high-ranking leaders of the Chinese Communist Party, including Zhou Enlai, Deng Xiaoping, Chen Yi, etc.

This traditional classification continued to be used until the late 1980s. In the 1990s, it was replaced by the parental branch classification, which is based on the classification of all descendants of a common ancestor and a common ancestor, and only monophyletic groups are recognized as valid taxonomic units or evolutionary lineages. Since arachnids evolved into mammals, mammals are classified within arachnids. However, in general, arachnids are still used to include non-mammalian species in this evolutionary lineage. Reptiles are replaced by sauropods, containing only amorphous subspecies, and dimorphous subspecies; porphyrins are considered to be complex families, and are no longer used. As a result, mammalian reptiles are also used less frequently. Arachnids (not including mammals) are usually classified into two categories according to their evolutionary extent: Pantheonidae and theropodidae. Pantheonidae contain at least six genera, and are classified together because of their more primitive evolutionary extent, and are therefore a non-natural family.

In the late 1902s, the first modern, electrically driven air conditioning system was invented by Willis Curry. Its design differed from that of Wolfe in that it not only controlled temperature, but also air humidity to improve the process quality of a printing plant in Brooklyn, New York. This technology provided a low temperature and humidity environment, making paper area and ink sequencing more accurate, i.e., the invention of a humidifier. Curry's technology then began to be used between jobs to improve productivity. Gradually, air conditioning began to be used to improve the comfort of home and car driving. Built in 1906, the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, Northern Ireland, is of special significance in architectural engineering, being called the world's first building with air conditioning. In 1906, Stuart W. Cramer of Charlotte, North Carolina, USA, was looking for a way to increase the air humidity of his southern spinning mill.

In 2010, Taipei Prefecture, Taichung City, Tainan City, Kaohsiung Prefecture, and Taoyuan Prefecture were also upgraded to municipalities with direct jurisdiction.The total area of the province is 72.75% of the total area under the actual jurisdiction of the Government of the Republic of China, and the population is 39.85%.To simplify the level of local government, the province was virtualized (also known as "Zhen Province" or "Frozen Province") in 1998 after the Constitution was amended by the National Assembly in 1997.

Coordinates: 53°30′0′′N 7°38′0′′W / 53.50000°N 7.63333°W / 53.50000; -7.63333The Republic of Ireland (Irish: Éire), commonly known as the Republic of Ireland (Irish: Poblacht na hÉireann), is an island nation in Western Europe, comprising 26 of Ireland's 32 counties.

In 1927, Zhao entered the Seventeenth Primary School in Sangcun Village. In the autumn of 1932, Zhao's father sent Zhao to study at the First Primary School in Sangcun Village. In the summer of 1933, Zhao successfully passed the examination for the Provincial Primary School in Kaifeng (now Kaifeng Senior High School). During the secondary school period, he achieved excellent results and received many scholarships from the school authorities. In 1937, after the Lugou Bridge Incident, China entered a state of total resistance to war. At the age of eighteen, Zhao Ziyang, who was studying in Wuhan, dropped out of school due to the war, returned to his hometown to form an anti-Japanese group. In February 1938, Zhao Ziyang again gained contact with the CCP organization, after which he was sent by the CCP to study at the Party School of the Jiluyuan Provincial Committee. In May of the same year, formally joined the Chinese Communist Party. In 1939, under Zhao Ziyang's tactics, his old classmates, former Kuomintang Nationalist Su County Governor Chen Shuohui led the army to rely on the Chinese Communist Party, declared the secession of the Kuomintang leadership, and accepted the adaptation of the Chinese Communist Party.

The Drakensberg Mountains (South African: Drakensberge, Dutch: Drakensbergen, meaning "dragon mountains") also known as the UKhahlamba Mountains (Zulu: uKhahlamba), are a group of high mountains in South Africa and Lesotho. The mountains are composed of granite, with the highest peak being Mt. Tabanan Treniana at an altitude of 3482 m, at the border between South Africa and Lesotho. The Drakensberg Mountains are mainly composed of basalt, with a basalt layer about 1400 m thick at the top and a sandstone layer below. The main reason for the formation of basalt is the continental instability and volcanic activity of the Precambrian period. The area is characterized by frequent rainfall throughout the year and snowfall in winter. The Drakensberg Mountains are northeast-southwest-facing, located in eastern South Africa, crossing Lesotho. The main peaks of the Drakensberg Mountains are: The area of the Drakensberg Mountains is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2000, with a registered area of 242,813 hectares.

The Eastern Qing Railway was originally a joint venture between the Qing Empire and Russia, with administrative and even judicial powers stretching for tens of kilometers along both sides of the railway. China and Russia shared important functions. Due to the weakness of the Qing dynasty and the intensification of the Xinhai Revolution, the loss of control of the Eastern Province Railway by the Qing Empire was effectively controlled by Tsarist Russia. In the heart of northeastern China, a much larger-scale "state in the middle of the country" was created that was not controlled by China. Tsarist Russia was also able to conveniently control the entire northeastern part of China. After the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War, Japan controlled the section south of Changchun, commonly known as the Nanchang Railway; the section north of Changchun continued to be controlled by Russia. The entire Eastern Qing Railway was originally a Russian 1524 mm wide track, but after the Japanese occupation of the section south of Changchun during the Russo-Japanese War, it was changed to a 1067 mm narrow track.

Malawi has five national parks: Malawi is located almost entirely on the top of mountains, so the vertical differences in the climate of most areas are significant. It is a highland climate in a tropical dry season climate zone, generally the temperature of the high mountain plains is very mild and stable, but the temperature in winter can be as low as 4 degrees Celsius. The temperature in the basin is rather hot, the hottest time can be 39 degrees Celsius, and the annual rainfall varies depending on the geographical environment, on average from 600 mm to 3,000 mm. Usually the rainy season starts from November to May, and the rainfall from May to November is very low. Malawi is located in a highland zone, so it is rarely threatened by hurricanes, floods, etc. Malawi has been rated by the United Nations as one of the world's poorest countries, about 55% of the country lives below the poverty line, the per capita gross national product is only $600, it is one of the lowest income groups in the world.

In 2014, the Shanghai Municipal Government decided to phase out all liquefied petroleum gas-powered vehicles by December 31, 2015. In 2003, due to the limited availability of engines and maintenance conditions, diesel-fuelled buses emitted large amounts of black smoke, seriously affecting public health and the image of the city. The Guangzhou Municipal Government proposed to control the black smoke emitted from the tail gas of buses. According to the Guangdong Provincial Motor Vehicle Pollution Prevention and Control Ordinance, LPG, LNG and electric vehicles are the same clean energy sources. The construction of pure electric vehicles and supporting facilities was not mature at the time. As for the choice between LPG and LNG, the answer given by the Guangzhou Municipal Government was: LPG supply is guaranteed and engine technology is more mature. Between 2003 and 2004, the government decided to replace LPG. Many bus companies, after weighing the costs, considered that the replacement cost was too high, and gasoline was still used without the convenience of refueling.

Leung Chun-ying (Chinese: 梁振英; pinyin: Liang Zhenying; born 12 August 1954) is a Hong Kong politician who served as the 3rd Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) and the current Vice-Chairman of the National Political Coalition (NPC).

Satellites within the Roche limit must be able to coalesce by their own mechanical forces rather than gravity, and loose material on the surface will simply "fall" into the rings. Neptune's rings are unusual, appearing as incomplete arcs when first observed from the ground station, and Voyager 2's images show a complete ring, but with bright clusters. It is thought to be influenced by the gravitational pull of the Shepherd Dog moon Grady, and some unknown Shepherd Dog satellites are associated with these clusters. Pluto is not known to have any ring system at all, but some astronomers speculate that a ring system may have been discovered during the 2015 visit of New Horizons. Furthermore, it is predicted that Ferbers will collapse into a planetary ring due to orbital decay in 10 million years. Earth is also generally thought to have a ring system after the collision of Theia and before it fuses with the Moon.

Paul Biya (born 13 February 1933) is a Cameroonian dictator and current President of Cameroon. He has been Cameroon's supreme leader since 1975 and is the world's oldest living current head of state. He was born in the village of Mumeca in the French province of Southern Cameroon. He graduated in International Relations from the University of Paris in 1961. His first wife, Jeanne-Irène Biya, died on 29 July 1992 and they had no children. On 23 April 1994, he married Chantal Biya, 38 years younger than him, and they had two children. During the years of President Ahmadinejad, his position was greatly enhanced. He served as President's Secretary-General from 1968 to 1975.

Tainan is one of the cultural, academic, educational, and technological centers of South Central Taiwan, as well as the whole South Central China. Apart from the National Success University, which has its headquarters in Tainan, the National Library, the Central Research Institute, the Institute of Industrial Technology, the Science Park, and the South part of the National Yangming Jiaotong University are located in Tainan. According to the flat media poll, Taiwan's competitive ranking of the city of Tainan, the city of Tainan ranks second in sixth place for four consecutive years since the Neolithic period.

It may be a physical event, such as scoring a goal or crossing the finish line first, or it may be decided by the referee on the basis of objective or subjective performance indicators. In organized sports, there is usually a record of excellent performance, and in some popular sports, this information may be widely reported in the sports news. At the same time, sport is also a form of entertainment for non-participants, and amusement sports often attract large numbers of spectators to the stadium and reach a wider audience through broadcasting. With the expansion of international exchange, the scale and level of sports development has become an important indicator of a country's social development and progress, as well as an important means of diplomatic and cultural exchange between countries. A country's level of sports development is measured in several ways: the physical condition of its people, the extent to which sport is popular, the level of scientific theory and the condition of sports facilities, the level of sports technology and the best athletic performance, etc.

Snake Wang Man is a flavored snake restaurant originally located in Lai Wan District, Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province. It was established in 1887 by Mr. Wu Man, a native of Dong Lai Zhuang Village, Guangdong Province. The restaurant was originally named Snake Wang Man. In 1938, during the fall of Guangdong Province, the Great Fire of Saiguan, from the west to the east of Zhen'an Road to the whole area of Rong Street (now the entire site of Cultural Park) was burned down. Snake Wang Man was also in the restaurant. The following year, Mr. Wu Man and his partner Mr. Wu Jianchuan jointly erected the sign of "Snake Wang Man" at No. 41 Oval Lane. The Foshan branch was operated by his daughter Ms. Wu Guiho. In September 1950, Mr. Wu Man died of illness and was 94 years old. After 1949, many owners of snake restaurants had moved overseas, and in 1952, the government merged Oval Lane's Lianchun Hall, Guanyin and other snake restaurants into Snake Wang Man.

On July 7, 2019, the Macau Peninsula Fishermen's Ferry Terminal will be opened as a new destination, officially serving the Macau Peninsula and Luang Wan. Starting from the end of June 2020, the ferry will become a daily departure point for the Macau-MA-D Community Cruise Line. In addition, as the Macau Passenger Ferry Terminal has been designated by the Health Bureau as a central quarantine site for all returnees from high-risk areas and as a test site for routine viral nucleic acid testing, the ferry will no longer stop at the Ferry Terminal. From July 1, 2021, the ferry will be operated from Macau Ferry Terminal to Luang Wan Ferry Terminal, every 90 minutes. The ferry will take you to the Inner Harbour and Cross Gate Waterway. The fare will be 60 yuan Macau. Each ferry will depart from Macau and Luang Wan every day, with a duration of about 25 minutes. The ferry will operate from Thursday to Sunday. To and from. The ferry will depart from and return to Macau.

As the orbit of a particle moves closer to the center, its velocity increases; as the velocity increases, the friction increases, as more particle energy (relative to the black hole) is radiated out; the accretion disk of the black hole is very hot, warm enough to emit X-rays outside the event horizon. The high luminosity of quasars is thought to be the result of gas being accreted by supermassive black holes. In closely related binary systems, larger main stars evolve faster, and when smaller companions reach giant states and exceed the Roche flap, they have evolved into white dwarfs, neutron stars, or black holes.

In the first four months of his tenure as governor, he removed eight governors, governors and governorate governors, and in the next nine years he removed seven envoys and envoys; he revived the library to promote Confucianism, issued books to governors and governorate governors, and rewarded gentlemen, and promoted Confucianism; he set up a modest military camp to save military expenditures, reduced the number of local villagers from 43,000 to 5,700, and supplemented the green camp's shortage so that no one in the army would exaggerate the amount of troops to invade the army's funds; at the same time, he reformed tariffs and customs duties, raising the annual rate of duty from 872 to 1532 to replenish local finances; and he reduced rural taxes, providing grain and agricultural equipment to revive the agricultural economy, and resting with the people.

The Cairo Declaration (Russian: Каирская декларация, Japanese:カイロ宣言) is a declaration issued by President Roosevelt of the United States and Chairman of the Military Committee of the National Government, Chiang Kai-shek. The original Chinese collection was kept by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and is now in the National Palace Museum. In August 1943, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Roosevelt met in Quebec, Canada, to discuss the reconstruction of the post-war international order. Later, Roosevelt planned to convene the Four-Party Summit of China, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the United States. However, the Soviet Union and Japan signed the Treaty of Non-Aggression between the Soviet Union and Japan (signed on April 13, 1941, finally the Soviet Union unilaterally declared its abolition on April 5, 1945, and in August sent troops to attack Manchuria, southern Sakhalin and Japanese Korea), indicating that Stalin would not participate in the international conference with Chiang Kai-shek.

Until the 16th century, the Low Countries—including today's Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg—were ruled by the Duchy of Holland under the Holy Roman Empire. Most of the Low Countries were ruled by the Burgundian and Habsburg families, and in 1549 the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V expanded his powers to guarantee dictatorship, so that the Seven Provinces united in rebellion against the rule and revolution broke out. Charles's son was King Philip II of Spain, continued his father's policy of high taxation and centralized rule, and finally the Eighty Years' War broke out. In 1579, the Seven Grand Provinces of Northern Netherland signed a treaty establishing the Utrecht Alliance, which was supported by the army of the anti-Spanish forces, until the independence of Netherland and Philip in 1581. The following year, the Seven Provinces invited the Duke of Anjou of France to lead them, but left Netherland after the Duke's failure to capture Antwerp in 1583.

Los Angeles County is the most populous county in the United States; San Bernardino County is the largest county in the United States. California is the largest of the U.S. states with a total production of $2.67 trillion. California was originally referred to as the area comprising Mexico's Baja California Peninsula and today's U.S. state of California. The name is believed to derive from a legend in the 16th-century Spanish-language knightly novel Amadís de Gaula, written by García Rodríguez de Montalvo.

In 1983, Xu died while serving as mayor of Chiayi, and Zhang Boya was elected as a non-party member of the Chiayi mayoral by-election, and was re-elected in 1985. In 1986, after the establishment of the Democratic Progressive Party, Zhang Boya did not join the Communist Party, but in his position is closer to the Communist Party. Zhang Boya built a memorial to the 28th Incident in Chiayi City, breaking the historical taboo of the Kuomintang government at the time; in 1989, Zhang Boya was elected as the last additional member of the Legislative Council, and ran with the Communist Party Zhang Junxiang as the deputy chairman of the Legislative Council, challenging the deputy chairman of the Kuomintang, Liang Suyong, who belongs to the senior public opinion representative, and the additional member of the Legislative Council, Liu Song-han. However, Zhang Boya was defeated by 161 votes to 29 votes. In 1990, when the former commander-in-chief of the Army and Chief of Staff of the Ministry of Defense, General Ho Baicun was appointed as the chairman of the Executive Council, Zhang Boya was appointed as the director of the Health Department of the Executive Council.

It was founded on January 1, 1946, and ceased publication in 1980. On New Year's Day, 1946, the Minsheng Daily was established in Taichung. The Minsheng Daily has a significant position in the history of baseball in Taiwan. The "Minsheng Cup Baseball Game" promoted by the founders Xu Cheng and Xu Jian was one of the first regular baseball games held in Taiwan. The first Minsheng Cup Baseball Game was held from May 22 to 27, 1951, at the Taichung Water Source Baseball Stadium (now the Taichung Baseball Stadium); at the invitation of the Minsheng Daily to make money and the Taichung area baseball community, the first time there were 21 baseball teams from all over the country. Since the first successful launch, the Minsheng Cup Baseball Game fixed in May each year at the Taichung Water Source Baseball Stadium has become a national baseball scene event, attracting a total of 20 softball and hardball teams each year.

In 1939, Sin entered the Communist Party of China. In the second year, he studied and worked in the Soviet Union. During the Soviet period, he wrote symphonies "National Liberation", "Holy War", orchestral ensemble "Manjiang Red", orchestral "Chinese Dream" and violin "Guo Jir Biday". He has written 35 papers, including "Neill: The Creator of Emerging Chinese Music" and "On the National Form of Chinese Music". He received the title "People's Musician" because of his exploration of the use of music as a revolution. In 1945, Sin died of tuberculosis in Moscow and was buried there. In the 1980s, his ashes were moved back to China, and he was finally buried in Guangzhou, where Sin's grave is located.

The M1903 rifle has a unique single-shot magazine blocker located on the left side of the receiver, which, in the case of a magazine block, requires a single round per round to be loaded from the barrel hole to maintain the ammunition in the magazine, and can be fired quickly from the magazine during normal use. Early M1903 rifles also featured a stick bayonet, which was replaced in 1905 by the M1905 knife bayonet, and a new sight with a retractable calibre. The M1903 rifle was initially fitted with a 0.30-03 round cartridge, and in 1906 the M1906 cartridge (7.62×63mm, or 0.30-06 cartridge), with the barrel shape changed to a point (150 grains), was based on the improvements of the Mauser barrelless cartridge.

Currently, the right whale is protected under international conventions, and many regions have replaced whaling activities for profit with whaling awards. The southern right whale has been restored to a stable population because of relatively little human activity in the region, and has been assessed as a threatened species by the World Conservation Union (IUCN). Over the years, scientists have expressed various views on the number of right whale species. Recent genetic evidence indicates that the right whale family should be divided into four species, and these species are generally classified into two genera. The true right whale family includes the following three species: Since John Edward Gray published his study in 1821, the bowhead whale has generally been considered to be a genus in its own right, while the other three right whales have been classified as true right whales, but there is little genetic evidence to support this view. Compared to the species differences in the beard whale family, the differences between the bowhead whale and other right whales are smaller.

In July 1987, it was upgraded to "Taiwan Provincial Hsinchu Normal College" and established five departments, including primary education, language education, mathematics education, social science education and labor education, and a two-year kindergarten teacher training program. In July 1991, it was transferred to the Ministry of Education to become "National Hsinchu Normal College." In August 2005, it was approved by the Executive Council to be renamed "National Hsinchu University of Education" as one of Taiwan's seven educational universities. After being reformed into an educational university, it was divided into Education College, Faculty of Science, and Faculty of Humanities, Social Sciences and the Arts. At the same time, in response to the shrinking demand for Taiwanese teachers, in addition to the education and learning science departments, children's education departments, and special education departments, the remaining departments have been transformed into general university structures, thereby enhancing the ability of other universities to compete.

Finally, he was released on August 21, 1961. In 1963, the ANC won the general election and became prime minister of an autonomous government, during which time he called for national reconciliation and the retention of white farmers. On December 12, the same year, Kenya declared independence, the following year became a republic, and he became president. On November 10, 1964, after the merger of the opposition parties, the ANC became the only political party in Kenya. In the land reforms after independence, the government occupied a large amount of land, became the largest landowner in Kenya, its tribal Kikuyu people also received many concessions, but these were criticized by him, his government's secret police were criticized. However, Kenya maintained good relations with neighboring countries of Milton Obote's Uganda and Julius Nyerere's Tanzania, the stable domestic and foreign situation led to the influx of foreigners, and the Kenyan economy grew steadily.

On August 1, 1988, it was upgraded to Private and Spring Technical College. In 1995, it was moved to the present Daliao District, Kaohsiung City. It has been analyzed that after independence, South Sudan suffered from ethnic violence, and experienced a civil war characterized by human rights violations, including a variety of massacres and conflicts. Between 2013 and February 22, 2020, the parties killed journalists and then competing and fighting leaders Salva Kiir Maillard and Rick Machar, reached an agreement of unity, formed a coalition government, South Sudan's population is mainly composed of Nigerians, is the youngest country in the world in population statistics, about half of whom are under the age of 18. As of 2019, South Sudan is ranked number one in the latest United Nations World Happiness Report, the 1820s Egypt began to rule northern Sudan and expanded to South Sudan, before South Sudan's history is almost unrecorded, and related information is almost entirely oral history. According to these records, the Niles migrated before the 10th century BC, becoming the earliest inhabitants there.

There are five known moons of Pluto: Pluto I, Pluto II, Pluto III, Pluto IV, and Pluto V. On July 14, 2015, the New Horizons spacecraft became the first spacecraft to fly past Pluto. In the 1840s, Obon Levier predicted the position of Neptune by analyzing the perturbations of its orbit using classical mechanics. In the late nineteenth century, astronomers speculated that other planets were disturbing its orbit based on observations of Neptune. In 1894, wealthy Bostonian Pacival Lowell founded the Lowell Observatory; in 1906, Lowell began a search for the possible ninth largest planet, Planet X. Lowell's widow, Constance Lowell, filed a ten-year lawsuit against the observatory for her husband's inheritance, and the search for Planet X did not resume until 1929. Tombo's mission was to systematically pair photographs of the night sky and analyze the changes in the position of objects in each pair.

An electrical machine is a device that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy or converts mechanical energy into electrical energy. The discipline of studying electrical machinery is called electrical machinery. An electrical machine converts electrical and mechanical energy in two directions, mostly using the principle of electromagnetic induction. An electrical machine that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy is usually referred to as an "electric generator"; an electrical machine that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy is referred to as an "electric motor". Other new types of electrical machinery have emerged, such as ultrasonic electrical machines (applying the piezoelectric effect) that do not use the principle of electromagnetic induction. However, a stationary electrical machine is a transformer that converts electrical energy at one voltage into electrical energy at another.

Its orbit has a high eccentricity, its perihelion is inside the orbit of Saturn, and its farthest point is just outside the perihelion of Uranus (although it has not yet reached the mean distance of Uranus). In modern times, its closest approach to Saturn was in May 720, with a period of just under 30 Gm; it has almost never approached Uranus, because it crosses the orbit of Uranus at a distance farther than the mean distance. Because it is the first asteroid to be discovered with such an orbit, and because its orbit is between exoplanets, it has attracted much interest. Because its perihelion is in the region controlled by Saturn, and its farthest point is in the region controlled by Uranus, it is called a SU object. In December 1988, when it was 12 AU from the Sun, its brightness increased by 75%.

During the First World War, the Russian Empire was militarily weakened, the political situation in Russia was unstable and the population became increasingly agitated. In the February Revolution of March (February), the revolutionaries overthrew the Romanov dynasty and established the Russian Provisional Government. Subsequently, in the October Revolution of November (October) of the same year, the Bolsheviks overthrew the new Provisional Government and established Soviet Russia, and in March 1918 signed the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk with the warring German Empire. After the October Revolution, the Russian Civil War broke out, with the White Army defending the old imperial or Provisional Government against the Soviet Red Army of Workers and Peasants, and other political factions, both non-Red and non-White, mobilizing.

These two provisions, together with the lack of support work, constitute major obstacles to the work of the Legislative Council. Members of the Legislative Council are permanent residents of the Macao Special Administrative Region, the majority of whom are elected. Each term of office is four years. The Legislative Council has a Chairman and a Vice-Chairman. The Chairman and Vice-Chairmen are elected by the members of the Legislative Council and are Chinese citizens of permanent residents of the Special Administrative Region who have normally resided in Macao for a continuous period of 15 years. In the absence of the Chairman, the Vice-Chairman acts as the Vice-Chairman. In the absence of the Chairman or Vice-Chairman, separate elections are held. The current seventh term of the Legislative Council, which runs from 2021 to 2025, consists of 33 members, of whom: Currently, the Legislative Council consists of 30 constitutional members, two members with a civil service background and one interim member. 14 members are directly elected, accounting for a total proportion of 42% (three out of seven). According to Annex II to the Basic Law of Macao, if there is a need to change the way in which the Legislative Council is formed in 2009 (from the fourth session) and thereafter, two-thirds of the members must be in favour, the Chief Executive must agree, and the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress must report the draft.

On the ideological level, the New Life Movement fuses Chinese traditional hierarchical ideas, nationalism, and elements of Christian values. This can be seen in the speeches and practices of Chiang Kai-shek in the process of initiating the New Life Movement. Chiang Kai-shek saw a child smoking cigarettes while on a tour, felt that the national life was bad, and the idea of initiating the New Life Movement arose. There are many accounts of Chiang Kai-shek's "anecdote," and this explains the starting point of the New Life Movement—from the basic daily life of the people, striving to achieve a comprehensive social revolution. Chiang emphasized that the basic requirement of the New Life Movement is a life revolution. The people should combine "Righteousness and Humility" into all aspects of daily "eating, dressing, and living." "Righteousness and Humility" (four dimensions) is the central idea of the New Life Movement. The New Life Movement wants to achieve, not only the appearance of cleanliness and observance of order, but "to reform society, to rebuild a country and a nation."1

According to the Standard Solar Model, stars similar to the Sun should gradually increase in brightness during the lifetime of the main sequence, due to the contraction of the star's core caused by nuclear fusion. At the time of Earth's initial formation, the atmosphere may contain more greenhouse gases than it does today. The concentration of carbon dioxide may be higher, because no bacteria and light cooperate to convert CO2 gas into organic carbon and gaseous oxygen, and its partial pressure is estimated to be as high as today's atmospheric pressure, 1,000 kPa (10 bar). Methane, a very active greenhouse gas, is estimated to have a mixing ratio of 10−4 (a volume ratio of 100 parts per million) in the atmosphere, and the phenomenon of reactions with oxygen producing carbon dioxide and water may also be very common. Based on geological studies of sulfur isotopes, a group of scientists, including Yuichiro Ueno of Tokyo Institute of Technology, in 2009 suggested that there were carbonyl sulfides (OCS) in the atmosphere of Archaea.

In 1933, the Japanese invaded the He River with the army of Manchuria, the provincial governor Yu Yu Yulin fled the war; afterwards, the Japanese attacked Shanhaiguan, the Great Wall and the He River, the National Government dispatched Song Zheyuan, Feng Shui, Zhang Jizhong, Liu Yuming, Guanlin Xiang, Huang Jie and Liu to guard the entrances of Jiinkou, Lengkou, Xifengkou, Gubeikou, Luowenyu, and Kailingkou and defended the Japanese army, but eventually withdrew due to poor armament, exhaustion of combat forces, and loss of strategic position. Wang Yicheng's northeastern army belonged to the army. Later, the Republic of China established the National Government Executive Council for the North-Ping Administrative Reorganization Committee, by Huang Yuan and Ho Okin signed a ceasefire agreement with the Japanese representative Meijin Meijiro, designated Jidong Province No. 22 as a non-armed zone, the army was not allowed to enter, and the Japanese army retreated north of the Great Wall, but in fact the Japanese army remained stationed under the name of "monitoring the Chinese army", preparing conditions for the Lugou Bridge Incident.

The latest Human Development Report is the Human Development Report 2020, released by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) on 15 December 2020, which is actually based on estimates of 2019 data. Non-United Nations members such as Taiwan, Macau, Kosovo, etc. are calculated separately. These countries or regions are also classified according to the Human Development Index, divided into four groups: extreme (0.8 and above), high (0.799 to 0.6), medium (0.699 to 0.550), and low (0.549 and below). In the 2018 report, only the first group of "extremely high" countries is likely to be developed (some "extremely high" countries are considered to be developing, such as Bahrain, Qatar, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Saudi Arabia, Malaysia, Kazakhstan, and some Eastern European countries, etc.), the remaining three groups are developing or undeveloped countries.

High-speed cache (/kæʃ/ KASH) Cache, originally referred to as RAM that is faster than normal random access memory (RAM), usually using expensive but faster SRAM technology than DRAM technology as the system's main memory. The term cache is derived from a 1967 paper in the journal Electronic Engineering. The authors gave the French word cache the meaning of "safekeeping storage", used in computer engineering. In the PC-AT/XT and 80286 eras, without cache, CPUs and memory were both slow, and the CPUs directly accessed memory. The 80386 chipset added support for optional cache, the high-end motherboard had 64KB, and even the high-end 128KB Write-Through Cache.

On October 12, 2007, the Guangzhou Municipal Transport Commission requested the three-car company, Jingbo Bus, and Baima Bus to co-invest in an empty shell company, consolidated as Guangzhou Third Bus Co., Ltd., to prohibit other foreign or privately owned bus companies from entering Guangzhou and suppress companies that did not use LPG as requested by the Commission, the coating of the bus body of the three-car company was uniformly requested to use the style of the original three-car company (on the basis of the original nearly all-green, the head and side of the bus body added a large amount of yellow), the head and tail markings were uniformly used the logo of the original three-car company, but the lettering was changed from "Guangzhou Three-car" to "Third Bus", but the front door outside the left, the driver's seat outside the window below and all facilities inside the vehicle still bear the real names of the companies, making it very easy for ordinary passengers to be confused.

Coal is believed to have been formed by the transformation of ancient plant remains buried underground from peat to lignite to secondary lignite to smoke to smokeless coal. Smokeless coal can also be further converted to graphite. According to the different classifications of the degree of carbonization, it can be divided into peat, lignite (brown coal, black coal), secondary lignite (sub-lignite), smoke (raw coal), smokeless coal, and sub-lignite (a type of lignite, which is a special classification in Japan). Smokeless coal has the highest degree of carbonization, and peat has the lowest degree of carbonization. According to the different classifications of the rock structure, it can be divided into candle coal, silk coal, dark coal, light coal and mirror coal. Mirror coal contains more than 95% of the mirror mass, the coal surface is bright, solid, mirror and mirror coal contains light coal, dark coal contains coarse particles, silk coal contains silk particles, and candle coal consists of microparticles formed by many small spores.

In physics, natural abundance (NA) refers to the abundance of naturally occurring chemical isotopes found on a planet. The abundance is usually expressed as a percentage. The abundance of man-made isotopes is zero. The atomic weights listed on the periodic table are actually the averages of the isotopes weighted by their molecular abundance, because the distribution of isotopes in nature is often relatively even and the averages are more accurate. The abundance of isotopes varies between planets, even from one place on Earth to another, but remains relatively constant over time (in the short term). For example, uranium has three naturally occurring isotopes: 238U, 235U, and 234U.

"Glory to the Brave People" (Spanish: Gloria al Bravo Pueblo) was declared the national anthem of Venezuela on May 25, 1881, by President Antonio Guzmán Blanco. Inspired by the spirit of liberty following the unprecedented Venezuelan War of Independence in 1810, the composer Juan José Landaeta composed the melody of the national anthem and the later doctor and journalist Vicente Salías wrote the lyrics. After several years of warfare, the Second Republic of Venezuela, founded by the "liberators" Bolivar and others, was conquered by the Royalist Party at the end of 1814, and the authors Salías and Landaeta, two advocates of the revolution, were executed by the Spanish colonists in the same year. Unlike "Epic Music of Latin America" (the national anthem of most Spanish-speaking American countries), the style and setting of the lyrics remind some of the French national anthem, so it is also called "La Marsellesa Venezolana".

In 1932, Wang Jinyu was dismissed from his post and assumed command by Hao Mengling. An accretion disk is a structure (usually a circumstellar disk) formed by diffuse matter moving in orbit around a massive central body; the central body is usually a star. When the disk spirals inward toward the central body, gravity and friction compress and raise the temperature of the object, resulting in the emission of electromagnetic radiation; the frequency range of the radiation depends on the mass of the central body. The accretion disks of young stars and protostars radiate in infrared wavebands; some neutron stars and black holes radiate in X-rays in the electromagnetic spectrum. The study of accretion disk oscillation patterns is called disk seismology. Accretion disks are a common phenomenon in astrophysics, and active galactic nuclei, protoplanetary disks, and gamma-ray bursts all involve accretion disks.

The Pacific Ocean is the largest of the five oceans on Earth, with an area of 181.3 billion square kilometres. It extends from the Arctic Ocean to the Southern Ocean, to the west of Asia, Oceania, and to the east of the Americas. It covers about 46% of the Earth's surface and about 32% of its total area, more than the sum of all the land areas on Earth. The equator divides the Pacific into the North Pacific and the South Pacific. The North faces the Bering Strait, and the South faces the boundary at 60 degrees south latitude. The Mariana Trench on the west side of the North Pacific is the deepest point on the Earth's surface. The trench's maximum depth is 10,911 meters (35,797 feet) below sea level. The name of the Pacific originates from the Latin Mare Pacificum, meaning "sea of stillness", named by the navigator Magellan.
