For those who criticize the apartheid government's "homeland" (Tuisland), this is a derogatory term. Today, when describing an area lacking any real legitimacy, the term "Bantustan" is often used to derogate, referring to the fact that it consists of several unrelated enclaves, or is unjustly divided by national or international boundaries. South Africa's four Bantustans - Transkei, Bophutatswana, Venda and Siskei (collectively known as the "Three States of Transkei") were declared independent, but this was not recognised outside South Africa. Other South African Bantustans (such as KwaZulu, Lebowa and Kuwakuwa) gained some autonomy, but never independence. In Western South Africa, Ovamboland, Kavangoland and East Caprivi gained the right to self-determination.

Max Theiler (January 30, 1899 – August 11, 1972) was a South African microbiologist who won the 1951 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of the yellow fever vaccine. Born on January 30, 1899 in Pretoria, the then capital of the Republic of South Africa, he was the son of Arnold Theiler, a British colonel and veterinary bacteriologist who had travelled extensively in South Africa.

Gustav Husák (10 January 1913 – 18 November 1991) was a Czechoslovak politician and a former General Secretary of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia. Born in Bratislava in 1913 to an unemployed working-class family, he attended the Faculty of Law of the University of Český Krumlov in Bratislava. He joined the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia in 1933 while still a student, and later participated in the underground anti-fascist struggle. During World War II, Husák was imprisoned for three years (1940-1943) by the Czechoslovak puppet government. He was released from prison in 1943. After 1945, he worked in the government. In 1950, he was accused of being a bourgeois nationalist and dismissed from his positions within and outside the party.

Military academies are institutions specialized in training military personnel for the armed forces. Military academies are formed by ordinary students or soldiers and officers in the armed forces who, after graduation, serve in the armed forces. Students in military academies participate in the study of professional knowledge and military training, and are subject to militarization. There are three types of academies: academic degrees awarded by institutions of first-class congress, university degrees awarded by institutions of first-class bachelor's degrees, and those of preparatory officers who undergo an examination to military rank. A naval academy is either a type of military academy (in the broad sense of the term) or a distinction (specific). In American usage, the United States Military academy and the United States Naval Academy are both military academies. The Royal Military College of Sandhurst, England, was founded in 1801 by John Le Marchant, and by the beginning of the century, under the impetus of the Napoleonic Wars and the subsequent pressure of the European armed forces, most fighting nations have established military academies specializing in training military officers.

It extends about 400 kilometres (250 mi) north along the Atlantic coast and about 500 kilometres (300 mi) east along South Africa's southern coast (South Indian Ocean). It borders North and East Cape in the north. West Cape has a total land area of 129,462 square kilometres (49,986 sq mi): 9, which accounts for about 10.6% of South Africa's total land area. It is roughly the size of England or Louisiana. Its capital and largest city is Cape Town, with some other major cities including Stellenbosch, Worcester, Paal and George. Garden Avenue and Overberg are popular coastal tourist destinations. West Cape is the southernmost region of the African continent, with the southernmost point being Cape Erie, just 3,800 kilometres from the Antarctic coastline.

The Mongolian People's Republic (1924-1992, Mongolian: ᠠᠠᠠᠠ ོ ᠠᠠ, Cyrillic: Бүгд Найрамдах Монгол Ард Улс, abbreviated: БНМАУ) was a socialist state in East Asia from 1924 to 1992, and the second socialist state in the world after the Soviet Union. In October 1911, the Xinhai Revolution broke out in China, the Qing Dynasty collapsed, at the instigation of the Russian Empire, on December 29, 1911, the princes of the Kalka Mongol (outer Mongolia) tribal kings introduced Tibetan Buddhist gurus Living Buddha Tebuson Dan Bahu Tuk Tu for the Mongolian Great Khan, ascended to the throne as "Erzhen Khan" (popularly known as "Bocta Khan"), declared independence from the Qing Dynasty, established a state of unity of religion and establishment of Great Mongolia.

The above formula is often called the mass equation. It can be used to derive the mass of any object in nature by combining a number of geometric relations. The equation is applicable to any object or substance in nature and is not affected by the state of matter. The mass equation has been widely applied in the quantitative analysis of many branches of physics, such as condensed matter physics, solid state physics, continuous medium mechanics, and fluid mechanics. The unit of density in the International System of Units is kg/m3, the other common units are g/cm3, and the common unit of density in engineering is t/m3. Density reflects a property of the substance itself, and can therefore be influenced by external factors. In general, the main physical quantities affecting the density of matter are pressure and temperature. The influence of pressure and temperature on the density of gases is more pronounced. Gases usually give only the density under standard conditions or at constant temperature, while density under other conditions can be calculated by the equation of the state of gases (such as the ideal gas state equation or the Van der Waals equation).

In October 2001, he launched the Afghan War to overthrow the Taliban regime and eliminate Al Qaeda, and in March 2003 he launched the Iraq War to overthrow the Saddam regime. In 2001, he led the effort to help China enter the World Trade Organization. After a fierce election campaign, the 2004 U.S. presidential election defeated Democratic Party candidate John Kerry, winning the general election and re-election. President Bush implemented $1.3 trillion in tax cuts, health insurance and social welfare reforms, as well as social conservative policies, such as banning late-term abortion legislation, and opposing federal bills to recognize same-sex marriage. At the same time, the Bush administration faced numerous criticisms over the legitimacy of the war on terror, the Guantanamo Bay detention center incident, the slaughter of prisoners, and the handling of Hurricane Katrina.

The station was opened on December 28, 2009. The station has four floors, the ground floor is the station entrances and exits, the periphery is the Ring City East Road, Gold Road, Construction Six-Mare Road, Garden Hotel, Baiyun Hotel and other buildings; the underground floor is the reserve space of the Ring City East Road Municipal Project; the underground floor is the station hall floor; the underground floor is the buffer and equipment floor; and the underground floor is the platform of Line 5. The station is colored yellow, corresponding to the station name Gold Station. To facilitate pedestrian entrance and exit, the station hall charging area is located on the east and west sides of the station hall, in the middle of the station hall there are multiple ticket machines, cloud ticket machines for passengers to sell tickets. Due to the layout of the station, the west side of the station hall charging area escalator and stairs can be directly accessed to the platform floor.

Today's Caribbean region consists of 22 island nations or territories, bordered by 12 continental countries. Due to its abundant sunshine, year-round warmth, wind-controlled climate, and many scenic attractions, the Caribbean became a popular tourist destination from the second half of the 20th century to the 21st century. The International Organization for the Survey of the Seas defines the Caribbean as follows: In addition, although Barbados is also on the same continental shelf, it is considered to be part of the Atlantic rather than the Caribbean Sea. Most of the Caribbean lies on the Caribbean Plate, separated from the Atlantic by several arcs of different ages. The youngest of these arcs extends from the northeastern corners of the Antilles, the Virgin Islands, Chile and Tobago to the northern coast of Venezuela. This arc is formed by the collision of the South American Plate with the Caribbean Plate, and has many active and dormant volcanoes on it, including Mount Perez, Mount Queer in the Dutch Caribbean region, and the Three Peaks of Dominica.

Phosphate (symbol: PO3−4) is a salt of phosphate, an important substance in inorganic chemistry, biochemistry and biogeochemical chemistry. A phosphate ion is a multi-atomic ion with the experimental formula PO43− and a molecular weight of 94.97. It contains one phosphorus atom and is surrounded by four oxygen atoms to form a tetrahedron. A phosphate ion has a 3-form charge and is a covalent base of the hydrogen phosphate ion (HPO42−); a hydrogen phosphate ion is a covalent base of the hydrogen phosphate ion (H2PO4−); and a hydrogen phosphate ion is a covalent base of the phosphate (H3PO4). It is a supervalent molecule (a phosphorus atom has 10 electrons in its electron layer). If phosphate is an organic phosphorus compound, it is called a phosphate ester, and its chemical formula is OP(OR)3.

Libra is the celestial sphere used by the Greek goddess of justice, Asterya, to judge between good and evil. Asterya holds the celestial sphere with one hand, and the sword to cut off evil with the other. For the sake of justice, she keeps her eyes closed. Once upon a time, the gods and mankind lived together in peace on the earth. Although God has eternal life, mankind's life is limited. Therefore, the lonely gods only created mankind constantly. However, the people struggled and did evil deeds, and the gods returned to heaven after the disappointment of mankind. Only the goddess Asterya refused to return and remained in the world, teaching mankind to do good. Nevertheless, mankind continued to fall, so war broke out, killing began. Eventually, Asterya gave up mankind and returned to heaven. And the sky rose above Libra, who loved justice and justice. Libra's stars have been recognized since ancient times, but Ptolemy did not consider them to be independent constellations.

Vertical wind shear prevented further intensification and weakening of the cyclone, which was downgraded to a tropical depression early on August 8, and dissipated shortly thereafter near Bermuda. Colin remained offshore from land, but generated large-scale offshore currents along the eastern coast of the United States, triggering at least 205 maritime rescue operations. Bermuda was largely unaffected, with winds below tropical storm strength and rainfall of less than 1 inch (25 mm). On July 28, 2010, a narrow wave moved westward from Nigeria and passed through Senegal. The wave continued westward, separating a low pressure trough with little movement. A few days later, another large wave left the west coast of Africa. On August 1, the two tropical waves merged to form a broad low pressure area about 1,210 kilometers (1210 mi) west-southwest of Cape Verde.

The 333rd Mechanized Infantry Brigade (Chinese: 333 Mechanized Infantry Brigade) is an army unit of the People's Republic of China stationed in Wanluan, Pingtung County, Taiwan, under the command of the Eighth Army Corps. The regiment's name, "Pu Guang" (Chinese: 埔光部隊), is derived from the name of the 333rd Mechanized Infantry Brigade (Chinese: 333 Mechanized Infantry Brigade), which was the second division of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) in the Continental period. The NRA's first division was destroyed in the Second Sino-Japanese Civil War, and was transferred to the second division that was withdrawn to Taiwan. The second division was also known as the "First Division of the World." The second division of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) during the Great Patriotic War, also known as the Changchun Division. After the Seventeenth Incident, it belonged to the 52nd Army of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA), and the Communist Party called the 52nd Army the sixth main force of the National Army. The shield represents the 333rd Mechanized Infantry Brigade (Chinese: 333 Mechanized Infantry Brigade). The square represents thirty-five provinces and a special administrative region.

Licheng Subdistrict is a subdistrict under the jurisdiction of Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province, China. Formerly known as Licheng Town, it was established in 2004 and is the seat of the government of Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province. It has a population of 170,000, a permanent population of 155,000 and a total area of 149.71 square kilometers. As of July 2019, Licheng Subdistrict is under the administrative jurisdiction of seven village committees, including Luogang, Meijiang, Guangming, Taiping, Wuyi, Xiguanling, Sanlian and Yanta Community Housing Committees, and the area of Yanta Community Housing Committee. Licheng Subdistrict is now under the jurisdiction of seventeen village committees, including Tong Xia, Qingdong, Mutan, Long Kok, Litang, Gun Ai, Qiaotou, Tong Village, Liao Quatang, Liao Village, Qian Zhao, Jiang Village, Xinlian, Qingfeng, Chengfeng, Xiajie, Jinxing, and 16 community housing committees, including Fupeng, Jinxiu, Shayuan, Baohua, Kaiyuan, Huafeng, Lixing, Jinchiu, Xiyuan, Hang Green, Jihai Mei, Xiangjiang, Phoenix, Wan Cui, Xingfa and Lijiang Rivers.

Ye Chu (Chinese: 葉楚; October 14, 1887 – February 15, 1946) was a Chinese politician, Nansha poet, journalist, writer, and educator. He was born on October 14, 1887 in Zhouzhuang Town, Wu County, Jiangsu Province. His great-grandfather, Ye Qingjiang, was a government official, and his great-grandfather, Ye Houfu, opened a soy sauce garden in his hometown. His father's poor management led to a worsening of the business. In 1898, his mother died early, and after his father's re-marriage, he and his sister were taken care of by his aunt. In 1902, he participated in the provincial and provincial examinations, but due to the beginning of the educational reform, he abandoned the examination. In 1903, he was admitted to Shanghai Nanyang Normal School, and transferred to Nanyang's Xixi Normal School for only one semester.

Ariel (/ˈɛəriəl/) is a moon of Uranus, discovered by William Lassell on October 24, 1851, together with Ariel II. The name comes from the Elves of Ariel in the poem The Rape of the Lock by the British poet Alexander Pope. It is also the name of the Elves in William Shakespeare's The Tempest. Both Ariel I and the four known moons were named by commission of John Herschel. Lassell had previously praised the concept of naming Saturn's seven moons adopted by John Herschel in 1847, and Saturn Eight, discovered in 1848, was named in accordance with this rule.

Communist Party of China Executive Agency of the People's Republic of China: People's Liberation Army People's Armed Police Force Chinese People's Police Force Hardliners: Liberals: Students Leaders: Workers Leaders: Intellectuals: The 64th Incident, also known as the 89th Students' Movement or the 89th Students' Movement, is a general term for a nationwide demonstration that began in mid-April 1989 in memory of Hu Yaobang, initiated by students of Chinese mainland universities in Tiananmen Square in Beijing and lasted for nearly two months.The 64th Incident is a turning point in the history of the People's Republic of China, its eruption marked the failure of the late political system reform promoted by Deng Xiaoping and others in the mainland since the reform and opening, the resignation of Zhao Ziyang, Bo Tong and other high-level moderates of the Communist Party of China, and Hu Yaobang had resigned as General Secretary of the Communist Party of China in the 86th school tide, so that the liberalization reform promoted to varying degrees in the 1980s also stopped, after which the officials approved only a small number of demonstrations.

Established in 1934, Deming Secondary School is one of the most famous schools in Hong Kong. After the transfer of power from the mainland to Taiwan, General Chen Zitang came to Taiwan from Hainan, still wanted to establish an educational project in Taiwan, so he searched for a school site, but he was ill and died in 1954, so the establishment of the school was suspended. Meanwhile, Deming Secondary School in Hong Kong continued to operate until the beginning of 1986. In 1962, Chen Zitang's daughter Ms. Chen Baoxin came to Taiwan for the first time, decided to inherit his father's wish to establish a school in Taiwan. The following year, Ms. Chen Baoxin visited Taiwan again to investigate the school site, selected Lake Nai as the place to establish the school, originally wanted to apply for the secondary school; considering the needs of the times, decided to establish a "specialized school".

The Supreme People's Court is the supreme people's court of the People's Republic of China, and the lower-level court is the middle-level people's court.According to the Organization Law of the People's Court, a high-level people's court is established in provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities directly under the Central Government and consists of one president, a deputy president, a presiding judge, a deputy presiding judge and a number of judges.According to the "Reply of the Ministry of Organization of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on the Appointment and Removal of the Presidents of the Higher People's Courts of the Provinces, Municipalities and Autonomous Regions and the Procurators of the People's Procuratorates by Category A Functions" (No. 652 [80]), and the "Notice of the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Strengthening the Staffing of Local Courts and Procuratorates at All Levels" (No. 47 [1985]), the administrative level of the presidents of the high-level people's courts is allocated to the sub-provincial level.

In April 1927, the Central Inspection Committee of the Nationalist Party of China convened in Shanghai, proposed that the Communist Party members in the Nationalist Party, under the direction of the Third International, attempted to overthrow the Nationalist Party, sabotage the National Revolution, demanded the elimination of the Communist Party members in the Nationalist Party, immediately passed the "Qing Party Principles," established the "Qing Party Committee," carried out an all-out anti-Qing Party, and cleared the Communists, which was the 42nd incident. On July 15, 1927, Wuhan Wang Zhaoming government learned that Soviet adviser Borotin wanted to divide the Nationalist Government in order to help the Chinese Communist Party seize the power of Wuhan government, and decided to peacefully divide the Communist Party. In Wuhan, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (chaired by Qu Qiu Bai), on the recommendation of those in charge of Jiujiang Jiangxi's central committee, comrades Li Li, Tang Zhongxia, Tan Pingshan, etc., decided to launch an armed uprising in Nanchang, Jiangxi.

Legend has it that the last (fourth) voyage of Columbus to the New World in 1502, when the fleet encountered a storm, ended with his exclamation:¡Gracias a Dios que salimos de estas honduras!("Thank God, we have finally come out of this deep and unpredictable water!"). Cape of Good Hope (and later the province of Good Hope), the province of Columbus and "Honduras" are believed to have been named after it. However, the legend has since become legendary. The name "Honduras" has never appeared in Columbus' writings or in the abstract. According to Reclus, it was named after Bartholomew de Las Casas, but Rolando Serraya and Ferreira state that the first people to use the name "Honduras" were probably Juan Díaz de Soares and Vicente Añas Pinzón, who decided in 1508 to explore the area on their own.

Established in 1989, National Chungcheng University is a national university located in Minxiang, Chiayi County, Taiwan. Chungcheng University is a member of the Taiwan Comprehensive University System. It has seven faculties: Arts, Sciences, Social Sciences, Engineering, Management, Law, and Education. The research in engineering and general social sciences is ranked in the top 1% of the ESI Basic Science Index, and the research in chemistry, computer science, and materials sciences is also well-performing. Designed in 1989 by Professor Su Maosheng of National Taiwan Normal University, the design is divided into two parts, the center is a two-character graphic of "Chongcheng," surrounded by five steel pens representing the five faculties of Arts, Sciences, Social Sciences, Engineering, and Administration at the time of the establishment of the university, and hopes that the five faculties will work together to achieve the ideal of Chungcheng University taking into account the humanities, social sciences, and science and technology, and a comprehensive university.

In 1673 he became a French citizen and changed his French name to Jean-Dominique Cassini, also known as Cassini Ier (his great-grandson also known as Cassini II). Cassini is believed to have discovered the Great Red Spot at the same time as Huck (1665). Cassini was the first to discover Saturn's four moons (Eighth, Fifth, Fourth, and Third). In 1690, he observed Jupiter's atmosphere and discovered that Jupiter's equator rotated twice as fast as it did, thereby discovering that Jupiter's rotation was distorted. In 1675, he discovered a dark gap in the middle of Saturn's light ring, which was later named after him. He speculated that the ring was composed of countless small particles. Spectroscopic observations more than two centuries later confirmed his conjecture. From 1671 to 1679, he carefully observed the surface features of the Moon, and in 1679 he sent a large moon map to the French Royal Academy of Sciences. No one had ever surpassed him in this respect in more than a century.

Sagittarius is a faint but unique northern constellation, originally named "Sagitta" in Latin, meaning arrow. Sagittarius belongs to the 48 constellations listed by the 2nd century astronomer Claudius Ptolemy, as well as the 88 modern constellations defined by the International Astronomical Union. Sagittarius has a long history, but all stars do not exceed the third magnitude, and the area is the third of the 88 constellations. Left-handed flag 5 of 3.47 magnitude is the brightest star in Sagittarius, with a mass of about 90% of the Sun, but has entered the ageing red giant period, 54 times the diameter of the Sun. Left-handed flag 3, Left-handed flag 1, Left-handed flag 4 and Sagittarius θ are stellar systems, the internal composition of which can be seen with small telescopes. Sagittarius V is a cataclysmic variable star, a binary system in which white dwarfs accumulate and contribute to the formation of stars, is expected to develop into a new star around 2083 and briefly become the brightest star in the Milky Way, and is also a very bright object in the sky.

In June 1949, the government moved to Dapeng Bay Base in Donggang Township, Pingtung County, Taiwan, and continued to implement education until May 28, 1951, when the school was closed after the completion of the sixth grade. In 1957, the former headmaster of the Air Force Junior School, Mr. Chen Jia-shang, was promoted to the rank of Commander-in-Chief of the Air Force, submitted a report to the then President Chiang Kai-shek and was granted permission, and instructed the then headmaster of the Air Force Junior School, Mr. Liu Cheng, to plan for the reopening of the Air Force Junior School. On September 1, 1958, the reopening of Dapeng Bay in Donggang Township, Pingtung County, began to admit junior high school graduates, the establishment of the seventh grade of the Air Force Junior School (the 46th grade of the Air Force Academy). On February 1, 1961, the school was renamed the Air Force Junior School. In 1978, the 24th grade (the 63rd grade of the Air Force Academy) after graduation, it was incorporated into the National Guard Senior Reserve School. In 1975, after the President Chiang Kai-shek presided over the 22nd National Defense Conference, the above-mentioned three schools were merged into the National Guard Senior Reserve School, to provide additional training for political operations reserve students.

Progressive Web Apps (PWA) are web applications that are typically web-based or web-structured, but that can be presented to users in the form of traditional applications or native mobile applications. This application morphology view combines the functionality provided by the most modern browsers with the experience advantages of mobile devices. Since 2005, web development has been upgraded from static form to server-side technologies (such as PHP, ASP.NET, etc.) and client-side tools (such as Ajax). At the time, some web-based applications (such as the iPhone launched in 2007) were unsuccessful in competing with native applications.

Prey is the target of any hunting activity, generally referring to animals that are hunted in nature by predators that are higher up the food chain. Prey is usually herbivorous, but some meat-eating or omnivorous animals may also be hunted by larger, stronger, and more ferocious animals than themselves. In human hunting, game orquarry is the target of hunters' choice. Human hunters usually hunt prey for meat (so-called game and jungle meat), economically valuable animal products (such as leather, fur, feathers, bones, horns, tusks, oils, special secretions, etc.), or purely for recreational purposes and for collecting trophies (such as skeletons or skinned specimens). The types and ranges of animals that are permitted and more popular with hunters vary from one region of the world to another.

Assassination or assassination conspiracy refers to murder committed for a number of reasons, often political; the person who commits the assassination is called the assassin, killer or assassin. Some terrorist organizations (first the medieval Assadists, later the modern Irish Newfoundland Party, the Italian Coal Party, the Russian Popular Party and the Chinese Axe Gang, etc.) often plot to assassinate heads of state or important leaders. Similarly, many national intelligence agencies or secret police have trained members to carry out secret assassination operations, such as the CIA in the United States, the KGB in the Soviet Union, the MI6 in the United Kingdom, the Israeli intelligence intelligence agency (Mossad, Mossad), the Ministry of Security of the People's Republic of China (MSS) and the National Security Bureau (NSB) of the Republic of China, etc., in order to assassinate high-ranking leaders of enemy states or terrorist organizations and dissidents.

Pakistan is one of the recognized nuclear-weapon states and has not acceded to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Pakistan (Pakistan) is actually an English name, composed of different parts of the geographical name. On January 28, 1933, the soul of Pakistani nationalism, Jodouri Lakhmat Ali, coined the word “Pakstan” in his essay “Now or Never; Are We to Live or Perish Forever?” (also known as the “Pakistan Declaration”) in Cambridge, England. Coincidentally, in Persian and Urdu, “Pakistan” literally means “the Holy Land”. Around 3,000 BC, the Harappan culture originated in present-day Pakistan, where Harappa and Mohenzo-Daro were built.

In April 1929, Longyun led Zhu Xu, Zhang Fengchun Division together with the 43rd Army of Li Shang formed the Yunnan-Guangzhou Joint Army, launched the war against the 25th Army. Zhou Xicheng was wounded and drowned. But the 25th Army destroyed the 43rd Army in a single move. After the war, the 3rd Division commander Mao Guangxiang succeeded as the commander of the army. After the control of Guizhou, the 25th Army headquartered in 1934, the Red Army commander conquered Guizhou. In March 1935, Xue Yue, Wu Qiwei and Wu Qiwei entered Guiyang. Subsequently, Chiang Kai-shek went to Guizhou, purchased the royal commanders Baihui Zhang and He Chizhi, forced the fall of the imperial army. In May 1935, the Guizhou army was reorganized according to the order of the Central Army Number; its predecessor was the 2nd mixed brigade of Hubei, Xia Duan Division. In 1926, it was reorganized as the 1st Division of the O Army, commander Xia Duan Division. Xia Duan was famous in China's modern history because of the defeat of Ye Ting Division in the rebellion against the Wuhan National Government. In June 1927, it was expanded to the 10th Army of the National Revolutionary Army, commander general, chief of staff Zhu Huai-bing.

Lieutenant (Chinese: 中尉) is the rank of a military officer, a lieutenant officer, ranked between a lieutenant and a captain. The use of the word "lieutenant" in Chinese dates back to the military rank system established by the provisional government of Nanjing in the early years of the People's Republic. In English, a lieutenant in the Army, Air Force, Marine Corps is called a Lieutenant or First Lieutenant, a U.S. Navy lieutenant is called a Lieutenant Junior Grade, a British Royal Navy lieutenant is called a Sub-Lieutenant, and a British Royal Air Force lieutenant is called a Flying Officer.

The International Tribunal for the Prosecution of Persons Responsible for Serious Violations of International Humanitarian Law Committed in the Territory of the Former Yugoslavia since 1991, also known as the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTY), is an international criminal tribunal established by the United Nations.

The most important mechanism in stars is that pure radiation in some stars can be converted into pulsating energy in the surface layer. The resulting pulsations are often studied under the hypothesis of small pulsations and isolated sphere symmetries. In binary systems, stellar tidal forces also have a significant effect on stellar oscillations. One application of stellar seismology is the study of neutron stars. The internal structure of neutron stars cannot be directly observed, but may be inferred from the study of neutron-star oscillation. Seismic waves in Sun-like stars can be divided into three different forms: in Sun-like stars, such as South Gate II, the p-mode is the most prominent state, while the g-mode is confined to the internal convection zone. However, only the g-mode can be observed on white dwarfs. Helioseismology (or Solar seismology) is closely related to stellar seismology, but is specialized in the study of seismic waves in the Sun.

In this context, the term "Middle America" is used to describe Central America. "Middle America" is more commonly used as a cultural term, rather than a geographical one. Culturally, "Middle America" can refer to small towns or suburbs populated primarily by middle-class, Protestant, and white residents. As a result, the term is often caricatured to depict the United States of the 1950s. "Middle America" generally does not include areas such as Chicago (the third largest city in the United States, and one of the top ten cities in the world) or the extremely wealthy Aspen. However, coastal areas of the southern United States are also commonly included in "Middle America." Furthermore, the concept of "Middle America" as defined by the United States is easily confused with Central or Central America.

According to statistics, from 1945 to 1950, nearly two million soldiers and civilians from all over mainland China moved to Taiwan. In order to solve the housing problems caused by the rapid increase in population, the National Government began to build houses or arrange for the remaining Japanese to live in dormitories, and gathered the new residents according to military type, occupation, characteristics, etc., in a certain area, which is now known as "family villages." After the 1990s, due to various social factors such as the mixing and age structure of the old and the newly rebuilt family villages, Taiwan's proportion of the population living in family villages in foreign provinces rapidly decreased. Generally defined family villages refer to the family houses in which the Army, Navy and Air Force, the Constitutional Guard and other types of officers and their families live, and do not include the family houses built by the Government of the Republic of China for teachers, police, civil servants, public servants, and the Central People's Representative (the representative of the National Assembly, the Legislative Council, etc.).

In 2005, the original Lai Wan District was roughly composed of three parts: Saiguan, Lai Chi Wan, and West Village. Saiguan is outside the West Wall of the provincial city. These three areas were under the jurisdiction of Nankai County before the National Decade (1921). Saiguan's area is roughly outside the West Wall Taiping Gate (now People's Road), south to the west mouth of the Pearl River, north to the vicinity of Dai-Tsu, east to People's Road, west, south to the Pearl River (south to Shamen Island). From Dai-Tsu to Taiping Gate, etc., the area is called Upper Saiguan; from Guangfu Central Road west to Huangsha, Huaqi Road is called Lower Saiguan. Lai Chi Wan refers to the area from outside of Saiguan to the Pearl River, i.e. the present-day Dopo Road, Longjin Road, Pantang to Zhongshan Eight Road, Lai Wan Road, etc. West Village refers to the area on the northwest side of Saiguan and Lai Chi Wan. According to Huang Fuyi's "Guangzhou City Gazette" Volume 5, it is described: "Outside the western outskirts of Yoseong City, the name of the West Garden is commonly known as Saiguan.

Sun Yat-sen went to Beijiang on June 27, and the next day launched a full-scale offensive to defeat the Shen Army. On May 9, Chen Jiangming's remnants again rebelled in Dongjiang, and the main camp fought a series of hard and fierce military battles to eliminate this threat, in the face of severe financial difficulties and the weakness of military forces. Finally, in 1925, Chen's army vanished across the borders of Gansu and Min. The supreme leader of the main camp of the Grand Marshal of the Republic of China Army and Navy was the Prime Minister of the Kuomintang, Sun Yat-sen. Sun Yat-sen implemented the party constitutional system, a one-party controlled government of the Kuomintang. It had a secretariat, the Joint Military Office, the Legal Affairs Bureau, the Audit Bureau, the Accounting Division, the General Services Division, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Military Affairs, the Ministry of Construction, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Navy, the Staff Department and the Imperial Court. During this period, Guangzhou was controlled by the Gui army of Liu Zhenhua, the Yunnan army of Yang Xiimin and the Xiang army of Tan Yanxiang.

During the Xinhai Revolution, he joined the Revolutionary Party, and after the restoration of Chang Shaguang, the revolutionary governor of Hunan, Jiao Dafeng, was killed by Mei Kaolin. Subsequently, Tan was appointed as the military governor of Hunan and the chairman of the Hunan Senate, the third governor of Hunan. In 1912, he joined the Nationalist Party, and became the head of the Hunan Party branch. In 1913, he remained neutral during the Second Revolution, was dismissed by Yuan Shikai, sentenced to four years. Yuan Shikai pardoned Tan Yanxiang, but did not allow him to return to his homeland; Tan had to spend his exile in Qingdao and Shanghai: 9. Yuan Shikai died of illness in June 1916, Tan was reappointed as the head of Hunan and commander-in-chief of the Hunan army in August. In 1917, Zhang Hong launched the Restoration Period (May 13, 1917, i.e. July 1, 1917), Tan was granted the protection of Hunan by Sun Qing's court, and with Zhang Hong's failure, the title was changed to Governor of Hunan army. Tan tried to reduce the army by half, set up industry and education, and as a result, Hunan was again weakened during the War of Law Defense:11.

The former is suitable for left-handed pistols to prevent the leakage of ammunition from the front of the revolver and to reduce the leakage of gunpowder gas during firing, the latter is mainly for automatic pistols to be easily removed from the casing. In principle, the left-handed can be used without a rim or a semi- rim, but requires a clip to prevent the leakage from the front. Semi-automatic pistols are usually not suitable for a rim, with a few exceptions such as Desert Eagle or Smith & Wesson Model 52. There are also a few bottle-shaped rounds similar in appearance to rifle bullets, designed to fire high-first-rate specialty pistol bullets, suitable for certain high-powered (e.g. "Magnum") pistols or personal defense weapons. From a structural classification, the most common modern pistols are classified into four categories: revolvers, semi-automatic pistols, single-shot pistols, multi-barrel pistols, and the former two account for the vast majority.

A duty may derive from religious, ethical, social relations, or legal provisions. This term is derived from the English word duty. It originated in Latin: debere ordebitum, which originally meant debt, and became the past participle due in ancient French devoir. It evolved into medieval English duete, which ultimately became English noun, meaning debt owed, and should be done. Similar nouns include obligation, liability, etc. The Chinese translation of the word duty originated from Ding Liang's translation of the Universal Public Law, which used the words rights and obligations. This translation, which spread to Japan, influenced Western Zhou and the jurist Minsaku Linxiang (Japanese: Minsaku Linxiang), and Minsaku Linxiang's writings, in turn, influenced China.

The urea cycle, also known as the ornithine cycle, is a biochemical reaction in many mammals in which ammonia (NH3) produces urea (NH2)2CO. The urea cycle converts highly toxic ammonia into urea excretion. This is the first known metabolic cycle (discovered by Hans Krebs and Kurt Henseleit in 1932), five years earlier than the discovery of the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Urea cycling was first proposed in 1932 by Hans Adolf Krebs et al. through in vitro studies of rat liver sections. Later perfected by Wrightner et al. In mammals, the urea cycle occurs primarily in the liver, with a small range occurring in the kidney.

Coordinates: 23°1′59′′N 116°17′42′′E / 23.03306°N 116.29500°E / 23.03306; 116.29500Huilai County is a county in eastern Guangdong Province, China, under the jurisdiction of the city of Jieyang. The total land area of the county is 1048.7 square kilometers, the sea area is 7689 square kilometers, the coastline length is about 82 kilometers, is the only maritime transportation gateway of Jieyang City. The total population of the county is 114 million, of which the Han population accounts for about 99%. Postal code is 515200. The county people's government is located in the town of Huihai.

Reservoirs refer to artificial freshwater bodies, larger ones are called artificial lakes, and smaller ones are called reservoirs, dams or reservoirs. Most reservoirs are built inland, usually by building dams in the upper middle of rivers and flooding the valleys after the rivers are blocked. However, there are also reservoirs built offshore, such as in Hong Kong's Funan Freshwater Lake. Dams are generally built in narrow valleys, as the slopes on both sides of the river can serve as natural fences for the reservoirs, and the working life of the dams can be greatly shortened. Facilities and buildings such as dwellings and monuments in flooded areas, railway roads, etc., need to be moved elsewhere before they can be built. Water storage, irrigation, power generation, and flood control are the main purposes of most reservoirs, while aquaculture and tourism are often subsidiary functions. Some reservoirs are built to ensure water quality rather than to provide aquaculture and tourism, such as the Jade Reservoir.

On August 26, 1936, the National Revolutionary Army replenished the 1st Brigade ( Brigadier General Wang Yaowu, founded in January 1934, the three regiments under its jurisdiction were three new regiments for recruiting new soldiers for the Baoding Training Office, all cadres at all levels were from Huangpu, the regiment was the fourth phase of Huangpu, the battalion was the sixth phase of Huangpu) after the recruitment of one regiment, the number was changed to the new 11th Division, the number of the new 11th Division was subsequently revoked, the 51st Division number was opened, the original plan was to use the three regiments of infantry divisions composed of the 21st Division, the 301st, 302nd and 306th Divisions, the special battalions directly under the division, the heavy battalions, the communication battalions, the engineer battalions, the artillery platoons and the health companies. In 1937, the 51st Division was included in the third battalion of the "Adjustment Division" for re-equipment and reorganization.

In December 1941, U.S. President Harry S. Truman proposed to the foreign ministers of China, France, the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, and the United States that they should "agree on a peace treaty and a solution to the borders of European countries." This led to the establishment of the Council of Foreign Ministers. The Republic of China, as the representative of China at the time, was also a member of the Allies in World War II, and its territory was also one of the main battlefields in the war against Japan. Since the Lumizu Bridge Incident in 1937, Chiang Kai-shek, the Chairman of the Military Committee of the National Government of the Republic of China, issued a "Declaration of the General Staff of the People's Republic of China" on July 31, 1941, declaring a full-scale war against Japan. Before the outbreak of the Pacific War in 1941, China fought alone in Asia.

Since the end of 2005, ESO has been working with and using the community of European astronomers and astrophysicists to define this new polymorphic telescope. The ESO Observatory has made many important astronomical discoveries and catalogues of objects. Recent research results include the discovery of the most distant gamma-ray burst and evidence of black holes in the center of our galaxy, the Milky Way. In 2004, the Very Large Telescope provided astronomers with excellent images of the first brown dwarf orbiting an extrasolar planet, 2M1207b, 173 light-years away. An instrument mounted on another ESO telescope, the high-precision radial velocity planet finder, has found many extrasolar planets, including the smallest extrasolar planet to date, Gliese 581c. The Very Large Telescope has also discovered the candidate, Abel 1835 IR1916, the furthest distant galaxy from mankind to date.

Deng Yingchao was born on February 4, 1904, in the Zhentai official residence on the northern bank of Yongjiang River in Nanning, Guangxi, in the Qing Dynasty. At the time of his birth, he was known as "Dong Yu Ai" and studied under the name of "Wen Shu." Deng Yingchao's father, Deng Tingzhong, was a military officer, Jiao Jingxiong. He was born in 1861, originally in Zhengguan, Guangshan County, Henan Province, to Emperor Wu Hanlin. He was appointed Vice-Admiral of the Imperial Guard (a high-level guard directly administered by the emperor), and later was appointed Vice-Admiral of Guangxi Zhao Jiang Nanning. He went to Vietnam to participate in the war against France, and after the Eight-nation military alliance was launched, he was ordered to go to Beijing to guard Jixii and Guangxi Xian. After returning to Beijing in 1902, he was promoted to Guangxi Nanning Zhentai, and became a senior military officer of the Green Battalion, ranked second only to the Vice-Admiral. His mother, Yang Zhende, was from Changsha, Hunan Province, a member of the eunuch family, studied Chinese medicine from a young age, and made progress in thought.

During the Southern Song Dynasty, Haikou Pu, which includes today's Haidian Street and Haikou Old Town, gradually replaced Bai Sha Tsun and became one of the main ports for sea crossings and the import and export of goods from Hainan. In 1271, the Yuan Dynasty set up a barracks; in 1368, the Ming Dynasty set up a guard post for 1,000 households; in 1395, the Ming Dynasty began to build a city; in accordance with the military system, Haikou Pu was rebuilt as a mansion (called "Haigudokoro" or "Haigu Ward"); the area of Desheng Sha Road in present-day Haikou City is said to have been known as "Desheng Sha" in ancient times. In 1849, Doguang was captured by foreign invaders, and after fierce fighting, the foreign invaders finally conquered Desheng Sha in Desheng Sha. During the Qing Dynasty, it became a port of foreign trade under the terms of the Treaty of Tianjin, and Japan established a consulate in Joongju in 1873; in 1875, the Qing Dynasty set up the Haikou Customs, and foreign trade began to form and develop.

Italy and Germany each won four titles, Uruguay, Argentina and France each won two. England won one title at their home games and Spain won the first World Cup at their home games in South Africa. The first international football match in the world took place in 1872 in Glasgow, Scotland, between the Scottish national team and the English national team. At that time, the sport was almost non-existent outside the United Kingdom. At the end of the 19th century, football was introduced to South America. In 1901, the first official international match outside the United Kingdom (including Ireland) took place in the Uruguayan capital, Montevideo, between Uruguay and Argentina. Between the 19th and 20th centuries, football became increasingly popular throughout the world, and the Olympic Games introduced football, with performances being included in 1900, 1904 and the Inter-Olympic Games (no medals won); in 1908, football became an official Olympic sport.

The National Taiwan University of Marine Science and Technology (Taiwan: 国立臺灣海洋大学, 海洋大学, 臺灣海大, 基隆海大 or 海大) is a national university specializing in marine science, located in Keelung City, Taiwan. It was established in 1953 as the Taiwan Provincial School of Marine Science and Technology. It is a member of Taipei United University System as a university specializing in marine science. The National Taiwan University of Marine Science and Technology focuses on marine science, shipping, marine law, aquaculture, aquatic engineering, marine biology, fisheries science, food science, shipbuilding engineering, motor engineering, navigation, marine science, marine engineering and navigation technology and all marine related fields. It currently has seven colleges, including the College of Marine and Management, the College of Life Sciences, the College of Engineering, the College of Marine Science and Resources, the College of Electrical Information, the College of Humanities and Social Sciences, and the College of Ocean Law and Policy. The National Taiwan University of Marine Science and Technology has 15 departments, 11 independent institutes, 26 master's courses, 19 doctoral courses, and Keelung Higher Secondary School of Marine Science.

Ionization, or freezing, ionization, or ionization, refers to the process by which atoms or molecules, under (physical) energy action, produce free ions in aqueous solution or molten state. Ionization can be roughly divided into two types: sequential ionization and nonsequential ionization. In classical physics, only sequential ionization can occur. Non sequential ionization violates a number of laws of physics, and belongs to quantum ionization. For example: it applies only to classical physics and the Bohr model, making the ionization of atoms and molecules completely certain, i.e. every problem always has a clear and computable answer.

In the summer of 1915, the Chinese Revolutionary Party formed the "Chinese Revolutionary Army", secretly ordered Chen Qimei to organize the Southeast Army in Shanghai, moved to Qingdao to organize the Northeast Army, Hu Hanmin returned to Guangzhou to organize the Southwest Army, and in his right-hand office went to Shaanxi Province to organize the Northwest Army, four headquarters, and dispatched party members to the provincial movement armies and the Party.From 1914 to 1916, the Chinese Revolutionary Party staged a series of armed uprisings, among which the most famous were: in October 1914, the Guangdong Partyman Zhong Ming Guang plotted to assassinate the Guanghui garrison commander Long Kuan Guang; in November, Hong Zhonglin gathered 2,000 troops in Guangdong Huizhou against Yuan; Zhu Jianxin led more than 1,000 men in Shunde to attack Foshan.

In the years between the founding of the People's Republic of China and the promulgation of the Constitution, the People's Republic of China adopted a unicameral system under the Common Program of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), in which the CPPC exercised the functions and powers of the highest organ of state power, the Central People's Government Committee exercised the functions and powers of the permanent organ of the highest organ of state, and the functions and powers concentrated in one body. By 1954, when the first session of the First National People's Congress was convened in Beijing, the NPC became the first statutory congress in the history of the People's Republic of China. In the Constitution adopted by the First National People's Congress, the structure of the NPC inherited the framework of the CPPCC Charter and the Common Program of the CPPC, and also borrowed from the form of the National Assembly in the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union and the Five Powers Constitution of Sun Yat-sen, i.e., it formed a National People's Congress of up to thousands of people and produced a permanent organ to undertake work in peacetime.

Google Books is a search tool developed by Google that allows you to search for data from Google's scanned, optical character identification (OCR) stored digital database. The service was launched at the Frankfurt Book Fair in October 2004, and is called Google Print. When you use it, the Google Books search results index appears above Google's web search service. You can also search for books in Google Books. Clicking on Google Books search results index opens the page, users can view the pages in the book and content-related advertisements, link to publishers' websites and bookstores. Google restricts the number of visits to the website to prevent books from being printed and protects the reproduction rights of text content, and tracks user usage records as a basis for various access restrictions and safeguards.

After the Wuchang Uprising, on January 3, 1912, Liu Xianxiang joined forces with some foreign envoys and sent a telegram to the Qing emperor to ask him to abdicate. When the Republic of China was founded in 1912, President Yuan Shikai sent a telegram to the emperor to request him to resign from the post of Foreign Minister. After returning to China from the post of Foreign Minister in Russia, Yuan Shikai promoted the reform of China's modern diplomatic institutions and changed the "Foreign Ministry" to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the Qing Dynasty. He became Prime Minister in June, resigned in September. He was appointed to the post of Foreign Minister in Switzerland at the end of 1912, returned to China at the end of 1914. He was reappointed Foreign Minister in early 1915, and negotiated Article 21 with Japan with Deputy Foreign Minister Cao Rulin in February and May. From October 1915 to March 1916, Yuan Shikai claimed that the emperor, because Secretary of State Xu Shichang asked for leave, had briefly served as Acting Secretary of State in the Diet and official Secretary of State. In 1919, as Foreign Minister, led the delegation of the Republic of China to the Paris Peace Conference, and finally refused to sign.

Feng Nyo (January 12, 1884 - August 25, 1912) was a Chinese aviation engineer and the first person in China to develop, design and manufacture aircraft. He was praised by the American newspapers as the "Orient Letter". In February 1911, Feng Nyo turned down various American appointments, returned to China with his assistants and two aircraft, advocated and fought for the cause of aviation rescue, but was killed in a flight demonstration in Yantang, Guangzhou. After his death, Feng Nyo was awarded the rank of Major General of the Army of the Republic of China by the Provisional President of the Republic of China, Yuan Shikai, and his remains are buried in the 72nd Cemetery of the Martyrs of Huangshangang (now Huangshangang Park), a monument commemorating the "China's Founder of Aviation." On January 12, 1884 (November 15), Feng Nyo was buried in Yantang, Yanping County, Guangdong Province, in a poor peasant family in the village of Anpo.

Also known as Oberon, it is the largest moon farthest from Uranus, the ninth-largest moon in the Solar System in terms of volume and mass, and the second-largest moon in the Solar System. It was first observed by the British astronomer William Herschel in 1787. Oberon is named after the Midsummer Night's Dream and the fairy king of European folklore. Part of the orbit of Oberon lies outside the magnetosphere of Uranus. Oberon is composed of nearly equal amounts of ice water and rocks, and may differentiate between a rocky core and an icy mantle. In addition, a layer of liquid water may exist between the core and the mantle. Oberon's surface is dark red, its main terrain is formed after asteroid and comet impacts, and there are many craters up to 210 km in diameter.

Luminosity IV is a subgiant star that lies between the main sequence star (luminosity V) and the red giant (luminosity III). In contrast to defining absolute characteristics, a typical method of spectral type determination is standard stars with relatively similar spectra. Many of the ratios and contours of the spectral lines are very sensitive to gravity, so they can be used as indicators of luminosity. However, some of the most useful spectral lines for each spectral type are: Morgan and Keenan, when establishing their two-dimensional classification table, listed examples of their stars in luminosity IV: Subsequent analysis showed that some of them were binary mixed spectra, some were variable stars, and extended more to serve as standard reference stars, while many of the original stars were still regarded as standard stars in the subgiant classification. Type O and cooler K1 subgiants are rare.

Until the establishment of Fujian-Taiwan Province in 1885, the Taiwan Province still retained this office. However, since the newly established administration, inspection, military, and taxation systems of the Fujian-Taiwan Province were still quite closely related to the administrative system of the Fujian-Taiwan Province, the official name of the province was still called the Fujian-Taiwan Province by the Qing court in various official documents. The Taiwan Province belonged to the first-class officials of the Fujian-Taiwan Province, and in the middle of the Qing Dynasty, it was assigned the rank of Inspector-General (Senior Third Rank). In addition to the administration of Taiwanese politics through the establishment of internal affairs, the Taiwan Province was assigned the rank of Military Governor-General (Senior Second Rank). Thus, until the middle and late Qing Dynasty, the Taiwan Province was the actual military leadership of the Taiwanese region, but it was subject to the supervision of the senior chief of the Fujian-Taiwan Patrol, or the Governor-General of Hokkaido. The full name of the Taiwan Province official post was the Fujian-Taiwan Patrol Xiamen Road, the Fujian-Taiwan Patrol Road, the Fujian-Taiwan Patrol Road, the Fujian-Taiwan Patrol Road, and the Fujian-Taiwan Patrol Road by Inspector-General.

The metropolitan area (Métropole) is a level of municipal public cooperative organization in France, which was further improved in the establishment of the "Réforme des collectivités territoriales françaises" promulgated on 17 December 2010. Due to various historical reasons, the administrative units of the "cities" in France are unified as towns, and have always been in a more diffuse state, so that the municipal public cooperative organization is often regarded as an effective regional management body linked between towns and provinces. Until 2008, the highest level of the municipal public cooperative organization was the "Communauté urbaine" (urban community), with very limited administrative powers.

In October 1945, after the surrender of Japan in World War II, Taiwan was taken over by the Office of the Governor-General of Taiwan Province headed by Chen Yi. Politically, the government conducted politics in a biased manner, the bureaucracy was defeated, political discrimination, the majority of Taiwanese elites were excluded; economically, the planned economic policies caused inflation and economic crisis, the unemployment population expanded, social problems abounded; culturally, after the war, Taiwan and mainland China had marked differences, the Taiwanese affected by Japaneseization were accused of "enslavement", and were asked to "Chineseization". Taiwanese people's dissatisfaction with the government gradually accumulated, the contradictions between the government and the people and ethnic groups led to the tensions continuing to rise.

Two government institutions, the Central Academy of Sciences and the National Museum of History, are directly subordinate to the President's Office. On January 10, 2003, the President's Office followed the example of the U.S. White House internship system by establishing the President's Youth Working Group, and President Chen Shui-bian announced the official establishment of the Youth Working Group. On May 20, 2008, after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, the President's Office officially added the post of Spokesperson; prior to that, the President's press releases were always the responsibility of the Director of Public Affairs. In order to enable the President to exercise his powers, the President's Organization Act was amended on September 1, 2010, and the Regulatory Committee was added. In 2017, a man attacked the President's guards with a sword stolen from the National Army Historical Museum. On January 1, 1912, the Provisional Government of the Republic of China was established in Nanjing, and the President's Office was established at the site of the former Governor-General's Office of the Yangtze River in the Qing Dynasty (now the Nanjing Museum of Modern Chinese History Sites); in April, Beijing was relocated.

In 1908, a group of white athletes formed the Outrigger Canoe Club at Wakey Beach and vigorously promoted canoeing and surfing. In the same year, Duke Kahnamoku, Knut Cotterell and Ken Winter formally founded the Hui Nalu Surfing Club in Hawaii, which is considered the beginning of modern surfing organizations. In 1962, the first World Surfing Championships were held in Manly, New South Wales, Australia, and surfing became popular around the world. The development of surfing is inextricably linked with the development of surfboards. The invention of more scientific surfboards greatly reduced the threshold for surfing. Early-rising surfboards are made of thick redwood and can reach 16 to 20 feet in length.

Regional Representatives(102): Military Representatives(60): Group Representatives(206) The First Plenary Session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) was held from September 21 to 30, 1949, in the Huai Ren Hall of the People's Government of North China under the control of the Communist Party of China. On September 21, Mao Zedong proclaimed in the opening words, "The People's Republic of China has been established," and "The Chinese people stand up from here." On September 29, the Plenary adopted the Common Program of the People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), equivalent to the Provisional Constitution of the People's Republic of China. On September 30, the Plenary elected the members of the Committee of the Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China, and Mao Zedong was elected President of the Central People's Government.

The earliest descriptions of Penghu in Chinese literature appeared in the Southern Song Dynasty.Rokyu "Seize Collection Volume 88" Quanzhou Governor's Office "Wang Tai Yau": In April 1171, "Kiti Quanzhou, to county... county actually overlooking the sea, there are tens of thousands of acres of sand, called Pinghu..."Wang Tai Yau is described in the text as protecting the Han people in Pinghu was not plundered by the Pasha evil nations (it is said that the indigenous people of the Misha Islands in the Philippines today), but sent 200 houses in Pinghu to guard the ancestors of the Yuan Dynasty until November 1281.The Penghu officially established Penghu Castle Patrol Division, which belongs to Fujian Tong'an, so that Penghu entered the Chinese version of Taiwan before 403.According to the relevant historical books, the Penghu Castle Patrol officer position in Penghu was the most basic official of the Yuan Dynasty, and Chen Xinhui, who was in office until the first year of the Yuan Dynasty, was the first Chinese patrol recorded in Chinese literature.

Founded in 1987, Bond University is Australia's first private university. The university has a three-semester system, students only have to study for two years. However, the law curriculum has to be studied for eight semesters. Japan has a number of internationally renowned private universities, especially the "Sokei Shoji MARCH" in the Tokyo area and the "Kansai Coalition", the most important of which is the 13 "Kansai Private Universities". In addition, the International Christian University is MacArthur's push for the establishment of the American Beauregard College, one-third of the courses are taught entirely in English. Study College is traditionally the "Royal University"; Kokugakuin University and Kogakukan University have a special mission in theology. In addition to receiving special subsidies from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology's Global 30 program, Sokei Shoji, Meiji University, Doshisha University and Ritsumeikan University, other private universities also receive a small part of the regular subsidies from the government, but still use tuition fees and alumni donations as the main sources of funding.

The Third National Congress of the Communist Party of China was held in Guangzhou from June 12 to 20, 1923. Nearly 40 delegates from all over the country and Moscow attended the Congress, representing 420 Party members. In early June 1923, Mao Zedong left Shanghai for Guangzhou to attend the Preparatory Meeting of the "Three Great Powers" of the Communist Party of China, presided over by Chen Duxiu, Li Dazhao, Zhang Guoxu, Tan Pingshan, Tsai Heson, Chen Tanqiu, Luo Zhanglong and Communist International Representative Marine, Marine conveyed the views of the Communist International on the issue of cooperation with the Communist Party of China, reported on the international situation, the meeting discussed the election of Central Committee members and drafted various resolutions of the "Three Great Powers".

He was opposed to organizing political parties and formulating policies, and advocated "that all men speak the truth and do the deeds with their consciences"; on 21 August 1968, when the Soviets invaded Prague, Havel was invited to work at the Radio Free Czechoslovakia, broadcasting what he saw on the radio. Havel wrote and publicly demanded an amnesty for dissidents, and, together with other writers and dissidents, published Charter 77, demanding that the Czechoslovak government comply with the human rights provisions of the Helsinki Accords. In 1977, Havel wrote an open letter to the then General Secretary of the United Workers Party, Mr. Husák, in which he stated that he believed that under the social system of the time "humanity and the decay of the system". He believed that the manifestation of human nature and the release of human rights were the only way out of society. Under the intervention of the international community, Havel was imprisoned in 1983 on the grounds of lung disease, and other sentences were pardoned by the government in commemoration of the 40th anniversary of liberation.

The "One China" principle was formulated by the Government of the People's Republic of China in 1982, the first time that the People's Republic of China incorporated the "One China" policy in the preamble to the Constitution. In 2005, the Anti-Secession Law was enacted, formalizing the "One China Principle" policy and legalizing it. The Government of the People's Republic of China considers that the ruling group of the Kuomintang has remained in Taiwan since its departure, and that although its regime continues to use the names "Republic of China" and "Government of the Republic of China", it has no right to represent China in the exercise of state sovereignty, in fact, it remains only a local authority on Chinese territory. The Government of the People's Republic of China regards "One China" as the basic principle for establishing diplomatic relations with other countries, and adopts the policy of "one legitimate government". Any country that establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of China cannot establish diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China at the same time.

In addition, in accordance with the Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Certain Major Issues Concerning the Reform and Development of State-owned Enterprises, "the administrative level of enterprises and enterprise leaders shall no longer be determined." As stated above, the Party Committee and the presidents of universities (centrally administered universities), subordinate institutions under the supervision of the deputy ministers, some major state-owned enterprises and centrally administered financial enterprises are included in the Central Administration. As the institutions themselves are not sub-ministerial units, this Article is no longer listed. The Notice of the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the General Office of the State Council on Further Strengthening and Improving the Management of Institutional Establishment and Strict Control of Institutional Establishment (No. 2 [2007]) stipulates that "the central and state organ departments, organs of the relevant mass organizations and institutions at the sub-bureau (bureau) level or above of the Party political organs of provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities directly under the Central Government shall have the authority to approve and approve the establishment of institutions at the sub-bureau (bureau) level or above.

Rho Cassiopeiae is a yellow supergiant in the constellation of Cassiopeia. It can still be seen with the naked eye (invisible to the southern hemisphere) even 11650 light-years away from Earth, as it is 350,000 to 650,000 times brighter than the Sun. Transitional justice is the remedy for the illegal and injustices of past dictatorships in democratic countries, usually in the areas of justice, history, administration, constitution, reparations, etc. In short, it is the review by the government of past violations of international law or human rights guarantees arising from political ideological conflicts or war crimes, the prosecution of perpetrators, and the recovery of property rights derived from such violations. It also considers the valuation and legal evaluation of "institutional crimes", such as the Nuremberg Trials, the Tokyo Trials, de-Nazism, and the Secret Police. The purpose of transitional justice is to consolidate and safeguard universal values of fundamental human rights, to urge governments to cease, investigate, punish, correct, and prevent future governmental violations of human rights.

Leopards can be solitary or in small groups of close relatives or mates. They are the most solitary of all cats except for lions. They feed on small antelopes and cooperate in hunting large hoofed animals such as zebras and horned horses. Unlike other cats, which primarily hunt by ambush, leopards mainly hunt by running. They are known for their amazing running speed, with a maximum speed of over 120 km/h, making them the fastest-running animals in the world. However, because of their weak limbs, their climbing and jumping abilities are far inferior to those of other cats, they are the worst climbers in the family. To adapt to fast running, leopards evolved a unique body structure. They have light skeletons, thin trunks, long limbs that form a tall figure, flexible spines that allow them to stretch, and a long tail that keeps their balance while running.

CONMEBOL (Spanish pronunciation: ) is the governing body of football in South America. It was founded on 9 July 1916. The CONMEBOL is currently the best-performing of the six continental federations, with all but Venezuela reaching the finals of the FIFA World Cup. It is headquartered in Lucca, Paraguay. satire is a literary genre used to expose the contradictions or flaws of an object. It is often exaggerated or caricatured in order to produce a humorous effect. It is usually used to humiliate or expose the flaws of an individual, company, government, or society itself in order to make improvements. Of course, bad imitation, acting, adjacency, juxtaposition, parallelism, contrast, analogy, analogies, etc. are also often used in satire techniques. To say that satire is satire is a big mistake. Strictly speaking, satire is a colloquial type; and satire is a more specific modification technique. Although satire usually means humor, its larger purpose is often constructive social criticism, using intelligence to draw people's attention to specific problems in society and to wider problems.

The warring Caribbean later occupied the islands of Antigua and Barbuda, but did not occupy either. Christopher Columbus landed in Antigua in 1493 on his Second New World voyage. He named the island St. Mary's of Antigua. Spain did not colonize the island because it lacked fresh water, and there were warring Caribbeans. British colonization of Antigua began in 1632, followed by colonization of the adjacent island of Barbuda in 1634. The French briefly invaded Antigua in 1666. The British established sugar plantations and trafficked slaves from Africa. Slavery in Antigua was abolished only in 1834. Slaves were liberated, but they remained economically dependent on farmers. The Antigua Chamber of Commerce was formed in 1939.

Despite the fact that Chengdu and Chongqing have become one of the most developed cities in China, the overall backwardness of the West has not improved. How to deal with the West, especially the Northwest and Tibet, has become one of China's greatest challenges. On the other hand, the provinces of Guizhou, Tibet and Qinghai, where the situation is complex and the tasks of poverty alleviation and stability are daunting, are also often political highlands with easy achievements. The experience of the ruling party in these provinces can often be a knock on the door to the Central and South China Seas. Hu Jintao, Qian Yunro and Cheng Jingshu, who once ruled Guizhou, were all among the leaders of the Party and the State, and Zhao Keqi and Chen Miner were transferred to Hebei and Chongqing, two important provincial administrative districts, respectively, after leaving office. Chen Kuiyuan, Guo Jinlong and Zhang Qingli, who once served as members of the CPPCC, became vice-chairmen of the CPPCC, members of the CPPCC and secretary-general of the CPPCC, respectively. Hu Jintao, who once served as members of the CPPCC, was promoted directly to the CPPCC Standing Committee after leaving office.

Most of the island is covered with ice caps, with the exception of the northernmost part of the island and the narrow strip on both sides of the east and west, where the surface is exposed due to the extreme dryness of the air and the difficulty in forming snow. The central part of the island is also subjected to long periods of ice cover, so that if the ice caps are removed, the central part of the island will be lower than the peripheral part. The highest elevation of the island is 3300 m in the east-central part of the island, and the peripheral part of the island is about 1000-2000 m above sea level. If all of the ice and snow on Greenland were melted, the island would appear to be in a state of archipelago under the influence of glacial erosion. At the same time, the sea level would rise by 7 m. The indigenous people of Greenland are the Inuit, one of the Eskimo peoples (the rest are the Yukon people, and are closely related to the Aleutians), but they do not call themselves Eskimo, as this is a derogatory term used by other indigenous tribes in North America for them, meaning "people who eat raw meat".

Coordinates: 37°6.38′S 12°17.14′W / 37.10633°S 12.28567°W / -37.10633; -12.28567Tristan da Cunha, also known as Tristan da Cunha, is an island group in the South Atlantic Ocean, part of the British Overseas Territories of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha. It is the world's most remote and inhabited outlying island, 2,816 km from South Africa, and 3,360 km from South America. The Tristan da Cunha archipelago comprises the main island of Tristan da Cunha (98 km2) and several uninhabited islands: Inaccessobul and the South Dingle Islands.

Line 14 of the Guangzhou Metro is one of the lines of the Guangzhou Metro, belonging to the Commuter Railway. The line runs roughly from southwest to northeast, connecting the Jia Wo Wanggang station in the northern part of Guangzhou city and Zhenhua District, and at the same time, a branch line is separated from the Xinhua station, passing through the knowledge city, to Zhenlong in Huangpu District. Line 14 is one of the first lines built according to the "Grand Station Express Line", the main line has a Grand Station Express train service. The knowledge city branch line has been opened on December 28, 2017. Line 14 consists of the main line and the knowledge city branch line. The main line and the knowledge city branch line are currently operated as separate lines. Currently, the main line starts at Jia Wo Wanggang station, exits northwards, goes down Songyuan Road, turns eastwards along the planned Yongshi Road, then turns northwards along 105 National Road, turns northwestwards on Longxing Central Road, turns northwards on the planned road to the east of Longxiang City. Then, the line turns northeastwards under the northeast through the Second Ring Expressway, again turns northwards along 105 National Road, exits the overhead bridge near Da Luo Village and continues northwards, crosses the Jinzhu Expressway, and the Xinhua station on the north side of Xinhua West Street branches out of the knowledge city branch line.

Nantou Private Wuyuan Senior High School is a private high school located in Nantou City, Nantou County, Taiwan Province. It is also the first private high school in Nantou County. It is located at the foot of the eastern side of Bagua Mountain. It has a multimedia animation department, a beauty department and a care service department. Wuyuan Senior High School recruited first-grade students in 2001 (six classes in the national section and two classes in the high school section). Founded by the first principal Mr. Lai Wenji (who has resigned) and the chairman Mr. Ho Ki-de (who has resigned), it is committed to running the school affairs. Its ideal of establishing the school is to establish Wuyuan Senior High School as " Nantou 1 Middle School". Currently, there are three classes in the high school section; there are 13 classes in the high school section. Exoplanets are planets located outside the Solar System. As of October 20, 2021, there are a total of 4,531 confirmed exoplanets, about three-quarters of which have been discovered through transits. In the Milky Way, there are an estimated 100 to 400 billion stars (if each star has at least one planet, this would result in 100 to 400 billion planets), and the closest known exoplanet is Neighbor b. Almost all exoplanets that have been discovered are in our own galaxy, but a small number of galactic exoplanets may be detectable.

The Council of Ministers of the USSR (Russian: Совет Министров СССР) was the supreme administrative organ of state power of the USSR from 1946 to 1990, that is, part of the Soviet government. Its predecessor was the Soviet People's Committee established after the victory of the October Revolution in 1917, the first meeting of the Second Supreme Soviet of the USSR in March 1946 decided to change its name to the Council of Ministers, and the People's Committees were subsequently renamed Ministers. The Committee issued statements and orders according to appropriate laws, and had jurisdiction over the republics throughout the Union. However, the most important decrees issued joint statements with the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, because the latter was in fact more powerful. In 1991, the Council of Ministers was dissolved, replaced by the newly established Soviet Cabinet, and disappeared a few months later with the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

The following two institutions are included in the CPC and the Central Military Commission of the People's Republic of China: After the establishment of the Central Military Commission of the People's Republic of China in 1983, the members of the CPC and the National Military Commission of the People's Republic of China were essentially the same, effectively "one institution and two flags." The CPC Military Commission of the People's Republic of China was formed or abolished by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. The National Military Commission of the People's Republic of China was formed or abolished by the National People's Congress, and was responsible to the National People's Congress and its Standing Committee.

In military terms, Nyerere completely disbanded the uncultured, unpolitical army left over from the colonial era, established a new People's Defence Army with the "Youth League" (i.e., the Tanzanian Youth League) as its core, made a fundamental change in the composition of the armed forces, became a cultural, African nationalist and patriotic army led by the ruling party, that is, a politicized army. In military terms, the remnants of colonialism were relatively thoroughly cleansed. The Africanization and politicization of the armed forces made them a powerful tool for the ruling party to carry out its policies. In political terms, Nyerere used the coup d'état to further combat the opposition forces, eliminated all existing opposition groups, and made Tanganyika a virtually one-party state. In April 1964, he visited the newly established People's Republic of Zanzibar, met with President Sheikh Abed Amini Karom, and reached an agreement on the union of the two countries into a sovereign state.
