As of December 31, 2017, Wal-Mart has opened 441 stores in 140 cities in 21 provinces and 4 municipalities.

The Portuguese colonists used slave labour in the middle of the 16th century to make São Tomé and Príncipe the most important sugar export destination in Africa. São Tomé and Príncipe came under the direct rule of the Portuguese kingdom from 1522 and the Portuguese kingdom from 1573. The sugar industry collapsed in the following hundred years. By the middle of the 17th century São Tomé was only a port of call for ships. In the early 19th century, two economic crops were introduced: coffee and cocoa. The fertile volcanic soil of the region was particularly suited to these new economic crops, and many roças were established.

Religion has many definitions, ranging from a cultural system that associates people with gods or supernatural, sacred beings to a principle or theoretical system of belief that is upheld with enthusiasm and firm conviction. Different religions may contain different elements, including but not limited to divinity, sacred objects, faith, supernatural existence (one or more), and ultimate or transcendental life experiences that confer norms or powers on believers. Expressive forms of religion include rituals, sermons, commemorations or worships, worships of gods, sacrifices, festivals, celebrations, funeral services, marriage services, prayers, music, art, dance, public services, or other cultural forms. Religions may record the origin of life, the universe, or other things, and thus express the meaning of life through sacred history, narratives (possibly preserved through the Bible), symbolic meanings, and sacred sites.

Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is an epidemic caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronary virus (SARS-CoV). It spread to 29 countries and regions between November 2002 and September 2003. The epidemic originated in Shunde City, Guangdong Province, People's Republic of China. The epidemic infected more than 8,000 people worldwide, resulting in the death of 774 patients, including medical personnel. The term "SARS" has different usages in various parts of Asia. On the mainland of China, the term "atypical pneumonia" is commonly referred to simply as "atypical pneumonia", but the two are not synonymous, SARS is just one type of atypical pneumonia. In Hong Kong, the term "SARS" is translated as "SARS" in Cantonese, or "SARS" is used directly in English. In Taiwan, the term "SARS" is also commonly used in English.

Cape Town (Afrikaans:Kaapstad or Cape Town) is the second most populous city in South Africa, and is part of the City of Cape Town Metropolitan Municipality, the provincial government of West Cape. Cape Town is the legislative capital of South Africa, and is the seat of the parliament and many government departments. The city is famous for its beautiful natural scenery and wharves, its famous landmark Table Mountain, which is known as the "Table of God", and the Cape of Good Hope, the intersection of the Indian Ocean and the Atlantic Ocean. Cape Town is known as one of the most beautiful cities in the world for its beautiful natural and geographical environment, and it has also become one of the tourist attractions in South Africa. The city was originally developed around the wharves, as merchant ships from the Netherlands to East Africa, India and Asia transited through it, and it has long been the first long-term settlement of Europeans in Sub-Saharan Africa.

He then travelled to Germany and received a doctorate in philosophy from the University of Tübingen in 1936; at the age of 23. After the outbreak of the Sino-Japanese War, he returned to China to participate in the war, and mainly engaged in newspaper work. During this time, he wrote international essays in English Hong Kong under the name "Joki" in such publications as "The Evening Post", "World Knowledge", etc.

The dwarf planet Ceres was discovered in 1801 at the orbital distance predicted by Bohr. Because these objects look like planets, William Herschel adopted the Greek root aster- (similar to a star), naming them asteroids. The Napoleonic Wars ended the first phase of asteroid discovery, and modern asteroid survey systems use automated equipment to keep the number of asteroids growing. After the discovery of asteroids, it was necessary to calculate their orbital elements. In 1866, Daniel Kirkwood announced that, calculated from the Sun, there were empty regions at certain distances where there were no asteroids, and in these regions the orbital periods around the Sun had a simple integer ratio to the orbital periods of Jupiter. Kirkwood believed that perturbations of Jupiter caused the asteroids to be removed from these orbits.

The first principal, Rak Huijie, initially borrowed the empty classrooms of Yatou National Primary School. On October 24, 1985, all the students moved back to the new school site. At that time, each year four classes, a total of 500 students, 24 teachers, two secretaries, and two workmates. In August 1992, the secondary school was established to promote adult education. In August 1996, the sports subsidiary was established. In 1997, the wind and rain playground was built, and a nutritional lunch was held. In 1999, it was designated by the Ministry of Education as a "nine-year integrated pilot school." In 2000, the laboratory of natural sciences was established. In August 2010, the Preparation Department of the High School was established, and the then principal, Zhu Keng-jin, also served as the Preparation Director. In August 2011, Keelung City Yatou Senior Secondary School was officially established, and became a full secondary school, with Zhu Keng-jin still serving as the principal.

The Portuguese State (Portuguese: Estado Portuguesa) is one of the 23 states of the South American nation of Venezuela, and is one of the first administrative divisions of the country, located in the northwest of the country. It covers an area of 15,200 square kilometers. Its name derives from the river that flows through the state. The economy is based on livestock farming, crops include rice, coffee, etc. It is the largest rice producing area in Venezuela, with an area of rice cultivation of 62% of the country. It is known as the "garden of Venezuela". The capital city of Guanare is named after the Guanare River, 425 kilometers from the capital of the country, Caracas. The population is 130,000, with an average annual temperature of 28 degrees Celsius. Guanare's importance lies in the fact that it is the "spiritual" capital of Venezuela. In 1942, the Virgin of Coromoto was proclaimed by Pope Leo VII as the patron saint of Venezuela, and the shrine is located in the Bolivar Square in the city of Guanare, which makes the state attractive for religious tourism.

The Seventy-third Army of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) is an infantry-class unit of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) organized in 1937. It was first formed by Tang Seng-chi's Xiang army, then centralized as the legitimate line of King Yaowu. The core unit of the NRA is the 15th Division of the NRA, but it is not the first use of this designation, nor is it related to the 7th Army of the NRA that first used this designation. During the Northern Expedition of the NRA, which consisted of 15 divisions, it was expanded by Tang Seng-chi's Xiang army system of the NRA thirty-fifth Army; however, in 1927, during the Ninghan War, Tang Seng-chi's mistaken support caused his commanding units to be either reorganized by the Nanjing National Government led by the New Guizhou Army, or diverted to provinces outside Hunan, resulting in the 35th Army relying on the New Guizhou Army after the battle, and stationed in Guangxi. However, in March 1929, the conflict between the New Guizhou Army and the Nanjing Government controlled by Chiang Kai-shek, the 35th Army relying on Chiang Kai-shek's Nanjing Government with guns during the collapse of the New Guizhou Army, but this time could not maintain the existing treatment, the unit was reduced to the 15th Division of the NRA; this designation is derived from the newly disbanded Guizhou Army when the National Revolutionary Army's 7th Army was captured.

The Edict of Wakashu is a collection of waka poems compiled by order of the Emperor or the Retired Emperor during the Heian period to the Muromachi period of Japan. From the Edict of Wakashu (compiled from 905) to the Edict of Wakashu (compiled in 1439), a total of 21 Edicts of Wakashu were compiled over 534 years, collectively known as the Edict of Wakashu. The Edict of Wakashu compiled by the Southern Court is called the Edict of Wakashu. The Edict of Wakashu of the Twentieth Dynasty can be divided into the Edict of Wakashu of the Third Dynasty, the Edict of Wakashu of the Eighth Dynasty, and the Edict of Wakashu of the Twentieth Dynasty. The Edict of Wakashu of the Twentieth Dynasty includes the Edict of Wakashu of the First Dynasty to the Edict of Wakashu of the Third Dynasty; the Edict of Wakashu of the Eighth Dynasty includes the Edict of Wakashu of the First Dynasty to the Edict of Wakashu of the Ninth Dynasty to the Edict of Wakashu of the Twentieth Dynasty (the Edict of Wakashu of the Third Dynasty and the Edict of Wakashu of the Eighth Dynasty are duplicated); the Edict of Wakashu of the Thirteenth Dynasty includes the Edict of Wakashu of the Ninth Dynasty to the Edict of Wakashu of the Twentieth Dynasty.

5.4.2 billion years ago, the end of the Edictaean extinction event, followed by the Cambrian life explosion, the explosion of multicellular species on Earth (such as thermal gases, shrimps, etc.). 15 to 4.5 billion years later, the Earth's axis of rotation may change up to 90 degrees. It is estimated that from now on, complex life on the Earth's surface is still young, activity can continue to reach its peak, and will last for about 5 to 1 billion years, but if the nitrogen in the atmosphere completely disappears, this time will be extended to 2.3 billion years. Rising temperatures on the Earth's surface will accelerate the inorganic carbon cycle, reducing the atmospheric carbon dioxide content. After about 5 to 900 million years, the atmospheric carbon dioxide content will gradually decrease to 10 ppm, even C4 plants will be unable to survive without new evolutionary methods, and the decrease in seawater will cause dramatic temperature changes that adversely affect complex life.

Leo is a faint constellation in the northern sky, corresponding to the name Leo. To the north is the larger and more recognizable constellation Ursa Major and to the south is Leo. Classical astronomers did not classify Leo as an independent constellation until 1687, when John Hurville designated it. Leo has 37 stars with a luminosity of more than 6.5 magnitudes, and only three stars with a luminosity of 4.5 magnitudes. The brightest star four light-years from Earth is an orange giant of 3.8 magnitudes. Beta Leo 4.4 is the second-brightest star in the constellation, and the only star to be named by Bayer. Beta Leo is a binary star, with an orange giant and a yellow-white main sequence. The third-brightest star is Neptune II, a fast-rotating 4.5-magnitude white main sequence. Leo has two stars with planetary systems, two pairs of interacting galaxies, and a unique deep-sky Hani body.

A geographical coordinate system is a coordinate system consisting of longitude, latitude, and relative altitude that can indicate any position on the Earth. In order to distinguish it from a coordinate system that uses longitude only on a flat or spherical surface, a three-dimensional geographical coordinate system that uses latitude with relative altitude is also called a geographical coordinate system. A three-dimensional geographical coordinate system that uses the definition of the latitude of the Earth's center is a spherical coordinate system. A geographical coordinate system also uses the three-dimensional Cartesian coordinates of the Earth's center and the Local tangent plane coordinates.

Asteroseismology, from Ancient Greek ἀστήρ,astēr, star,σεισμός, seismos, vibration, -λογία, -logia, study. or called stellar seismology. Asteroseismology is a tool for studying the internal structure of a star. Vibration frequency can provide the source of seismic waves and the density of matter passing through the region. Star spectra can allow astronomers to analyze the composition of stars, so spectroscopy and asteroseismology combine to learn about the internal structure of a star. Asteroseismology can change the light of a star into acoustic waves. Asteroseismologists propose that the vibration in a star is caused by the conversion of thermal energy into pulsating kinetic energy. This process is similar to any heat engine, where heat is absorbed in the high-temperature vibrational phase and released at low temperatures.

Zhang Jingjiang (Chinese: 张静江; pinyin: Zhang Jingjiang; September 19, 1877 – September 3, 1950), also known as Zhang Jiang (Chinese: 静江; pinyin: Zhang Jingjiang; pinyin: Zhang Jingjiang), was the first Chairman of the Standing Committee of the Central Executive Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC). Zhang Jingjiang's family, originally from Huining County, Huizhou Prefecture, Anhui Province, moved to Zhejiang at the end of the Ming Dynasty to escape the war.

The false cross is a cluster of four stars in the constellation δ, κ, ι and ε Sagittarius, he is often mistaken for the constellation of the Southern Cross, causing errors in astronomical navigation. An interesting deep-sky object in Sagittarius is the planetary nebula NGC 3132 ( nicknamed the Octagon Nebula), which is also an interesting remnant of the Sagittarius supernova in this constellation.

Apparent magnitude (m) was first defined by the ancient Greek astronomer Hipparchus, who divided the 1022 stars in his catalogue into six orders of magnitude, from 1st to 6th magnitude. In 1850, the British astronomer Pson found that 1st magnitude stars were 100 times brighter than 6th magnitude stars. On the basis of this relationship, the magnitude was quantified. In the redefinition of magnitude, the difference between each order of magnitude was 2.512 times, and the magnitude of 1 Lex (unit of magnitude) was -13.98. However, the magnitudes 1 to 6 did not describe the brightness of all the objects discovered at that time, and astronomers extended the original magnitude — introducing the concept of "negative magnitude".

On December 21, 1975, the country was renamed the Democratic Republic of Madagascar, or the Second Republic of Madagascar. On August 19, 1992, the country was renamed the Republic of Madagascar, or the Third Republic of Madagascar. In 1959, the interim government of the Republic of Madagascar fulfilled its mandate, a constitution was created, and Madagascar became officially independent. Filipe Cirana was elected as the first president. On December 21, 1975, the country was renamed the Democratic Republic of Madagascar, or the Second Republic of Madagascar. The Second Republic had a socialist system, and in 1990, under pressure from the West, it implemented multi-party democratization and economic liberalization. In 1992, Madagascar held a referendum, adopted the "Constitution of the Third Republic", on August 19, 1992, the country was renamed the Republic of Madagascar, or the Third Republic of Madagascar, and in February 1993, in the first open multi-party elections in Madagascar's history, Albert Zafy was elected President of the Third Republic.

With the help of the Soviet Union, China and Cuba, the Liberation Front formed a decade-long war. From a military point of view, the Portuguese army prevailed in this war, but was ultimately defeated by the Liberation Front for Mozambique, which was at a disadvantage, mainly because of the Orange Revolution of April 25, 1974, which overthrew the Second Republic government, which continued to retain overseas territory. After the revolution, political negotiations between the Portuguese and Mozambican sides resulted in Mozambique's independence on June 25, 1975, ending the Portuguese colonial empire's 470-year rule in East Africa. One of the causes of the Orange Revolution was the concern of some Portuguese about Portugal's treatment of Mozambicans. Mozambique's earliest known inhabitants were the Bushmans. In the 1st and 4th centuries, some Bantu-speaking tribes crossed the Zambezi River into Mozambique.

Liu Zhaoxuan (Chinese: 劉兆玄; born May 10, 1943 in Hengyang, Hunan Province) is a Chinese politician, chemist, writer, and professor of chemistry at the University of Toronto, Canada. He has served as President of the Executive Council, President of the National Tsinghua University, President of Dongwu University, Chairman of the Li Guoding Foundation, Vice Chairman of the National Political Foundation, Chairman of the Chinese Cultural Association, Minister of Transportation, Chairman of the National Science Council, Chairman of the National Security Council, Chairman of the Education Reform Group of the Executive Council, Chairman of the National Tsinghua University School of Science, Chairman of the Chinese Cultural Sustainable Development Foundation, Chairman of the Chinese Entrepreneurs' Summit and Chairman of the Chinese Educational Culture Foundation.

Each awards ceremony has its own set of nominations and voting procedures, as well as different rules for the juries. Each different awards ceremony has its own categories of awards, but some of them have similar or the same names, but they are not nominated in the same way. Generally, the same program cannot be nominated for a different awards ceremony. For example, a syndicated program may be nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award or a Daytime Emmy Award, but cannot be nominated at the same time. Furthermore, under normal rules, to compete for a National Emmy Award, the program must be guaranteed to be viewed by at least 50% of American households; less than this percentage will be eligible for a Regional Emmy Award.

During the Cold War, it was primarily used to monitor nuclear activity in the Soviet Union without violating the Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. On September 22, 1979, at 00:53 GMT, satellite 6911 of the COSPAS-SARSAT system detected twin flashes (a fast, bright, long, and slightly faint flash) in the area between the South Atlantic and Indian Oceans at the intersection of the Prince Edward Islands and the Crozet Islands. Twin flashes were a typical feature of nuclear explosions. The U.S. Nuclear Weapons Intelligence Team subsequently determined that an undisclosed nuclear explosion had occurred in the area, with an estimated amount of 2 to 3 thousand tons of nuclear material. But the U.S. government later claimed that 25 U.S. Air Force WC-135 nuclear reconnaissance aircraft had arrived in the area to gather intelligence, and no explosions or radiation had been detected. Uniquely, the University of Cornell's Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico responded with similar information.

On January 25, 1926, at the first plenary session of the Second Central Executive Committee, the Standing Committee of the Central Executive Committee was elected, and nine members were appointed as Standing Committee Members of the Central Executive Committee: Chiang Kai-shek, Wang Zhaoming, Tan Yanxiang, Tan Pingshan, Lin Zuhan, Hu Hanmin, Chen Guobo, Gan Noguang, and Yang Guan'an.The Standing Committee of the Central Executive Committee was formally established.In March 1927, the Third Plenary Session of the Second Central Committee of the Kuomintang adopted the Resolution on the Leadership Organs of the Unified Party, reaffirming that the National Congress was the highest organ of power of the Kuomintang, and that after the National Congress, the Party's organs of power were the Central Executive Committee.

There are also records of the appearance of comets in ancient times, and the ancients generally believed that comets were omens. Comets were named after their long tails, and the meaning of 'comet' was 'broom'. 'Comet, bamboo also.' Ancient Chinese people called the comet 'Star Báb.' The Spring and Autumn Chronicle recorded, in 613 BC, 'In the autumn of July, a star Báb entered the North Pole.' This is the earliest record in the world of Halley's comet. According to Dong Zhongshu, 'The Báb was born of evil, the Báb was hindered, and the appearance of chaos was unknown.' In fact, in ancient China, comets were often associated with misfortune, and Liu Xiang also said, 'The Báb was rebellious, and the table of usurping was also,' but Liu Qiqiu and others have long said that this statement is ridiculous.

Blackie Ko (February 22, 1953 – December 9, 2003) was a Taiwanese male entertainer, nicknamed "Asian Flyer". He was born in Yushan Li Island, Zhejiang Province, and was born in Linhai County, Zhejiang Province. He is known for his flying car stunts. He flew motorcycles over the Great Wall and the Tibetan Budara Palace, and on June 1, 1997, he flew a Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution IV RS (CN9A) over the Yellow River to celebrate Hong Kong's return, earning him the title of "Asia's First Flyer". He had planned to fly over the Three Gorges of the Yangtze River before his birth, but failed to do so. Ko was born in 1953 in Xiangshan, China, at the end of the Chinese Civil War.

On October 16, 1987, the General Office of the State Council of the People's Republic of China issued the Notice of the General Office of the State Council of the People's Republic of China on Measures for the Reception of Compatriots from Taiwan on Visits to the Mainland of the People's Republic of China, stating that "Taiwan compatriots returning to the Mainland of the People's Republic of China for visits to the Mainland of the People's Republic of China shall apply for travel documents, which shall be processed in Hong Kong by the visa office of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of China in Hong Kong, or on behalf of the Hong Kong China Travel Service; in the United States, Japan or other countries, travel documents shall be processed by China's embassies and consulates abroad." Article 89 of the Law of the People's Republic of China on the Administration of Entry and Exit, adopted by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress in 2013, states that "Exit means traveling from the Mainland of the People's Republic of China to other countries or regions, from the Mainland of the People's Republic of China to the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, the Macao Special Administrative Region, and from the Mainland of the People's Republic of China to Taiwan."

Paraguay's constitution declares it to be a multicultural and bilingual country, with both Spanish and Guaraní as official languages. 87% of the population speaks Guaraní. Paraguay was originally a colony of the Guaraní Indians, discovered in 1525 by the Portuguese Alejo García, and founded in 1537 by a Spanish colony. Five years later, Jesuit missionaries from the Catholic Church also visited the city and taught local farming and handicrafts. In 1767, Spanish colonists expelled Jesuit missionaries. In the 18th century, Paraguay was the most populous region in South America. On May 15, 1811, Paraguay gained its independence from Spain, under the dictatorial rule of Rodrigo.

Indonesia is the world's largest Muslim country, Thailand is the world's largest Buddhist country, and the Philippines is the most Catholic country in the Eastern Hemisphere. In addition to the newly formed East Timor, ten countries in the region formed the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN, or "ASEAN," "Tokyo," or "Asian") organization. Before the 20th century, Southeast Asia was also called East India by Europeans. Historically, China referred to the region as the "South Ocean." Due to the geographical location between China and the Indian subcontinent and the cultural influence of the neighboring regions, the Southeast Asian continent was partly referred to by European geographers as Indochina. However, in the 20th century, the term was more restricted to the territory of the former French Indochina (Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam). The term "Southeast Asia" was first used in 1839 by the American pastor Howard Malcolm in his book Southeast Asia Travels.

September 14, 1939, at the same time as the outbreak of World War II in Europe, the Japanese army launched the First Battle of Changsha. In this campaign, the Ninth War Area troops used the characteristics of the Hunan River and canals scattered throughout the defense, and adopted the tactics of "against each other to exhaust the Japanese forces; to seek out the outer wing in an attempt to subsequently surround; to retreat to defend Changsha; while the enemy retreats to surround and destroy" in order to kill and injure the Japanese forces in large numbers. However, the commander of the Japanese army at the time, the commander of the Eleventh Army, Ninji OKAMURA, was more cautious, in judging its hopelessness of capturing Changsha, ordered a timely withdrawal, so that the Chinese army failed to achieve its strategic goal of destroying the Japanese army. However, this battle was also the first time that the Chinese army successfully defended the major cities and repulsed and killed the Japanese army, thus being promoted by the Chinese as "Shobei Dai-Jet".

Emperor Taiji originates from Taoism and Confucianism. The earliest written record of the Emperor in Japan is the Asuka Pure Imperial Order (Asuka Pure Imperial Order), enacted by the 40th Emperor Tenmu and promulgated in 689 CE. The first emperor to use (self-proclaimed) the name was Tang Emperor Gaozong Liji in 674 CE, and after his death, his pseudonym was "Emperor Taiji." He was also the only emperor in China to use the name Emperor. Emperors are equal to emperors, and the emperor differs from the emperor in the stronger religious nature of the emperor. Early Japanese history in the 1st to 3rd centuries C.E., small states were established, the monarchs of each of the small states were called "king" or "king", and around the 4th and 5th centuries C.E., all the states formed a coalition, the leaders were called "great kings" (Japanese: 大王/おおきみ), "great dukes" or "great princes", and called "governing the great kings of the world."

Zhu De (December 1, 1886 – July 6, 1976), originally Zhu Dezhen, was a citizen of Yilong County, Sichuan Province. He was one of the main founders, founders and leaders of the People's Liberation Army of China and the People's Republic of China, and one of the early leaders of the Communist Party of China. Zhu De is an important revolutionary and military figure in the modern history of China, and the head of the Ten Commanders-in-Chief of the People's Republic of China. Zhu De graduated from the Yunnan Army Hall of Martial Arts early in his life, participated in the Revolution in Xinhai, the War for the Protection of the State, the War for the Protection of the Law, and was appointed as the head of the Yunnan Provincial Police Department. In 1922, while studying in Germany, he joined the Communist Party of China, and later studied at Zhongshan University in Moscow. On August 1, 1927, he participated in the Nanchang Uprising. Afterwards, he led the Igonshan and Mao Zedong Divisions, successively serving as the commander of the Red Fourth Army, the commander of the Red One Army Corps, the commander of the Red One Army, the commander of the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army, the chairman of the China Revolutionary Army Commission, and participated in the Long March.

On November 2, 1928, the Fifth State Council of the National Government enacted the Law on the National Flag of the Republic of China. On December 17, 1928, the National Flag of the Republic of China was promulgated with the blue sky and the red sky as the national emblem. In 1928, the five-colored flags of the Northern Expeditionary Army were gradually replaced by the red sky and the red sky. On December 29, 1928, the General Commander of the Northeastern Security Force, General Zhang Xue Liang, telegraphed the proclamation of the flag of the Northeastern Region: "From now on, we declare our adherence to the Tri-Nationalism, our obedience to the National Government, and our change of the flag." On December 29, at 7 a.m., the red sky and the red sky were raised simultaneously, and the red sky and the red sky completely replaced the five-colored flags.

Feng Yuxiang was the voice of Baoding throughout his life. Feng Yuxiang's parents had an early taste for opium. Chen Shui-bian's paternal ancestors came from the Choda Baomagnet Kiln Village in Zhangzhou Prefecture, Shantou County, Fujian Province, in the Greater Qing Dynasty, belonged to the Fou Yao people. As of October 2019, the People's Republic of China has unveiled eight batches, totaling 5,058 key national cultural heritage protection units: the first to three batches of key national cultural heritage protection units and the fourth to seven batches of unified categories, of which the first three batches are divided into six categories: revolutionary sites and revolutionary memorial buildings, cave temples, ancient buildings and historical memorial buildings, stone carvings and other works, ancient sites, ancient tombs, etc. Starting with the fourth batch, it has been reclassified into six categories: ancient sites, ancient tombs, ancient buildings, cave temples and stone carvings, important historical sites and representative buildings in modern times, etc. On the basis of the third national cultural heritage survey, the National Bureau of Cultural Heritage has reclassified the first three batches according to the new classification (the former "revolutionary sites and revolutionary memorial buildings" have been reclassified as "important historical sites and representative buildings in modern times", the former "cave temples", "stone carvings and other works" have been largely reclassified as "cave temples and stone carvings", a minority have been reclassified as "other works", the former "ancient buildings and historical memorial buildings" have been largely reclassified as "ancient buildings", a minority have been reclassified as "important historical sites and representative buildings in modern times"), and the first to seven batches have been renumbered according to the new classification.

After the outbreak of the Soviet War in June 1941, the entire territory of Latvia was occupied by the Soviet army, which was quickly defeated by the Army of the Northern Group of Nazi Germany. In order to facilitate the occupation of the Baltic States, the Nazis merged Latvia with Lithuania, Estonia and parts of Belarus into the Governor-General's Region. In 1944, the Soviet Union counterattacked against Germany and occupied Latvia. After the end of World War II, Latvia was again under Soviet control until the 1980s. The Soviet Union initiated political reforms in the 1980s, which also facilitated the development of the Baltic independence movement. On August 21, 1991, Latvia declared independence again, and the Soviet State Council also recognized Latvia's independence on September 6 of the same year. Since independence, Latvia has actively cultivated relations with Western countries, and has joined the European Union and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 2004.

The Republic of Colombia (Spanish: República de Colombia), commonly known as Colombia, is a country in northwestern South America, the fourth largest country in Latin America, and a former member of the Union of South American Nations (withdrawn in August 2018). It is bordered by the Caribbean Sea to the north, Venezuela to the east, Brazil to the southeast, Peru and Ecuador to the south, and Panama and the Pacific Ocean to the west. Colombia is a presidential state, composed of 32 departments and the Metropolitan District of Bogotá. It is famous for its culture and is also the largest manufacturing center in South America. Due to the waves of migration in Europe, the Middle East and Asia in the 19th and 20th centuries, Colombia is a very diverse country.

Guangzhou Bus Route 1 is the first bus route in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, China. It is operated by Guangzhou Motor Bus Co., Ltd., and connects the main stations of Fangcun Garden South Gate in Lai Wan District and Dongshan (Signed Road) in Yuxiu District. It crosses the Pearl River, runs through the East and West of the city, and travels through the Memorial of the Three Congresses of the Communist Party of China, the Martyrs' Mausoleum, the Memorial of the Agricultural Seminary, and the Museum of the South Vietnamese Royal Palace. It combines daily commuting and tourism sightseeing functions. In 1928, the Guangzhou City Hall officially delineated the bus route, divided into three lines: Red, Yellow and Green. The Yellow line starts from Huangsha, runs through the Yangtze River, Yonghan Road and Huiyi Road to Dongshan Park, which is the predecessor of Route 1.

It is equivalent to Latin: locum tenens, Arabic:ملازم (mulāzim), or Hebrew:סגן (segen). In Chinese, a lieutenant and a captain are traditional Chinese military titles. For example, a lieutenant is a "lieutenant," a court officer is a "lieutenant," and a captain is a "lieutenant." At the end of the Qing Dynasty, the Qing court followed the Western countries and established a system of ranks of the 3rd and 9th ranks. Among them, the 2nd rank is a deputy colonel, i.e. the original thousand, or sixpence. According to the North Sea government's "Royal Military Officer Rank Schedule," a lieutenant is a lieutenant. Since then, the Chinese names of lieutenants and other ranks in the 3rd and 9th ranks have been fixed, and are used to this day. In the U.S. Army, U.S. Marine Corps, U.S. Air Force and U.S. Space Force, a lieutenant is a junior officer. Higher than a second lieutenant, lower than a captain.

Coordinated Universal Time (French: Temps Universel Coordonné, abbreviated UTC) is the main world time standard, which is based on the seconds of atomic time, as close as possible to Greenwich Mean Time in time. The Republic of China adopts CNS 7648 "Data Elements and Exchange Format – Information Exchange – Date and Time Representation" (similar to ISO 8601) as "World Coordinated Time"; the People's Republic of China adopts ISO 8601:2000 National Standard GB/T 7408-2005 "Data Elements and Exchange Format Information Exchange Date and Time Representation" as "Coordinated World Time".

Yang Hucheng (Chinese: 杨虎城; November 26, 1893 – September 6, 1949), born in Shaanxi, Shaanxi Province, China, is a 61-year-old military general of the Republic of China, one of the leaders of the Xi'an Incident, and a staunch supporter of the removal of Chiang Kai-shek, the then Chairman of the Military Committee of the National Government. He served as the Central Supervisory Commissioner of the Republic of China, Director of the Northwest Suicide Prevention Department, Commander-in-Chief of the Seventeenth Route Army of the National Revolutionary Army, and Second-in-Chief of the Republic of China Army. He was forced to go overseas to investigate the Xi'an Incident with Zhang Xucheng, and then returned to China in secret. He was imprisoned for 12 years by the military authorities. He was executed at the White House in Chongqing on September 6, 1949, and died at the age of 56. Yang Hucheng grew up in a peasant family, starting with the Green Forest Ranger (Guangzhou "sniper").

Kaizan County (Japanese: 海山郡/かいざんぐん Kaizan Gun) is one of the administrative divisions of the period of the Japanese occupation of Taiwan, founded in 1920, the county belongs to the Taipei province. Kaizan County controls Itabashi Street, Yinghua Street, Three Channel Street, Zhonghe Zhuang and Dongcheng Zhuang, as opposed to the current location, namely, Cheng Itabashi District, Dongcheng District, Three Channel District, Yinghua District, Forest District, Zhonghe District and Yonghe District. Kaizan County office was established in Itabashi Street, the site of the old Taipei County government, now the New Taipei City Government Police Bureau. 1945, the end of the period of the Japanese occupation, the Taipei County government moved from the old Taipei State Hall in Taipei City to Kaizan County office, Kaizan County was abolished, Haishan Mountains was established in 1946, but was abolished in 1947, after the streets belonging to the former name independently as towns or villages and directly belonged to the Taipei County. Since then, due to the population growth, the former Zhonghe has been divided into Yonghe, Forest and Yinghua District, etc.

Charity is a kind of well-intentioned social activity, which may include charity, relief of poverty, animal welfare or even environmental protection. The practice of charity means the voluntary provision of help to those in need, as a humanitarian act. Charitable relations are "donor" and "recipient." In society, regardless of material repayment, giving to the needy community help, sponsorship, etc. is the altruistic care that promotes the progress of human welfare, usually by donating money, assets or work activities, donated by educational or medical institutions to those in need, or public welfare assistance to other social needs. The main charity in China is more than charity, especially the food of the charity in times of famine or war, and Qian Ao presided over is a kind of charity. Later Buddhism and Taoism believed that good deeds can accumulate merit, and during the Kangxi era of the Qing Dynasty, a university student Li Guangzhi set up a porridge factory to cook porridge and distribute it to hungry people.

For example, global warming has accelerated the melting of continental glaciers in Antarctica and Greenland, causing sea levels to rise and flooding low-lying coastal areas. About three-quarters of the world's population lives less than 500 kilometres from the coastline, and the shrinking land area affects the area suitable for human habitation. In addition, in times of typhoons, floods, landslides or earthquakes, the urgent need to rescue and resettle disaster victims also becomes an important national security issue. In order to ensure the sustainable development of the country, the state should intervene in a timely manner as a public warehouse to control and regulate the price of all kinds of energy, food, mineral and water resources. However, this is not to avoid the blockade and embargo imposed by the enemy in times of war, but to preserve the "war reserves" of the resource reserves. Rather, it is to stabilize prices, to stabilize people's hearts, and to avoid dramatic changes in prices, leading to internal disintegration of the country.

It is the interaction between stars and interstellar matter that makes them so important in astrophysics. Stars form in the densest regions of interstellar matter, eventually feeding into interstellar matter through planetary nebulae, stellar winds, and supernovae, helping to form molecular clouds. This interaction between stars and interstellar matter helps determine the speed at which the galaxy depletes its gaseous content, thereby determining the lifespan of its star-forming activity. Voyager 1 arrived in interstellar matter on August 25, 2012, becoming the first individual to enter interstellar matter. The mission to study interstellar dust and plasma is expected to continue until 2025. Voyager 2, which is twin, also entered interstellar matter in November 2019. Table 1 shows details of the main components of interstellar matter in the Milky Way.

During this period, many newly-established colonial powers applied to join the United States, gradually recognizing the expansion of the territory as a new state. By 1848, the borders of the United States had crossed the entire North American continent. Subsequently, the victory of the American Civil War, the United States' foreign intervention extended beyond the present-day United States mainland, allowing U.S. forces to enter the Caribbean and the Western Pacific. After the turn of the 20th century, the United States joined the war in the late World War I and laid the foundations for a global military power. After the end of the roaring 1920s, the United States experienced the Great Depression in the 1930s, and after the victory of the Second World War, the United States rapidly rose to become a superpower. As one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, the United States is not only the possessor of nuclear weapons, but also the world's first to develop nuclear weapons, and the only country to have deployed them in action.

On September 24, 1909, he went to the United States with Cai Guangxue and others. Arriving in San Francisco in late October, the autumn class at the University of California, Berkeley had already begun, and he had to concentrate on studying English until the spring class next year. In February 1909, he applied for a degree in Oceanography at the University of California, Berkeley. Six months after entering the university, he was advised by friends to transfer to the Academy of Social Sciences in the fall of 1909. The Constitution of the People's Republic of China, which was adopted at the first session of the First National People's Congress in September 1954, established the National Defense Committee of the People's Republic of China and repealed the People's Revolutionary Military Committee of the Central People's Government. However, the 1954 Constitution did not explicitly stipulate the functions and powers of the National Defense Committee. Article 42 of the Constitution states: "The President of the People's Republic of China shall command the armed forces of the country and shall serve as Chairman of the National Defense Committee," i.e. the command of the armed forces belongs to the President of the People's Republic of China. However, from the practical point of view, the National Defense Committee of the People's Republic of China is a military council, with no decision-making power, no command of the armed forces, and no military decision-making power. In fact, on the evening of September 20, 1954, the night on which the Constitution was adopted, the Politburo of the Communist Party of China convened a meeting and decided to establish and form the Central Military Committee of the Communist Party of China, as the military work decision-making organ under the leadership of the Political Bureau.

Suicide in China has been studied since the late 1970s, when China's economy opened up to the West. Overall, China's suicide rate is lower than that of neighboring Japan and South Korea, and higher in the Yangtze River basin than elsewhere. A 2014 study of suicide in China during the Great Depression (2007-2008) found that while the global suicide rate soared, it was declining: in the 1990s, China ranked among the top countries in the world in terms of suicide rates (more than 20 per 100,000 people), but during the 2008 Great Depression, China's suicide rate continued to decline (similar to the declining situation in the late 1990s), as large numbers of people migrated from rural to urban areas.

On 2 November 1983, South Africa held a referendum on a new constitution (Suid-Afrikaanse referendum van 1983, 1983 South African constitutional reform referendum), in which only whites had the chance to vote for or against the Constitution of 1983. The Constitution proposed the introduction of a three-chamber parliament, in which coloured and Indians would have representation in different parliaments, but blacks were excluded and still had no representation.

He graduated from the University of Southwest Political Science and Law with a degree in Civil Law and a Master's Degree in Law. A longitude is a geographical coordinate used to determine the position of different points on the Earth's surface from east to west. A longitude is an angle measurement, usually expressed in degrees, and is denoted by the Greek letter λ (lambda). A meridian passes through the South Pole and the North Pole and connects points of the same longitude. By convention, this meridian passes through the Royal Observatory at Greenwich, London, and is the location of the zeroth meridian. The longitude of other locations is obtained by measuring the angle at which it passes from the east to the west of the meridian, from the meridian 0° east to 180° west to 180° W. Specifically, the longitude of a location is a two-sided angle composed of a plane passing through the meridian and a plane passing through the South Pole, the North Pole and that location. (This forms a right-hand coordinate system, with its z-axis (the right thumb) pointing from the center of the Earth in the direction of the North Pole, and its x-axis (the right index finger) pointing from the center of the Earth to the intersection of the meridian and the equator.

The College of Foreign Languages and Literature, Providence University, formerly known as the College of Foreign Languages and Literature, is one of the faculties of Providence University. It is located in Baudougou and consists of the Department of English Language, the Department of Japanese Language, and the Department of Spanish Language. In August 1987, it was moved from the old campus in Fuxing Road to the present site in Shalu District. It was originally the Department of English Language of the College of Foreign Languages and Literature, located in the old campus in Fuxing Road, Taichung City. In 1963, it was approved to be upgraded to the College of Foreign Languages and Literature, and four departments such as the Department of Foreign Languages were established.

Coordinates: 23°24′N 113°30′E / 23.4°N 113.5°E / 23.4; 113.5 History of Guangdong Guangdong Province is the southern coastal province of the People's Republic of China, the provincial capital is Guangzhou. "Guangdong" originated in Guangxin County, which was the administrative center of the historical department of Qingzhou in the Han Dynasty. It means "the first open Cantonese territory, Guangdong Buonxin," later called Guangxin as the eastern region of Guangdong, Song to Tao three years ago (997 AD) set Guangdong Southeast Road, the origin of the name Guangdong Province today. Guangdong is one of the earliest provinces in China to reform and open up, the total economy has been in the first place on the Chinese mainland since 1989, and is the first major province in China's economy. Guangdong's Han inhabitants, mainly can be divided into three ethnic groups: Guangfu, Hakka, Minhai. In addition, there are different minorities, such as Zhuang, Yao and Xiang, the largest number of which are Zhuang, language, traditional customs and so on have their own unique characteristics.

Depending on the type of legislation, the Provincial Council has four decision-making mechanisms. The President of the Senate of South Africa was replaced in 1997 by the Chairman of the National Provincial Committee; and the first Chairman of the Provincial Council was Mosiuoa Lekota, who served from 1997 to 1999.

The concept of human rights is closely related to the concept of equity and justice, and the defence of disadvantaged human rights is considered to be an extension of equity and justice.Although people have the freedom to give up their rights to a certain extent, fundamental human rights themselves are inalienable, even if a person voluntarily gives up his or her fundamental human rights.In general, unless it is a situation in which the rights of a particular fundamental human right must be denied by law (and as mentioned above, in a country's constitutional system there are often rules such as proportionality principle and restrictions on the government's legislation to deny or limit the practice of fundamental human rights), otherwise everyone in any way enjoys freedom and other fundamental human rights, such as Article 16 of the Civil Code of the Republic of China stipulates that "the ability to exercise rights and the ability to act must not be abandoned"; and Article 17(1) of the Civil Code of the Republic of China stipulates that "freedom must not be abandoned."In ancient society, the concept of universal human rights has not matured, and a person has rights only because he or she is a member of a group.

After the outbreak of the Xinhai Revolution, the revolutionaries and the new army all over the country responded independently and broke away from the Qing government. In 1912, after the establishment of the provisional government of the Republic of China, the revolutionary army of each region was approved by the revolutionary army government of each region, the new army was attached to the revolutionary army of the provisional government. After the establishment of the northern government of the Republic of China, the revolutionary army of all regions of the country was attached to the northern government army. After the death of Yuan Shikai, no one was able to take control of the northern government army of the country, subsequently the northern government army of each region was divided into various northern army factions subordinated to one side. Sun Yat-sen established the national government in Guangzhou, and established the revolutionary army of the Kuomintang government, historically known as the Huangpu army. After the Northern Expedition of the National Revolutionary Army, the old northern army factions were extinguished or converted into the National Revolutionary Army, and the country was unified. During the mainland period of the Republic of China, 158 army numbers had appeared before and after. On March 3, 1956, the Ministry of Defense (45) signed Ordinance No. 060.

In 1982, in conjunction with Chiayi City's elevation to provincial jurisdiction, it was renamed the "Private Chong Yan Higher Nursing and Midwifery Vocational School of Chiayi City."In 1989, the midwifery department was abolished, the four-year nursing and midwifery training department was changed to a one-year nursing department.In the 1990s, Taiwan's medical care professional standards began to rise steadily, nursing staff with only high-level nursing school qualifications were no longer able to meet the demands of the medical workplace at the time, the school deliberated on the development policy of the specialized school, and established the "Chong Yan Specialized Nursing Management School Preparation Office."On August 1, 2005, the school was renamed the "Chong Yan Specialized Nursing Management School", recruiting five-year daytime and two-year daytime nighttime nursing students, and subsequently added: five-year restaurant management department, two-year bakery department, five-year beauty care department, five-year foreign language application department, two-year elderly care department in-service classes, and five-year elderly service business management department.

The planet and its moons are named after the mythological figures of the Tongva tribe of Native Americans in Southern California. Quaoul is the creator god of the Tongva tribe, and Vivator is his son and Zodiac I. The discovery was announced at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society on October 7, 2002. The earliest retrograde discovery can be traced back to the May 25, 1954, dry version of the Palomar Observatory. Since astronomers can directly estimate its size from observations with the Hubble Space Telescope, it may be classified as a dwarf planet. In 2004, astronomers estimated its diameter to be 1,260 ± 190 km, with subsequent downward revisions. At the time of its discovery by astronomers in 2002, it was the largest object in the Solar System since Pluto was discovered in 1930.

Grigory Evseevich Zinoviev (Russian: Григорий Евсеевич Зиновьев; September 11, 1883 – August 25, 1936) was a Soviet revolutionary, politician, one of the early leaders of the Soviet Communist Party, and a member of the Politburo of the USSR. Zinoviev was an aide to Lenin during the October Revolution. When Lenin died in 1924, he was elected a member of the Politburo of the USSR along with Trotsky, Stalin, Bukharin, Kamenev and Likov. Together with Kamenev, together with Stalin, collectively known as the Three Horsemen, he ousted Trotsky from the People's Committee of the Army and Navy. Frustrated by the growing power of Stalin, he formed a new opposition with Kamenev in 1925, was overthrown and expelled from the Politburo in 1926.

Wang Jiuling (Chinese: 王九龄; 1879-1951) was a Chinese politician. He studied in Japan at the end of the Qing Dynasty and graduated from the University of Law and Political Science. He was vice-director of student affairs in Yunnan and joined the Communist Party of China. In October 1911, he participated in the Xinhai Revolution. After the establishment of the Yunnan military government, Wang Jiuling was responsible for the administration of civil affairs. In 1913, he was appointed secretary of the Yunnan military administration. Later, he belonged to Tang Jiyao. After the beginning of the Law Enforcement Campaign, Wang Jiuling was appointed Director of the Military Law Department of the General Command of the Jing Province Joint Army. In 1921, he was appointed Director of the Military Law Department of the Yunnan Army. In 1923, he was appointed Director of the Finance Department of Yunnan. In November of the following year, when Tan Qi Rui took over the interim government, Wang went to Beijing to serve as the Chief of Education of the Beijing Government (未就).

The People's Chamber (German: Volkskammer) is the unicameral legislative body of the German Democratic Republic, located in the Reichstag. It was founded in 1949 and held its first free elections on 18 March 1990. During this period, all members of the People's Chamber were members of the National Front controlled by the Socialist Unity Party of Germany. Although nominally a multi-party system, all satellite parties were effectively controlled by the Socialist Unity Party. Other mass organizations affiliated to the Socialist Unity Party, such as the Free German Youth League, also held seats. Under the Constitution of the German Democratic Republic, the East German Federal Parliament and the People's Chamber initially formed the upper and lower houses of the East German parliament. However, after the abolition of the state system in 1952, the Federal Parliament was abolished in 1958 and the legislative body was changed to a unicameral system.

In the 16th century, the Dutch rulers of Taiwan, from the mountains of the Three Gorges to the coastal hills of the Five Plains region, called the cold water pit stream 'Spruijt nae Gaijsan', meaning 'Sea Mountain River'. Since the Qing Dynasty, there has been a so-called 'Sea Mountain Fort', covering the area of today's Three Gorges. Sea Mountain County was established in Itabashi, but the name is derived from the Three Gorges and the two streets of Itabashi. At that time, the strength of the Governor's Office decided that the county seat was located in Itabashi, considering 'people's harmony', so the name of the Fort of Three Gorges Sea Mountain as the county name, slightly harmonized. The same example is also found in Dongseok County, Taiwan, and North Gate County, Taiwan may also be the same.

). All planets, comets, and asteroids in the Solar System have elliptical orbits (a kind of non-circular orbit) (any object that orbits only the Sun is close to an elliptical orbit, a phenomenon called perihelion oscillation, which prevents the orbit from becoming a simple closed curve, such as an ellipse). Therefore, they all have nearest and furthest points from the Sun: perihelion and farthest sunspots, also known as arc points, measure the flatness of their orbits (the difference between an ideal circle and a perihelion). A perihelion is the point at which a planet, asteroid, comet, or any object orbiting the Sun is closest to the Sun in its orbit. It is relative to the farthest sunspot from the Sun in its orbit. The Earth is closest to the Sun on about January 3 of each year, and the furthest from the Sun on about July 4.

Cabinet Decree No. 3 of 1937 was repealed and promulgated again in 1954 as Cabinet Notice No. 1, but the Hebrew script was not accepted as an international standard due to difficulties in international relations and previous practices. In 1989, the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) adopted the Hebrew script as the ISO 3602 standard. Until the various symbols were accurately defined, there existed a variety of romanization methods influenced by Western European languages, which are still in existence today. The Japanese standard is the Hebrew script promulgated by the Cabinet in 1954. The international standard is the ISO 3602 standard, which was approved by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 1989. See https://web.archive.org/web/20061206005922/http://www.age.ne.jp/x/nrs/iso3602/iso3602.html The contents of the two are no different.

In order to limit Yuan Shikai, the Provisional Senate of the Republic of China passed the Provisional Treaty Law of the Republic of China, which regulated the political system. In 1913, the first parliamentary elections of the Republic of China ended, and the Kuomintang, representing the Southern Revolutionary forces, obtained a parliamentary majority. Kuomintang secretary-general Song Kyoren was assassinated in Shanghai on his way to Beijing. The Kuomintang asserted that Yuan Shikai was the assassin's mastermind, and with his influence, launched a series of wars against Yuan and the subsequent North Sea government. On December 12, 1915, Yuan Shikai proclaimed himself emperor, changed the Yuan Hong Keng, and on December 25, Tsai Yuan, Tang Jiyao, Li Li Lijun, and others in Kunming proclaimed Yunnan independence, and launched a nation-protection movement. In 1916, Liu Xianzeng of Guizhou, Guangxi Lurong Ting, Guangsu Governor Feng Kunzhang, Jiangxi Governor Li Jun, Zhejiang Governor Zhu Rui, Hunan Governor Yuan Yuan Ming, Shandong Governor Jin Yunpeng and other five marshals joined forces to suppress the imperial palace, and various foreign envoys expressed their opposition. In March, Yuan Shikai ordered the abolition of the Hong Keng imperial system, and on June 6, Yuan Shikai died in anger. After Yuan Shikai's death, the North Sea soldiers went their separate ways, splitting internally, forming three main forces: the Anhui branch led by Dan Qiray, the direct branch led by Cao Yuan, and the subordinate branch led by Zhang Shaolin.

Sirius/Sopdet's Icon The earliest astronomical records have described Sirius, which the ancient Egyptians regarded as "Sopdet" (the sacred goddess Satitha), and whose Icon is a star and a triangle. In Sanskrit, it means "Mrgavyadha" and "Lubdhaka" (the hunter). The ancient Egyptian calendar of the Middle Kingdom period began with Sirius rising with the sun on that day, that morning, because Sirius was far enough away from the Sun that it could rise earlier than the Sun, avoiding strong light, and after disappearing 70 days reappeared in the sky. The ancient Greeks believed that the appearance of Sirius represented a hot summer, causing plants to dry up, men to be weak and women to be boring.

Chad was occupied by France in 1920 and became part of French Equatorial Africa. In 1960, Chad gained independence from France under François Tombabaye, but Tombabaye's policies caused discontent in the northern Muslim regions, eventually triggering a long-lasting civil war in 1965. In 1979, the rebels seized N'Djamena, ending the rule of the southern regime. However, internal strife between the rebel commanders resulted in Hussein Habré winning the fight to become president, but being overthrown by his general Idriss Déby in 1990. Since 2003, the Darfur conflict in the western Sudan has destabilized the situation on Chad's borders. Although Chad has many active parties, the Patriotic Salvation Movement led by former President Idriss Déby is firmly in power, and political violence and intentional military coups are still rife in the country.

Individualism is closely related to classical liberalism. In political philosophy, individualism argues that the state should primarily be a tool for protecting individual liberty, protecting the individual from doing whatever he or she wants without violating the equal freedom of others. This is contrary to the theory of collectivism: collectivism believes that the individual exists to serve the overall interests of society. Collectivism is similar to communism and fascism, which require the individual to serve the interests of the state. The term individualism is also used to describe "the individual's accessibility" and "the individual's freedom", more specifically the French word "laissez faire", which stands for "let him or her do, let him or her go, let him or her go".

Liu Gui-go (July 4, 1902 – April 22, 1938) was a retired Chinese military commander who was one of the high-ranking generals of the Republic of China during the Sino-Japanese War. Liu Gui-go was born into a poor peasant family in the villages of six villages and eight villages in Chaoyang County. In 1924, he joined the army as a student in the Zhengyuan Department of Song Dynasty, and later as a platoon commander, major colonel and colonel in the Bai Fengxiang Department of Hebei River. In 1931, after the "November 8" Incident, the Northeast Army was ordered to withdraw to Guangxi, and subsequently stationed in Hebei, Shaanxi and Gansu. In 1934, Liu Gui-go was elected to the third phase of the Lushan Military Officer Training Corps. In 1935, Chiang Kai-shek established the "Northwest Anti-Banditry Headquarters", and transferred the Northeast Army to the Northwest to fight against the Communist Army. Liu was strongly dissatisfied with Chiang Kai-shek's non-resistance, and asked Zhang Xue-lin to lead 500 soldiers back to Hebei River to fight against the Japanese.

In addition, similar regimes have emerged in non-communist countries such as the Syrian Arab Republic (however, the 1963-2012 constitution also called itself a socialist state), the Saharan Democratic Republic, Eritrea, and the Republic of South Sudan. Historically, party states have emerged mostly during the interwar period, including but not limited to Nazi and fascist Germany, the fascist Kingdom of Italy, the militaristic Empire of Japan, the three-party Republic of China, and the puppet states belonging to the above-mentioned countries as well as the majority of the party-led administrative regimes. Politburo Members of the Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union Politburo Members of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union Party-led regime originated in the Soviet Union, referring to Lenin's seizure of power after the October Revolution led by Bolsheviks in 1917, as the first communist country, the Lenin government took control of the country, transferring all power to the Soviet Union (parliament), then the Communist Party took control of the Supreme Soviet (parliament) and the People's Committee (government), forming a party-led regime, i.e. Leninism.

The sand dunes in the sand dunes sometimes have three faces, two smooth faces, the other face is rougher downward contact with the ground, the smooth face is polished by the fine sand carried by the wind to the light surface, the ridges between the faces are very sharp, so it is called the triangular stone or triangular stone. Algal reefs are reefs that produce calcium or silica by the secretion of algae, which have accumulated over the years, and both coral reefs belong to the biotic reef (bioherm).

Zhuhai Station is the southern terminus of the Guangzhou-Zhuhai Intercity Railway Main Line. It is located at No. 5 Changsheng Road, Arbei Street, Xiangzhou District, Zhuhai City. The station was originally opened in 2000 and is the site of the five-storey Golden Port Resort Hotel. Due to the delay in the construction of Zhuhai Station, the function of the terminus of the Guangzhou-Zhuhai Intercity Railway can only be operated for a long time by Zhuhai North Station in Jinding. Unlike most of China's high-speed railways, the Guangzhou-Zhuhai Intercity Railway does not have an overhead line at almost every station. Therefore, although there are several stations between Zhuhai North Station and Zhuhai Station, as these stations do not have an overhead line enabling trains to transfer from the lower line to the upper line, they do not have the ability to reverse as the terminus. Since Zhuhai Station has not been opened, it is only possible to choose the nearest station with an overhead line, namely Zhuhai North Station, as the temporary terminus.

Although he lost the case, the court agreed with him that the existence of ID cards was inappropriate. Nevertheless, some Secretaries of State suggested re-introducing the ID card system, for a variety of reasons. In 2003, then Secretary of State David Blankett said that the British government intended to introduce a biotechnology-based national ID card scheme, using a database to record the population of residents, which would be enforced by 2013. The Home Office believed that ID cards could combat international terrorist activities, 35% of terrorists used false ID travel. More recently, the government has also claimed that ID cards would help prevent illegal immigration, "health travel," defrauding subsidies, and identity theft, and that biometric passports would also make it easier for British citizens to travel to the United States. The United States does not currently have a genuine national ID card, because there is no federal agency nationwide with sufficient jurisdiction to issue an ID card to all U.S. citizens.

In October 2020, the Communist Party of China's 19th Plenary Session of the Fifth Central Committee proposed accelerating the modernization of national defense and the armed forces, achieving the unification of rich and powerful nations, ensuring the achievement of the "One Hundred Year Struggle Goal" by 2027, achieving basic national defense and armed forces modernization by 2035, and achieving a new "three-step" strategy of building a world-class national defense and armed forces by the middle of the 21st century. The PLA's official newspaper, the PLA Gazette, described the "One Hundred Year Struggle Goal" as "requiring our army to accelerate the pace of construction and development, take on the mission tasks of the new era, and provide strategic support for achieving the great revival of the Chinese nation." The South China Morning Post quoted military figures as saying that China would build three aircraft carrier battle groups by 2027, match the military capabilities of the United States in the Pacific region, and prevent outside interference in the reunification of Mainland China and Taiwan.

Despite some emergency relief measures, Montenegro's debt is expected to approach 80% of GDP in 2018, and the International Monetary Fund says the country cannot shoulder any more debts. In 2021, Montenegro faces the risk of defaulting on its debts due to the effects of the epidemic. China-Montenegro cultural exchanges have a certain historical basis, and since the establishment of diplomatic relations in 2006, China-Montenegro exchanges and cooperation in the fields of education, science and technology have been steadily deepening, both maintaining official academic exchanges and encouraging private-sector academic exchanges. Chinese has also become one of Montenegro's more influential foreign languages. In 2015, China established the first Confucius Institute at the University of Montenegro to support the country's development of Chinese language teaching, and in 2017, the University of Montenegro planned to include Chinese in the optional curriculum of the European Credit Transfer System, but it has not yet been implemented.

In industry, diamonds are mainly used in the manufacture of drilling probes and grinding tools. Completely shaped diamonds, which are polished, are called diamonds and can be used in the manufacture of high-end jewellery. They are very expensive. There are three known isotopic isomers of carbon: diamonds, graphite and fluorene. In thermodynamics, diamonds are less stable than graphite and can spontaneously change to graphite, but this change is slow and negligible at room temperature. Naturally formed diamonds are generally formed in high-temperature and high-pressure environments within the Earth, and are subsequently carried to the surface by volcanic eruptions and other crustal movements. As a result, many diamonds are found near volcanoes. Modern industry can produce diamonds at high temperatures and high pressures, called "synthetic diamonds". Diamonds have a Mohs hardness of 10; because of their highest hardness, diamond cutting and processing must be carried out using diamond powder or lasers (such as 532nm or 1,064nm wavelength lasers).

In 1966, the military-born Prime Minister Michel Michel Michel Michelbéro deposed the original Prince (who had only just assumed the throne) and established the Republic of Burundi, which entered a period of military dictatorship. Burundi has two major ethnic groups, the Tutsi, about one-half of whom have ruled the country since the 16th century, dominated by a civilian population composed mainly of Tutsis, as well as a very small number of indigenous Twa. This abnormal social structure of a minority occupying high positions undermined the stability of the country, and reached its peak in October 1993.

Earthquakes occur on the Earth's crust as earthquakes, caused mainly by the shaking and displacement of plates. Tsunamis can also occur with earthquakes. Earthquakes on the Moon as lunar earthquakes, discovered by the seismographs installed by astronauts in the Apollo program, recorded 28 surface earthquakes between 1972 and 1977. According to NASA, lunar earthquakes can be classified as follows: the intensity of the first to the third types of earthquakes is lighter, and the intensity of the surface earthquakes can reach the magnitude of the Darri earthquake of 5.5. Compared to strong earthquakes, the magnitude of the lunar earthquake is relatively light. Due to the lack of water on the Moon to absorb the earthquake waves, the duration of the lunar earthquake is longer, some even as long as one hour.

Tun Abdul Razak bin Haji Dato' Hussein (March 11, 1922 – January 14, 1976) was the second Prime Minister of Malaysia, known as the "Father of Development" of UMNO. Born to Dato' Hussein bin Mohd Taib and Hajah Teh Fatimah binti Daud, Dato' was educated at the prestigious Jiangsha Malay College in Perak at the age of 12.

The Eastern District Public School is the dispatching agency of the Hsinchu City Government in the Eastern District, in the framework of the Government of the Republic of China, it is the executive agency of the Hsinchu City Government's Shuri District Administration, and the upper-level supervisory agency is the Hsinchu City Government. The district governor is appointed by the mayor, whose term is guaranteed for no term. Under the district governor and secretary, there are three divisions, three rooms and six internal units. There are two existing colleges and universities in the Eastern District, respectively, the National Tsinghua University, the National Yangming Jiaotong University, and so on. Nine public and private high school secondary schools, respectively, there are the National Hsinchu Senior Secondary School, the National Hsinchu Women's Senior Secondary School, the National Hsinchu Science Park Experimental Senior Secondary School, the Hsinchu City Jiangong Senior Secondary School and so on, and the National Hsinchu Senior Commercial Vocational School, the National Hsinchu Senior Industrial Vocational School, the Hsinchu City Private World Senior Secondary Technical Senior Secondary School, and the Hsinchu City Private Guangfu Senior Secondary School, and the Hsinchu City Private Akebono Women's Senior Secondary Ordinary and Technical Comprehensive High School.

Zhongli District ( Hakka: Chûng-la̍k-khî; Taiwanese: Tiong-li̍k-khu) is located in the center of the flat area of Taoyuan City, Taiwan. From the north to the north, in chronological order, it is bordered by the Great Park, Ashchiku District, Taoyuan District, Yade District, Pingchun District, Yangmei District, Xinya District, Guanyin District, a total of eight administrative districts, the number of adjoining administrative districts is the largest in the city. With a population of about 422,000, it is the second largest administrative district of Taoyuan City, the population is the third highest in the country among all the three-level administrative districts. Zhongli District can be divided into Zhongli, Inner Li, Longgang, Da Lun. This district and Taoyuan District is the core of Taoyuan Zhongli metropolitan area, is one of the important economic, educational, and transportation centers of the city. Traditionally, the district center is the Zhongli station station front shopping district, in addition to the more prosperous areas, there are six and shopping district, Zhongyuan shopping district, Inner Li area, high-speed Taoyuan station specific district, etc.

In February 1976, Spain implemented the agreement and began to withdraw all its troops from Western Sahara. Morocco and Mauritania subsequently signed an agreement to partition Western Sahara: Morocco occupied 170,000 square kilometres in the north and Mauritania occupied 90,000 square kilometres in the south, but this was strongly opposed by the Western Saharan Frente POLISARIO and strongly condemned by Algeria. On 26 February 1976, Spain withdrew all its troops from Western Sahara.

Coordinates: 23°10′27′′N 120°29′11′′E / 23.1741428°N 120.4863358°E / 23.1741428; 120.4863358 Nanxi District (Chinese: 楠西區; pinyin: Lâm-se-khu; Hakka: Nàm-sî-khî) is located in the eastern part of the southern city of Taiwan, in the northern eastern mountains of Chiayi County, Tai Po District, Nanhua District in the east, Six Jia District in the west, Da Nang District in the south, and Yujing District in the south.

A small article is a relatively short article. A small article already contains basic information about a topic, but the content is less depth and breadth. A small article is not an inappropriate article, but often needs to be expanded. Disambiguation pages, lists, and pages in non-item spaces such as templates and classifications are generally not considered a small article. If you have created or encountered a small article, you can add a {{Stub}} at the bottom of the editing page to indicate the contents of the small article template on the page: If a small article can be classified, try to find a template from Wikipedia:Stub Category List instead of {{Stub}}, for example, if a molecular physics article is not sufficiently complete, you can add a {{Physics-stub}} template. If you need to create a new small article labeling template, try to use {{Asbox}}, which has the function of prompting you to label a small template with more than a few characters.

Born on 21 June 1953 in Sindh Province, Pakistan, Benazir was the eldest daughter of the late Prime Minister Ali Bhutto. Benazir was educated at Lady Jennings Nursery School, Convent of Jesus and Mary, and two years later at Rawalpindi Presentation Convent and Jesus and Mary Convent in Muli. Benazir claimed that her time at Harvard was "the happiest four years of her life" and laid the foundation for her belief in democracy.

Founded in 1990 (Hua Van Institute of Technology), renamed in 1993 (Hua Van Institute of Humanities and Technology), and reorganized in 1997 as Hua Van University, Hua Van University is a comprehensive university located in Shi'an District, New Taipei City, Taiwan. Since 2019, Hua Van University has reduced the original 12 departments to 5 departments. Founder Xiao Yun Fashi, a Buddhist Buddhist monk, brings together educators, religious scholars, and artists to promote a spiritual education that emphasizes moral education. The name of the university, "Hua Van," means to highlight the 5,000 years of Chinese culture and 2,000 years of Chinese Buddhist thought, to serve people with professional technology, and to lead a correct society with noble morality.

Guangzhou Art Museum (Chinese: 广州藝術博物院) is a large multi-functional comprehensive art museum in Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province, China. It is located in Yuxiu District, Yuxiu Lake Road south of Yuxiu Lake Park. It is the base of patriotism education in Guangzhou City. It absorbed part of the functions of the original Guangzhou Art Museum, and the original museum was located at the Zhongyuan Library next to Yuxiu Mountain Town Hall. It was opened to the public in February 1957. It is one of the earliest museums established after the Republic of China. In 1995, the Guangzhou Municipal People's Government re-designated the site for the construction of the Art Museum, the first phase of the project was completed in 2000, and it opened on September 23, 2003. The second phase of the project was completed in 2003. After the opening of the Art Museum, the "Guangzhou Art Museum" sign, which is a set of two signs running simultaneously. The original Zhongyuan Library (still hanging the old plaque of the Art Museum) building is used by the Guangzhou Museum as an exhibition area.
