Edward Christian Prescott (December 26, 1940 – November 6, 2022) was an American economist who, along with Finn Kiedland, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2004 for his "contributions to dynamic macroeconomics: time inconsistencies in economic policy and the drivers behind the economic cycle." The research was conducted primarily while both Kiedland and Prescott were at the Graduate School of Industrial Management at Carnegie Mellon University (now the Tepper School of Business).

Since ancient times, Cantonese has been an integral part of the Lingnan region, and since the Ming and Qing dynasties, the meanings of Cantonese and Vietnamese have started to differ, while Vietnamese is used in the Wu language region of Jiangsu and Zhejiang, and Cantonese is used in the Lingnan region. In the Ming and Qing dynasties, Cantonese still refers to the Lingnan region, and Cantonese is used in two distinct dialects: Cantonese (i.e., Cantonese, Cantonese West, and Hainan), Cantonese (i.e., Cantonese East, including Hainan Island), and Cantonese West (i.e., Cantonese West). Cantonese is a language formed by the fusion of ancient Chinese and Vietnamese. Cantonese is represented by Cantonese, and is called Cantonese between Hong Kong and Macau; Japanese is called Cantonese. Cantonese is used in the cities of Nanning, Guiping, Wuzhou, etc. Cantonese is called Bai dialect, and Cantonese is used in the cities of Nanning, Guiping, Wuzhou, etc. Cantonese differs little from Cantonese in terms of pronunciation, culture, colloquialism, vocabulary, and can basically communicate with Cantonese, and is included in the Cantonese dialect system.

During this period, Chen Jitang participated in the War of Protecting the Country, the War of Protecting the Law, and the two Cantonese War of Guizhou led by Chen Jiangming and Sun Yat-sen. After the Sixteenth Incident of Chen Sun, he stood on the side of Sun Wen's National Army, attacked Chen Jiangming. In the spring of 1923, Chen Liu became the commander of the 2nd brigade of the 1st Division of the Cantonese Army, led three times into Guangxi, assisted Huang Shaoxing and Li Zongren to clear the Guizhou Bureau. In Zhaoqing, he also served as the Chief of Staff of the Office of the West River Governor: 30. In July 1925, the National Government was established in Guangzhou, the Cantonese Army's 1st Division was expanded to the 4th Army of the National Revolutionary Army at this time. Li Jishan became the commander, Chen Jitang became the commander of the 11th Division. During the autumn and winter of the same year, Chen led the Second Eastern Expedition and the Southern Expeditionary Campaign, quite distinguished in battle: 29.

Yao Wenyuan (January 12, 1931 – December 23, 2005) was an important political figure during the Cultural Revolution in China. He was a member of the "Four Men's Gang," a Zhejiang Zhu and Yao Guangbu people. He was a member of the Central Cultural Revolution Group, a member of the Propaganda Group of the Central Organization, and a member of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China. He was expelled from the Communist Party of China in 1977. In 1981, he was sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment by the Special Court of the Supreme People's Court and deprived of his political rights for five years. Yao joined the Communist Party of China in July 1948. After 1949, he worked in the Propaganda Department of the China Cooperation League and the Communist Party of Shanghai Luwan District Commission. Yao Wenyuan's father, Yao Pengzi, was a friend of Hu Feng, and Yao also once wanted to become Hu Feng's "in-room apprentice." In 1955, Yao Wenyuan attracted the attention of Zhang Chunqiao when he published an article critical of Hu Feng in the January and February 1955 issue of the Beijing Literary Gazette.

At that time, it was illegal for Japanese to go overseas. If they were arrested, they would pay the price of death. When Xiang Xinshima returned to Japan, he had become convinced of the logical doctrine based on Western ideals and Christianity, and realized the necessity of establishing higher education institutions, and founded the Doshisha English School. The emblem of the Doshisha University is made up of three adjacent equilateral triangles, meaning the Assyrian letter "matu" of the country or land. The emblem can also be interpreted as the trinity of knowledge, virtue and body, or as a manifestation of the educational philosophy of the Doshisha. Designed by Yuasa Hangetsu. Ben-K (read as Ben-Kei) was created in 2009. It is made as a commemoration of the 165th anniversary of the founder Xiang Xinshima's birth, referring to the hunting dog Miguru hunting rabbit "Benkei", and for it added Xiang Xinshima's beard and costume.

Chien Hsin University of Science and Technology (Chinese: 健行學校財団法人健行科技; pinyin: Jien Hsin University of Science and Technology), abbreviated as UCH, is a private university of science and technology located in Zhongli District, Taoyuan City, Taiwan. Currently, the university has four faculties and 16 departments. Formerly known as the "Triangular Telecommunication School" in 1933; reorganized as the "Chien Hsin University of Science and Technology" in 1966; renamed the "Qingyun University of Science and Technology" in 2003; and renamed the "Chien Hsin University of Science and Technology" in 2012. The school has an electronic sports team: the "Chien Hsin University of Science and Technology" electric sports team. Formerly known as the "San Ji Telecommunication School", it was founded in Shanghai on March 3, 1933, at the outbreak of the Sino-Japanese War in 1937, shortly after Pingjin was occupied by the Japanese army.

General Andromeda I (γ Andromedae) is also a pair of brightly colored binary stars favored by amateur astronomers. Beta Andromedae (β Andromedae) is a fainter red giant that can be seen with the naked eye. The visible Andromeda Galaxy (Messyl 31) is the most prominent deep-sky object in Andromedae. It is the closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and one of the brightest Messier objects. Some of the darker galaxies, including the companions M110 and M32 of M31, the blue snow star clouds that can be observed with telescopes, and the farther-away NGC 891, are all within the range of Andromedae. In Chinese astronomy, each of the stars that make up Andromedae belongs to four different constellations; in Indian mythology, there are also constellations corresponding to Andromedae. Andromedae is a low-grade meteor shower that occurs annually in November, with its radiation point in Andromedae.

A revolutionary situation (Russian: Революционная ситуация; English: revolutionary situation) is a political situation indicating the possibility of a revolution. In his 1913 article "The May Day Demonstrations of the Revolutionary Proletariat", Lenin stated: "It is not always possible to create a revolutionary situation in a country merely by suppressing it, however serious it may be.

The Ninety-first Army of the National Revolutionary Army, a branch of the National Revolutionary Army, was formed three times in its history. On February 12, 1938, it was formed with the 166th Division as its base, and the Second Army Department was stationed in Luoyang. On April 1, 1938, the northern crossing of the Yellow River recaptured the towns of Jiyuan, Boei, Meng County, etc. The 995th Regiment encountered the main force of the Japanese army at 18 Lipu in Qinyang, suffered heavy casualties, and the commander of the 995th Regiment Yan Puyun (the fourth phase of Huangpu) was martyred. During the Siege of Jiyuan, the commander of the 995th Regiment Yan Puyun, battalion commander Zou Fulong, battalion commander Wang Chaoxiang, battalion commander Wang Yantai, etc. suffered 800 casualties (including 712 Lushan soldiers), and 700 were wounded. On June 23, the commander of the 166th Division was relieved, Liu Hecheng was appointed as the commander, and Wang Yu (the first phase of Huangpu) was appointed as the brigade commander of the 496th Brigade.

Taurus (Latin: Taurus, astronomical sign: ) is one of the constellations of the zodiac, with an area of 797.25 square degrees, accounting for 1.933% of the total area of the sky, and ranks 17th out of 88 constellations in the total area of the sky. There are 98 stars in Taurus with a magnitude of 5.5, the brightest being Pisces (α Taurus), with a visual magnitude of 0.85. The center of Taurus passes through the upper middle of the sky on the night of November 30 every year. The first asteroid to be discovered in the Milky Way was discovered by Italian astronomer Piacenza in the Taurus region on New Year's Eve of 1801. Taurus is one of the largest and most prominent constellations in the winter night sky of the Northern Hemisphere.

However, current data suggest that the colors and chemical composition of Pluto II and Pluto III are similar to that of Pluto I, so their reflectivity is more likely to be the same as that of Pluto I, so their size should be close to the lower limit of the estimate. Astronomers suspect that the Pluto system is a colliding galaxy, similar to the Earth's collision with the Moon. In this case, it can be explained that the moons have a higher angular momentum. The near-circular orbits of Pluto II and Pluto III suggest that they may have been formed during the collision, rather than by Kuiper belt objects captured by Pluto. Their orbital resonance with Pluto I also suggests that the two moons were originally formed closer to Pluto, but were pushed into their present positions by Pluto. Pluto II and Pluto III are similar in color to Pluto I (grey like the Moon), and the color of Pluto is due to the influence of sunlight on the surface of nitrogen and methane.

While studying in Belgium, the Sixty-fourth Incident prompted many Chinese overseas students to hope to stay there. However, after one year of study, Mr. Cao insisted on returning to China. Shortly after his return, Mr. Cao was promoted to associate professor; and in August 1990, he was sent to the University of San Francisco Law School in the United States as a visiting professor for short-term teaching. In 1991, he was promoted to associate professor again, becoming the youngest law professor in China at the time, at the age of 36. On December 9, 1994, as a scholar of international law, Mr. Cao was invited to the South China Sea to lecture on the subject of the General Agreement on the Law of International Trade and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for the then leaders of the Communist Party of China, including Jiang Zemin, Qiao Shi, Li Ruihuan and Hu Jintao.

Yin Li (born August 1962), male, Han Chinese, Shandong Linyi, born in Jinan, Shandong Province, a politician of the Communist Party of China and the People's Republic of China, currently a member of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China, a member of the Beijing Municipal Committee of the Communist Party of China, and a director of the Standing Committee of the Fujian Provincial People's Congress. Graduate education, doctor of medicine, a health professional, formerly a director of the General Office of the Ministry of Health, a deputy minister, a director of the State Food and Drug Administration, a deputy director of the State Health and Safety Commission, a deputy director of the Sichuan Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China, and a governor of the Sichuan People's Government. Yin Li was born in August 1962 in Jinan City, Shandong Province, into a family engaged in medical research and clinical therapy.

In July 2002, the Report on the National Defense of the Republic of China (1990-2001) was compiled in response to the events of the September 11 attacks, in which the crisis management mechanism of the Armed Forces of the Republic of China and regional security cooperation were promoted. In December 2004, the Report on the National Defense of the Republic of China (1990-2003) focused on the international security situation, the military security threat posed by the Communist Party of China to Taiwan, and possible attacks on Taiwan.

The Republic of Iraq (Arabic: République Iraqi; Kurdish: قۆماری عێراق ), commonly known as Iraq (العراق ), is a republic in the Western-Middle East region. Iraq borders Saudi Arabia to the south, Kuwait to the north, Turkey to the north, Syria to the northwest, Iran to the east and Jordan to the west. Historically, the region where Iraq is located has also been called Mesopotamia, one of the earliest in the cradle of human civilization. The word Iraq (العراق al-ʿIrāq) has been in use since the sixth century BC. There are many theories as to its origin, one of which is that the name comes from the Sumerian city-state of Uruk (Sumerian: Unug; Akkadian: Uruk; Arabic:وركاء or أوروك, Warkāʼ or Auruk; Arabic/Hebrew: אֶרֶךְ‬ ʼÉre), in Sumerian, the name means town.

The city was founded in 1886, when gold was discovered on a farm. Due to the discovery of massive gold mines in the Westwatersrand, the city is often referred to as the modern "Golden Country". The name derives from one or all of the three men who participated in the founding of the city. Over the decade, the population grew to 100,000. From the late 1970s to 1994, Soveto was an independent city, now part of Johannesburg. Soveto was originally an abbreviation for "South-Western Townships", originating from a series of settlements in the Johannesburg suburbs, mainly inhabited by local African workers from the gold mining industry. Soveto was eventually annexed to Johannesburg, but has been separated as a residential area for blacks, who are not allowed to live in Johannesburg.

In Taiwan, some religious people and most media also refer to the body as a grandfather, grandfather or grandfather teacher, however, the word grandfather is abbreviated from the word anatomy. In medicine, criminal investigation and other fields, the word "grandfather" is usually used in geology and ecology, such as "biological remains," "animal remains," "plant remains," etc. The corpse will occur a series of corpse phenomena, which is a reference for inferring the time of death in criminal investigation.

The Macau Light Rapid Transit (Portuguese: Metro Ligeiro de Macau, MLM) is an urban rail transport system in Macau and the first railway in Macau. The first main line project was started in February 2012 and the first section of the railway was opened on 10 December 2019. Currently, the Macau Light Rail is operated by the fully owned subsidiary of the Hong Kong Railways (Macau). The Macau Line, which is 9.3 km long and consists of 11 stations, is the only railway that has been planned for Macau. The main line project was launched on 21 February 2012. In 1887, the Government of Australia and Portugal proposed to the then Qing dynasty government a railway project from Macau to Guangzhou, but due to the economic and political environment of the time, it did not materialize.

In 1924, during the Second Jilin War, Zhang Zongchang was appointed as the deputy commander of the 2nd Army of the Zhenwei Army and served in military service. Hu Jingyi (1878-1950), Chinese writer. He was born in Ba County, Chongqing Province, Sichuan Province. He was a general of the Chuang army and one of the early leaders of the Sichuan military clique. He was born into a family engaged in the salt industry and later joined the army. In 1901, in order to train the new army, Sichuan Province needed to bring in military scientists from abroad. Hu Jingyi was supported by the government of Sichuan Province to study in Japan, and along with his colleagues in Sichuan Province, he sent Zhou Dao Gong, Xu Xiao Gong, Hu Jingyi, Zhang Yi, Liu Hong Kui, Xu Haiqing, etc.

The Republic of Ghana, commonly known as Ghana, is a country in western Africa, the capital of Accra. Ghana is bordered by Ce d'Ivoire to the west, Burkina Faso to the north, Togo to the east, and the Gulf of Guinea to the south. The official English name is "Republic of Ghana", short for "Ghana". In Chinese, the Republic of China is referred to as "Republic of Ghana", short for "Ghana"; the People's Republic of China, Malaysia and Singapore are referred to as "Republic of Ghana", short for "Ghana". From the 3rd to the 4th centuries, it was part of the Ghanaian Empire; in the 13th century, the Akan, Mossi and others successively established kingdoms in the north and south; in 1471, Portuguese colonists invaded, plundered gold; the coast is called "Gold Coast".

In accordance with Article 13 of the Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Cultural Relics, which was adopted by the Thirty-third Session of the Standing Committee of the Ninth National People's Congress on October 28, 2002, the cultural relics administrative department under the State Council shall, among the cultural relics protection units at the provincial, municipal and county levels, select those with significant historical, artistic and scientific values that are determined to be the national key cultural relics protection units, or determine them directly, and submit them to the State Council for approval and promulgation.The scope of protection and records of the national key cultural relics protection units shall be submitted to the cultural relics administrative department of the people's governments of provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities directly under the Central Government for the record.

In 1907, he graduated from the fifth class of the Artillery Department of the Japanese Military Academy. In 1909, he returned to China. In 1911, he participated in the Zhejiang independence movement during the Xinhai Revolution. In 1912, he was appointed Minister of the Armed Forces of the Zhejiang Governor's Office and Head of the Army Primary School. In 1914, he was invited to Beijing to serve as a member of the Board of Directors of the Bureau of Administration. In 1916, Chen Yi went to Japan Army University for advanced studies and graduated from the first class. During the period in Japan, he was recognized by Japanese instructors and adopted a daughter, Yoshiko Kugetsu. Later, Yoshiko returned to China with Chen Yi, and changed her name to Yoshiyoshi Chen. Returned to China in 1919, he was appointed Vice-Adviser to the President's Office. Before and after 1920, he was appointed Chairman of the Zhejiang Provincial Industrial Bank. In October 1924, Zhejiang local people, including Sun Quanfang, went to Zhejiang, appointed Xia Chao as the governor of Zhejiang, appointed Chen Yi as the commander of the first division of the Zhejiang Army, Ge Keng-on as the chief of staff of the first division. In 1925, he was appointed General Commander of Xuzhou.

In the 14th and 15th centuries, Chinese fishermen and merchants came here to do business with the Sinhalese. During the Dutch rule, one of the four largest Sinhalese tribes, the 'Maatschappij', lived here. In the early days of the Dutch rule, the Maatschappij rebelled against the Dutch rule, and on July 13, 1629, the Maatschappij attacked and killed 52 Dutch soldiers while the Dutch East India Company soldiers were crossing the river to attack the pirates. However, at that time, the Dutch forces were only able to defend themselves and were unable to directly conquer the Maatschappij. The new commander-in-chief, Puttmans, was only able to kill the Maatschappij in November 1629 and watch over the Maatschappij. After the attack on the Maatschappij, the Maatschappij sought peace. In September 1635, the Maatschappij suffered an aerial assault, losing about 200 to 300 soldiers.

Therefore, extra care should be taken when using liquid nitrogen, avoiding direct contact with the skin. Wear protective clothing, such as freezing gloves, when filling. Avoid using cotton gloves, because cotton gloves absorb a large amount of liquid nitrogen through the hair phenomenon, which freezes the gloves and increases the likelihood of frostbite (even more dangerous than not wearing them). Liquid nitrogen volatilizes rapidly at room temperature, from liquid to gas. At the same time, the volume expands rapidly, and stored in a non-pressurised sealed container may cause an explosion. If stored in a non-pressurised bucket, do not store liquid nitrogen at room temperature in the sealed container. Nitrogen is an inactive substance, if stored in a sealed space, the nitrogen vaporized by liquid nitrogen will fill the entire space, slowly replacing oxygen in the air, reducing oxygen concentration. Nitrogen cannot replace oxygen as an oxidant used for respiration, and is therefore suffocating, so liquid nitrogen must be used in an open space.

The National Archives (TNA) is an administrative body under the Department of Justice of the United Kingdom. It was formed in 2003 by the amalgamation of four institutions, namely the Public Archives, the Royal Historical Manuscripts Board, the Public Information Office and the Royal Archives. The National Archives is located in Kew, Leeds, on the River Thames in Greater London. The building was opened in 1977 and was used by the Government for public records. The building was a hospital during World War I and was subsequently used by several government departments. The building is located near Kew Garden Station. Until its closure in March 2008, the Family Records Centre in Islington was operated by the National Archives and the Registry Office. The National Archives also has an office in Norwich and a "DeepStore" record storage centre in Winsford, Cheshire.

In astronomy, epochs are astronomical variables that serve as reference points for time, such as celestial coordinates or elliptical orbital elements of an object, which are subject to perturbation and change over time. These astronomical variables that change over time may include the ecliptic or equinox angle of an object, the intersection of an orbit with the reference plane, the direction of perihelion and distant sunspots or arcs, the size of the semi-major axis of an orbit, etc. In ancient Chinese calendars, epochs are the reference points. For celestial coordinates, the positions of other objects at other times can be calculated based on ages and the motion of the object. In the case of epochs, perturbations caused by other objects must be taken into account in order to calculate the epoch of another moment.

Gujarati ( Gujarati ) is one of the 22 official languages of India and 14 regional languages of the Indo-Iranian language family. It is also a minority language of Pakistan. It is spoken by some 46 million people worldwide, making it the 23rd largest language in the world. It is spoken by 45.5 million people in India, 150,000 people in Uganda, 100,000 people in Pakistan and 50,000 people in Kenya. Gujarati is the main language of the Gujarat State of India, the federal states of Dadra Nagar Haveli and Daman Dayu. It is also the language of the Gujarati community of Mumbai, and has a large number of Gujarati-speaking residents in North America and the United Kingdom. Gujarati is also the first language spoken by Mahatma Gandhi, the father of India, the father of Pakistan, Muhammad Ali Jinnah, and Shada Wallachan Patel (recognized as India's first iron minister).

South Australia (Thai: Klesan, Kbbu'. The name of South Australia in the literature, began to be seen in 1810 in Qing Jiaqing, at the time of its status as the southern part of Suzhou, it was called Da Nangao. In 1912, it was renamed South Australia, in 1932, it became a society, the name was Namao Society, the name of South Australia was accepted by everyone. During the Qing Dynasty, it belonged to the "back mountain" area, maintained the form of tribal society for a long time. After the opening of Taiwan, a small number of Europeans perceived South Australia as an ungoverned area, so they tried to establish a small colony in this vacuum area, and the Da Nangao incident occurred. At the end of the Qing Dynasty, the government of the Qing Dynasty severely cracked down on the policy of opening mountain guards, in 1874, the Qing army invaded the northern shore of South Australia Creek, the South Australian Taiya people rebelled. In 1890, Liu Ming sent troops to invade, burn the tribe, the Qing army robbed food and other supplies.

Stalinist architecture (Russian: Сталинский Ампир) is an architectural style developed and extensively used in the Soviet Union during the Stalinist era. It began in 1933 (as a symbol of the final design of the Soviet Palace) and ended in 1955 (the abolition of the Soviet Academy of Architecture). Since the 1940s, a large number of high-rise buildings in the Stalinist style have been built in the Soviet Union. This architectural style also had a great influence on the communist countries of Eastern Europe and the People's Republic of China, which existed in the 1950s. Buildings influenced by this style can still be seen everywhere today in the capitals of the former German Democratic Republic, such as East Berlin, the Polish capital Warsaw, Beijing in China, and Pyongyang in North Korea. Like the various artistic forms of the Soviet Union during the Stalinist era, architectural styles exhibit strong ideological characteristics and contribute to the "praise of the ideal social order of communism".

Taichung City (Chinese: Taichung Taichung; Taiwanese: Tâi-tiong-chhī; Hakka: Thòi-chûng-s) was a city under the jurisdiction of Taiwan Province from 1945 to 2010. Taichung City was incorporated into Taiwan Province in 1920. After the restoration of Taiwan in 1945, it became a provincial city. On December 25, 2010, Taichung City and Taichung County were merged to form Taichung City. Taichung City was also known as "Cultural City." Prior to the Qing Dynasty, Taichung City was an area inhabited by the Bazai and Babsa peoples of Pingpu ethnic group, mainly for hunting livestock. In the late Qing Dynasty, the main towns of central Taiwan were located in the semi-line (today's Changhua City), until 1890, when Fujian Taiwan Cruiser Liu Mingchuan (劉銘傳) established a Bagua-shaped castle pond and a large number of government buildings (currently the North Gate Tower and the Research Center) near the settlement of "Hazai-tou" (or "Hazai-tou", "Hazai-zu" or "Hazai-zu; between the present National Light Road to Taichung Road) on the southern side of Dongdaedong Street at the time, in preparation for the provincial assembly after the establishment of Taiwan Province.

The war was fought during the Victorian era of Britain, the Napoleonic era of France, and the Xianfeng period of the Qing dynasty of China. The two countries disagreed on their interpretation of the pre-existing treaties, and the Great Shimizu Division boarded the British ship "Aro" to hunt for pirates. Conflicts arose, triggering the Anglo-French Combined Forces Campaign (1856-1858). As a result, the two countries signed the Treaty of Tianjin in 1858, and the British sent diplomatic representatives to China, and the war was put on hold.259. After the First Opium War ended, Britain thought that it could quickly open up the Chinese market and make huge profits by virtue of the trade relations stipulated in the Sino-British Treaty of Nanjing. However, because China's self-sufficient natural economy remained dominant, so that foreign goods were often under-sold. At the same time, the rapid growth of the British opium trade with China also directly squeezed the sale of other industrial goods.

On February 24, 1984, the President of the Executive Council of the Republic of China, Mr. Sun Yun-sun, was seriously ill with a cerebral hemorrhage. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC; Arabic: الاتحاد الدولي لجمعيات الأحمرِ و Redلالِ ; originally known as the League of Red Cross Societies) is an international humanitarian organization that, together with the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and national associations (Red Cross or Red Crescent Societies), formed the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement.

In order to ensure the subsidence of the upper part of the 3rd line structure, it is the key point of the transfer node project. In the course of the construction, it is necessary to first treat the southern side of the unfinished earthwork wall to form a closed water stop, then digging the two side holes under the negative two-layer slab, the beam under the slab and the steel support to reduce the load on the column, then digging the middle guide hole to form a central base plate stress system to further reduce the load on the column, then layering the soil squares on both sides of the node, forming the side wall and part of the base plate, and finally digging the central soil squares in the node to complete the construction of the remaining structure. The 7th line track measurement introduced German-imported station gauges and track inspection instruments, adopted the most advanced domestic "high-speed CPIII" measurement technology, compared with the manual measurement technology, "high-speed CPIII" measurement technology is better to ensure the smoothness of the track, when the train travels in areas with high traffic and housing density, it can "seismic reduction and noise reduction", and the public will be more comfortable to ride.

Kruger Mpumalanga International Airport (IATA: MQP, ICAO: FAKN) is a civilian airport located 27 km northeast of Nilesputte, in the province of Ppumalanga, South Africa. Built in 2001, it replaced the smaller Nilesputte Airport. Currently, the airport serves mainly visitors to Kruger National Park. There are scheduled passenger flights to other South African cities and regional destinations. Most of the flights are to Johannesburg. Although the terminal building is small, it is almost entirely covered by a moss roof, making it the largest moss structure in Africa, measuring approximately 7,350 square metres.

In the Qing Dynasty, the number of governors was fixed, the composition stable and the jurisdiction fixed. At that time, the bureaucratic emissaries and the procuratorial emissaries administered finances and justice, and were subordinate to the governors, not to the head of a province. In official documents, "province" has become a customary term. Under various circumstances, "the compilation of the Survey of Geography is also called 'province'." Researchers point out that the Qing Dynasty Literature Survey and the Survey of Geography list eighteen provinces, indicating that the Qing government followed the actual recognition of "province" as the official title of the jurisdiction of 18 governors (including the concurrent governor-general). It marked the completion of the Qing government's construction of the eighteen provinces that evolved from the 18 governor-general jurisdiction in the late Qing Dynasty. After the establishment of the Republic of China, "province" became a legal unit of the first-level administrative district. When the Republic of China was established in 1912, the provinces inherited the old Qing Dynasty system, at that time there were 22 provinces in the country.

Robert Anthony Eden, KG, MC, PC, 1st Earl of Avon (12 June 1897 – 14 January 1977) was a British politician who served as Foreign Secretary during World War II and later as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in the 1950s. It is widely believed that he bore the greatest responsibility for the 1956 Suez Canal crisis. In 2004 (archived on the Internet Archive), Churchill won the most votes and Eden the least. Eden was born into a very conservative landowning family in West Auckland, Dalhousie County, with his father from the barony and his mother (Sybil Grey) from the famed Grey family in North Auckland.

Mammals or mammals is the generic term for the mammalian subfamily of vertebrates. Existing species mainly belong to the three evolutionary groups of the placenta (the vast majority), the sac and the pore. Unlike reptiles and birds of the same genus, which evolved in the late Carboniferous (about 300 million years ago), mammals have neocortex, fur, three hearing bones and mammalian glands.
