In March 1904, Tainan Hall Street Zhuangsha was renamed Tainan Hall. In May 1909, the name of the district under Tainan City's jurisdiction was changed from Tsuenna Street to East and West Districts and was replaced by K.E.P.D.N.; in October of the same year, the Taiwan Governor's Office abolished the original twenty halls and merged them into twelve halls. Tainan Hall merged Fengshan Hall and part of the Salt Water Harbor Hall (Mazu, Rokka, Xiaolong, North Gate Island, etc.) into Tainan Hall. The area covered by the hall directly under Tainan City's jurisdiction (present-day East, Central, West, North, South and Ninde Districts) and 12 halls in Wanli, Mazu, Xiaolong, North Gate Island, Rokka, Huangbao, Daimeichu, Guandi Temple, Agongdian, Nanzhuang, Tainan District Court was transferred from Tainan East Gate Street to the new hall building at Zhuang Yaqiao Street. In the same month, the Tainan South Hall branch office in Tainan was abolished. In May 1914, the Forestry Testing Laboratory of the Ministry of Agriculture established a transplantation testing office in Tainan Mountain and the second half of Flag Island to conduct transplantation tests on dry and sandy land.

Ejection is an effective way of releasing angular momentum in a disk system without losing too much mass. The most spectacular accretion disks found in nature are those of active galactic nuclei and quasars, which are thought to be massive black holes in the center of the galaxy. When matter enters the accretion disk, it follows a trajectory known as the Tendex line, which describes a spiral line inward. This is because particles friction and bounce back against each other in turbulence, causing frictional heating, thereby emitting energy, reducing the angular momentum of the particles, causing the particles to drift inward, thereby pushing the spiral inward. The loss of angular momentum is represented by a decrease in velocity; at slower velocities, the particles must adopt a lower orbit. When the particles fall to this lower orbit, part of their gravitational potential energy is converted into additional velocity, and the particles are accelerated.

The United Mexican States (Spanish:Estados Unidos Mexicanos), commonly known as Mexico (Spanish:México), is a sovereign federal republic in North America, bordering the United States in the north, the Pacific Ocean in the south and west, Belize, Guatemala and the Caribbean Sea in the southeast, the Gulf of Mexico in the east, the fifth largest country in the Americas and the fourteenth largest in the world. It has a total population of more than 128 million, the tenth largest in the world, the largest Spanish-speaking population in the world and the second largest in Latin America. Mexico is a federal state, comprising 32 states; its capital and largest city is Mexico City. Pre-Columbian Mexico was the birthplace of many advanced Central American civilizations, such as Olmec, Toltec, Teotihuacan, Zapotec, Maya and Aztec.

The Soviet Union signed the Treaty of Non-Aggression between the Soviet Union and the United Kingdom as a delaying tactic, and the anti-socialist Adolf Hitler sooner or later tore up the treaty. As a result, the Soviet Union began to transport large quantities of goods and equipment from parts of Europe to the far rear, creating favorable conditions for the subsequent Soviet war. However, Stalin was one step ahead, and he always believed that Germany would not attack the Soviet Union until it had captured Britain. On the morning of June 22, 1941, Germany launched a surprise attack against the Soviet Union with more than 3.7 million troops, 5,100 aircraft, 3,800 tanks and a large number of artillery pieces. Due to insufficient preparation for the war, the Soviet Red Army suffered heavy military losses. Afterwards, the Soviet battlefield became the main battlefield on the European continent, until June 6, 1944, when the Allies launched the Battle of Normandy. In 1945, the Allies, including the Soviet Red Army, occupied the entire territory of Germany, ending the war in Europe.

In 109 BC, the Han Dynasty established Yunnan County in the territory of present-day Xiangyun County. Due to the fact that there is no historical record of the Han Dynasty, there are many speculations about the origin of the name "Yunnan," so there are various theories about the origin of "Yunnan": from "south of the colorful clouds," from "the county in the south of the clouds," and the name of minority ethnic areas was changed. In the 3rd century BC, the Yunnan regime, the general Zhang Zhuang of Chu Province entered the Yunnan area, established Yunnan Province. In 221 BC, the Qin Dynasty reunified six provinces, established counties in the northeast of Yunnan, and opened a five-foot road from present-day Qujing to connect the mainland. In 109 BC, the Emperor Wu sent general Guochang to Yunnan to conquer the southwest barbarians, established Yizhou County and 24 counties, governed Yunnan County (present-day Jinning), opened a trade route to Myanmar and India, and sent Tang Meng to repair and expand the five-foot road, renamed "Southwest barbarian road." When the Han Dynasty conquered the southwest barbarians, it was found that there were merchants from "poison (India)" (today's Sindh province of Pakistan is called "Sindhu" in Sanskrit).

Drought refers to the absence of long-term rainfall or low rainfall at high temperatures in a certain area, resulting in a lack of water in the air and soil. Drought is mainly related to the occurrence of accidental or periodic decrease in rainfall. Considering human factors, the causes of human-induced drought are mainly as follows: (1) population growth, resulting in a gradual shortage of limited water resources. (2) forest plants are destroyed by humans, plants lose their water storage function, and groundwater is extracted, resulting in a reduction in groundwater and soil water. (3) human activities cause a large amount of water pollution, resulting in a reduction in water availability. (4) water is wasted. Drought is one of the most serious climatic disasters affecting human society. It has the characteristics of high frequency, long duration and widespread impact. The frequent occurrence and long-term persistence of drought not only cause huge losses to the social economy, especially agricultural production, but also cause a shortage of water resources, increased desertification, frequent dust storms and other adverse ecological and environmental impacts.

Formerly known as Taichung Normal School, which was founded in 1899 at Changhua Confucius Temple, it is one of the earliest Normal Schools in Taiwan. It was closed down in 1902 due to the unsuccessful development of primary education, and in 1923 Taichung Normal School was reopened on its current site. After the restoration of Taiwan, it was renamed Taiwan Provincial Taichung Normal School, and the Department of Fine Arts was added the following year, making it the earliest professional art education institution in Taiwan. The National Taichung University of Education currently has two campuses, all located on Minsheng Road, Taichung West District, respectively, as "School Headquarters" and "Excellent School District." There is an attached elementary school, "Chinese University of Science and Technology", which is one of the only two national primary schools in Taichung. The National Taichung University of Education currently has four faculties, respectively, as the College of Education, the College of Humanities, the College of Science, and the College of Management; there are 17 departments, 5 master's degree courses, 1 independent research institute, and 16 master's courses, 2 doctoral courses, and 13 master's degree courses attached to related departments.

The functions and powers of the local people's congresses are as follows: The people's congress system was established in September 1954 within the territory of the People's Republic of China, but the standing committees of the local people's congresses were not established at the same time. On May 17, 1979, Peng Zhen, Director of the Legislative Affairs Committee of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, submitted to the Central Government a report on whether the Law on the Organization of the People's Congresses at and Above County Levels and the People's Governments at All Levels had decided to abolish the Revolutionary Committee, restore the People's Committee and establish the standing committees of the people's congresses. Deng Xiaoping supported the establishment of the local people's congresses. On July 1, 1979, the second session of the five-year National People's Congress adopted the Resolution on Amendments to Certain Provisions of the Constitution of the People's Republic of China and the Law on the Organization of the Local People's Congresses and the Local People's Governments at and Above County Levels of the People's Republic of China, and decided to establish standing committees of the local people's congresses at and above the county level.

In 1921, the Communist Party of China was founded in Shanghai with the assistance of the Communist International, under Soviet instructions, the Communist Party of China and the Kuomintang concluded military agreements, cooperated against foreign enemies, and thus the Kuomintang received military assistance from the Soviet Union.In 1922, the Communist International recognized the Kuomintang as the core of the leadership of the Chinese National Revolution, formulated a strategy of development with the help of the Kuomintang, instructed members of the Communist Party of China to join the Kuomintang as individuals, in August, the Communist Party of China abandoned its rejection of the Kuomintang, agreed to members of the Communist Party of China to join the Kuomintang, but the Kuomintang must be reorganized according to democratic principles.28 Sun Yat-sen led the Northern Expedition of the National Revolutionary Army of the Kuomintang, established good relations with the Soviet Union in 1923, signed the Sun Yat-sen Declaration, established a pro-Russian policy, but at the same time determined that communism was not suitable for China.

Luyi County is a county under the jurisdiction of Zhoukou City, Henan Province, China. It is one of the directly administered counties of Henan Province, and is directly headed by the Henan Provincial Government in the social and economic fields. Luyi is the hometown of Laozi, with a land area of 1238 square kilometers and a population of about 1.2 million. The county government office in Xinyuan. Luyi specialty products include Songhe grain liquid, Guandong hemp tablets, test dog meat, Guandong moon cakes, Kongshu roast chicken, etc. Gourmet products include mastic paste, hot soup, Henan noodles, etc. The main attractions in the territory are the National 4A-class scenic spots Taiqing Palace and Ming Dao Palace. Other attractions include the Ming City Wall Site (the existing wall was rebuilt in 1369 AD by Han Ji County, and now only about 200 meters), Baiyunan, the site of the ancient battlefield of Qiao Shita, the site of Yuji Tomb (newly built there is Yuji Garden), Wuping City Site, Luyi City Site, Lunyi Tomb, Longxi Lady Tomb, Millennium Ginkgo Garden, Yong'an Temple, Wenchang Emperor Temple, City God Temple, Wuhe Provincial Wetlands Park, Huiji River National Wetlands Park, etc.

In September 1974, at the age of 13-14, Paul's grandfather died, and his mother fell ill shortly after attending her father's funeral and died of a cerebral hemorrhage two weeks later. His mother's death had a profound effect on him, and he wrote about her in many U2 songs, such as "Out of Control", "I Will Follow", "Tomorrow", "Lemon", "Mofo". He formed a secret music club called Lypton Village with several of his better friends at the time, including Guggi (formerly known as Fionan Hanvey), Gavin Friday (formerly known as Derek Rowen, both of whom were members of Virgin Prunes, another U2 band with whom he had a close relationship), and sought to get rid of the unpleasantness of life through music.

"If we continue to follow the inflexible educational system of the past, it will be difficult to cultivate creative young people, and in an unprecedented new era of science and technology, we really need to drastically amend the original education system." Traditional economics, with labor, land and capital as the three elements of production. "The fourth element - the entrepreneur." "The large-scale enterprise organization has acquired the leading position in the modern mode of production, the entrepreneur is not only the organizer of large-scale enterprise production and operation, but also the soul of the enterprise." (see "The entrepreneur and the entrepreneurial spirit" by Li Guoding) There are five principles of Chinese tradition: "Father and son have relatives, monarchs have righteousness, husband and wife have different, the old and young are ordered, friends have faith" (Monji Tenbun Gong), is the classical norm of monarch, father and son, brother, husband and wife, and friend relations.

Its subcutaneous fat layer is 8 cm thick, functioning like whale oil. The ivory of the true ivory is 5 m long and more curved than the normal ivory. Whether the shape and length of the ivory is adaptive is unknown, but it is suggested that it may have used the ivory to clear the snow from the ground in search of food. In addition, many specimens of the ivory have abrasions on the surface, and it is likely that many animals inhabited the ivory. It is generally assumed that the true ivory disappeared in Europe and southern Siberia 10,000 years ago, but new data show that it survived until 8,000 years ago. It also disappeared from northern Siberia a little later. Most true ivory died in the late Pleistocene, possibly due to climate change and/or hunting by humans. It has been studied that warm climate was a threat to the ivory, causing its numbers to decline significantly before humans appeared.

In 1919, he joined the Revolutionary Party of China, and after the abortion of the Northern and Southern People's Congresses, he went with Sun Yat-sen to Guangzhou as the Minister of Military Government and Transportation. In 1921, he was a member of the Presidential Council of Sun Yat-sen. After the outbreak of the Xinhai Revolution, Wang returned to China and went to Beijing to participate in the Union of the People's Republic of China organized by Zhang Binglin (Zhang Tai-yin), Cheng Deqing and Zhang Xian. After that, Wang joined the Unification Party and served as its secretary, and then ran to organize the provincial branch of the party in Guizhou. In March 1912, the Yunnan army, led by Tang Jiyao, occupied Guizhou, and was supported by Liu Hsing-jeong. Wang served as the secretary of the Republican Party and the Progressive Party. In 1914, he participated in the political conference on behalf of Guizhou. In 1915, Yuan Shikai proclaimed Emperor Zhang against Wang and the Progressive Party members of Guizhou, including Dai Xian.

By the end of the 15th century, the Ottoman Empire had completely conquered Serbia, beginning a five-century reign. On 28 June 1914, the Serbian nationalist Gavrilo Princesp shot seven shots in the streets of Sarajevo with a Brenning M1900 automatic pistol, killing Franz Ferdinand, Crown Prince of Austria-Hungary, and his wife Sophie during a visit to Sarajevo. On 28 July, Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia, leading to the outbreak of World War I. Serbia successfully resisted three Austria-Hungary invasions at the end of 1914, and in 1915, allies (including Austria-Hungary, the German Empire, and the Kingdom of Bulgaria) jointly launched an offensive against Serbia, capturing the entire territory.

Siti Otari (1921; divorced 1923) Inggit Garnasih (1923; divorced 1943) Famavati (1943; divorced 1956) Hartini (1953; divorced 1970) Kartini Manoppo (1959; divorced 1968) Dewey Sukarno (1962; divorced 1970) Haryati (1963; divorced 1966) Yurike Sanger (1964; divorced 1968) Heldy Djafar (1966; divorced 1969) Soekarno (Indonesian pronunciation: ; born Koesno Sosrodihardjo; 6 June 1901 – 21 June 1970) was an Indonesian politician, leader of the National Independence Movement, and the first President of Indonesia.

Hydrogen (pronounced qīnɡ) is a chemical element with the chemical symbol H, atomic number 1, atomic mass 7000100794000000000♠1.00794 u, and is the lightest element in the periodic table. Hydrogen (H) is the most common chemical substance in the universe, accounting for 75% of the total mass of gravity. Isotopic hydrogen is the main component of main-sequence stars. The most common isotope of hydrogen is plutonium (the name is rarely used, symbolized H1{\displaystyle {\ce {^1H}}}), which contains one proton and no neutrons; natural hydrogen also contains a very small amount of the isotope deuterium (H2{\displaystyle {\ce {^2H}}} or D{\displaystyle {\ce {D}}}), which contains one proton and one neutron.

Manihot esculenta, also known as cassava, is a genus of cassava native to South America. Manihot esculenta is a shrub, with fleshy long columnar roots; erect stems with milky, interleaved leaves, palmate 3-9 deep fissures, split lanceolate to long elliptical lanceolate; apical or axillary open cone inflorescences, single flowers, male and female on the same inflorescence, female on top, male underneath, no petals; spherical plumage, with six ribs. plant inflorescencesFloor cross section1Manihot esculenta - Museum specimen The roots of the cassava are edible after being peeled and cooked, so many inhabitants of tropical and subtropical regions grow cassava, and the resulting flour is called tapioca (also called cassava flour or raw flour).

This is a list of current full-time deputy secretaries of the provincial administrative district committees of the Communist Party of China. Due to the reduction in the number of deputy secretaries, except for Xinjiang and Tibet, there are only two deputy secretaries of the Party committees of other provinces and municipalities in mainland China. One deputy secretary is the head of the government of the respective administrative district, and the other is usually called a full-time deputy secretary. Currently, the full-time deputy secretaries of Beijing, Hainan, Sichuan, Shaanxi and Qinghai are in a state of vacancy, and the time when the vacancy began is listed in the list. Excluding the village of Losangjiang, the longest-serving deputy secretary of the Party committee of the Tibet Autonomous Region, Zhuang Yan, since June 13, 2017 (2017-06-13), has been in office for 5 years 173 days. The shortest-serving deputy deputy secretaries of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee, Deng Shuming and Yang Weidong, since July 19, 2022 (2022-07-19), have been in office for 137 days.

) One of the myths of Scorpio, the son of Apollo the sun god, Phoebus, was born beautiful and sexy, so proud of himself, always arrogant and rude, and had a strong personality that he inadvertently offended many people. One day, someone told Phoebus, "You are not the son of the sun god!" He laughed and went away. How could the strong Phoebus swallow this, and asked his mother, "Am I not the son of Apollo?" But no matter how the mother repeatedly assured him that he was the son of Apollo, Phoebus still did not believe his mother, and said, "Your man is the son of Zeus, and he is in a high position. If you still do not believe him, ask the sun god Apollo himself!"

In 1711, the Portuguese king decided to upgrade Europa to a city. The city has a mix of well-preserved Portuguese colonial and contemporary urban architecture, and in modern architecture, the government strives to preserve the blend of new and historic architecture. The 18th and 19th-century churches, decorated with gold and Aladian sculptures, gradually developed Europa into a tourist destination. In 1789, a failed attempt at independence from Portuguese colonialism – the Minas Conspiracy – took place in Europa, with the leader hanged as a threat to the revolutionaries. In 1876, the Escola de Minas was founded. This school provided technical support for Brazil's subsequent discovery of new minerals. Europa served as the seat of the state government of Minas Gerais from 1822 to 1897, when government demand exceeded the capacity of the valley town, and the state government moved the seat to Belo Horizonte.

The Chinese official rifle, a Chinese licensed production version of the Mauser M24 rifle, uses 7.92×57mm pointed Mauser ammunition. Manufactured in 1935 by Gong County Arsenal (Works No. 11 of the Ordnance Department), it became a production rifle of the National Revolutionary Army. Later, it gradually replaced the Hanyang Type 88 rifle produced by various military factories. The Chinese official rifle production originated from a decision made at the National Revolutionary Army Production Weapons Conference in 1933. This conference mainly solved the serious problem of weapons in the National Revolutionary Army at the time, the meeting decided to adopt the standard Mauser M24 rifle, compared to the traditional long barrel rifles of the time, on the basis of the Mauser Gew 98 rifle, the concept of a 600mm short barrel carbine instead of a 740mm long barrel), the bullets were reduced logistical burden along with the domestic long-term stable production of 7.92×57mm Mauser ammunition; In 1934, the National Government Treasury ordered 10,000 M24 equipment from the German Mauser Company for the army requirements of the Tax Police Corps, through which the Ordnance Department obtained technical data from Mauser through the then Minister of Finance, Confucius Xiangxi.

A personal computer (PC; commonly referred to as a computer) is a computer that is suitable for personal use in many ways, such as size, performance, and price, and that is controlled directly by the end user. It is relative to large computers, such as batch processing computers or time-sharing systems, that are generally operated simultaneously by many people. From desktop computers (or desktop computers), laptops, to small notebooks and tablet computers, smartphones, and supercomputers, it belongs to the range of personal computers. On November 3, 1962, the New York Times reported the first use of the word "personal computer" in a related article.

In ancient China, there were also post roads. In terms of distance, the ideal way of connecting two places is straight line. However, in practice, it is necessary to take into account the route of the road, the level of the road network, and the influence of the actual geographical features and the original layout of the city. In addition, the design of the road should take into account mainly the width of the road, the site, the route, the maximum traffic volume and the speed of travel, and the appropriate turning radius. The road should also direct traffic to tunnels and bridges (in the design of transport engineering, the position of structures such as tunnels and bridges is better than the position of the local route of the road, so the route of the road should be transferred to the position of the bridge culvert tunnel). The width and depth (here referring to the height or depth of the road foundation) should also meet the requirements of the expected traffic flow and the weight of the means of transport.

In 1915, Yuan Shikai Hong declared the emperor, internally sealed Lu Rongting as the first rank marquis, Lu Rongting and the former Guizhou faction within this dissatisfaction. Lu Rongting on behalf of Guangxi, with the Yunnan army governor Cai Keng telegraphed the whole country to Yuan, launched the Yuan War of Protecting the State. In May, the southwest provinces organized the Protective Military Council, sent troops to attack Hunan controlled by the North Sea warlords. The failure of the war was a major blow to Yuan Shikai. On June 6, 1916, Yuan Shikai died of illness, Li Yuan Hong succeeded. The Protective War ended, the Protective Military Council was dissolved. Li Yuan Hong appointed Lu Rongting as Guangdong Governor in the name of the central government, but the former Guangdong Governor Long Jiguang did not want to resign. Lu Rongting sent Mo Rongxin, Ma Ji, Tan Ho Ming led the Guizhou army to attack Guangdong, defeated Long Jiguang, Guangdong became the former Guizhou faction. At this time, the Beijing government was controlled by the provincial prime minister Anhui warlord Dan Qi Rui, Li Yuan Hong overthrew. Dan repeatedly claimed to unite the country by force, causing the resentment of the southwest provinces.

Coordinates: 22°39′56′′N 120°30′17′′E / 22.665566°N 120.504637°E / 22.665566; 120.504637 National Pingtung University (NPTU) is a national university located in Pingtung, Taiwan. It was founded on August 1, 2014 by the merger of National Pingtung University of Education and National Pingtung College of Commerce and Technology. Pingtung University has four campuses, three of which are in Pingtung City and one in Chengcheng Town; a total of seven colleges and one experimental elementary school. Pingtung University was founded as the Pingtung Normal School of Taiwan Governor’s Office in April 1940 and the National Pingtung Specialized School of Commerce in 1991.

During the Heian period, Japan developed Tendai and Shingon Esoteric Buddhism through two envoys to Tang Dynasty China in 804 and 838 (not completed in 894). After the abolition of envoys to Tang Dynasty China in 894, Japan began to develop Japan's unique nationalistic culture. Usually, Japanese history places the Heian period at the end of ancient times, but recently it has been increasingly viewed as the beginning of the Middle Ages, so the Heian period can be understood as a transitional period in the transition from ancient Japan to the Middle Ages. In recent years, the view that the Insei period (1086 afterwards) established the Shoen koryo system (Japanese: shoen koryo system) as the beginning of the Middle Ages has also gradually become a dominant view. Japanese politics in the early Heian period The revision or addition of parts of the Ritsuryo politics of the centralized Nara period, basically still inherited the Ritsuryo system. However, because the Ritsuryo system was difficult to implement in accordance with the actual situation, the bunden system under the Ritsuryo system gradually collapsed in the Nara period, the land gradually privatized, and was controlled by the nobility, temples and shrines, but at this time the central government could still levy taxes on the land controlled by the nobility, temples and shrines.

This is where the mythical story of "White Maiden's Floating Temple" takes place. The legend of Liang Hongyu's drum-fighting with gold soldiers also takes place. This temple has been running the Jinshan Buddhist Academy since 1995. Jinshan is located about 2 kilometers northwest of the city of Zhenjiang, at an altitude of 43.7 meters and covers an area of 10 hectares. Jinshan originally stood on an island in the middle of the Yangtze River. In the Tang Dynasty, Zhang Yuan's poem "You can see in the shadow of trees, the sound of bells can be heard on both sides of the Yangtze River" is a portrait of Jinshan. Due to the changes in the Changjiang River, the Yangtze River was rerouted, and during the Gwangxu years, Jinshan gradually connected with the southern shore. In that year, Dongpo Kushi wrote "Do not go to Jinshan, the clear breeze half sail ear" and the water scenery evolved into a land-based victory. "A donkey ride on the mountain" became a wonderful enjoyment for those who visited the mountain at the end of the Qing Dynasty and the beginning of the Qing Dynasty. Qing Kangxi came to Jinshan in autumn of 1687.

In the 1960s and 1970s, China attempted to develop China's first manned spacecraft, the Dawn I, which was named the "714 Project." The design of the Dawn I resembled that of the American Gemini spacecraft, and was a two-seater, producing design sketches and full-size models. However, because of the weakness of the integrated national power in the 1970s, and the low level of industrial manufacturing and related processes, the 714 Project was ordered to be suspended and eventually cancelled in 1971. On March 3, 1986, with the situation stabilizing, four scientists, Wang Dahong, Wang Ganchang, Yang Jiaying and Chen Fangyong, presented to the Central Committee proposals and ideas for the overall tracking of the world's high-tech development and the formulation of China's high-tech development plan.

Taneh was born on October 30, 1678, at Yonghe Palace in Forbidden City. He was the fourth son of Emperor Kangxi and his mother was Empress Xiaogongren. Emperor Kangxi described his childhood as "uncertain" and asked Taneh to remove it in 1701. Emperor Kangxi warned him to be "quiet and patient." Taneh travelled around the world with Emperor Kangxi at an early age. Emperor Kangxi appointed Taneh as Belle in March 1698. Emperor Kangxi appointed Taneh as Concubine of Prince Yong in August 1711. Emperor Kangxi deposed Emperor Yong again in 1712 and no longer appointed Taneh as Crown Prince. The battle for the throne became even more fierce. Emperor Kangxi ascended to the throne as Emperor Yongzheng on November 20, 1721.

Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Turkmenistan became an independent state. On 12 December 1995, the United Nations officially recognized Turkmenistan as a permanent neutral state. President of Turkmenistan Saparmurat Niyazov became a lifetime president in December 1999, exercising dictatorial rule. On 26 August 2005, at the Kazan Conference, he announced his downgrading to associate member of the Commonwealth of Independent States. During his tenure, Niyazov was revered as Turkmenbashi, he promoted personal worship in the country, amended the country's constitution from 1994, gradually expanded his presidential powers, was granted indefinite presidential powers in 1999; when the ancient Roman dictator Julius Caesar changed the names of the 12 months—his name was January, his mother's name was April, and so on. In February 2005, Niyazov announced that he would relinquish his lifetime presidential status and that the next presidential elections would be held in 2010, while Niyazov himself died on 21 December 2006 from a sudden cardiac arrest, aged 67.

Within three days, 20,000 people left the post and returned to Guangzhou. Students from all schools also went on strike. In Guangzhou, Chinese workers in the Shaan Ying Concession Territory, also responded on June 21, refusing to provide services to British traders and consulates. At that time, the National Government of Guangzhou was under the Communist regime of the Soviet Union. Under the umbrella of the Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China under the name of the Kuomintang, large demonstrations were held in all areas of Guangzhou. Attendees included groups from Hong Kong and Macao provinces, private and public schools, business groups, peasant groups and the Huangpu Student Army, Cantonese army, Xiang army, police force, etc., with hundreds of thousands of people. The meeting hall was divided into three parts: the industrial and agricultural meeting hall was presided over by Tan Pingshan (cross-party activists); the academic and business meeting hall was presided over by Wu Chaozhi and Zou Ru; and the military meeting hall was presided over by Wang Jiewei.

The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation was founded on 8 December 1985 as a platform for promoting South Asian civil friendship, trust and understanding by the governments of Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. On 13 November 2005, it accepted Afghanistan as a member. Burma, Mauritius, Australia, the People's Republic of China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the European Union, the United States and Iran became observers. The 12th South Asian Summit, held in Islamabad, Pakistan, on 6 January 2004, first proposed the concept of a South Asian Free Trade Area.

Folk art is a type of art. It refers to the art and handicrafts that are closely related to a specific cultural context or community, and that are guided by traditional methods or principles, including painting, ceramics, textiles, sculpture and other forms of art. The meaning is somewhat similar to that of handicrafts, but more in the direction of simplicity. Folk art, from the point of view of folklore, refers to the creations that are made in the daily life of the little people who fight. Thus, the papercutting paintings of the country aunt, the sculptures of the cows of the neighbourhood uncle for the children, the drawings of the streets that attract the children, are all within the scope of this art category. Folk art can also be called folk art, but the scope of folk art is wider. The word art is narrower, focusing on the development of objects. Thus, the technique of making a gyroscope is considered folk art, but the decoration, shape, etc. of the gyroscope itself, even if it is one of folk art in general, folk art is different from "craftsmanship", that is, the creations of untrained artists, but not necessarily with a specific cultural community.

In September 1928, he was promoted to brigade commander of the 32nd Infantry Brigade of the 11th Division, and the following year he was appointed deputy commander of the 5th Division of the newly formed division. During the Great Plains War in 1930, he was promoted to brigade commander of the 2nd Central Instructors' Brigade after the reorganization of the division, and fought under the command of Zhang Zhi in the war. He was promoted to brigade commander of the 2nd Brigade of the division for his military achievements. The following year, he was promoted to brigade commander of the 4th Division of the 11th Brigade, and took part in the siege of Shiyou San in Hebei Province. In 1932, the Guan Department was transferred to the Su District of Oyuan and Anhui Province, and participated in the 4th Siege of the Red Army of Workers and Peasants of China, and fought fierce battles in succession with Zhang Jihoon and Chen Gang. Later, the Red Fourth Front was forced to abandon the Su District of Oyuan and Anhui Province, and he was promoted to brigade commander of the 25th Division for his military achievements. In March 1933, Guan Feng was ordered to lead the Department northwards to assist Song Zhe Yuan's Department in the fight against the Japanese Army, participated in the Great Wall Campaign, and during the battle, the Guan family led a regiment to the front, was seriously wounded, and was forced to withdraw from the battlefield. After the war, he was awarded the Order of the Blue Sky and White Sun.

Proxima Centauri is a star in the constellation Centaurus, the third star of the Alpha Centauri triad, also known as Alpha Centauri C in the Iberian nomenclature, the nearest star to the Sun (4.22 light-years away), and a red dwarf. It was discovered by the Scottish astronomer Robert Innis in 1915 in South Africa, when he was director of the Joint Observatory in Johannesburg. Red dwarfs are usually very faint and invisible to the naked eye, with the exception of Proxima Centauri. It has an apparent magnitude of 11 and an absolute magnitude of 15.5, which is very faint. If observed from the other two stars of the Alpha Centauri triad, it would be 4.5 magnitudes. A visual difference of 772.33 ± 2.42 milliseconds, measured by the European astronomical satellite Hipparcos, estimates that Proxima Centauri is about 4.22 light-years away from Earth, or 270,000 times the distance from Earth to the Sun (AU, astronomical unit).

The United Kingdom has been a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council since 1945. It is also a member of the Commonwealth, the G-7, the G-20, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the World Trade Organization. The earliest evidence of human existence in the United Kingdom today dates back to about 780,000 years ago in England, and the oldest known primitive human bones found in England date back to 500,000 years ago. Modern humans inhabited the area in the late Paleolithic, and permanent settlements were established within the last 6,000 years. Today's southern part of Britain, including much of England and Wales, was once a province of the Roman Empire. After the end of the Roman Empire, the Germanic peoples began to migrate to the British Isles, England entered the Anglo-Saxon period, and Christianity began to spread to the United Kingdom during this period.

They also gained the approval of the then prefectural governor Yuan Guoqin, and the admission was supervised by the headmaster of the Torao Agricultural School, Wang Anjun, who admitted nearly 400 students. Later, the Education Department of the Office of the Chief Executive of the Taiwan Provincial Government considered that China was an agricultural country and it was not appropriate to suspend the agricultural school, and demanded the establishment of a separate elementary school. Therefore, on April 20, 1946, the old site of the Torao Ordinary School was established as "Tainan County Torao Elementary School" (Chinese: 虎尾初中). In August 1949, the Taiwan Provincial Government Education Department ordered the Torao Junior High School and the nearby Taiwan Provincial Torao Girls' Secondary School to be merged, called "Taiwan Provincial Torao Secondary School", with the former Torao Girls' Secondary School headmaster Chen Dong-yong as the headmaster, the former Torao Girls' Secondary School as the headquarters and girls' section, the former Torao Junior High School as the boys' section, and Liu Keqiang as the branch headmaster. In August 1950, the Education Department considered that the boys and girls' sections were too far apart, so the school headquarters was restored as "Taiwan Provincial Torao Girls' Secondary School", Chen Dong-yong returned as the headmaster of the school, and separated the boys' section separately, established "Taiwan Provincial Torao Secondary School" (Chinese: 虎中), and Pa Ling Xiaofen as the acting headmaster.

In the past, the main ethnic groups of Hsinchu and Miaoli County were Hakka, Hsinchu City and Miaoli Sea Line were Minnan inhabitants of Taiwan, Taoyuan City represented the "North Minnan Cantonese"; but in recent years, due to the rapid development of industrial and commercial activities, the population of the outer cities has increased, the composition of the ethnic groups has become increasingly complex, and the geographical distinction between traditional ethnic groups is gradually being leveled.

David Dacko (French: ; 24 March 1930 – 20 November 2003) was the first President and Prime Minister of the Central African Republic (August 14, 1960 – January 1, 1966). Before the formal independence of Central Africa from the French colonies, his cousin, Barthelemy Boganda, founded the Movement for the Social Development of Black Africa and served as President (Prime Minister) of the Autonomous Government of the Central African Republic within the French Community. He was Minister of the Interior, Economy and Trade. After Boganda's death in the air disaster, he won a dispute with Abel Gomba and became President of the Autonomous Government. After independence, he was President of the Provisional Government of the Republic, elected the first President of the Republic, and was overthrown by Ivory Coast's Bokassa. First arrested, then released, he served as the President's private adviser. Bokassa was known as the Empress, who succeeded him as the Emperor's private adviser.

In 1937, the Ordnance Department, under the leadership of Director Yu Dawei, also formulated the "Standards for the Application of Materials for the Chinese Formal Rifle," which included a complete list of manufacturing drawings, requirements material standards, and processing techniques. This was the first Chinese rifle to be manufactured without the assistance of foreign technicians since the Sino-Japanese trade movement, so that later generations regarded the Chinese Formal Rifle as the first Chinese rifle to adopt uniform specifications, and the situation of China's military weapons complexity began to change during the warring factions.

In the 1946 reorganization plan, the 2nd Regiment was reorganized into the 1st Brigade 1st Regiment in April 1946. In September 1946, it was annihilated at Uksan. The successive commanders of the regiment were Chiang Dingwen, Yan Liai, Wen Zhiwen, Li Yannian, Tang Yunshan, Liao Yong, Yang Dingnan, Yang Jie, Deng Hongyi, Wu Jun, Wang Yawu. Later rebuilt. In September 1925, Chiang Kai-shek again occupied Dongjiang with the support of the Southwest clique, threatening the Guangzhou National Government.23. In January 1926, Chiang Kai-shek resigned as the commander of the army, Ho Ying-chin succeeded as the commander, Wang Bailing as the deputy commander, Chiang Bai-shing as the chief of staff, and Zhou En as the head of the political department.23. Cheng Daqun took over the command of the 1st Division. On February 26, the 2nd Division commander Wang Maogong was dismissed, and Liu Qian took over. Soon after, Cheng Daqun and Wang Bailing met. In March, Chiang Kai-shek forced members of the Chinese Communist Party to withdraw from the 1st Army of the National Revolutionary Army through the "Zhongshan Ship" incident, and Deng Wenda took over the head of the political department.

The Sixth Army of the National Revolutionary Army is a military-level unit of the National Revolutionary Army. The Sixth Army was formed five times in history: 1926, 1929, 1938, 1945, and 1948. Before the 1937 war, the main use of this number was for local forces, until the death of the Korean Resistance in 1938, this unit was officially centralized after the third reorganization; the Sixth Army participated in many major battles in the war, but its military achievements were not significant. In January 1926, the Jiangxi Xiang Army was reorganized into the Sixth Army of the National Revolutionary Army, subordinated to the 17th, 18th and 19th Divisions (formerly the Army of the O, the Guards Army, the Army of the Chaomei), commander Chengyu, party representative and head of the Political Department Lin Zuhan. In July 1926, the Sixth Army participated in the Northern Expedition, fighting in northern Hunan and southern Hubei. In mid-September, the National Revolutionary Army attacked Nanchang, the Sixth Army was disbanded.

The main city of Xi'an still retains the complete walls and gates of the Ming Dynasty, the moat, the bridge, the corner tower, the urn castle, the archery tower and other facilities. The city and its surroundings are scattered with a large number of ancient cultural relics such as the Qin Dynasty Mausoleum, the Hanyang Mausoleum, the Han Chang'an City Site, and the Tang Dynasty Ming Palace Site. It is of great archaeological research value. Geographically and transportationally, Xi'an is located in the middle of the Guanzhong Wei River Plain plain, the largest tributary of the Yellow River, the Wei River flows from the north side of the city from the southwest to the northeast, the north and the west also have rivers such as the Xi'an River, the Xi'an River and the Jin River south of the northern slope of the Qinling Mountain.

After the fall of the Qin Dynasty, in 314 BC, the Qin Dynasty established the Jiaoyang Garrison District, which belonged to the Nanhai County. Established the Jiaoyang County by Emperor Hanwu in 111 BC, and controlled the areas of present-day Chaoshan, Meizhou and Minnan, such as Longxi and Zhangpu. In 331 AD, the Eastern Jin Dynasty established the Emperor Xian and divided Jiaoyang County into four counties: Haiyang, Chaoyang, Haining and Sui'an. After a few years of abolition, Jiaoyang County was established in 1140 AD. After the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Jiaoyang County was successively subordinated to the Chaoshan District, Dongguan Administrative District, Shantou District, and Shantou City. The local dialect of Jiaoyang County is the Chaozhou dialect, and the northern and western dialects are Hakka dialects. Before the establishment of Meizhou City (Mezhou Region) in July 1983, eight communes in the northern Hakka dialect areas of Jiaoyang County were divided into Fengshun County.

The Earth, the Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, and other planets' crusts are largely composed of ivory, and the planets' crusts have more incompatible components than their mantle. The Earth's crust refers to a thin crust composed mainly of ivory, metamorphic rock, and sedimentary rock between the Earth's surface and the Moho interface. It is part of the lithosphere, with an average thickness of 17 kilometres, beneath the crust is the mantle, and the upper mantle is composed largely of olivine (a rock much denser than ordinary rock). The line of demarcation between the crust and the mantle is called the Moho discontinuity. The crust accounts for only 0.2% of the Earth's mass and is structurally divided into continental and marine crusts.

Chiang Min-young (1930 - June 6, 2012), a citizen of Wu County, Jiangsu Province, a politician of the People's Republic of China. Studied mechanical engineering at Shanghai Institute of Technology from 1947 to May 1950. Between May 1950 and 1952, he was a technician at the 4O1 plant of the Northeast Industrial Administration, deputy director of the plant, director of the plant's basic construction department, deputy director of the plant's engineering department, vice-president of the plant's trade union, vice-president of the plant's technical school. Between 1952 and 1955, he studied at the Fushun Russian language training course of the Northeast Industrial Administration, trained at the Ulaanbaatar Aluminum Plant of the Soviet Union, was deputy director of the Technical Unit, deputy director of the plant's workshop, deputy director of the plant's workshop. Between 1955 and 1966, he was deputy director of the factory of the State-run 1O1 plant, deputy director of the plant's workshop, director of the plant's innovation department, deputy director of the test production workshop, deputy commander of the plant's production command department.

The Affiliated Zhongli Senior High School of National Central University (CLHS), also known as Zhongli Middle School, Zhongli High School, Zhongli Middle School, Zhongli Middle School, is located in Zhongli District, Taoyuan City, Taiwan, adjacent to the National Central University and Zhongli Night Market. It was originally established in 1940 as the "Zhongli Household Administration Girls' School". Zhongli Shrine was originally built on October 15, 1939, but after 1945, Zhongli Shrine on the top of Zhongli Mountain was abolished, and Zhongli Middle School was established on the same site.

During the War of Resistance against Japan, he served as Vice-Chairman of the Central Military Commission, Commander-in-Chief of the Eighteenth Army Group and Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Second War Area. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, he was the Commander-in-Chief of the People's Liberation Army and, together with Mao Zedong, commander of the Communist Party of China. After the founding of the People's Republic of China, he successively served as Vice-Chairman of the Central People's Government, Secretary of the Disciplinary Inspection Committee of the CPC Central Committee, Vice-Chairman of the People's Republic of China, Vice-Chairman of the CPC Central Committee, and so on. In 1959, he was elected Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. During the Cultural Revolution, he was shocked. He died in Beijing on July 6, 1976. During the Northern Ocean Government, he was awarded the Order of the Five, the Order of the Silver Tiger, the rank of Lieutenant General of the Army. During the War of Resistance against Japan, he was awarded the rank of General of the National Revolutionary Army by the National Government, and after the war, he was awarded the Medal of Victory in the War of Resistance. At the beginning of the founding of the People's Republic of China, he was awarded the rank of Marshal of the People's Republic of China in 1955 and was awarded the Order of the Eighth Rank, the Order of Independence and Freedom, and the Order of Liberation.

Vilko Velev Chervenkov (Bulgarian: Валко Велев Червенков, September 6, 1900 – October 21, 1980) was a Bulgarian communist politician, who served as General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Bulgaria from 1949 to 1954 and as Chairman of the Council of Ministers (Prime Minister) from 1950 to 1956. During his rule, Bulgaria was a model of Stalinism, rapid industrialization, collectivization and mass persecution of political opponents. Chervenkov was born in Zagreb, Bulgaria, in 1919 he joined the activities of the Communist Youth Group and worked as a newspaper editor. He participated in the anti-fascist armed uprising in September 1923, which failed and was sentenced to death by the Royal Military Court, but was allowed to emigrate to the Soviet Union.

The Central and South China Administrative Committee was the representative organ of the Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China in the Central and South China Administrative Region between 1953 and 1954. It is located at 36 Jiefang Park Road, Hankou. On January 21, 1953, the Central People's Government established the Central and South China Administrative Committee in accordance with the Decision of the Central People's Government on Changing the Organization and Mandate of the People's Government of the Great Administrative Region (Military and Political Committee), which was formed from the former Military and Political Committee of the People's Republic of China and was established as the delegated organ representing the Central People's Government in leading and supervising the work of local people's governments in the South China region. Its seat is still in Wuhan City, and its districts include Wuhan City, Guangzhou City, Hubei Province, Henan Province, Hunan Province, Jiangxi Province, Guangdong Province, and Guangxi Province. On November 7, 1954, the Central People's Government in accordance with the Decision of the Central People's Government on Repealing the Organization of the First Level of the Great Administrative Region and Merging Certain Provinces and Cities, the Central and South China Administrative Committee announced the repeal of the Central and South China Administrative Committee, and each province was placed under the direct jurisdiction of the Central Government, while Wuhan City was placed under the jurisdiction of Hubei Province.

From its known distance, its actual diameter is estimated to be about one-seventh of the Sun's, or 1.5 times that of Jupiter. It has a mass of about one-eighth of the Sun's, or 150 times that of Jupiter. Its age of formation is the same as that of Alpha Centauri A and B, about 485 million years ago, slightly earlier than that of the Sun. However, because it is only slightly larger than the minimum mass required for hydrogen fusion, the rate of fusion is slow and unstable, so astronomers estimate its lifespan to be several billion years or more. Neighboring stars with active chromosome activity, the emission of which can be observed in the X-ray wavelength of its chromosome, belong to the typical flare star (variant star named V645 Centauri); observations of changes in its chromosome at ultraviolet wavelengths indicate that it has a rotation period of about 31 days. Data measured by the Hubble Space Telescope in the 1990s indicate that Neighboring stars should have an unobserved faint companion.

The National and South International University has five faculties, a total of 22 bachelor's degree programs, 35 master's degree programs, 14 doctoral programs, seven university-level research centers, five institute-level research centers, and two affiliated institutions and several interdisciplinary programs. cumulatively, cumulatively, there are more than 60 societies, including service, fraternity, academic, musical, sports, and autonomous societies. Students can engage in various societies in the Student Activity Center or organize competitions, performances, campfires can engage in large-scale activities such as camping, roasting, and so on.

The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (Arabic: أردنّ ), commonly known as Jordan, is a Middle Eastern country located in Western Asia, north of Syria, east of Iraq, south of Saudi Arabia, west of Israel and Palestine. Its capital is Amman. The Dead Sea lies on the western border of Jordan, and the Red Sea lies to the southwest of the pole. Strategically, Jordan is at the crossroads of Eurasia and Africa. The capital Amman is the most populous city in Jordan and is also the economic, political and cultural center. Jordan's name derives from the Jordan River to the northwest of its border. The name of the Jordan River may have evolved from the Shia word "Yarad", meaning "downstream". Historically, the present-day region of Jordan has been called the Transjordan, meaning "crossing the Jordan River", which refers to the east bank of the Jordan River.

Wang Qishan (Chinese: 王岐山; pinyin: Wáng Qishan; born July 19, 1948) is a senior economist from Qingdao, Shandong Province. He graduated from the History Department of Northwestern University and holds the title of Senior Economist. He is one of the leading leaders of the Communist Party of China and the People's Republic of China. He is the current Vice-President of the State of China. He is a leader at the state level and enjoys political treatment at the Standing Committee of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China. He ranks second only to Han Zheng, the first Deputy Prime Minister of the State Council. He was a member of the Standing Committee of the 18th Politburo of the Communist Party of China (ranked sixth), a secretary of the Central Commission for Disciplinary Inspection, the head of the Central Inspection Working Group, and the head of the Pilot Working Group of the Central Commission for Deepening the Reform of the National Supervisory System. He joined the Communist Party of China in February 1983. He was a member of the Standing Committee of the 18th Politburo of the Communist Party of China, a substitute member of the 15th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, a member of the 16th to 18th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, a member of the 17th and 18th Politburo of the Communist Party of China, a member of the Standing Committee of the 18th Politburo of the Communist Party of China, and a secretary of the Central Commission for Disciplinary Inspection.

The Association of Christian Universities and Colleges in Asia (ACUCA) is an Asian Christian universities and colleges organization dedicated to the service of Christian faith in the field of education.It currently consists of 57 member schools: 3 in Hong Kong, 2 in India, 12 in Indonesia, 10 in Japan, 9 in South Korea, 9 in the Philippines, 9 in Taiwan and 4 in Thailand.From 2012 to 2014, Jiang Han-sheng, President of Suwon University, served as the Chairman of ACUCA.Hong Kong Chinese University Chongqi College Hong Kong Baptist University Lingnan University Wanlong Catholic University Petra Christian University Satya Wacana Christian University Indonesian Christian University Maranatha Christian University Duta Wacana Christian University Santa Matadama University Soegijapranata Catholic University University Pelita Harapan Krida Wacana Christian University Atma Jaya University, Yogyakarta HKBP Nommensen Christian University Lady Doak College International Christian University Kansai College Meiji College University Sophia University Nanshan University Doshisha University Aoyama College University Momoyama College University Sakura Meilin University Tohoku Gakuin University Saigakuin Women's University Seijiang University Chongqing University Yonsei University Kaimei University Hannam University Jeonju University Southeast University Pashuen University Manila Athens University Central Philippine University De La Salle University Philippine Christian University Silliman University Trinity University

Line 6 of the Guangzhou Metro is one of the operational lines of the Guangzhou Metro, belongs to the urban rail transport system, represented by the color purple, the entire line is roughly east-west U-shaped, currently has 32 stations (of which Shahe station has not been opened due to the demolition problem), one vehicle section and one car park, connecting Baiyun District, Lai Wan District, Yuexiu District, Tianhe District, Huangpu District, connecting Baiyun District, Xianfenggang to Huangpu District. The cars are composed of four L-shaped trains. Line 6 is divided into the first and second phases of construction, the first phase opened on December 28, 2013, the second phase opened on December 28, 2016. The route starts at Xufenggang in the Jinshazhou area in western Guangzhou, the elevated overpass crosses the North Ring Expressway and proceeds along Jinshazhou Road Central to the southeast, in the eastern part of Sha Fung Village, crosses the Pearl River tributary by the Baishan River Bridge, connecting to the sandy top of Datangsha Island.

The Guangzhou Branch of the Chinese Academy of Sciences is the sending agency of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, responsible for liaising and coordinating the scientific research units of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Guangdong. On April 19, 1956, the Guangzhou Branch Preparatory Committee of the Chinese Academy of Sciences was established. On December 29, 1958, the Guangzhou Branch of the Chinese Academy of Sciences was officially established. On January 25, 1961, the Guangzhou Branch and the Wuhan Branch were merged to form the South-Central Branch of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. On December 30, 1969, the South-Central Branch of the Chinese Academy of Sciences was abolished. On May 23, 1978, the Guangzhou Branch of the Chinese Academy of Sciences was restored. On January 5, 1978, the Guangdong Academy of Sciences was established. The offices of the two branches were merged, "a set of institutions, two blocks of signs." On June 28, 2015, the Guangdong Province merged the provincial Academy of Sciences, the provincial Institute of Industrial Technology, the provincial Institute of Testing and Analysis, the provincial Institute of Petroleum Chemistry, etc. into the new Guangdong Academy of Sciences.

Military nationalization is the assertion in the field of military and political science that the army or armed forces are not subordinate to the command of a political figure. The army is not subordinate to an individual, and is independent of political parties, but belongs to the whole people of a country and is subordinate only to the command of the whole people; no political party group or individual has the right to convene a delegation. Making the national armed forces subordinate to the state, respecting the separation of military and political orders, is also a key basis for maintaining the stability of the state. Military nationalization, on the other hand, can also be seen as one of the indicators of whether a democracy is a democracy. The opposite of military nationalization is the privatization of the army and militarism. The essence of military nationalization is that the armed forces should not be owned by any party or private group, as a tool for violent intervention and influencing the political situation, i.e. no one should defend himself or herself by armed violence or overthrow a political party or regime; the duty of the military is solely to defend the state, and is directly subordinate to all the people.

The Office of the President of the People's Republic of China (OCPR) is a nominally comprehensive day-to-day administrative body (Office) within the President of the People's Republic of China (PRC) under the 54th Constitution. On July 30, 1955, President Mao Zedong appointed Zhang Chengwu as the only "Chief Office of the President of the People's Republic of China" in history, as well as the representative of the Central People's Government in Tibet and the first secretary of the CPC Tibet Works Commission. On October 31, 1968, President Liu Shaochi was "removed from all offices inside and outside the Party" by the CPC's Eighth Twelfth Plenary Session, and died of ill-treatment on November 12, 1969. From 1969 to 1972, the offices of the President of the People's Republic of China were exercised by Vice President Song Qingling and Vice President Dong Biwu. From 1972 to 1975, Dong Biwu served as the Vice President of the People's Republic of China. In 1971, Zhang Chengwu was severely wounded and died in Qincheng Prison.

Palaeoloxodon namadicus is an extinct elephant found in the mid to late Pleistocene Indian subcontinent (possibly including other parts of Asia). Some scientists, based on similarities in ivory teeth, believe that the named elephant is a subspecies of the ancient rhinoceros. Subsequent studies have shown that the named elephant can be distinguished from the ancient rhinoceros on the basis of its thinner limbs and stronger skull. The named elephant is thought to have been extinct in the late Pleistocene, and is one of the four extinct megafauna species of the Indian subcontinent. Fossils of presumed named named elephants have also been found in Sulawesi, Indonesia, estimating the size to be similar to that of the named elephant inhabiting the Indian subcontinent. Many studies have attempted to estimate the size of the named elephant from a comparison of femur length and known growth rates with other ancient longnose species, even if the excavated fossils are incomplete.

Taiwan Sugar's first branch opened in Kaohsiung City in 2001, as the nation's first composite retail store combining lifestyle retail and DIY home repair, and subsequently opened branches in Yunlin County, Pingtung County, Tainan City, Tainan City, etc. In October 2003, Taiwan Sugar's Carnival Shopping Center was also opened. Since 2007, Taiwan Sugar's expanded community supermarket, opened an experimental regional fast-food store Express- Yongkang fast-food store (later renamed Health Supermarket), with Taiwan Sugar products such as organic rice, vegetable, meat, health food, biotechnology and recreational goods as a base for in-depth community exhibition stores. Due to the economic scale of Taiwan Sugar's branch stores and poor operating performance, Taiwan Sugar has been interested in ending the operation of the retail business since the opening, and later losses were even more severe, with a total loss of NT$24.3 billion from 2011 to 2017.

From the 7th to the 11th centuries, the maritime trading empire of Emperor Lifu died and trade flourished, which also brought Hinduism and Buddhism to Indonesia. Zheng and the Lower West once visited Indonesia and had diplomatic activities in Malacca. Although Muslim merchants arrived in Southeast Asia in the early Islamic period, there are signs that Muslims first inhabited northern Sumatra in the 13th century. The first regular contact between Indonesians and Europeans began in 1512, when Portuguese merchants led by Francisco Serrão sought and monopolised resources such as nutmeg, ginger and cider on the Moluccas. During most of the colonial period, the Dutch control of the islands outside the coastal fortresses was relatively weak, and it was not until the early 20th century that the Dutch dominion expanded the map of Indonesia to the present day. After the end of World War I, the locals began to fight for autonomy.

In January 1924, at the First National Congress of the Kuomintang, Sun Yat-sen announced the implementation of the Soviet-Russian-communist policy, and issued the Declaration of the First National Congress of the Kuomintang. With Soviet assistance, Huangpu Military School was established in March, and Chiang Kai-shek was appointed as its principal. From January 20 to January 30, 1924, Mao Zedong, as a representative of the local organization of the Hunan Kuomintang, attended the First National Congress of the Kuomintang convened in Guangzhou; more than 20 members of the Communist Party of China, including Li Dazhong, attended the Congress; the Congress was presided over by Sun Yat-sen; through the drafting of the Declaration of the Communist Party of China, with anti-imperialism and anti-feudalism as the main contents, as well as the new Party Charter and Party Charter, determined Sun Yat-sen's three major policies of the USSR, the Soviet Union, and support for farmers; the Congress elected the Central Executive Committee, with the Chinese Communist Party members Li Dazhong, Tan Pingshan, Yu Qide as members, Shen Xuan Lu, Lin Zuhan, Mao Zedong, Yu Fangzhou, Qu Qiu Bai, Han Linpu, and Zhang Guangxu as candidate members; during the Congress, Mao Zedong was appointed as one of the members of the Constitutional Review Committee, and made several statements at the meeting: 121.

It is often argued that democratization can be viewed as a long and continuous historical process. However, in the understanding of common people and most social scientists, democratization usually refers to the process of transition from authoritarianism or totalitarianism to liberal democracy. In this process, the organization of political power may change in essence. The social ecology of democratization will change greatly. According to the famous American political scientist Samuel Phillips Huntington in his book "The Third Wave: The Wave of Democracy in the Late 20th Century", it is common to divide the modern history of democratization into three waves, the first wave began with American independence and the French Revolution, which led to the democratization movement throughout Europe at the end of the 19th century; the second wave began with the wave of national-state independence after the Second World War, but gradually declined in the 1960s. The third wave of democratization is generally considered to have originated in the transition of power between Greece, Portugal and Spain in South Europe between 1974 and 1975, including Brazil and Argentina and Chile in Latin America, followed by the June Movement in South Korea in Asia and the Taiwan Resolution of the Republic of China, and finally ended with the democratization of Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Yugoslavia, Albania and the former Soviet republics and Mongolia in Eastern Europe.

There are currently 88 constellations, all defined by the International Astronomical Union (IAU), most of whose names are derived from Greek mythological figures and animals. The ancient Sumerian and Greeks (recorded by Ptolemy) established most of the northern constellations. European explorers were able to see previously unseen starry skies as they sailed south, so European astronomers added new constellations to fill the southern sky. The first constellation congress was held in Rome from May 2 to 10, 1922, and the names of the modern 88 constellations were established by the Third Committee. Subsequently, Eugene Delporte drew precise boundaries for each constellation, so that each point in the sky belonged to a constellation, and published a boundary star map of the constellations in 1930. Constellations are not in a certain order, it is said that they are usually based on an alphabetical sequence of their English names.

Almost all planets orbit near the ecliptic plane. The Solar System also contains many smaller objects, usually referred to as moons by the Moon. Each planet outside the Solar System is surrounded by planets made up of dust and small bodies. The solar wind is an electrically charged stream of particles flowing out of the Sun, forming a bubble-like region in the interstellar medium, called the solar circle (or globular layer). The top of the globular layer is where the pressure of the solar wind and the interstellar medium reaches equilibrium, extending to the edge of the discrete disk. The Oort cloud, believed to be the source of long-period comets, is probably more than 1,000 times farther away than the top of the globular layer. The Solar System is located on the hunter-gatherer arm of the Milky Way, about 26,000 light-years away from the center of the Milky Way. Objects orbiting the Sun are divided into three categories: planets, dwarf planets, and small objects in the Solar System.

In April of the same year, he was appointed Deputy Minister of Justice of Tang Shaoyi's cabinet in Beijing's interim government (the Minister of Justice was Wang Fonghui). In June of the same year, Yuan Shikai revised the Provisional Treaty Law of the Republic of China, which stipulated that the orders issued by the Grand President must be signed by the Deputy Minister of Justice. Tang Shaoyi resigned in anger, and Xu Qian resigned along with the other members of the League of Communists. In August of the same year, the National Coalition formed the Kuomintang together with the League of Communists, the National Communist Party and several other groups, and Xu Qian was elected a member of the Kuomintang headquarters. On March 20, 1913, the leader of the Kuomintang, Song Kyoren, was assassinated. On April 27, the same year, Xu Qian published a famous article in the People's Rights Gazette, "Declaration of the People," calling on the national armed forces to oppose the Grand President Yuan Shikai. After the failure of the Second Revolution, Xu Qian fled Shanghai, practised law, and sold his writings. Meanwhile, some Christian friends persuaded him to enter the priesthood, and Xu Qian replied, "If you have a good God, you should not allow such a man as Yuan Shikai to live in the world.

The "Youth Party" active in Mozambique is loyal to the Islamic State, not a branch of the Somali Youth Party. Since 1991, the Somali civil war has left the country in a state of anarchy. The Somali Youth Party was officially founded in 2004. On 6 February, the Somali Youth Party carried out a terrorist bombing in the seaside city of Bossasso, killing 90 people. On 26 February, the United States State Department declared the Somali Youth Party a "terrorist organization" and included it in the list of terrorist organizations, and its leader was killed in an airstrike by the United States Air Force. In 2009, the Somali Youth Party declared its allegiance to Al Qaeda. On 17 September, the Somali Youth Party carried out a suicide car bombing attack on the African Union Command in Somalia, killing 21 people. In October, the organization declared its allegiance to terrorism leader Ben Laden, and called the Somali President a "thief of the state".

Peng Yunyi (1878-1943), a resident of Xiangtan County, Hunan Province. Educator and politician in the Republic of China. Early in his life, he studied at Changsha Ming De College. After graduation, he went to Japan to study at Tokyo Police Academy and Waseda University. In 1905, he joined Sun Yat-sen's League organized in Tokyo. After the outbreak of the Wuchang Uprising in October 1911, he returned from Japan to serve as a foreign adviser to the newly formed Hubei Military Government. At the time of the North-South Reconciliation, he went to Shanghai as one of the representatives of the South to participate in negotiations. In January 1912, he was elected a member of the Provisional Senate of the Republic of China. Shortly afterwards, he organized the unification of the Republican Party with Song Kyo-jin and Tsai-chi, and was appointed a permanent secretary. In August 1912, the League was reorganized into the Kuomintang, with its headquarters in Beijing. Peng was elected as the head of the Kuomintang's main department of literature, supporting the bourgeois "parliamentary politics" and "party politics" of Song Kyo-jin.

According to the Local System Law, the reconstruction district is under the direct jurisdiction of the indigenous mountainous areas of the city, as a local self-government group with the status of a public corporation, the nature of the reconstruction district is not the same as that of other municipal districts of Taoyuan City, and applies the local self-government rights of the townships; the reconstruction district public office is the administrative body of its autonomous matters, not the dispatch body of the Taoyuan City Government, and the reconstruction district people's representative council is established as the legislative body of its autonomous matters. The old name "Kao板山", which was the territory of Daxi County, Hsinchu Prefecture in the Heiji period, Kao板乡 was established at the beginning of the post-war period. According to the statistics of the Office of Reconstruction District Administration and the Department of Home Affairs of the Ministry of the Interior of Taoyuan City, by the end of 2021, the number of reconstruction district households is about 3.9 thousand households, the population is about 130,000. The reconstruction district public office is the highest-level local administrative body of the reconstruction district, in the framework of the Government of the Republic of China, is the administrative body of the autonomy of the indigenous mountainous areas under the direct jurisdiction of the city, while it is responsible for the execution of municipal government and central agency commissioned matters, and the reconstruction district's autonomous supervisory body is the government of Taoyuan City.

In 1946, he joined the Communist Party of Indochina and became one of the leaders of the anti-Lao anti-Lao movement. In 1947, he led the anti-Lao anti-Lao movement in the northeastern part of the country. In 1950, he was appointed Minister of Defence of the Resistance Government of the Kingdom of Laos. In 1953, he was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the Combat Forces of the Kingdom of Laos. In March 1955, he was appointed General Secretary of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party. In 1959, he was appointed Vice-Chairman of the Lao Patriotic Front. In 1972, 1982 and 1986, he was elected General Secretary of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party at the second, third and fourth congresses. After the seizure of power by the Lao People's Revolutionary Party, the abolition of the monarchy and the establishment of the Lao People's Democratic Republic in 1975, he was appointed General Secretary of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party and Prime Minister of the Government. In 1982, he was appointed Chairman of the Council of Ministers.

On June 8, 1939, the National Government, pursuant to the provisions of Article 2 of the Ordinance on Punishment of Rape, designated him as a rapist and sought him out. He claimed to be one of the controversial figures in the struggle against war, who tried to delay Japan's annexation of China. In 1940, Wang cooperated with Japan in the establishment of a puppet-like "National Government of the Republic of China" in Nanjing. After the outbreak of the Pacific War, the regime gained importance in attempting to fight for autonomy, and Wang's regime held the chairmanship of the "National Standing Committee of the Kuomintang," the chairmanship of the "Central Political Committee," the chairmanship of the Executive Council, the chairmanship of the "National Government," and the chairmanship of the "Supreme Council of National Defence." On May 4, 1883, Wang was born in Sansui County, Guangdong (now Sansui District, Foshan City).

Thus, there are 252 known stable isotopes, each belonging to 80 chemical elements, i.e. all elements of atomic orders 1 to 82 (except for 43 yttrium and 61 yttrium). Elements of atomic orders 83 or higher and those of yttrium and yttrium without stable isotopes, i.e. all isotopes are radioactive, are called radioactive. Of these 80 elements with stable isotopes, 26 have only one stable isotope, called a single isotope, while the remaining elements have more than one stable isotope, including 10 stable isotopes of tin, which is the largest number of stable isotopes. Since stable isotopes do not decay or are difficult to decay, and can persist in nature in stable amounts, their abundance is often much higher than that of radioactive isotopes.

In an X-ray burst source, these substances from the companion star can form a layer of accreted matter on the surface of a dense neutron star. With only a few hours of accumulation and gravity compression, these substances can begin to fuse. Usually, an increase in temperature (above 1 × 109 k) causes thermal uncontrollable. The explosion of this star's nuclear synthesis begins with thermal carbon-nitrogen-oxygen cycle, rapidly undergoes the Rp-process, the accreted matter burns out within a few seconds, and the energy it provides is the bright X-ray flash observed by X-ray telescopes. Theoretical evidence suggests that, at least in some cases, the accreted hydrogen will continue to burn continuously, causing the accumulated helium to burst. The behavior of the X-ray burst source is similar to that of a nova. In the case of dense white dwarfs, the continuous accretion of hydrogen may eventually cause an uncontrollable explosion.

Thus, a proton with a positive charge is composed of two super quarks and a lower quark. A neutron without an electric charge is composed of one super quark and two lower quarks. By weak interactions, the super quark can also change its flavor to a lower quark, resulting in β radiation. positron emission is caused by the transformation of an upper quark into a lower quark. Nuclei capable of positron emission can also be electron captured. For low-energy decay, electron capture has an energy advantage of 2mec2 = 1.022 MeV, because the final state has one electron less than one more positron. As the decay energy increases, the branching fraction also increases. However, if the energy difference is less than 2mec2, positron emission will not occur, and only electron capture can occur.

The new astronomical unit (AU) is defined as the metre, whereas the metre is derived from the speed of light in a vacuum, i.e., the astronomical unit is no longer linked to the actual distance between the Earth and the Sun, nor is it affected by time (although the original origin of the astronomical unit was the mean distance between the Earth and the Sun). The most primitive definition of the astronomical unit (AU) is the length of the semi-long axis of the elliptical orbit of the Earth around the Sun. In 1976, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) revised the definition of the AU to make it more precise, using the Gaussian gravitational constant (k) to define length, time and mass, with its value of 0.017 202 098 95 as the length of the astronomical unit, or the Sun's center gravity constant (the result of GM☉) equal to (0.017 202 098 95)2 AU3/d2.

The Islamic Republic of Iran (Persian:جمهوری اسلامی ایران, Jumhuriye Eslâmiye Irân, pronounced ) is a Middle Eastern country located in Western Asia. It is bordered by the Caspian Sea in the north, the Persian Gulf and the Arabian Sea in the south. Iran is bordered by Pakistan and Afghanistan in the east, by Turkmenistan in the northeast, by Azerbaijan and Armenia in the northwest, and by the internationally recognized Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Republic of Azerbaijan in the west, and by Turkey and Iraq (Kurdistan) in the west. It has an area of 1,648,195 square kilometers. It is located mainly on the Iranian plateau and has a relatively dry climate.
