A party system is a political system in which the ruling party holds absolute power, exercises sovereignty on behalf of the state, and overall controls the state machinery, achieving the integration of the party organization and the government from the central to the local level, i.e. the unity of party politics (all party leadership). A party system is not the same as a constitutional one, the former sovereignty lies directly with the party organization, the latter directly with the people, and even the national constitution clearly indicates that it serves the party organization. If the people wish to enter the government, they must first become party members or even leaders. Under a party system, the position and power of the party leader (chairman, general secretary, first secretary) outweigh that of the head of state (president, president of the state) and of the head of government (prime minister, chairman of the council of ministers). The party system is mainly implemented in the socialist republics long ruled by the Communist Party, mainly including the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the People's Republic of China, the Republic of Cuba, and the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.

Full-time students of the Warsaw University of Economics can choose to study Polish language courses in the following fields: Starting from the 2006/2007 academic year, the duration of each course is as follows: All students must complete a specified course in the first three semesters in individual and general economics, mathematics, statistics, philosophy, social sciences, law, history, geography, languages, etc. After completing the course and passing the specified examination, students must choose one of the fields offered by the school to continue their studies. A bachelor's degree (usually six semesters) and a master's degree (including a bachelor's break of approximately eight to ten semesters) will be awarded after completing the specified credits, respectively. Ten semesters are the maximum duration of tuition-free tuition at the Warsaw University of Economics, over and above the cost of tuition.

The Chinese translation of "Afghanistan" is first seen in the 1856 American-North American Council of Elders' Dictionary of the Earth, compiled by the Chinese missionary Richard Quarterman Way. According to archaeological findings, ancestors have settled in Afghanistan since 50,000 years ago. Afghanistan is often referred to as the crossroads of Central Asia, and its history is fraught with wars and social upheavals. Historically, this region, now called Afghanistan, has been on the fringes of many major empires at various times, including the Persian Empire, the Peacock Empire, the Song Dynasty, the Tang Dynasty, the Mughal Empire, the Qing Dynasty and the British Empire, as well as other great empires, including those established by Genghis Khan and Alexander the Great. Throughout its long history, Afghanistan has undergone countless invasions and conquests, or by local factions formed large armies, invaded neighboring states, and formed a nation.

"Latin America" originated in the 19th century and presupposes that regions must be defined on the basis of European categories (especially "Latin America"). Thus, strictly speaking, there was no Latin American history before October 12, 1492. Furthermore, because of the ethno-geographical characteristics of the concept, the concept does not include indigenous cultures and African-American cultures. During the pre-Columbian period, hundreds of cultures and dozens of primitive civilizations developed on the American continent. Among them, in Central America and the Andean Mountains, the higher civilizations of the pre-Columbian period are generally accepted. From north to south, we can name the cultures of Mexico, Toltec culture, Teotihuacan culture, Zapotec culture, Olmec culture, Maya culture, Muisca culture, Canaris culture, Moche culture, Nazca culture, Kimu culture, Inca culture, and Tiavanaco culture.

Maldives gained independence from the United Kingdom in 1965, however, after independence, the country still provided the air base on Gan Island in Addu Atoll to the British until 1976, when the United Kingdom withdrew completely from the air base in 1976, the exact year of the onset of the Cold War, international attention on the future direction of the air base. The Soviet authorities had attempted to lease the air base to the Maldivian authorities, but were repeatedly rejected by the Maldivian government. The challenge facing the Republic of Maldives before 1990 was rapid economic development and modernization to provide the country with the basic resources of limited fisheries, agriculture and tourism; Maldives was also hailed as "God sprinkled the necklace on the earth", "the last paradise on earth in the Indian Ocean".

TaiKoo Hui, an international high-quality integrated development project at the intersection of Tianhe Road and Tianhe East Road in Tianhe District, Guangzhou, China, was completed in May 2011. The project consists of a large shopping mall, two A-class office buildings, and Guangzhou's first Wenhua Oriental Hotel. It combines leisure, entertainment, business activities and cultural appreciation. It is owned by TaiKo Estate Development, Hong Kong, with a 97% stake, and the remaining 3% by Guangzhou Daily News Group. It is rated as a five-star national shopping centre in 2019 according to China's Shopping Centre Rating Standards. TaiKoo Hui, with a total building area of over 358,000 square metres, is located in the core of Tianhe Central Business District, designed by the world-renowned architectural firmArquitectonica and managed by TaiKo Estate.

Doshisha University (Doshisha University/どうししゃだいがく Dōshisha daigaku */?) is a private university located in Kyoto, Japan, short for Doshisha University, founded in 1920 under the reform of the University Ordinance. It is one of the member schools of the famous university group "Kankan Toli" in the Kinki region of Japan. Formerly, it was the "Doshisha English School" founded in 1875 by Xiang Nishijima, one of the Meiji Sixth University educators. The school name "Doshisha" means "the association founded by people who are aligned with one another." Being a Christian Protestant school, Doshisha University follows the trend of the Ecumenical Council, but is not a missionary university (Japanese: University of Mission), but belongs to the Christian school (Japanese: Christian school) with the aim of teaching the Christian faith, with Christianity, liberalism and internationalism as the three main principles of teaching, cultivating students to become "the conscience of a nation".

Whatever method of measurement is used, the life expectancy of modern people is indeed much higher than that of people in the Middle Ages or earlier, such as, for example, in the 13th century, the average life expectancy of the British nobility was about 30 years, but at that time, for adult men up to the age of 21, their life expectancy was about 64 years. Therefore, it is meaningless to estimate the age at which adults were generally able to live by taking the average life expectancy of ancient times (including the life expectancy of newborns and the life expectancy of adults). In 2001, the World Health Organization published healthy life expectancy (or active life expectancy) statistics.

Algeria's oil reserves rank second in Africa, sixteenth in the world, ninth in the world, and the Algerian National Petroleum Company, which is responsible for extracting its petrochemical resources, is the largest company in Africa. Algeria is currently a member of the United Nations, the African Union, the Arab League, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and the founding members of the Arab Maghreb Union. "Algeria" translates from its English name Algeria. The name of the country derives from the city of its capital Algeria. "Algeria" derives from its Arabic name al-Jazāʾir (الجزائر al-Jazāʾir), meaning "islands", referring to the former four islands in the Gulf of the city, and after 1525 the four islands gradually merged with the mainland.

In December 1974, at the age of 18, Huang joined the People's Liberation Army as a soldier and deputy commander of the 84th Battalion, 32866th Infantry. After serving in the army in 1977, he returned to his hometown to work as a farm worker, and was appointed to a battalion clerk of Tongxian Public Corporation in Sheung Hang County. He entered the Department of Political Science and Education of Fujian Normal University in 1978, and after graduating in 1982, he was assigned to work in the organizational department of the Longyan District Committee of the Communist Party of Fujian Province as a local party cadre. After that, Huang worked for a long time in his hometown of Longyan, serving as deputy head of the Qinggang Section of the organizational department of the Longyan District Committee in 1985, deputy director of the office of the Longyan District Committee in 1990, deputy secretary general, and also director of the office of the Longyan District Committee in 1993. He was appointed as a secretary of the Yongding County Committee and a member of the Longyan County Committee in 1993. In 1997, the State Council approved the establishment of the city of Longyan, Huang was appointed as a member of the Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China and a secretary of the Yongding County Committee.

Villages and villages are the names of the fourth-level administrative divisions of the Republic of China. They belong to districts, county municipalities, towns and villagers are called villages; they belong to villagers are called villages. Villages and villages are also called "neighbourhoods," and currently there are 7,470 villages in the Free Zone of the Republic of China. The origin of each village(s) in Taiwan, mainly from the reform or merger of the Bao-A system in the Heiji period, Bao changed to village(s), A changed to neighbourhoods. Later, due to the need for development, the division of village(s) is very frequent. At present, the division of village(s) mainly according to the geographical environment, transportation, urban planning and administrative area, while the size of the village(s) is regulated by the autonomous ordinance of each city, the remote areas can set up a village(s) as long as there are 100 households, but the densely populated areas in the northern part of the city are at least 1,000 households, up to 4 thousand households, and the size of each other varies greatly. Village(s) belong to municipalities in rural areas, have village(s) offices, except for the village(s) head, there is also a village(s) secretary.

In 1949, the People's Republic of China, led by the Kuomintang, withdrew from Taiwan, and the Cold War continued to be militarily supported by the United States. The People's Republic of China, founded by the Communist Party of China in 1949, remained in a state of long-standing antagonism and isolation with the United States, supporting the anti-American wars in the Korean Peninsula and Vietnam. Subsequently, Sino-Soviet relations deteriorated, and in 1972, President Richard Nixon, guided by the need to confront the Soviet Union jointly, invited Premier Zhou Enlai of the State Council of China to visit Beijing. Relations between China and the United States gradually thawed. For strategic reasons, the United States formally established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1979, while declaring a break with the Republic of China, which had withdrawn from Taiwan, and terminated the Treaty of Common Defense of the People's Republic of China with the United States. The purpose of the People's Republic of China's government was to develop China into a prosperous, strong and united China under the leadership of the Communist Party of China; and the purpose of the United States was to establish an international order led by the United States.

Establishment of bases in underdeveloped areas where local warlords have not touched, using guerrilla tactics to avoid attacks by warlords. This policy has been somewhat successful, and the branches of the Communist Party of China in each province have copied their experience to establish local bases. In June 1928, Field Marshal Zhang Shaolin was bombed by the Japanese Guangdong Army, and on December 29, Zhang Xue Liang, Zhang Shaolin's son, in Fengtian Telecommunication Northeast Banner, removed the five-colored flag of the North Sea government, overturned the national government blue sky white sun full of red flag, declared the surrender of Nanjing, successful Northern Expedition, symbolic unification of China. Although the national government completed the Northern Expedition, but because the process was through compromise with the local warlord forces, it took ten years to eliminate the local warlord forces. Among them, the local government established by the Communist Party of China with the support of the Soviet Union, was also seen as an obstacle to the unification of China. After the Northeast Banner, the national government, although nominally unifying all of China, but dealing with the real power of the various warlords with strong backs is the next step to stabilize the country, and the CCP is certainly one of the important goals.

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC, pronounced /ˈoʊpɛk/ OH-pek) is an intergovernmental organization of 13 countries, founded on 14 September 1960 in Baghdad by five founding countries (Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela). Its headquarters are now in Vienna, Austria (relocated in 1965), and currently has 13 member states. As of 2019 (2019-Missing required parameter 1=month!), OPEC's oil production accounts for 38% of global output and 71.8% of global oil exploration reserves, which could have a significant impact on global crude oil prices previously dominated by the "seven sister" transnational oil companies.

1961: First Vice-Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Socialist Republic of Romania. 1965: George U-Dji died. Chairman of the Central Council of the General Trade Unions of Romania. 1969: Director-General of the State Property Reserve. 1969: Exclusion from the Bureau and Political Executive Committee. 1975: Exiled as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to Latin American Countries. 1977: Ambassador of Romania to the Argentine Republic. In 1928, the National Government completed the Northern Expedition, replacing the North Sea Government as the central government of the Republic of China, and Nanjing also formally replaced Beijing's status as the capital, and Beijing was renamed "Beijing Beiping." The National Government subsequently enacted the Treaty of the Qing Dynasty of China in 1931, Article 5 of which stipulates in Chinese: "The capital of the Republic of China shall be in Nanjing," establishing Nanjing as the legal capital. After the establishment of the capital of the Republic of China, the National Government constructed a large number of government office buildings in Nanjing City, and devised China's first modernization city plan — the Capital Plan, which planned to transform Nanjing into the most advanced city in China. However, shortly after the implementation of the Treaty of the Qing Dynasty of China, China entered the period of the Anti-Japanese War.

Recently, IIT expanded its campus in Suvarnabhumi, adopting Gothic and other European architectural styles, creating a nature-based atmosphere known as "University in the Park". IIT is famous for attracting a large number of foreign students from Russia, China, Myanmar, Uganda, Bangladesh, Pakistan, and other Asian countries. Chinese students are the largest group of foreign students, numbering up to 6,000, followed by Indian students, numbering 1,001, as well as exchange students from Loyola University in the United States and Europe. IIT is also Thailand's first international university. IIT has many majors, such as engineering, information technology, science, nursing, law, business administration, communication arts, architecture, biology, and music. On December 21, 2002, the IIT School of Distance Education was established.

The Executive Yuan is the highest administrative body of the Republic of China, shortened to the Senate, headed by the President of the Executive Yuan, and has political responsibility to the Legislative Yuan in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Constitution. The Executive Yuan is regarded as the Cabinet of the Republic of China, the President as the uprising, the Vice President as the vice uprising, the Secretary-General, the Deputy Secretary-General, the Political Affairs Commissioner and the heads of the various ministries are members of the Cabinet, and the meetings of the Executive Yuan are held regularly to agree on important national affairs. The President of the Executive Yuan is directly appointed by the President, without the approval of the Legislative Yuan, the Vice President and other officials such as the heads of the various ministries are requested by the President to appoint the President. The Executive Yuan is the highest administrative body of the country, based on the Five Powers Constitution theory of the founder of the Republic of China, Sun Yat-sen. In 1928, after the completion of the Northern Expedition and the nominal unification of China, the National Government of the Republic of China passed the Law on the Organization of the National Government of the Republic of China on October 3 of the same year, and according to this law the Executive Yuan (National Government Executive Yuan) was established.

Generally refers to a stable social order and the agreement between the government and the people (such as the law) is not easily overturned by the change of party or leadership. Changes of government, or a decline in the credibility of the government, are threats to national security and social stability. Internally, generally refers to maintaining the normal functioning of economic sectors and elements within the country and ensuring a fair and orderly trading and investment environment; Externally, refers to an investment guarantee agreement between the two countries. Maintaining the stability of monetary values and free economic markets, as well as preventing foreign commercial spies from large-scale spying on unauthorized patented technology and infringing intellectual property rights. Also, controlling and preventing the exodus of industrial clusters or cross-border acquisitions, with tariffs or anti-dumping duties to protect domestic industries from the influence of overseas producers. To maintain the overall competitiveness of the country in the economy and the normal livelihood of the people.

This World Cup makes Qatar the smallest country ever to host the World Cup. Asia (6 teams) Africa (5 teams) Central and North America and the Caribbean (4 teams) South America (4 teams) Oceania (0 teams) Europe (13 teams) This World Cup final week the teams remain the same as the previous year and 32 teams remain unchanged: As part of the Asian qualifiers will continue the previous system, the first two rounds of the Asian qualifiers will be the same as the first two rounds of the 2023 Asian qualifiers, so the host country Qatar will still participate in the second round of the Asian qualifiers, but if Qatar qualifies in the second round of the qualifiers, they will only qualify for the 2023 Asian Cup final week, the next ranking team will qualify for the third round of the Asian qualifiers.

In April 1944, in Chongqing, the National Government of the People's Republic of China, commissioned by the Central Design Bureau, established the "Taiwan Inquiry Committee," and appointed Chen Yi as its chairman. The Inquiry Committee conducted a very detailed investigation of the economic, political, civil and military aspects of Taiwan under the Japanese occupation at that time. After the war, the National Government of the People's Republic of China in Chongqing had two opinions on how to take over Taiwan. One side proposed the same as the other 34 provinces of the Republic of China, establishing "Taiwan Province." The other side advocated the establishment of a "Special Administrative Region" on the island of Taiwan with special public powers such as the military and police. Finally, the President of the National Government at that time, Chiang Kai-shek, accepted Chen Yi's opinion in "The Outline of the Plan for the Taking Over of Taiwan by Local Government," and established the Office of the Chief Executive of Taiwan Province. In this regard, the Office of the Chief Executive of Taiwan was responsible for receiving Taiwan, and the total number of administrative officers of the Office was initially set at 2,000. On August 29, 1945, Chiang Kai-shek appointed Chen Yi as the Chief Executive of Taiwan Province.

The Declaration also explicitly supported the national liberation movements of Algeria, Angola, Tunisia, Cuba and other countries, as well as the struggle for the seat of the People's Republic of China in the United Nations. The Second Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement was held in Cairo, Egypt, in October 1964, at which time the membership had increased to 47, mostly from newly independent nation-states in Asia and Africa. In addition to reaffirming its opposition to colonialism and imperialism, the Summit focused on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the Indo-Pakistani conflict, and condemned China's attacks on India in the wake of the outbreak of the Sino-Indian War. The Third Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement was held in September 1970 in the Zambian capital, Lusaka.

Planetary nebulae are stars that evolved into the late aged red giant stage, when their gaseous shells expanded outward and were ionized, forming expanding emission nebulae, often abbreviated PN or PNe. Most planetary nebulae are thought to be formed as follows: At the end of the star's life, the stage of the red giant, the outer gaseous shells were blown into space by strong stellar winds. After most of the red giant's gas was scattered, ultraviolet radiation from the hot planetary nebula nucleus (PNN) ionized the scattered outer gas. Absorbing ultraviolet high-energy gaseous shells around the central star emitted a faint fluorescence, making it a colorful planetary nebula. Planetary nebulae played a key role in the chemistry of the evolution of the Milky Way, diffusing elements created by stars into elements in interstellar matter.

Army General Hospital Hualien, Army No. 85 General Hospital, is a medical institution of the Republic of China Army in eastern Taiwan, currently under the jurisdiction of the Military Medical Bureau of the Ministry of Defense. In addition to providing medical services to members of the armed forces and their families and medical research activities in response to national defense and military needs, it also provides medical services to the general public under the name of the "People's Clinical Service Department attached to the General Hospital Hualien." It is divided into administrative and medical departments. Under the director, there is a deputy director, who manages all operations. Medical tour rooms, main accounting rooms, administrative rooms, medical service rooms, guard supply recreation rooms, blood bank rooms, staff rooms, eastern regional mental health rooms. – Europe (green and dark grey) – European Union (green) The Republic of Slovenia (Slovenija), commonly known as Slovenia (Slovenija), is a country in Central and Eastern Europe, bordering the Alps. It borders Italy to the west, the Adriatic Sea to the southwest, is surrounded by Croatia to the east and south, Hungary to the northeast and Austria to the north. Slovenia covers an area of 20,273 square kilometres and has a national population of about 2.05 million people. Although it is a Central European country, it is historically and culturally influenced by Italy in southern Europe and by Croatia and Serbia in southeastern Europe. Before independence on 25 June 1991, Slovenia was a member republic of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Socialist Republic of Slovenia).

In accordance with the Treaty of Brest of March 3, 1918, between the Russian Federation and the German Empire, the Soviet Union ceded Finland, Estonia (Estonia), Livonia (Lithuania and Latvia), Lithuania and Ukraine to Germany, and the Soviet Red Army and the Russian Red Guards withdrew from these territories. Subsequently, Germany attempted to establish a Commonwealth of Poland under the German Empire, headed by Duke Adolf Friedrich of Mecklenburg, in the areas of Estonia and Latvia ceded by the Soviet Union. In November 1918, the November Revolution broke out in Germany, and on November 11, Germany declared its surrender. The Soviet Union took the opportunity to annul the Treaty of Brest and attempted to recover the territories ceded to Germany. In this context, Estonia declared its independence on November 28, 1918, and German-speaking residents and some German troops formed volunteer corps, together with the newly formed Estonian army, to resist the attacks of the Soviet Red Army and the Red Guards.

It is now generally believed that Qatar refers to an abandoned city called al-Zbara (الزبارة ), which used to be an economically prosperous port. On the Qatari peninsula, the inhabitants have maintained thousands of years of productive activity, but for most of the earlier period, it was only a short-lived residence of nomadic tribes. Among them, the Khalifa and Saud tribes swept the entire Arabian peninsula (later they became kings of Bahrain and Saudi Arabia respectively), and settled along the coastline, fishing and pearl farming. These tribes often fought each other for favorable oyster farms, divided the entire territory, and never established a unified sovereignty. Qatar was part of the Arab Empire in the 7th century.

In Uyghur, Onogur is the collective name of the last ten tribes that joined the Bulgarian League and ruled the eastern part of present-day Hungary after the fall of the Avars. It does not refer to a single ethnic group or tribe. The place name of Hungary is Magyarország in the mother tongue of the Magyars, the dominant ethnic group in the country. In Turkish and Persian, the country is referred to as "Magyar" only with the suffix of its own language at the end. "Magyar" is the name of Magyeri, the ally of the seven semi-nomadic tribal leagues. The two languages of Japan and Korea, unlike Chinese, translate the name of Hungary as "Hungarian", short for "Hungarian". The Japanese also have the pseudonym "Hungarian" (pronounced the same as "Hungarian").

During the Three Kingdoms period, the Yunnan region was called "South Central." In 225, Shu Hanjo Su Zhuge Liang led a large army to subdue the "South Central" great king Meng Ju. In the 320s, the Yuan clan (音cuàn) entered Yunnan, and Yuchen became king in Kunchuan (now Jinning), its rule lasted for 400 years. At the end of the Sui Dynasty, the Central Plains Rebellion, and the economic and social stability of southwestern areas such as Ba Shu Yuan. In 621 AD, the Tang Dynasty established the Yaozhou local administrative district in Yunnan, and in 664 AD, the Yaozhou Governor's Office was established. In the seventh century AD, about the same time as the rise of the Tang Dynasty, six ethnic tribes in the Erhai region, which were in the primitive social stage and did not unite with each other, were called "six bulls." These were the Monsha bull, Yuexia bull, Dengzhou bull, Shilang bull, Rong Dome bull, Monsha bull, "bull" means "evil", Chinese means "king" or "leader". In 738 AD, the Monsha bull tribe chief Piro Guang, with the help of the central power, combined with the other five bulls, established the South Bull state, and was enthroned as the king of Yunnan by the Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang Dynasty.

A murder is a murder, whether committed in person or ordered to be committed. The right to life is the basis for the exercise of all rights, and once lost cannot be recovered, murder is one of the most serious criminal offences in all ordinary French families. The statutory penalty for murder (or homicide) is usually the highest penalty prescribed by the criminal law of the country (e.g. death, life imprisonment or the statutory maximum term of imprisonment). Prohibition of murder is considered to be part of universal humanity, i.e. all human cultures prohibit murder. The components of the crime of murder vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, but generally include the following definitions: Once the crime is established, the perpetrator of the crime of murder is often sentenced to the highest penalty in the country; in many countries and territories, the penalty for murder includes capital punishment, while in some countries and territories there is no capital punishment; in countries without capital punishment, the maximum penalty for murder may be life imprisonment or a term of imprisonment close to the statutory maximum.

Before the Song Dynasty, the Yangtze River, as a local cultural, economic and political center, was only a relatively high hillside or mound. In 606 AD, the Yangtze River was officially established as the Yangtze County. In 1097, in the fourth year of the Northern Song dynasty, Dingxu (Panyu people) of Chizhou built a mound castle on Mt. Yixiang (now the vicinity of the first primary school of Jiangcheng), which is the ancient ancestor of the Yangtze City. For a long time, the administrative centers of the Yangtze River were located at the foot of Mt. Yixiang, so the Yangtze River was also called Yixiang City. According to the archaeological findings of the Yangchun Dushichai Cave Site (Late Paleolithic to Early Neolithic Ancient Human Cave Sites), both Yangchun and the Yangtze River had signs of human existence 10,000 years ago. The pre-Qin Dynasty was a place where hundreds of ethnic Vietnamese lived outside Ugongyang Province, and did not belong to the Zhongyuan regime. In 214 BC, the Qin Emperor Pingding established Nanhai County after hundreds of ethnic Vietnamese, and the two Yangtze Rivers were part of Nanhai County.

Cameroon is famous for its national football team and its indigenous musical style, the best known of which are Makusa and Bikusi. The official languages of Cameroon are English and French. The earliest inhabitants of Cameroon were the Baka tribe of the Biscomians. The Bantu-speaking ethnic group originated in the highlands of Cameroon at the earliest, but most of them were displaced before the European invasion. Until 1884, the king, Douala, was Cameroon's most powerful local monarch from mainland Africa. As early as 1472, Portuguese sailors from Europe had begun to land on the coast of Cameroon. Cameroon is named after the shrimp-producing river, which was formerly known as the Rio de Camarões. Trade in ivory, palm oil and raw sugar with Portugal began in 1520.

In 1989, the Velvet Revolution, led by the Civic Forum, ended Communist rule. On 1 January 1993, Czechoslovakia voted to secede from the Velvet Revolution, making Slovakia a sovereign and independent state. Slovakia has an advanced high-income economy and a high ranking in the Human Development Index. It performs well in the areas of civil liberties, freedom of the press, freedom of the Internet and democratic governance. Slovakia maintains a market economy combined with social security, and a sound system for the implementation of health care, free education and the longest legal paid parental leave in Europe. Slovakia is also a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Organization for Nuclear Research in Europe, the Eurozone, the Schengen Area, the United Nations, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the World Trade Organization, the European Commission, the Visegrad Group and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

Instead, astrophysicists understand how stars evolve by observing many stars at different points in their lifetime, and by using computer simulations of stellar analogues. Star evolution begins with the gravitational collapse of a giant molecular cloud. A typical giant molecular cloud is about 100 light years in diameter (9.5×1014 km) and contains up to 6,000,000 solar masses (1.2×1037 kg). When it collapses, a giant molecular cloud splits into smaller and smaller fragments. In each fragment, the collapsed gas releases gravitational energy and converts it into heat. As temperatures and pressures rise, the fragments condense into a rotating ball of gas called the superheat of the protostar. Further development and evolution are closely related to the mass of the star; in the following, the mass of the protostar is usually compared to the mass of the Sun: Meaning 1.0 M☉ (2.0×1030 kg) as the basic unit of mass.

The current (46th) President of the United States is Democratic Party Joe Biden, who took office on January 20, 2021, and his partner in the vice-presidential office is the party's Geoffrey Kaczynski. Since the inauguration of the first President of Washington, the United States has produced 46 presidents in more than 230 years, of which only the 44th President, Barack Obama, has half African-American ancestry or was a U.S. citizen when the Constitution was passed (see: U.S. Constitution). Only the President of the United States holds public office, and vice-presidents must be "U.S. citizens at birth". The President's official residence is the White House in Washington, D.C., and the permanent office is the Oval Office in the White House. The President's wife is called "First Lady", and the family is called "First Family". The President's private jet is called "Air Force One", the private helicopter is called "Navy Squadron One", and the official anthem is "Welcome to the Commander-in-Chief".

Python's design philosophy emphasizes the readability and simplicity of code syntax, especially the use of spaces to separate blocks of code. Compared to C or Java, Python allows developers to express ideas with less code. The Python interpreter itself runs on almost all operating systems, and its official interpreter, CPython, is written in C. Python is a community-driven free software, currently managed by the Python Software Foundation. Python is one of the most popular programming languages. Python's founder, Gido van Roosum, worked on several projects of the Dutch Society for Mathematical and Computer Science between 1982 and 1995. In February 1991, van Roosum released the initial code (labeled version 0.9.0) at alt.sources.

The giraffe is a frequent visitor to many national and theme parks, and as of 2010 (2010-Missing required parameter 1=month!), there are about 97,500 giraffes in the world. In 1758, Carl Linnaeus assigned the extant giraffes to the genus Deer on the basis of two methods. However, Morten Thrane Brünnich reclassified them in 1772 as a genus of giraffes, which is one of the only two extant genera in the family Lepidopteridae, the other being Lepidopteridae. The family Lepidopteridae was once very widely distributed, with more than 10 genera. Their most recent known relative is the extinct genus Lepidopteridae.

Xi'an railway station is located on Longhai Railway, is a large-capacity hub station. Xi'an currently has domestic high-speed transportation hubs such as Xi'an Xianyang International Airport on the 4th floor, and Xi'an North Station. In terms of urban transportation, Xi'an currently has eight underground lines in operation, and earlier there were also railless trams. At present, a number of large-scale transportation infrastructure projects, including Xi'an Xianyang International Airport expansion, new high-speed rail east station and high-speed rail line construction, etc. are being intensively promoted. Xi'an is one of China's national central cities, Silk Road Economic Belt, New Asia-Europe Continental Bridge and an important city in the Yellow River basin, economic, science, technology, education, energy, finance, culture, and trade center of the Guanzhong City Group, and Yanliang District, to which it belongs, is an important aviation industry base in China. On November 10, the Congress of First National Party Members of the Communist Party of China adopted the Party Charter, Program and Disciplinary Arbitration Measures, and Jiang Pengjian was elected the first President of the Party. The Outside Party Election Support Association was elected 11 members in the first Third Extraordinary National Assembly election held on December 6, 1986; 12 members in the first Fifth Extraordinary Legislative Assembly election held on December 6, 1986. A total of 23 people's representatives of the Democratic Progressive Party entered the National Assembly. Yao Jiawen was elected the second President of the Party on November 10, 1987. Huang Xinjie was elected the third President of the Party on October 29, 1988. Xu Xinliang was elected the fourth President of the Party on November 12, 1991. On December 2, 1989, the Democratic Progressive Party won six seats in the mayoral elections, including the seat in Taipei Prefecture, the most populous prefecture in the country. On December 25, the DPP launched a large-scale mass demonstration, calling for "presidential elections" and "support for Xu Xinliang."

Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the Western-led eviction of Russia from the World Bank's Financial and Telecommunications Association (SWIFT) system was seen as the most severe sanction in the 21st century. Common forms of military sanctions include military blockades, military strikes, destruction of facilities, suspension of military technical cooperation, suspension of military exchanges, cancellation of military assistance, restrictions on arms exports, and so on. For example, following Turkey's deployment to the Syrian Civil War in 2019, the European Union imposed a ban on its implementation of arms export restrictions. Sports sanctions are seen as part of a psychological war aimed at shattering the morale of the peoples of the targeted countries, with the following measures ranging from heavy to light: Between 1992 and 1995, the United Nations Security Council passed Resolution 757, imposing sporting sanctions on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, resulting in their immediate exclusion from the 1992 European Nations Cup and the 1992 Summer Olympics, and is currently the only example of sporting eligibility being denied by the United Nations.

The National Tuku Vocational High School of Commerce & Industry (Chinese: 国家土庫高級商工職業学校) is a high school of the National Tuku Vocational High School of Commerce & Industry (Chinese: 国家土庫高級商工職業学校) located in the town of Tuku, Yunlin County, Chiayi Province, Taiwan. Due to the fact that the government moved from mainland China soon, the Republic of China was aware of the instability of the situation, and implemented the "air defense evacuation policy," planning to establish branches of provincial schools in Taiwan. In 1955, Lin Tingjun, then mayor of Tuku, Yunlin County, Chen Zhangqing, and others invited Taiwan Provincial Chiayi Commercial Vocational School principal Liu Fangqiu to visit the town, and established a branch at the present Tuku Vocational School site, establishing the "Taiwan Provincial Chiayi Commercial Vocational School Tuku Branch".

Nansha District (Chinese: 南沙区) is a district under the jurisdiction of Guangzhou City, Guangzhou Sub-Centre, Guangdong Province, China. It is located in Panyu District, formerly the Nansha Economic and Technological Development Zone, which was established on May 12, 1993, and was upgraded to Nansha District under the jurisdiction of Guangzhou City in May 2005. Nansha District was established on September 6, 2012, as the sixth national new district under the jurisdiction of the People's Republic of China, and the first national new district under the jurisdiction of a municipality. Nansha District has a total area of 803 square kilometers, a permanent population of 259899 on November 1, 2010, and the district government is located at No. 1 Phoenix Avenue, Huangkou Town, Guangdong Province. The China (Guangdong) Free Trade Experiment Zone was officially established in April 2015, with an area of 60 square kilometers, Nansha Self-Trade Zone is the largest in Guangdong Province. It is divided into seven sub-districts, including financial, shipping and other areas. Nansha District is under the jurisdiction of six towns and three streets: Nansha District is located in the southernmost part of Guangzhou City, is the "only coastal district" of Guangzhou City, and is the only district on the border between Guangzhou City and Shenzhen City (Bao'an District), and the only district on the border between Zhongshan City.

However, some astronomers believe that all of these objects may be dwarf planets. According to estimates, the number of minor planets should be several million, see the list of minor planets in detail, and the largest asteroids are now beginning to be reclassified, defined as dwarf planets. In 1760, it was conjectured that the distance of the planets in the Solar System from the Sun constitutes a simple numerical series. According to this series, there is a gap between Mars and Jupiter, and there should also be a planet between the two planets. At the end of the 18th century, many people began to search for this unknown planet. The famous Titius-Porter theorem is one example. At that time, European astronomers organized the world's first international scientific research project, under the leadership of the Observatory of Gotha, the whole sky was divided into 24 regions, within which European astronomers systematically searched for the planet known as the "ghost".

In 1838, Nicaragua formally became a republic, but the Mosquito Coast remained a British protectorate. Since independence, Nicaraguan politics has once been dominated by two major factions—the Conservative Party of Grenada and the Liberal Party of Leon. In 1855, the Liberals sought the aid of the anti-Conservative American adventurer William Walker, who conquered the Conservative capital of Grenada and gained effective control of Nicaragua. In June of the following year, Walker declared himself president and was recognized by the United States, but the move angered the two parties and provoked strong interference from neighbouring countries. Eventually, in conjunction with Honduras and other Central American countries, Walker was successfully expelled from Nicaragua in 1857, and Walker was executed in Honduras in 1860.

Impact craters, also known as craters or craterlets, are circular depressions formed by the impact of meteorites on the surfaces of planets, moons, asteroids, or other terrestrial objects. A crater usually has a small mountain in its center, a crater on Earth often contains water, forming a lake, and an island in the middle of the lake. Older craters on objects that have weathering processes or that have crustal motions are gradually eroded. On Earth, for example, by weathering, wind-blown dust deposits, and magma craters are covered or eroded. On other objects, there may be other effects that erode craters. For example, the surface of Jupiter is ice, and as time passes, the ice slowly flows away, causing the craters on the surface of the satellite to disappear. There are about 150 large identifiable craters on Earth, of which only five are larger than 100 km in diameter.

He was born on October 1, 1924, in the Lillian G. Carter Health and Rehabilitation Center in Plains, Georgia, the predecessor of the Wise Men's Home, where his mother worked as a registered nurse. He was the first President of the United States to be born in a medical institution. His father, James Earl Carter, was a farmer. He was a descendant of Thomas Carter, an English immigrant, who settled in Virginia in 1635. Several generations of the Carter family lived in Georgia, working as cotton farmers as a source of livelihood. Carter learned hard work as a child. He began selling boiled peanuts in the town at the age of five, and by the age of nine, he had become a thriving small businessman.

On February 7, 1928, the Fourth Plenary Session of the Second Central Executive Committee unanimously appointed Dai Jitao, Ding Kefen, Yu Yin, Tan Yanxiang, and Chiang Kai-shek as standing members of the Central Executive Committee. On October 3, 1928, the 172nd Standing Committee of the Kuomintang Central Executive Committee adopted the Training Program and the Law on the Organization of the National Government. On October 8, the Standing Committee appointed Chiang Kai-shek as President of the National Government and Commander-in-Chief of the Air Force and Navy. In December 1931, the First Plenary Session of the Fourth Central Executive Committee unanimously appointed Hu Hanmin, Wang Zhaoming, Chiang Kai-shek, Yu Yet Chuxiang, Gu Mengyu, Kuo Zheng, Sun Ko and Chen Guo as standing members of the Central Executive Committee. In February 1933, the 59th Session of the Standing Committee adopted the Law on the Organization of the National Council of Counsellors.

Brazzaville is located south of the equator, 506 kilometres from the Atlantic Ocean. The city is flat, 317 metres above sea level, and surrounded by extensive grassland. Brazzaville is home to one-third of the country's population and 40 per cent of the country's non-agricultural population. Administratively, it is an independent city in the Congo (Burgo), surrounded by the province of Pul. This region has been a major African centre for centuries. In the language of the Lari (French: Lari (ethnie du Congo))), the Mphoa and Mpira regions are known as Mavula, the "place of wealth", and the name is still used by the Lari. Although the number of speakers of this language is the largest in Brazzaville, it is not listed as a national language in the Constitution. However, by 1880, the Lari no longer lived in the area, being replaced by Teké immigrants, who called it Nkuna.

The archbishop, also translated as archbishop, is a high-ranking clergyman of the traditional Christian church, and according to the Catholic and Episcopal systems, several dioceses form a diocese, of which there is one archdiocese, and the titular bishop of the diocese is called archbishop; and the archbishop of the diocese has certain powers in the dioceses In the early Roman Empire, Catholicism was influenced by the metropolitan system, metropolitan archbishops, because of the centrality of the dioceses in the region, often became the leaders of the bishops of the region, thus extending the metropolitan position, receiving special responsibilities under ecclesiastical law.

It is named after the Polish astronomer Nikolai Copernicus, who proposed the idea of the Sun. After a beam of superheavy elements passes through the target, it reaches the next chamber, the separation chamber. If the reaction produces a new nucleus, it is carried by this beam. The stability of the nucleus derives from the strong nuclear force, but the action of the strong nuclear force is short-lived. As the nucleus grows larger, the influence of the strong nuclear force on the outermost nuclei (protons and neutrons) decreases. At the same time, the nucleus is torn apart by an unrestricted electrostatic repulsion force between the protons. The information that a physicist trying to synthesize superheavy elements can get is the information collected by the detector: the location, energy and time of the particle's arrival on the detector, and the information about the decay of the particle. Physicists analyze these data and try to come to the conclusion that it is indeed caused by new elements, not by different nuclei.

In developing countries, the most expensive expenditure is often the rent of houses. Because it has a large impact on the poverty threshold, economists often pay attention to the real estate market and housing prices. Almost all societies have poor people. The poverty threshold is a useful economic tool that can be used to statistic the poor population and help governments consider whether to use welfare and unemployment insurance to reduce poverty. For different situations, individual factors such as single parenthood, age, childhood, marital status, etc. are also taken into account. Economically, there are two types of poverty: absolute poverty and relative poverty. Politically, many governments have goals to combat and eradicate poverty for social welfare, and many governments have established organizations or institutions specialized in dealing with poverty. These organizations do their work mainly by conducting population censuses and identifying the number of low-income households.

In 1937, at the outbreak of the War of Resistance against Japan, he was appointed commander of the 14th Army, commander of the Left Wing Corps in the Battle of Xinkou in Shanxi, commander of five divisions in two weeks of intense fighting with the Japanese invaders, and then transferred to the guerrilla base in Zhonglishan, where he fought for a long time against the Japanese invaders. In 1938, he was transferred to the commander of the 33rd Army because of a quarrel with his immediate superior Wei Lihuang over the actual control of the army. Because of his long-term cooperation with the Communist Party in northern China, he was familiar with guerrilla tactics. In 1940, he was appointed commander of the Shanxi-Ogan border district and head of the Nandake guerrilla cadre training class, and together with the Eighth Route Army instructors, he trained anti-Japanese guerrilla war commanders. At the end of 1941, he was ordered to train the guerrilla forces in cooperation with the British military delegation, he was appointed commander of the Army's guerrilla squadron, and was later appointed deputy commander of the 14th, 26th, and 38th Army Groups, and commander of the 32nd Army Group, stationed in Zhejiang.

In 1517, Copernicus summarized the theory of monetary quantification. In 1473, Copernicus was born in the small town of Torun on the Vistula, then part of the Royal Prussian Province of the Kingdom of Poland. His father was a merchant from Kraków, his mother was the daughter of a local merchant from Torun, and his family was prosperous. Copernicus was the youngest of four children. His father died between the ages of ten and twelve, and he was adopted by his uncle, Lucas Vasenrod. In 1491, Copernicus entered the University of Jagiellonian University in Kraków (then known as the University of Kraków), where he developed an interest in astronomy. In 1496, he went to the University of Bologna, Padua, Italy, to study mathematics, astronomy, law, medicine, etc., and to receive humanistic ideas. In 1503, he obtained a doctorate in law from the University of Ferrara, and his uncle offered him a position as a priest in the city of Freiburg on the Polish coast.

It became a Spanish colony in 1524 and declared independence on 15 September 1821. It later became part of the Mexican Empire. After the dissolution of the Central American Federation in 1838, the Republic was proclaimed on 18 February 1841. The Salvadoran Civil War (1980-1992) was a civil war between government troops and guerrillas, in which more than 750,000 people died or disappeared. Apart from the narrow coastal plains of the south, the rest of the country is covered by mountainous plateaus, with many volcanoes, nicknamed "The Land of Volcanoes". Mount Santa Ana, at an altitude of 2381 meters, is the highest peak in the country. The coastal and lowlands have a humid climate, and the mountains have a cool climate.

Indigenous peoples of different cultures have lived on the land for thousands of years before the creation of the territory. The Angel Mounds State Historic Site is one of the best preserved ancient civil engineering sites in the United States, located near Evansville, Southwest Indiana. The inhabitants of the state are known as the Hoosier. The origin of the term is disputed, but the mainstream view is that the word originates in the highlands of the southern United States, a disrespectful slang term meaning "soilbag." The term is also recognized by the Indiana Historical Society and the Indiana Historical Society. The state of Indiana is named for the land of the Indians. The name dates back to the 1760s, when the territory was separated from the Northwest Territory in 1800 and established separately for the first time in the United States Congress.

In 1900, she was married to Tang Tingzhong to fill the house. In the third year of her marriage, she gave birth to her only daughter, Tang Yingchao. Due to the old-fashioned notion of "heavy man, light woman," Tang Yingchao wanted to send her daughter, Yang Zhende forced her husband to die. At the same time, she also refused to give her daughter to her husband, who was still popular. These progressive words and actions of her mother against feudal bad habits had a subtle effect on the young Tang Yingchao. In 1911, the Xinhai Revolution broke out, the Qing Dynasty was overthrown, Tang Yingchao died in the same year, Yang Zhende was forced to start raising Tang Yingchao on her own. She had carried Tang Yingchao to Guangzhou, Shanghai and other places in order to educate her daughter, traveled to the greater part of China, and finally settled in Tianjin. After she was admitted to the First Women's Normal School (today's Tianjin Academy of Fine Arts, Hebei Normal University), the teacher changed her name to "Dun Yingbin"; but she also changed her name to "Dun Yingchao."

In the Han Dynasty, due to Zhang Qian's access to the west, the Hexi Corridor became a necessary route for the Silk Road, and many new towns were founded. Emperor Wu of Han divided the Yellow River westward into four counties, and the Yellow River eastward into five counties, all under the jurisdiction of Liangzhou. In the Sixteen Kingdoms period, five states established capitals in Gansu. In the Northern and Southern Dynasties period, it belonged to the Northern Wei Dynasties, when Buddhism was introduced from the west, Daxing Grottoes were found in Gansu, and the most important ones today are Dunhuang Grottoes (Mo Gao Grottoes, Thousand Buddhas Cave), Meiji Mountain Grottoes, Bingling Temple Grottoes, etc. The Tang Dynasty attached importance to the role of the transportation route to the west in the Gansu region, dividing it into Guannai Road, Longyu Road, and Shannan Road, and governing 22 provinces, the largest of which in the Hexi Corridor was Gansu (now Zhangye and Suzhou) and Suzhou (now Jiuquan). After the Anglo-Saxon War, Gansu was twice invaded by foreigners, and in the Song Dynasty it belonged to Xixia.

The origin of life is a natural process by which life emerges from non-living matter (such as simple organic compounds) (see Wikidata:Q13878858). The general scientific assumption is that the transition from non-living to living is not a single event, but a gradually increasing process of complexity. Life on Earth first appeared 428,000 million years ago, shortly after the formation of the oceans 441,000 million years ago, and shortly after the formation of the Earth 45,400 million years ago. The mechanism by which life originates on Earth is still uncertain, but there are many hypotheses about the origin of life. After life has evolved into many different forms, biologists classify it as a system of many taxonomic units. Life can survive under many different conditions. The ability to metabolize and self-replicate is sometimes regarded as a fundamental condition for judging life, called a life phenomenon.

A lieutenant general is a rank in many national armies, ranging from major general to admiral. The origin of the title goes back to the person who received the orders of the general on the battlefield in the middle ages and passed them on. The Chinese word for lieutenant general comes from the Japanese military system, and the Japanese military system derives from the ancient Japanese official position of the commander-in-chief of the left and right guards. In the United States, lieutenant generals of the Army, Air Force and Marine Corps are called Lieutenant Generals, vice admirals of the Navy are called Vice Admirals, and air marshals of the British Air Force are called Air Marshals. In the Republic of China, People's Liberation Army, Russian Federation, and Royal Navy (changed to three stars after 2001), lieutenant generals are awarded two stars, while in the U.S. Army and other militaries heavily influenced by the U.S., such as the Korean Army, German Bundeswehr, and Japanese Self-Defense Forces, the rank of lieutenant general is usually awarded three stars, while in the French Army and other former French colonies, lieutenant generals are awarded four stars.

In the Anglo-Saxon period of England, when the Seven Kingdoms were successively Christianized, Old English was influenced by a small number of Church Latins. In the Viking Age, when the Danish legal district was established, Old English was deeply influenced by Old Norse, and began to develop in a more analytical direction. Later Middle English began with the Norman conquest in the late 11th century, during which time it was influenced by Norman French. As a refractory language, English is a relatively simplified synthetic language with fewer refractory changes than many other languages, relying more on auxiliary verbs and sequences to express complex tenses, moods and moods, and passive moods, questions, and some negation. Although the various accents and dialects of English differ markedly in pronunciation and pitch, and sometimes in their vocabulary, grammar, and spelling, English-speaking people around the world can communicate and communicate virtually unhindered.

But after the Roman occupation of Huda in 42 AD, the poor city had only a military role. About 400 years later, the Vandals expelled the Romans, followed by the Kingdom of Visigoth and the Byzantine Empire. In 710, a Muslim army approached Huda, but at the advice of Huda's Visigoth ruler Julian (also king of Gomara), the army turned against Spain—according to the Arabic chronicles, Julian's hatred of Spain stemmed from the mistreatment of his daughter by the Spanish Visigoth king Rodrigo. Thus, Huda agreed to attack the Iberian peninsula as a base for the Berber army led by General Tariq ibn Ziyad. It was then ruled by Islamic forces for nearly five centuries. After the death of Julian (early 7th century), the Arabs began to rule the city, causing hatred among the Berber tribes around the city.

A solar eclipse, also known as an eclipse, is an astronomical phenomenon that occurs in part of the Earth when the Moon is completely or partially blocked from sunlight. An eclipse occurs only when the Moon travels closest to the ecliptic plane between the Sun and the Earth. An eclipse in which the Moon is completely blocked from the Sun is called a solar eclipse, and an eclipse in which the Moon is partially blocked from the Sun is called a partial eclipse or a circular eclipse. Science has long recognized eclipses as a natural phenomenon, but for many ancient and modern cultures, eclipses are a disastrous supernatural phenomenon.

In 1855, during the Tiananmen Rebellion, Liu joined the army of the Jiangchuan dynasty of the Xiang dynasty to conquer the Tiananmen army. After the death of the Jiang army, he followed Liu Changyu. Later, because he led the Xiang army in the war, he was promoted to the rank of teacher, governor of Chi Prefecture, Chi Prefecture, Chi Prefecture, Guangdong Governor's envoy and Guangxi Governor's envoy, and in 1865 he was promoted to Jiangxi governor's envoy.

The Republic of Benin (French: République du Bénin), commonly known as Benin, is a West African country, formerly known as Dahomey. Benin borders Guinea-Bissau to the south, Nigeria to the east, Niger to the north, Burkina Faso to the northwest, and Togo to the west. Benin covers an area of 114,762 square kilometres and has a population of 11.85 million in 2020. The capital, Port-au-Prince, is the seat of the National Assembly, while Cotonou is the seat of government. The Republic of Benin (French: La République du Bénin, Taiwanese for "Republic of Benin"). Formerly known as Dahomey until 1975, it was renamed Benin. The name Benin originates from the ancient kingdom of Benin. However, today the territory of the Republic of Benin does not overlap with that of the ancient kingdom of Benin (but lies to the east), the capital city of the kingdom of Benin is not within the territory of the Republic of Benin, and its eastern neighbour is Nigeria, so theoretically, Nigeria is more closely related to the ancient kingdom of Benin.

The Syrian Arab Republic (Arabic: الجمهوريّة العربيّة السّوريّة, romanized: al-Jumhūrīyah al-ʻArabīyah as-Sūrīyah ), commonly known as Syria (Arabic: Сири, romanized: Sūriyā), is a Middle Eastern Arab state located in Western Asia, on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean Sea. It borders Turkey in the north, Iraq in the east, Jordan in the south, Lebanon and Israel in the southwest, and the Mediterranean Sea in the west. It declared independence on January 1, 1944, and was recognized by the United Nations and the rest of the world as an officially independent state on April 7, 1946.

Essonne (French: ) is a province of France, belonging to the Île-de-France region, code 91. The Essonne River flows through the province. The name of the province and the name of the river are both derived from the name of the goddess of the Gaul river, Exona. The province of Essonne was established on 1 January 1968. It was formerly part of the southern part of the province of Seine-et-Marne. In 1969, the two towns of Chateaufort and Tours-le-Noble separated from the province of Essonne and became part of the province of Ivrin. In 1985, the number of counties reached 42. The province of Essonne belongs to the Île-de-France region. The main rivers of the province: the Seine and its tributaries, the Yerres, the Orly and the Essonne. The most populous towns: Évry, Colbert-Essonne, and Masy. The province of Essonne has a degraded marine climate, mainly influenced by the west-southwest sea winds. The province receives more rainfall (about 160 days per year), but is one of the driest provinces in France, with a low rainfall (560 mm/year).

The human desire for companionship is one of the most powerful and innate human characteristics, and may be related to sexual desire. Human mating is a social and cultural process in which two people meet and evaluate the suitability of their interpersonal or courtship relationships. However, human sexuality is still an animal sexuality, and some sexual similarities can still be found between humans and non-human animals. People have a variety of motivations for engaging in sexual activity. Although the primary purpose of sexual activity in evolutionary chemistry is reproduction, a study of college students has shown that there are four main purposes for engaging in sexual activity: to be attracted to one another's body, to help oneself achieve other purposes, to increase emotional connections, and to reduce insecurity. Most people engage in sexual activity in order to delight oneself from the excitement of sex, especially when it leads to orgasm.

No fossils of elephants have been found on the island of Borneo, and the term elephant is not used in the local indigenous language. It is believed by some scholars that the modern Borneo elephant was brought to Borneo by humans from other parts of Asia. In the 1950s, anatomical differences, such as smaller skulls and deformed teeth, led to the classification of the Borneo elephant as a subspecies of the Asian elephant. At the same time, zoologists point out that the population of large elephants in Borneo looks different from other Asian elephants, with smaller skulls and a few differences in ivory teeth. The history of the gift of two reindeer to the Sultan of the Zulu Kingdom by the King of Java is documented, and the reindeer later bred in the wild in the western part of Borneo. When Ferdinand Magellan arrived in Brunei in 1521, the story of the king decorating the reindeer with silk was recorded.

In 1916, Yuan became the emperor and abolished the post of Grand President. On June 6, 1916, after Yuan's death, the post of Grand President of the Republic of China was reinstated, but was controlled by the North Atlantic Warring States and became a virtual head of state. During the period, when Sun Wen established the Guangzhou Military Government in Guangzhou, which was not recognized by the international community, he acted as "extremely great president" and tried to replace the North Atlantic Government by force. The Nationalist Party of China, with the support of the Soviet Union, carried out the Northern Expedition of the National Revolutionary Army and was victorious, established the Nationalist Government in Nanjing, the post of Grand President of the Republic of China was replaced by the President of the Nationalist Government, and the party-state system of the Nationalist Party was gradually established. The first Grand President was Yuan Shikai, elected in 1913 by the Nationalist Congress. After Yuan Shikai's sudden death in 1916, the North Atlantic Warring States became the actual leaders of the Beijing Government, the Grand President and the Prime Minister of State did not have much real power, and important decisions were made by consultation with the major warring States.

The sex is mild and easier to tame. In the past, there were four subspecies: Indian elephant, Ceylon elephant, Malaysian elephant and Sumatran elephant. There are two types of African elephant, the most common being the common African elephant, is the largest terrestrial animal in existence, the ears are large, both females and males have long and curved teeth, the forefoot has four toes, the hind feet have three toes (one fewer toes than Asian elephants), there are 21 pairs of ribs, the back is flat, the length is 6-7.3 meters, the height is 3-4 meters, and the weight is 10 tons. The more ferocious sex, especially solitary males, is more ferocious and difficult to tame.

Some regions also use dogs as food, such as North Korea in East Asia, South Korea, parts of China, Vietnam in Southeast Asia, Switzerland in Europe, France in the United States and Hawaii in the United States. Today, there are hundreds of breeds of domestic dogs, most of which have been around for hundreds of years. Many different breeds have been bred as needed, such as the Irish wolfdog from a height of just 15.2 cm to 76 cm, and various colors, such as white, black, gray or brown. Dogs were domesticated from wild dogs by humans as domestic animals as early as 16,000 years ago and as late as 14,000 years ago. Although dogs are descended from wolves and carnivores, dogs have been described in various literature as being carnivorous, but they accept fewer foods than humans. For example, they metabolize cocaine in chocolate at a much slower rate than humans, and heavy intake of chocolate can lead to cocaine poisoning and even death in dogs.

Historically referred to as British Somaliland, it was a British protectorate. Occupied by Italian troops from Italian East Africa during World War II, it was liberated by the British Army. On 26 June 1960, the region gained independence as Somaliland, and five days later, on 1 July, it was merged with the newly independent Italian Somaliland to form the "Somali Republic". Former Somali Prime Minister Muhammad Haji Ibrahim Egal served as Minister of Defence, Minister of Education in 1962, and Prime Minister of Somalia in 1967, but was overthrown in a coup d'état in 1969.

Dutch navigators and explorers Pieter Keyser and Frederick de Houtman, who accompanied the first Dutch expedition to the East Indies in the Indonesian fleet, charted twelve constellations in the southern sky, the largest of which is Phoenix. Astronomer Richard Allen notes that the Phoenix Cluster was formed by ancient astronomy, unlike other constellations delineated by Pluto or Nicolas Louis Lacaille. Arabs viewed the sky as a hummingbird, a vulture, or an eagle. Ancient Chinese linked the brightest star in Phoenix, Alpha Phoenix (later named Firebird 6), to a neighboring star in the constellation Taurus, forming a bird-hunting net known as the Eight Quails.

The city of Xiangtan was founded in 1949 as the capital of Xiangtan County. It was subsequently abolished and re-established in 1950. In 1983, it was re-established as a city at the district level. The city of Xiangtan was founded in the Southern Song Dynasty. The following mainly describes the history of the city of Xiangtan. Historically, the entire territory of Xiangtan City is composed of Xiangtan County and Xiangxiang County. The development of the two areas is not the same, and Xiangxiang City developed even earlier than Xiangtan. Therefore, for the comprehensive history of the current territory of Xiangtan City, please refer to the history of Xiangtan, Xiangxiang City and Shaoshan City. Stoneware and pottery excavated at Jinqi Village in Yangjiaqiao Town, Jinshi Town in Xiangtan City, Daiziping Site in Jinshi Town, prove that the inhabitants of the Stone Age have reached a higher level of civilization. The site of Daxi Culture indicates that the settlement of Xiangtan began 5,000 years ago. Furthermore, the bronze porcupine statue of the late Shang Dynasty excavated at Mt. Funagata, and the burial grounds of the Warring States period, reflect the city of Xiangtan that was formed at that time.

The 6.5×50mm Hayabusa cartridge was a standard rifle cartridge used by the Imperial Japanese Army during World War I and World War II to fire powder, and was used in Japan for the Hayabusa 30, 38 and Taisho 11 light machine guns. Developed in 1897 as a companion to the "30th-year rifle," it was the first smokeless powder cartridge in Japan. It was originally called the "30th-year round"; when the Type 38 rifle was introduced in 1905, the original purpose was only to improve the shortage of the 30th-year rifle, so it was developed to be compatible with this cartridge as the standard, and no new cartridges were developed. With the development of the world's most sophisticated ammunition, the 6.5mm Hayabusa cartridge was also introduced in 1907 as the first Japanese version of the pointed bullet, developed to be compatible with the 30th and 38th-year rifles as the standard, for the long pointed bullets (both of which were lead cores), called the "40th-year cartridge," the total length of which was the same as the "30th-year round."

In early October 1930, Li left the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CCPC) for Moscow for inspection by the Communist International. In December 1930, Li went to the Soviet Union, and in 1931 to the Soviet Union. After the Communist International reviewed Li’s mistakes, Li was assigned to study at the Lenin School of the Communist International. A year later, the Eastern Bureau of the Communist International decided to appoint Li to Red Workers International as a representative of the General Trade Union of the People’s Republic of China, as well as a member of the Communist Party of China’s delegation to the Communist International, director of the Chinese section of the Communist International Workers’ Publishing House, and editor-in-chief of the State Relief Times. In October 1934, after the Communist International cut off telecommunications with the Shanghai Central Bureau of the Communist Party of China (CCPC), in consultation with the CCP delegation, Li was immediately dispatched to the Sino-Soviet border city of Almaty.

In the 13th-14th centuries, the Tswana people moved here from the north. In 1885, the British colonized the area and established the "Protectorate of the Bay of Biscay", which made it part of the United Kingdom. Separated from the United Kingdom on September 30, 1966, it declared independence, changed its name to the Republic of Botswana, implemented democratic politics, active social policies and the wealth brought by rich mineral deposits (especially diamond mines, which accounted for 80% of the country's export profits) allowed Botswana to have a level of development not seen in most parts of Africa. In addition, the country's active cooperation with the international community, the establishment of large-scale national parks in the country for the protection of wildlife, and the opportunity for tourism to gradually thrive in the country. The capital of Botswana is Haborone, with a population of about 230,000 (2011), is a city on the southern border of the country, which rose at the end of the 19th century because of the mining exploitation nearby.

Yangshan is located in the conjunction of the Pearl River Delta and the inland, belongs to the tropical monsoon climate of Central Asia, the year-round seasons are clear, the temperature is suitable, sufficient light, abundant rainfall. Yangshan County is administered by 12 towns and one ethnic township: Qinglian Town, Jiangying Town, Dupu Town, Seven Arch Town, Taiping Town, Yang Mei Town, Dahui Town, Xiaojiang Town, Lingping Town, Huangjiang Town, Libu Town, Yang Town and Liqiao Yao Township. Yangshan County residents are predominantly Han people, and some Yao people. Yangshan County's main language is Yangshan dialect, which is a Guangdong dialect; in addition, some residents are accustomed to using Hakka and Yao languages. Overview of Chinese Overseas Chinese: According to the Guangdong Historical Records (Second Edition, 1993) of the first article on the situation of Chinese Overseas Chinese in Yangshan: There are about 6,000 Chinese overseas Chinese of ancestry of Yangshan, distributed in Malaysia, Singapore, the United States and other countries.

There are also transfer stations (such as Huangbeiling Station, Che Kung Temple Station, Mae Ha Wan Station, Red Bay Station) where the platforms are parallel to each other. Two-sided platforms consist of two sided platforms, which provide four tracks and four platforms, including the island platform in the middle, which can be used for the transfer of two tracks. Tai Wai Railway Station can be seen as a representative of such stations: when a passenger transfers from the Tuen Ma Line to the Eastern Railway Line in the direction of Jinzhong, or a passenger transfers from the Eastern Railway Line to Tuen Mun Station, he can transfer directly to the other side of the platform; but when a passenger transfers from the Tuen Ma Line to the Eastern Railway Line in the direction of Luohu / Lok Ma Chau, or a passenger transfers from the Eastern Railway Line to Wuxi Sha, he can transfer through the hall. Nanchang Railway Station is another example: when a passenger transfers from the Tung Chung Line to Hong Kong in the direction of Tuen Ma Line to Tuen Mun Station (or vice versa) he can transfer directly to the other side of the platform; but when a passenger transfers from the Tung Chung Line to Hong Kong in the direction of Tuen Ma Line to Wuxi Sha, or a passenger transfers from the Tung Chung Line to Tung Chung, or a passenger transfers from the Tung Chung Line to Tuen Mun in the direction of Tung Chung, or a passenger transfers from the Tung Chung Line to Tung Chung, or a passenger transfers from the Tung Chung Line to Wuxi Sha in the direction of Tung Chung, he can transfer through the hall.

This discovery, together with supernovae observed in 1572 and 1604, proved that the sky was not as eternal as Aristotle and other ancient philosophers had taught. Thus, the discovery of variable stars contributed to the astronomical revolutions of the 16th and early 17th centuries. The second variable star was Geminiano Montanar's eclipsing variable Ursa Major Beta, discovered in 1669; John Goodrick correctly explained its origin in 1784. Chi Cygni was confirmed in 1686 by Gottfried Kirch, then R Hydra was discovered in 1704 by G.D. Maradi. Up to 1786, there were ten known variable stars, with John Goodrick's own discoveries of Delta Persei and Beta Centauri.
