He invaded and conquered several tribes in the Zululand region, establishing the Zulu kingdom. The Zulu then became a major tribe between the Tugaila and the Pongola rivers. This expansion forced the migration of many tribes in the Zululand region, known as the Mfecane movement. In the process, there were also many internal struggles, known as the Zulu Civil War. Dinok and Mhlangana plotted to kill their eldest brother, Shaka (three half-brothers), and after at least two assassination attempts, finally killed Shaka. After Shaka's death, Dinok killed his half-brother, Mhlangana, and succeeded in usurping the throne, ascending to the throne.

George VI (14 December 1895 – 6 February 1952), known as Albert Frederick Arthur George, King of the United Kingdom and its Autonomous Territories, the last Emperor of India, and the first Head of the Commonwealth of England, was born on 14 December 1895 in York Villa, Sandringham Palace, Norfolkshire, the second son of Prince George, Duke of York and Queen Mary (later King George V), on the thirty-fourth anniversary of his great-grandfather's death.

Its high bonding energy also explains why it is a product of fusion and nuclear decay. Helium-4 is the most important isotope of helium in the universe, with the most extensive sources being formed during the Big Bang. New helium is formed in the nuclear fusion reactions inside stars. Helium is named after the Greek mythological Titanian sun god Helios. The first discovery of helium was confirmed by Georges Lepage, while Joseph Norman Locke was the only person to discover it in Britain. It is believed that helium was discovered by Jules Jansen and Joseph Norman Locke. Locke was the first to propose that the spectrum came from a new element, and named it. The formal discovery was made in 1895 by two Swedish chemists, Per Teodor Cleve and Abraham Langlet, who separated helium from bituminous uranium ore.

Green stars, in astronomy, are due to the illusion that white or blue stars are visually green. The reason why there are no real green stars is that the color of the star is more or less given by the spectra of the black body, which never looks green. Although the spectra of the stars have some lines, the stars are usually similar to black bodies, so its color is more or less the color of a black body. The color of the black body is located on the black Planckian locus in the middle of the graph. We can see that this trajectory just goes through the red, orange, yellow, white and light blue regions, and indeed we see many of these colors of the stars. On the other hand, it does not go through the green, blue-green (dark blue) or violet regions, so few stars of these colors can be seen, even if there are some other optical effects.

Under normal temperature and pressure, hydrogen forms diatomic molecules (commonly referred to as hydrogen gas, molecular formula H2), which are colorless, odourless, tasteless, non-metallic, non-toxic, and highly flammable. Hydrogen easily forms covalent bonds with most non-metallic elements, so most of the hydrogen on Earth exists in molecular forms, such as water and organic compounds. Hydrogen is particularly important in alkaline reactions, in which various molecules have to exchange protons with each other. In ionic compounds, hydrogen atoms can either gain an electron to form hydrogen anion (H−), or lose an electron to form hydrogen anion (H+).

The People's Republic of China is a major source country for trafficking in human beings, forced labour, forced marriages and forced prostitution, as well as an important transit and destination country. Women and children from mainland China are trafficked to Africa, Europe, Latin America, the Middle East and North America, while those trafficked to Taiwan, Thailand, Malaysia and Japan are mainly engaged in severely exploited sex work and forced high-intensity manual labor. Women and children from Myanmar, Vietnam, Mongolia, the former Soviet Union (except the Baltic States), North Korea, Romania, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan and Ghana are also mainly engaged in severely exploited sex work and forced high-intensity manual labor after being trafficked to China.

The tail passes through the galactic plane and contains many deep-sky objects in the Milky Way, such as the eagle nebula and its associated M16 cluster. The eagle nebula is 70 light-years long and 50 light-years wide, and the Hubble Space Telescope captured a famous photograph of three dust clouds in it, the Pillar of Creation. Other notable objects in the tail include: the extremely rare square object of the red square nebula, Westgate 40, a large star-forming region nearby that contains a molecular cloud and an area of ionized hydrogen. The giant snake in the hand of Greek mythology represents the therapist Askepia (Snake), who is said to have saved the snake from death by bringing a resurrected herb to its rescue. The snake, which molts its skin every year, is a symbol of revival in the eyes of ancient Greeks, and it is rumored that Askepia learned the art of resurrection from the resurrected snake. This theory is likely to be the reason why Snake and Snake converge, but the scientific community is still uncertain.

Zhang Xu (c.675-c.750), Zhao Bao, Wu County, Wu County (present-day Suzhou City, Jiangsu Province), known as "Zhang Changshi," is a calligrapher, known as "the saint of the grass." His year of birth is unknown. Zhang Xu was appointed to the Imperial Court, served as a government official in Chang'an and Kamigyo, and became acquainted with Yan Xinqing and Du Fu. Zhang Xu is known for his love of drinking. In Du Fu's poem "Drinking the Poems of the Eight Immortals," Zhang Xu is also one of the characters depicted, and others are called "Drinking the Poems of the Eight Immortals." Zhang Xu is known as the most liberal calligrapher of the grass, according to the New Tang Dynasty, Zhang Xu likes to write works after drunkenness, called "crazy grass." His calligraphy is often odd-shaped, crude compared to exaggeration, and full of emotional lines, praised in the Old Tang Dynasty as "changeless, if there is a helper." Before Zhang Xu, the calligraphy world had been ruled by Wang Xizhi and Wang Xian, but Zhang Xu's calligraphy broke this rule, bringing a cyclopean reform to the calligraphy world.

The poems of the Kii family of Imperial Princess Yushi (Japanese: 祐子内親王家紀伊/ゆうしないしんのうけ のきい Yūshi Naishinnō-ke no Kii */?, 1035 – after November 1113) total 31 poems in the Edict Collection of Japanese Poems, the style of poetry is competent in the concept and deduction of random variation, the works are also skillful, the Mirror of the Present describes her as a poet of the times, and MINAMOTO no Yoshinori also thinks that she knows the poems well.

Wu Kun-chen (October 21, 1903 – June 6, 1984) was a Chinese politician who served as Mayor of Shanghai and Chairman of the Taiwan Provincial Government. He was one of the key figures in the shaping of modern Taiwan. He was also known for his open boldness and fierce disputes with Chiang Kai-shek. Wu Kun-chen was born in 1903 in Liangshui Town, Jiangsu Province. From a young age, he lived in Sun Tianfu with his father, Wu Jingming, who was the Director of Army Training. In 1914, at the age of 10, Wu Kun-chen enrolled in Tianjin Nankai Secondary School and met Zhou Enlai and Li Fu Jing. After graduating from Nankai, he attended the Beijing Qinghua School. After graduating in 1921, he went to the United States to study. After obtaining a master's degree in economics from Greennell College, he received a Ph.D. in political science from Princeton University in 1926. After Wu Kun-chen returned to China in 1926, he entered politics.

China acceded to the Convention on Wetlands in 1992. Every three years, the Conference of the Contracting Parties (COP) is convened by the representatives of the Parties. The COP is the decision-making body of the Convention, adopting decisions (resolutions and recommendations) to manage the work of the Convention and improve the ability of the Parties to achieve its objectives. COP12 was held in Cape Town, Uruguay in 2015. COP13 was held in Dubai, United Arab Emirates in October 2018. To commemorate the signing of the Convention, 2 February each year is designated as World Wetlands Day. In May 1999, at the 7th Conference of the Parties in Costa Rica, the World Wildlife Fund (WWF), BirdLife International, the World Conservation Union (IUCN) and Wetlands International (WI) were officially recognized as partner organizations of the Convention.

Most calendar systems integrate more complex time periods, for example most calendar systems have years, months, weeks, and days, but the definitions may vary. Many calendar systems have seven days in a week, and have been in use for thousands of years. The solar calendar defines a date for each solar day, the day is measured as the time between two consecutive events (such as sunset), the interval between two consecutive events may vary slightly during the year, or the day is averaged as the average solar day. Other calendars also use the solar day as a unit of time. There are many proposals for calendar reform, such as the world calendar, the international fixed calendar, the new century year, and the Hanke-Henry Permanent Calendar. Similar ideas have emerged at different times, but have not been implemented in the end due to lack of continuity, large-scale adjustments in implementation, or religious opposition.

In 1603, the German astrographer Johann Bayer made the first drawing of Hydra in the Astronomical Survey. The shape of Hydra is irregular. Koser and de Gauthmann named the 15 stars of Hydra in Malay and Malagasy dictionaries, including the head of Hydra, the chest appendage of Hydra, and stars representing the body and the tail, some of which were later assigned to Tucana, Nepenthes, Sagittarius or Clock. The brightest yellow star in Hydra, the 2.8-magnitude tail of Hydra, is 24 light-years from Earth. The appendage of Hydra is located on the northern edge of Hydra, not far southwest of Mercury. The appendage of Hydra is located in the southeastern corner of the constellation. Hydra has two famous optical twins. π Hydra can be observed with binoculars. There are three other stars with planets, the most famous of which is the Sun-like star HD 10180. In addition to the seven confirmed planets, there may be two more, more than all known galaxies, including the Solar System.

The first round of the International Invitation Competition for Planning and Architectural Design was launched in April 2003. Eight design units from the U.S., Canada, Japan and Germany submitted their design proposals. On October 10, 2003, the second round of the International Invitation Competition for Planning and Architectural Design was announced. A total of 12 domestic and foreign design units participated in the competition. In the end, the "Technology Carrier" project of the South China Institute of Architectural Design won the competition and became the implementation plan of the architectural design of the Guangdong Science Centre. On March 28, 2004, as one of the first priority projects in Guangdong's "Top Ten Projects," the Guangdong Science Centre held a groundbreaking ceremony in Guangzhou University City. The construction project is scheduled to be completed in June 2007, and the exhibition project will be completed in November.

The operation of the Cantonese-Macedonian-Greek-Guangdong Intercity Railway has been completed. At present, the Cantonese-Macedonian-Greek-Guangdong Intercity Railway has opened four tracks (72 stations), with a distance of 419 km. At the same time, in order to expand the coverage of the railway network and achieve the goal of one-hour interchange between major cities, the Cantonese-Macedonian-Greek-Guangdong Intercity Railway is still undergoing large-scale construction of new tracks. According to the plan, the long-range distance between Cantonese-Macedonian-Greek-Guangdong Intercity Railway will reach 1890 km. Early in the design of the Guangzhou Metro Line 1, part of the structure was reserved at Xidi Station for the use of the future Cantonese-Guangdong Light Railway. At that time, the concept of connecting the two places of Cantonese-Guangdong through railway transportation was already in place. In 1997, in the Guangzhou City Rapid Railway Line Network Planning Study (Final Report), the then Line 4 Industrial Avenue section and Line 5 Fangcun Crossing River section were the prototype of the current Cantonese-Guangdong section of the Cantonese-Guangdong Metro. Subsequently, in the 2003 plan, the two sections were reorganized, Fangcun Crossing River section and the middle and southern sections of Industrial Avenue section became part of the existing Cantonese-Guangdong section of the Cantonese-Guangdong Metro.

A color index is a purity measurement of the surface temperature of a star using color. To measure this index, an observer needs to use two different filters, U and B or B and V, to measure the luminosity of the target object in sequence. This is a commonly used bandwidth or filter light measuring system, U is a UV-sensitive filter, B is a blue-sensitive filter, and V is a yellow-green visible light sensitive filter (see UBV system). The difference in luminosity measured using different filters is called the U-B or B-V color index, respectively. The smaller the value, the closer the star's color is to blue; conversely, the larger the color index, the redder (or lower the temperature). This is a series of logarithmic results showing that bright objects have smaller numbers than dim objects (which can be negative). In comparison, the pale yellow Sun's B-V color index is 0.656±0.005.

Du Zhengsho (born June 10, 1944) is a Taiwanese historian specializing in ancient Chinese history, ancient Chinese social history, ancient social history, cultural history, medical history, etc. In July 1992, he was elected a member of the Central Academy of Sciences, a former elementary school teacher, a professor at Dongwu University in Taiwan, a professor at National Qinghua University, a director of the National Palace Museum, and a director of the Ministry of Education under President Chen Shui-bian of the Republic of China. Currently, he is an honorary professor at National Chengqing University, a professor at Changrong University Taiwan Institute, a professor at National Taiwan University, a researcher at the Central Academy of Sciences Institute of Historical Language, a researcher at the Central Academy of Sciences Institute of Historical Language and Communications, the editor-in-chief of Continent Magazine, the editor-in-chief of New History, and a member of the Central Academy of Sciences. In 1966, he graduated from Taiwan Provincial Taiwan Normal Specialized School (then a five-year specialized school, now a National Taiwan University), Du Zhengsho studied both elementary school teaching and self-study, enrolled in the Department of History at National Taiwan University, graduated from the Department of History at Taiwan University in 1970, obtained a master's degree from the Institute of History at Taiwan University in 1974, and transferred to the London School of Economics and Political Science, the School of Oriental and African Studies, and other academic institutions.

The President of the Kuomintang (Chinese: 中國国民党主席) is the leader of the current party of the Kuomintang, as well as the chairman of the National Assembly, the Central Committee, and the Standing Committee of the Central Committee. The name of the highest leader of the Kuomintang has changed several times in history, the longest position permanently reserved for his predecessor, the first chairman of the KMT, Yang Quyun, the prime minister permanently reserved for the first prime minister, Sun Yat-sen, and the president permanently reserved for the first president, Chiang Kai-shek. The current president is Zhu Lilong, the most recent election for the party's presidential election in 2021. The President of the Kuomintang has been elected directly by all party members since 2001, the party charter stipulated that the Kuomintang would serve as both the president and the party president as the ruling party, but this provision was removed in 2019. According to Article 19 of the Party Charter of the Kuomintang, "The term of office of the President is four years, re-elected once."

Zhongshan Avenue is located in Tianhe District and Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China. It was built in 1925 and named Zhongshan Highway in honor of Sun Yat-sen. In 1987, the 48-metre-wide concrete road was extended and renamed Zhongshan Avenue. It is now part of the 107 National Highway. The line runs east-west for about 14 km. It connects Tianhe Road to Huangpu District in the east and Huangpu East Road in the east. The line is divided into two sections: Zhongshan Avenue east and Zhongshan Avenue west. Zhongshan Avenue east starts from Huangpu District Harbour Road and ends at Dongpu Junction of Guangzhou Ring City Expressway. Zhongshan Avenue west-east starts at Dongpu Junction and ends at Shek Pik East Road in the west. It connects Tianhe Road via Shek Pik East Road and Wushan Junction via a high-rise bridge. Currently, the first experimental rapid transit line in Guangzhou is being built on Zhongshan Avenue east, Tianhe Road and Huangpu East Road.

Corona Australis is a minor constellation in the southern sky, originally named Corona Australis, meaning "the southern crown" and corresponding to Corona Australis ("the northern crown") in the northern sky. Corona Australis is one of the 48 constellations identified by the astronomer Claudius Ptolemy in the 2nd century AD, and one of the 88 modern constellations recognized by the International Astronomical Union. In the eyes of the ancient Greeks, Corona Australis had nothing to do with the crown, but was associated with the flower rings of Capricorn or Centaurus. Other civilizations viewed it as the home of turtles, ostrich nests, tents, or hares. Corona Australis is less luminous than Corona Australis, but its brightest stars are elliptical or horseshoe-shaped, and are prominent in the night sky. Capricorn 6 and Beta Corona Australis are the two brightest stars in the constellation, both of 4.1 magnitudes.

The Constitution of the People's Republic of China (1982), abbreviated as the 82nd Constitution, is the fourth part of the Constitution of the People's Republic of China and the current Constitution. It was proposed by the then leader Deng Xiaoping on August 18, 1980, and amended for more than two years. It was adopted at the fifth session of the Fifth National People's Congress on December 4, 1982. The birth of the 82nd Constitution had the background of disruption, reform and reconstruction of the legal system after the Cultural Revolution. In the early 1980s, as disruption and reform were gradually deepened, the Cultural Revolution was completely rejected.
